PREFACE 
This publication contains the Charter for the City of White Plains, being Chapter 356 of the Laws of 1915 as amended; the Related Laws, which contains special laws relating to the city and selected local laws of Westchester County; and the White Plains Municipal Code, being a codification of all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted by the city. The White Plains Municipal Code also contains various local laws enacted by the city which were not amendatory of the Charter and various resolutions, rules and regulations in force in the city. When adopted the White Plains Municipal Code will supersede all ordinances not included therein or recognized as continuing in force; local laws, resolutions, rules and regulations are not re-enacted by the White Plains Municipal Code and are included for the convenience of the user of the Code. 
The Charter is numbered and arranged as enacted and amended from time to time. In the Related Laws, the various laws have been arranged into articles and divisions; only one law, together with any laws amendatory thereof, is included in any one division. The arrangement and numbering system in the White Plains Municipal Code, has been developed with the cooperation of city officers and employees. The Code is arranged into titles and the titles contain independent chapters. The sections in each chapter are catchlined to facilitate usage. 
As the Code contains many titles each chapter is preceded by an arabic number designating the title. Thus the second chapter of Title II is Chapter 2-2 and the second chapter of Title IX is Chapter 9-2. Section numbers are keyed to chapters so that the first section of Chapter 1-1 is section 1-1-1 and the first section of Chapter 2-1 is section 2-1-1. 
Under this system each section is identified with its title and chapter number and any additions can be inserted in their proper place by the use of the decimal system. New material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 2-4-2 and 2-4-3 would be designated as sections 2-4-2.1, 2-4-2.2 and 2-4-2.3, respectively. When appropriate sections have been reserved at the end of articles and divisions for future expansion. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 2-4 and 2-5 it will be designated as Chapter 2-4.1. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Footnotes which tie related sections of this publication together and which refer to relevant provisions of the state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within this publication is included at the back of this publication. The source of each section is indicated by the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables any ordinance, law, resolution, rule or regulation included herein can be readily found in the Code. 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of the Code with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Morton H. Zucker, Deputy Corporation Counsel, and to other city officers and employees too numerous to mention, for their invaluable cooperation and assistance in the preparation of the manuscript of this publication. 
The publication of this Code was under supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
Credit must also be to Mr. Robert L. Laslie, Vice President, who was the editor of the 1970 publication "Charter and Appendix of the City of White Plains, New York" from which the editor obtained the city charter and related materials. 
ORDINANCE ADOPTING CODE 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting the White Plains Municipal Code; Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein, Except as Herein Expressly Provided; Providing That no Local Law, Resolution, Rule or Regulation Contained Therein Is Adopted or Repealed; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code of Ordinances; and Providing a Penalty for the Violations Thereof. 
The Common Council of The City of White Plains Hereby Ordains and Enacts as Follows: 
Section 1. That the White Plains Municipal Code, consisting of Chapters 1-1 through 9-10, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "White Plains Municipal Code," and shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances of the city passed on or before August 1, 1983, to the extent provided in Section 2 hereof. 
Section 2. That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force from and after the effective date of this ordinance and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of The City of White Plains, enacted on final passage on or before August 1, 1983, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of this ordinance, except as hereinafter provided. 
Section 3. That the repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not affect the following: 
(a)  any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this ordinance; 
(b)  any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by the city; 
(c)  the administrative ordinances of the city, not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of such Code; 
(d)  any ordinance creating jobs or positions, or any ordinance fixing salaries of officers or employees of the city or any ordinance providing social security, health insurance or retirement benefits for specific officers or employees of the city; 
(e)  any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(f)  any right or franchise granted by the Common Council to any person, firm or corporation; 
(g)  any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(h)  any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; or any ordinance prescribing standards and specifications for streets and sidewalks within the city; 
(i)  any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(j)  any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city, or providing regulations for the same; 
(k)  any ordinance annexing property to the city; 
(l)  any zoning ordinance of the city; 
(m)  any ordinance approving or authorizing any contract; 
(n)  any ordinance relating to urban renewal; 
(o)  any ordinance enacted after August 1, 1983; 
nor shall such repeal be construed to revive any ordinance or part of an ordinance that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Nothing in this ordinance or in the Code adopted hereby shall be deemed to adopt, amend or repeal any local law, resolution, rule or regulation approved by the Common Council. It is hereby declared the intent of the Common Council that such local laws, resolutions, rules and regulations as are included in such Code are included only for the convenience of the user of the Code. 
Section 5. That a copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk, preserved in looseleaf form or in such other form as the City Clerk may consider expedient. It shall be the express duty of the City Clerk or someone authorized by him, to insert in their designated places all amendments and all legislation which the Common Council desires made a part of such Code when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such Code all provisions which from time to time may be repealed by the Common Council. 
Section 6. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are to the extent of such conflict hereby repealed. 
Section 7. That this ordinance shall take effect immediately. 
Adopted by the Common Council of the City of White Plains, N.Y., January 7, 1985.  
CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— This is the Charter of the city of White Plains, being Ch. 356 of the Laws of 1915, as amended. The numbering system and catchlines are as set out in such act. In some instances, however, catchlines and other material have been added by the editors for clarity or to facilitate indexing; in such instances such material has been encased in brackets. In the original charter the symbol "§" was used for the term "section;" in catchlines the editors have used the term "Sec.". The editors have also used parentheses for editorially inserted numerals in the body of many sections, subsections and subparagraphs. 
Absence of a history note following a section in the charter indicates that the content thereof is set as originally enacted in the basic charter act; a history note enclosed in parentheses following a section indicates that such section has been amended by the act and/or local law cited in such history note. Provisions of such amendments, including, but not limited to, severability, repealer and effective date provisions, not being of a substantive or regulatory nature, have been deleted. Whenever the term "title" appears in the charter, such word is to be construed to mean "act". 
 
ARTICLE I. - CITY AND WARD BOUNDARIES; INCORPORATION[2] 
Section 
1.
Short title. 
2.
City boundaries. 
3.
Reserved. 
4.
Corporate name and powers. 
5.
Official and fiscal year. 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— The city of White Plains lies in the County of Westchester which has its own Charter and Administrative Code. The city is a member of the Westchester County Public Welfare District, the County Health District and the County Laboratory District, the Bronx Valley Sanitary Sewer District and the Mamaroneck Valley Sanitary Sewer District. 
The city school district is a separate political entity created by Laws 1950, Ch. 762 and having its own taxing powers. 
 
Sec. 1. - Short title. 
This act shall be known as the charter of the city of White Plains.  
Sec. 2. - City boundaries. 
The territory in the county of Westchester included within the following boundaries shall constitute the city of White Plains. 
All that portion of the towns of White Plains, North Castle and Greenburgh, in the county of Westchester, which is embraced in the following limits, namely: 
Commencing at the center of the Bronx river, on the line dividing the towns of White Plains and North Castle, running thence southerly by and along the center of said Bronx river and along the division line between the town of White Plains and the town of Greenburgh till it comes to the junction of a small brook known as Randall's brook with said Bronx river, a little to the northward of the former residence of William Roberts, in said town of Greenburgh; thence running northwesterly and westerly by and along the center line of said brook, with its various windings and turnings until it comes to the northerly side of the highway which runs westerly from the westerly side of the Tarrytown road to Hart's Corners, now known as North street; thence westerly by and along the northerly line of said road which leads to Hart's Corners, until it comes to a bend in said last mentioned road, opposite the southeasterly corner of the former residence of Daniel Burtnett; thence running southwesterly by and along the northwesterly side of said road which leads to Hart's Corners, now known as Hartsdale road or Fulton street until it comes to the projection of the southerly line of the road which leads from White Plains over Chatterton's hill, now known as Battle avenue, nearly opposite the former residence of John Hart; thence running in a straight line southerly to the town line dividing the town of White Plains from the town of Scarsdale (at the westerly end thereof at its intersection with the Bronx river); thence southerly and southeasterly by said town line, to the west side of the highway known as the New York Post road, where the same is intersected by the division line between the towns of White Plains and Scarsdale; running from thence in a southerly and southeasterly direction along the division line between the said towns of White Plains and Scarsdale as the same winds and turns, to a small brook known as Branch brook; thence following the center line of the said brook in a southeasterly and southerly direction as it winds and turns, and still along the division line between the towns of Scarsdale and White Plains, to a point in the center line of the Mamaroneck river and to the town line of the town of Harrison; thence in a northeasterly, northerly, northwesterly and northeasterly direction through the center line of said Mamaroneck river and the center line of the west branch of the Mamaroneck river and by and along the division line between the towns of White Plains and Harrison, as said river and the west branch thereof winds and turns, continuing in said line to the line dividing the towns of White Plains and North Castle; thence westerly by and along said line between the towns of White Plains and North Castle to a point on the westerly line of Cottage avenue, so-called; thence northeasterly along the westerly side of Cottage avenue to an angle in said avenue; thence crossing said avenue to a point at the southeast corner of the land of the village of White Plains and used by the village of White Plains for water purposes; thence in a northeasterly, westerly, northerly, westerly, northerly, westerly, southerly, westerly and southerly direction along the lines of the lands of the village of White Plains owned and used for water purposes to a point where the westerly line of said lands intersects the division line between the towns of White Plains and North Castle; thence westerly by and along said line between the towns of White Plains and North Castle to the place of beginning. 
Being all of the territory heretofore comprising the village of White Plains as defined by chapter seven hundred and sixty-eight of the laws of eighteen hundred and ninety-six, and all that part of the town of White Plains, not included in the village of White Plains, lying southerly of said village and all that part of the town of North Castle owned and used by the village of White Plains for water purposes. 
Related laws references— Boundary line between city of White Plains, city school district, Town of Harrison in the Cross Westchester Expressway Right-of-Way, between the former Central Westchester Parkway and Maplemour Golf Course, Art. A, Div. 9; boundary line between city, city school district and Town of Harrison between a point in the center line of the Cross Westchester Expressway and a point in Silver Lake, Art. A, Div. 11; boundary line between city of White Plains and Town of North Castle, Art. B, Div. 1.  
Sec. 3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 1 of L.L. No. 1-1972 repealed former § 3 pertaining to ward boundaries.  
Sec. 4. - Corporate name and powers. 
The citizens of the state of New York, from time to time inhabitants of the territory comprised within the boundaries of the city of White Plains, shall be a municipal corporation, by the name of "the city of White Plains," and shall be a municipal corporation in perpetuity under its corporate name and the same shall in that name be a body politic and corporate in fact and in law, with power of perpetual succession. The city shall have power to make, have and use, and from time to time alter, a corporate seal; to sue and be sued; to acquire property in fee simple, or lesser interest or estate, by condemnation or by purchase, gift, devise, lease, or lease with the privilege to purchase, for any municipal purpose; to sell, lease, hold, manage and control such property, and make any and all rules and regulations by ordinance or resolution which may be required to carry out fully all the provisions of any conveyance, deed or will, in relation to any gift or bequest, or the provisions of any lease by which it may acquire property; to acquire by purchase or condemnation, contract, own, lease and operate and regulate public utilities; to make contracts for water supply; to erect suitable memorials in memory of the citizens of White Plains who were in the service of their country in the wars in which the United States were engaged; to assess, levy and collect taxes for general and special purposes on all the subjects or objects which the city may lawfully tax; to appropriate the money of the city for all lawful purposes; to create, provide for, construct, regulate and maintain all things of the nature of public works and improvements and prescribe the width and grade of streets, and sidewalks and provide for the numbering of the lots or buildings adjoining the street; to levy and collect assessments for local improvements; to license and regulate persons, corporations and associations engaged in any business, occupation, profession or trade which it may be necessary or proper to license or regulate, to promote the health, morals, safety or general welfare of its inhabitants; to define, prohibit, abate, suppress and prevent all things detrimental to the health, morals, comfort, safety, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the city, and all nuisances and causes thereof; may regulate the construction, height and material used in all buildings, and the maintenance and occupancy thereof; may regulate the planting, maintenance, protection and control of shade trees planted or growing upon the public highways or public places of said city, and for that purpose shall have power to enact an ordinance or ordinances providing for the appointment of a shade tree commission; and establish fire limits and require the erection of fire escapes; may regulate and license the construction of billboards, signs and similar structures; may regulate and control the use, for whatever purposes of the streets and other public places and require and compel railroad companies to provide flagmen or to erect and maintain gates at street crossings at grade and to suitably protect street crossings other than at grade and to regulate the obstruction of the streets by railway locomotives and cars and their running and rate of speed; may compel the owner or occupants of any premises adjoining any street to construct, maintain and repair sidewalks in front of said premises, including the space between the outside limits of the street and the curb and to erect barriers or safeguards at dangerous places and to remove snow and ice from such sidewalks and barriers and in case of the failure of such owner or occupant to remove such snow and ice, to assess the cost and expense thereof against such property; may create, establish, abolish and organize offices and fix the salaries and compensation of all officers and employees; may make and enforce local police, sanitary and other regulations; may regulate and license the running at large of dogs and provide for impounding and killing unlicensed dogs; may contract at the expense of the city for insurance indemnifying the city against any loss arising from injuries to persons or property, and may pass such ordinances as may be expedient for maintaining and promoting the peace, good government and welfare of the city; and for the performance of the functions thereof. The city shall have all the powers that now are or hereafter may be granted to municipalities by the constitution or laws of the state of New York; and all such powers, whether expressed or implied, shall be exercised and enforced in the manner prescribed by this act, or when not prescribed herein, in such manner as shall be provided by ordinance or resolution of the common council. The enumeration of particular powers in this act shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, but in addition to the powers enumerated herein implied thereby or appropriate to the exercise thereof, the city shall have and may exercise, all other powers which, under the constitution and laws of the state of New York, it would be competent for this act specifically to enumerate. 
(Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1925, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1928, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1951, § 1) 
Cross reference— Common council constituted and organized, § 28; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32. 
State Law reference— Bill of rights for local governments, Const., Art. 9, § 1; grants of powers to local governments, Statute of Local Governments, § 10; general powers of the city, General City Law, § 19; powers enumerated, General City Law, § 20; power of local governments to adopt and amend local laws, Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10; municipal powers, limitations and liabilities, General Municipal Law, § 70 et seq.  
Sec. 5. - Official and fiscal year. 
The official year of the city shall, except as otherwise provided in this act, commence on the first day of January, in each year. The fiscal year of the city shall commence on the first day of July in each year and shall terminate at midnight on the thirtieth day of June next following. 
(L.L. No. 3-1951, § 1)

Cross reference— Regulation of powers and duties of officers by common council, § 39; emergency succession of mayor and others, §§ 46, 46-a; officers not to incur expenditures, debts or contracts in excess of appropriations, § 70; creation of debt, § 289. 
Code reference— Officers and employees generally, Ch. 2-5.

Sec. 6. - City officers. 
City officers, within the meaning of this act, include all persons elected or appointed to any office of the city created or authorized by this act or otherwise by law.  
Sec. 7. - Elective officers. 
There shall be elected by the qualified electors of the city a mayor and six councilmen. 
(Laws 1964, Ch. 588, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 1) 
Cross reference— Common council constituted and organized, § 28; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32; executive power, duties of mayor, § 45 et seq. 
State Law reference— Election of officers not provided for, Const., Art. 9, § 1(b).  
Sec. 8. - Appointive officers. 
There shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the common council, a commissioner of finance, an assessor and a board of assessment review, a corporation counsel, a commissioner of public works, a commissioner of public safety, a commissioner of building, a commissioner of recreation and parks, one or more city marshals, a personnel officer, a commissioner of purchase, a commissioner of traffic, a commissioner of planning, a city clerk, a chief information officer, a commissioner of parking and a budget director. In order to obtain the consent of the common council to any such appointment, the mayor shall submit a nomination for such appointment to the common council, at a meeting of the common council, whose consent to such appointment shall be evidenced by either the affirmative vote of four members of the common council taken within thirty days of the nomination, or such consent shall be deemed to have been given if the common council fails to approve or disapprove such nomination within said thirty day period. Other officers may be appointed as provided in this act or otherwise by law. Any city officer, when authorized by the common council, may appoint a deputy or deputies, or other representatives, who when so appointed, shall be authorized to act generally for and in place of their principals, and other subordinates. The aforementioned officers shall appoint, direct, and have authority to discharge their respective staff. All appointments to any city office shall be evidenced by a certificate in writing, signed by the appointing officer and filed in the office of the city clerk, if an appointment is made by the common council, or by the mayor, with the consent of the common council, such certificate shall be signed by the officer presiding at the time the appointment was made and attested by the city clerk. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 1; Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1932; L.L. No. 4-1940, § 1; L.L. No. 5-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 10-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 5-1957, § 1; L.L. 5-1960, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1961, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1962, § 1; Laws 1970, Ch. 469, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1971, § 1; Laws 1972, Ch. 843, § 5; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 5; L.L. No. 4-1976, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 5; L.L. No. 2-1977, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1979, § 2; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 5; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 2; L. L. No. 2-1999, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2004, § 2; L.L. No. 2-2006, § 1; L.L. No. 3-2012, § 5; L.L. No. 3-2014, § 2) 
Editor's note— See § 74 of the charter and Arts. 5 and 15-A of the Real Property Tax Law for the duties of the assessor and board of assessment review generally. 
Cross reference— City clerk as clerk of common council, § 31; powers and duties of city clerk generally, § 50; powers, duties of commissioner of finance, § 51 et seq.; powers and duties of assessor and board of assessment review, § 74 et seq.; powers, duties, jurisdiction of commissioner of public works, § 117 et seq.; powers, duties of commissioner of public safety, § 219 et seq.; power, duties of commissioner of recreation and parks, § 238-b; duties of personnel director, § 238-g; duties of commissioner of purchase, § 238-i; duties of commissioner of building, § 238-u; duties of commissioner of planning and traffic, § 238-y; powers and duties of corporation counsel, § 239 et seq.; board of library trustees, general powers, appointment § 270 et seq. 
State Law reference— Appointment of officers not provided for, Const., Art. 9, § 1(b).  
Sec. 9. - Term of office. 
The term of office of each elective officer, unless elected to fill a vacancy then existing, shall commence on the first day of January next succeeding his or her election; the term of office of each appointive officer shall commence on the day succeeding his or her appointment unless a different date is specified in the certificate of appointment. The term of office of the mayor and the council shall be four years. The term of office of the four full-time city court judges shall be for a period of ten years, except that in accordance with chapter five hundred forty-eight of the laws of two thousand and thirteen, the term of the person serving in the part-time judgeship abolished by said act shall continue in service in the newly created full-time judgeship for the remainder of the term of office to which he was selected in the abolished judgeship until the nineteenth of December two thousand and fifteen. All other city officers shall be appointed without term and shall hold office at the will and pleasure of the common council, except as herein otherwise provided. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 2; Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 2; Laws 1970, Ch. 469, § 2; Laws 1971, Ch. 81, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1976, § 2; L.L. No. 5-1976, § 1; Laws 1982, Ch. 790, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2003, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2007, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2014, § 1) 
Cross reference— See § 10 of Charter as last amended by Laws 1970, Chapter 469, § 4.  
Section 9-a. - Appointment of four full-time city court judges. 
The terms of the city court judges and the part-time city court judges in office upon the effective date of this act are continued until the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred eighty-two. In the month of January, nineteen hundred and eighty-three, and in such month or months every ten years thereafter, or upon the vacancy of such office, the common council shall appoint four full-time city court judges for a term expiring ten years from the date of such appointment. An appointment by the common council at any time to fill a vacancy in such offices shall be for a full ten year term if such vacancy occurs in the office of a full-time city court judge. 
The full-time city court judges shall give their whole time to their duties and shall not engage in the practice of law, act as an arbitrator, referee or compensated mediator in any action or proceeding or matter, engage in the conduct of any other profession or business which interferes with the performance of their duties as city court judges. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 3; Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 3; Laws 1970, Ch. 469, § 3; Laws 1971, Ch. 81, § 2; Laws 1982, Ch. 790, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2003, § 2; L.L. No. 1-2007, § 2; L.L. No. 1-2014, § 2) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-2014 changed the title of § 9-a from "Appointment of three full-time city court judges and one part-time city court judge" to "Appointment of four full-time city court judges." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes.  
Sec. 9-b. - Termination of powers, duties and jurisdiction of civil justices. 
Upon the appointment and qualification of the city judge and the acting city judge, as provided for in section 9-a of this act, in the month of January, nineteen hundred and twenty-seven, the powers, duties and jurisdiction of the civil justices then in office shall terminate. All actions and special proceedings commenced prior to the time this act takes effect before a civil justice of the city of White Plains may be prosecuted in the same manner and with the same effect as they might under the laws then existing and for that purpose the present civil justices in the city of White Plains shall continue to hold office until the determination of such actions and special proceedings. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 3; Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 4)  
Sec. 10. - Eligibility. 
No person shall be elected to a city office in said city unless at the time of his or her election he or she is a resident elector of said city and shall have resided in the city for at least two years prior to his or her election. Whenever any elective officer shall cease to be a resident of said city his or her office shall thereby become vacant. 
A corporation counsel hereafter chosen shall be an attorney-at-law who has been admitted to practice in this state for at least five years. The four full-time city court judges hereafter appointed shall be attorneys-at-law who shall have been admitted to practice in this state for at least five years and shall be a resident of the city. No person shall at the same time hold more than one salaried city office. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 4; Laws 1923, Ch. 570, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1957, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1967, § 1; Laws 1970, Ch. 469, § 4; L.L. No. 7-1979, § 1; L.L. No. 1-2003, § 3; L.L. No. 1-2007, § 3; L.L. No. 1-2014, § 3)  
Sec. 11. - Qualifications. 
Every inhabitant in said city who shall at the time and place of offering his vote be qualified to vote for member of assembly shall be entitled to vote for all officers to be elected by virtue of this act in the ward and district where he shall be qualified.  
Sec. 12. - Election districts. 
The common council shall have authority to subdivide the several wards into election districts in accordance with the general election laws; and said districts, when so designated by said council, shall constitute election districts for all general and other elections to be held in said city, unless herein otherwise provided, and all provisions of law applicable to election districts and to the inspectors and other officers of election thereof and therein shall apply to said election districts, inspectors and other election officers. 
Code reference— Election districts, § 2-1-1. 
State Law reference— Division of city into election districts, Election Law, § 4-100.  
Sec. 13. - City elections; procedure in event of a tie. 
All city elections, except as otherwise provided herein, shall be held biennially on the Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday of November in each odd-numbered year, and shall be conducted and the votes cast thereat canvassed and the returns thereof made in all respects in the same manner as general elections in cities are required to be conducted, and all provisions of law relative to such elections shall be applicable to the election of officers of the city. In case of the failure to elect an elective city officer, except as otherwise provided herein, the office shall be deemed to be vacant for the purpose of choosing a successor and the vacancy shall be filled in the manner provided herein for the filling of a vacancy in such office happening otherwise than by expiration of term. In each district for the election of officers under this act there shall be a ballot box and other boxes required by the general election law of the state. Upon the closing of the polls, the inspectors shall forthwith, without adjournment, canvass the votes, and shall make and certify statements of the result in the manner required by the general election laws of the state. Separate returns as to the city officers voted for shall be filed in the office of the city clerk on the next day succeeding the election. 
In the event that each of two (2) or more candidates for the office of Mayor or supervisor has more votes than any other candidate for the same respective office, and such votes are equal in number for such office, the common council shall appoint one of such tied-vote candidates as mayor, or supervisor, as the case may be, to serve until the first day of January next succeeding the first annual election after such appointment at which the vacancy can be filled. 
In the event that each of two (2) or more candidates for the office of councilman has more votes than any other candidates for such office, and such votes are equal in number, each shall be considered to be elected to such office, provided that no more persons shall be deemed to be so elected than there are offices of councilmen to be filled at such election. Should such candidates be more in number than the offices to be filled, the common council shall select and appoint whomever are to be deemed to be elected, such appointee or appointees to serve until the first day of January next succeeding the first annual election after such appointment at which a vacancy can be filled. Similar procedure should be followed in case of a tie vote among two (2) or more other candidates for the office of councilman, except that no more shall be selected and appointed than are necessary to fill the offices voted for at such election. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 14. - Vacancies. 
Except as otherwise provided in this act, if a vacancy shall occur in any elective office of the city otherwise than by expiration of term, the common council shall appoint a person to fill such vacancy until the commencement of the political year next succeeding the first annual election after the happening of the vacancy at which the vacancy can be filled. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 2) 
Cross reference— Emergency succession of mayor and others, §§ 46, 46-a. 
State Law reference— Creation of vacancies, Public Officers Law, § 30; filling vacancies in elective offices, Public Officers Law, § 42; vacancies in office, Const., Art. 13, § 3; election, term of officers, Const., Art. 13, § 8.  
Sec. 15. - Notice to persons appointed. 
The city clerk shall give notice, in writing, to every person appointed to any office under this act of his appointment, within twenty-four (24) hours after the certificate of his appointment has been filed in his office, which notice shall be served personally, or by leaving it at the residence of such person, or by mailing such notice to the place of residence or business of the person so appointed. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 3)  
Sec. 16. - Compensation of city officers and employees. 
Effective January 1, 1990, the mayor shall receive an annual salary of $99,500, and each councilman shall receive a salary of $24,875, except that the member of the common council elected by said common council to serve as president shall receive an additional annual salary of $2,500. Effective January 1, 1991, the mayor shall receive an annual salary of $107,500, and each councilman shall receive an annual salary of $26,875. The common council by an ordinance adopted by a two-thirds vote of all its members shall have the power to fix the salaries or compensation of all other officers and employees of the city, except as to such officers and employees as are required to serve without compensation. All salary or compensation changes for other officers and employees of the city shall not take effect until commencement of the next ensuing fiscal year of the city, except by reason of collective bargaining negotiations and related adjustments. The salaries of all city officers and employees shall be payable in such installments and at such time as the common council shall determine. A person appointed to fill a vacancy or temporarily appointed to discharge the duties of an office during the sickness, absence or suspension from office of the incumbent shall receive such salary or compensation as the common council may fix and determine. 
Any further changes to the salaries for elected officials are to be adopted by ordinance at the time the city's annual budget is adopted. 
(L.L. No. 1-1959, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1965, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1969, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1975, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1977, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1981, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1983, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1985, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1989, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991; L.L. No. 1-1994, § 1) 
State Law reference— Increasing compensation during fiscal year prohibited, General City Law, § 25; payment of overtime compensation to public officers or employees, General Municipal Law, § 90; local law increasing salary of elective officer during term of office subject to referendum on petition, Municipal Home Rule Law, § 24(2)(h).  
Sec. 17. - Fees and perquisites. 
No city officer except city marshals shall have or receive to his own use any perquisites, compensation or fees for services pertaining, directly or indirectly of which may hereafter be added, to the duties of his office in addition to his salary; but any perquisite, compensation or fee legally chargeable for services performed by any such officer shall be collected by him and paid to the commissioner of finance for the benefit of the city. Except as otherwise provided by law, every city officer receiving any such perquisites, compensation or fees shall, at least once each week and more frequently if directed by the commissioner of finance, report in relation to and pay over same to the said commissioner of finance. 
(Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 5; L.L. No. 3-1948, § 1)  
Sec. 18. - Official oaths and bonds of city officers. 
Each officer and appointee of the city shall before he enters upon the duties of his office take and file the constitutional oath of office. The said officer must take and file said oath within ten (10) days after notice in writing of his election or appointment and if he fails to do so and to file a bond as required by this section the office shall be deemed vacant and shall be filled as in case of a vacancy. Each commissioner of finance, commissioner of public safety, commissioner of public works, commissioner of recreation, commissioner of purchase, commissioner of building, city clerk, city judge, acting city judge and city marshal shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office, execute and file an official bond of a solvent fidelity or surety company, authorized by the laws of this state to transact business, which must be approved by the common council; the penal sum named in such bond, or the sums specified in such undertakings as the maximum amount of liability thereon shall be fixed by the common council. Where a surety company is required, the cost thereof shall be a charge against the city. All bonds shall be properly endorsed and filed in the office of the city clerk. In addition to the officers required by this section to give bonds for the faithful performance of their several duties, the common council may require any officers, or any person who is or may be appointed by them, or by any other city officer, to give like bonds with sureties such as the common council may approve, conditioned as the council may direct, and the common council may whenever it deems proper, require additional further security of any officer or person after the giving of the bond first mentioned. The city of White Plains may sue for and recover for any breach of such bond or bonds. Nothing contained herein or in this act, as amended, shall prevent the use of a schedule or a blanket bond for any officer or employee as authorized by law. 
(Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 6; L.L. No. 2-1960, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 3) 
State Law reference— Official undertakings generally, Public Officers Law, § 11 et seq.  
Sec. 19. - Office and business hours of city officers. 
All city offices shall be kept open for the transaction of business at such hours and times as the common council may from time to time direct. 
Code reference— Office hours designated, § 2-1-2. 
State Law reference— Operating hours of public offices, Public Officers Law, § 62.  
Sec. 20. - Resignations and removals. 
A city officer may resign his office by delivering a written resignation to the city clerk, and his resignation shall take effect upon the delivery thereof, unless a time be specified in such resignation, in which case such resignation shall take effect at the time so specified. Such resignation shall be filed with the city clerk in his office, and he shall immediately notify the officer, board or other body authorized to fill a vacancy in such office of such resignation. Any city officer, except the mayor, councilmen, city judge and acting city judge, may be removed from office by a majority vote of all the members of the common council to be taken by ayes and nays and recorded, at the pleasure of the common council and such officer may be suspended at the pleasure of the common council by a majority vote thereof. Any elective officer for whose removal no provision is made herein may be removed by the governor in the same manner as a sheriff, except that the governor may direct the inquiry provided by law be conducted by the attorney general. After charges have been received by the governor he may suspend the officer affected thereby for a period not exceeding sixty days pending the investigation. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to take from any officer or board the powers to remove subordinates according to law. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 627, § 5; Laws 1926, Ch. 633, § 7; L.L. No. 4-1976, § 3) 
State Law reference— Removal or suspension of appointive officer requires approval of mayor, General City Law, § 4; remedies for negligence, malfeasance of public officers, General Municipal Law, § 50 et seq.  
Sec. 21. - Appointments during disability and suspension. 
If any city officer, except the mayor, or councilmen, shall, from sickness, absence, suspension from office or from any other cause, be unable to discharge the duties of this office, the common council with respect to the library board trustees, city judge, acting city judge and associate city judges, and, the mayor with the consent of the common council with respect to all other city officers, may appoint some suitable person to discharge such duties during such disability, and the person so appointed shall have and exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties and be subject to all the provisions of law applicable to the officer whose place he shall supply, or to the officer or the duties of the office to which he is appointed, and shall receive such salary as shall be fixed by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 5; L.L. No. 4-1976, § 4)  
Sec. 22. - Clerk to keep a book containing list of officers. 
The city clerk shall keep a book, ruled in columns, in which he shall enter the name of every person elected or appointed to a city office, the name of the office, when elected or appointed, the commencement of the term, the expiration thereof, time of filing oath of office, and time of filing official bond, and every person so elected or appointed to any such office shall, upon filing his oath of office, subscribe his name beside the office to which he was elected or appointed. Such book shall be open at all times to the inspection of any elector of said city.  
Sec. 23. - Power to administer oaths. 
Every person elected or appointed to any office under this act shall have power to administer any oath or take any affidavit in respect to any matter before him as such officer. Any person who may be required to take any oath or affirmation or to make any affidavit or statement under oath or affirmation under oath or by virtue of any provision in this act, who shall under such oath or affirmation make any statement or affidavit or otherwise willfully swear falsely as to any material fact or matter, shall be guilty of perjury.  
Sec. 24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— As to the status of the board of supervisors, see Town of Greenburgh v. Board of Supervisors, 59 Misc. 2d 152, 298 N.Y.S. 2d 615 (S. Ct. 1969), aff'd. 32 App. Div. 2d 892, 30 N.Y.S. 2d 970 (S. Ct., App. Div. 1969), aff'd. 25 N.Y. 2d 817, 303 N.Y.S. 2d 673, 250 N.E. 2d 719 (Ct. App. 1969). This section was repealed by L. L. No. 1-1990, § 4.  
Sec. 25. - Officers to be elected at the first city election under this act. 
There shall be elected at an election to be held on the Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday of November in the year nineteen hundred and fifteen the following elective officers, provided for in this act, for the following terms, namely: A mayor, and three (3) councilmen, for a term beginning on the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and expiring on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred and seventeen, and three (3) councilmen, for a term beginning on the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and expiring on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred and nineteen. One supervisor from the first and second wards for a term beginning the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and expiring on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred and seventeen. One supervisor from the third and fourth wards for a term beginning on the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and expiring on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred and seventeen. One supervisor from the fifth and sixth wards for a term beginning on the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and expiring on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred and seventeen. 
For the purposes of providing for the above election, the board of trustees of the village of White Plains are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to procure the necessary supplies and appoint the necessary election officers to hold and carry out such election, and to define and elect the various election district boundaries within said wards, if required, and to perform all acts necessary for the holding of the said election in a manner prescribed by the provisions of this charter and the provisions of the election law, and the said board of trustees of the village of White Plains are authorized, empowered and directed to act as a board of canvassers in and for the said election so held. 
For the election provided under this section, all persons, residents of the said city entitled to vote at the last general village election of the village of White Plains, and those taken within this city by this act, who are electors of the towns of North Castle and White Plains, and would be eligible to vote at a town election, are hereby declared to be entitled to vote for the officers provided under this act. 
When the officers elected as hereinbefore provided shall take office on the first day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, this act and the city of White Plains shall then be in full force and effect, and the present form of government, including all existing town, village and school districts within the territory incorporated under this act shall thereupon cease, be dissolved and terminate and the present officers of the territory so incorporated by this act shall turn over to the new city officers all the books, papers, records, and property of every kind, and shall account to the said officers for all funds or property of any kind of which they are properly chargeable as such officers.  
Sec. 26. - City officers not to be interested in contracts. 
(1)  No member of the common council of the city of White Plains shall, during the period for which he was elected, be capable of holding under the appointment or election of the common council any other office the emoluments of which are paid from the city treasury, or paid by fees or compensation directed to be paid by any act or ordinance of the common council, nor shall the mayor or any councilman or other public or city officer of the city of White Plains be directly or indirectly interested either as principal, surety or in any other manner, in any contract, lease, concession or other agreement to or in which the city is a party, but this section shall not affect the right to any fees or emoluments belonging to any office. 
(2)  The terms "city officer," "public officer" or "employee" shall mean and include the mayor, councilmen and any elective or appointive officer, deputy, subordinate, or any other employee of the city receiving salary or compensation for services, from funds appropriated by the city of White Plains. 
(3)  No city officer, public officer or employee shall voluntarily be pecuniarily or individually interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract, sale or lease with the city, except for lawful compensation and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of duties. Any such contract, sale or lease made to or with the city shall be null, void and unenforceable. 
(4)  No city officer, public officer or employee representing or acting for the city shall accept any consideration, commission or gratuity from any vendor or real or personal property, purchased or acquired by the city, nor from any contractor of services to be rendered the city. 
(5)  The common council of the city of White Plains may allow sale of city bonds, notes or other obligations to, or may designate as a depository of city funds, any corporation in which any city officer or public officer or employee paid his compensation for services from city funds is only a director or officer or stockholder or employee of such corporation, provided not more than twenty-five per centum (25%) of the capital stock of the corporation is owned by all such city officers paid their compensation from city funds, who shall be deemed not interested individually in such sales or contracts under such conditions, and provided further that neither the commissioner of finance of the city nor any deputy or subordinate or employee in his office shall be a stockholder in any corporation which purchases city bonds, notes or other obligations or which is designated as a depository of city funds. 
(6)  The provisions of this entire section shall not apply to members of boards or commissions, appointed or created by the mayor or the common council of the city of White Plains, who receive no compensation or salary for services, but no such member of any board or commission of the city shall take part in, or vote or pass upon, any matter before said board or commission in which matter he has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest. 
(L.L. No. 7-1957, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 7-1957 which added § 26 to the Charter further provided in sec. 2 thereof that section three of chapter twenty-six of the laws of nineteen hundred nine, entitled "An act in relation to cities, constituting chapter twenty-one of the consolidated laws", as last amended by chapter eight hundred seventy-eight of the laws of nineteen hundred fifty-three, is hereby superseded in its entirety. Laws 1964, Ch. 946, §§ 13—15 provides for supersession of charter provisions inconsistent with General Municipal Law, Art. 18. 
Code reference— Code of ethics, § 2-5-106 et seq. 
State Law reference— Appointment of members of common council to other offices prohibited, General City Law, § 3; conflicts of interest of municipal officers and employees, General Municipal Law, § 800 et seq.  
Sec. 27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 27 was omitted from the basic Charter Act. Said section number is included by the editors to maintain sequence.

Sec. 28. - Common council, how constituted and organized. 
The council shall consist of a mayor and six (6) councilmen. Each member of the council, including the mayor, shall have the right to vote on all questions coming before it. Four (4) members of the council will constitute a quorum, and unless otherwise provided by law the affirmative vote of four (4) members shall be necessary to adopt any motion, resolution or pass any measure coming before it. Less than a majority of all of the members of the common council, in the absence of a quorum, may adjourn a meeting of such common council from time to time, and adopt such measures as may be necessary to compel the attendance of absent members. 
Meetings of the council shall be public and stated meetings shall be held as the council may provide by ordinance or resolution, but at least one meeting shall be held each month. The mayor shall preside at all meetings but shall have no power of veto any other provisions of this act to the contrary notwithstanding. The first meeting of the common council in January of each year shall be the annual meeting. Said council shall at the annual meeting in each even-numbered year elect one of its members president of the common council, who shall hold office until his successor shall have been elected and qualifies, and who shall preside at all meetings in the absence of said mayor. A journal shall be kept in which full and accurate minutes of each meeting shall be recorded, including the result of the voting upon each resolution. Special meetings may be called by the mayor when he deems advisable and shall be called by him at the request of any two (2) councilmen by giving such written notice that the council may by ordinance or resolution direct. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 6) 
Code reference— Council meetings, § 2-3-16 et seq.  
Sec. 29. - Rules; meetings. 
The common council shall determine the rules of its own proceedings. Its meetings shall be public, except when the public interests require secrecy, but no vote shall be taken in secret or executive session. Its records shall be open to public inspection. The passage of an ordinance, unless otherwise herein provided, shall require the affirmative vote of at least four (4) members. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 7; L.L. No. 2-1982, § 1) 
Code reference— Rules of order and procedure, § 2-3-16 et seq. 
State Law reference— Quorum and majority established, General Construction Law, § 41; Open Meeting Law, Public Officers Law, § 95 et seq.  
Sec. 30. - Discipline of members; expulsion. 
The common council may compel the attendance of absent members at any meeting properly called, and may punish or expel a member for disorderly conduct, for the violation of its rules, or for official misconduct, or declare his seat vacant by reason of absence, provided such absence has continued for the space of four (4) months; but no expulsion shall take place and no vacancy on account of absence be declared except by the vote of three-fourths (¾) of all the members of the common council, or until the delinquent member has had an opportunity to be heard in his defense.  
Sec. 31. - Clerk of council; city clerk. 
The city clerk shall be the clerk of the common council, and shall attend its meetings, keep a journal of its proceedings, and discharge such other duties as by law further provided, or which may be prescribed by the city ordinances, or the direction of the common council not inconsistent therewith. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 8)  
Sec. 32. - Legislative power. 
The legislative power of the city is vested in the common council thereof, and it has the authority to enact, amend or repeal ordinances, not inconsistent with the laws of the state, for the government of the city and the management of its business, for the preservation of good order, peace and health, for the safety and welfare of its inhabitants, and the protection and security of their property; and its authority, except as otherwise provided in this act or by other laws of the state, is legislative only. The common council shall have power to establish any office, position or employment that may in its opinion be necessary or expedient for the carrying out of the provisions of this charter and to fix the salary and the duties thereof. The common council may at any time abolish any such office, position or employment established by it, whereupon the salary attached thereto shall thereupon cease. All the legislative acts of the common council shall be by ordinance, and on the vote on every ordinance, the yeas and nays of the members shall be taken and entered in full in the journal. 
(L.L. No. 8-1961, § 1) 
Cross reference— Corporate name and powers, § 4. 
Code reference— Introduction and notice, etc., of local laws, § 2-3-28 et seq. 
State Law reference— Powers of city enumerated, General City Law, § 20; powers of local governments, Statute of Local Governments, § 10; Bill of rights for local governments, home rule powers, statute of local governments, etc., Const. Art. 9; general powers to adopt, amend local laws, Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10.  
Sec. 33. - Ordinances and appropriation of money; franchises. 
No ordinance shall be passed by the common council on the same day in which it is introduced, except by unanimous consent, which consent may be given by roll call vote or provided in writing on a form approved by and filed with the City Clerk prior to said roll call vote, and no appropriation of money shall be made for any purpose, except by an ordinance passed by a majority of all the members elected to the common council, specifying by items the amount thereof and the department or specific purpose for which the appropriation is made. No franchise shall be leased, assigned or otherwise alienated without the express consent of the city, and any franchise so leased, assigned or alienated without such consent shall be and become void. No exclusive franchise shall be granted; no franchise shall be made for a longer period than twenty-five (25) years, and no franchise shall be renewed prior to one year previous to its expiration. 
Every grant of a franchise or right shall provide that the city may, upon the payment therefor of its valuation, to be made as provided in the grant, purchase and take over the property and plant of the grantee in whole or in part. 
No franchise, lease or right to use the streets or the public places or property of the city shall be granted by the city without fair compensation to the city therefor, and in addition to the other forms of compensation to be therein provided, the grantee shall be required to pay annually to the city such percentage of the gross receipts arising from the use of such franchise and of the plant used therewith as shall be fixed in the grant of said franchise. 
Every grant of a franchise or right shall provide that the city may, upon the payment therefor of its fair valuation, to be made as provided in the grant, purchase and take over the property and plant of the grantee in whole or in part. 
The procedure to effect such purchase shall be as follows: 
When the council shall, by resolution, direct that the mayor shall ascertain whether any such property or part thereof, should be acquired by the city, or in the absence of such action of the council, when a petition subscribed by twenty-five per centum (25%) of qualified taxpayers requesting that the mayor shall ascertain whether any such property or part thereof should be acquired by the city, shall be filed with the clerk, the mayor shall forthwith carefully investigate said property and report to the council: 
(1)  At what probable cost said property may be acquired. 
(2)  What, if any, probable additional outlays would be necessary to operate same. 
(3)  Whether, if acquired, it could be operated by the city at a profit or advantage in quality or cost of service, stating wherein such profit or advantage consists. 
(4)  Whether, if acquired, it could be paid for out of its net earnings, and if so, within what time. 
(5)  Such other information touching the same as he shall have acquired. 
Such report shall be made in writing, shall include a statement of facts in relation thereto, with such particularity as will enable the council to judge of the correctness of his findings, and immediately after submission to the council, shall be filed with the clerk, recorded in a public utility record and published once in each of two (2) daily newspapers of general circulation published in the city, or printed and distributed in pamphlet form, as the council may deem best. 
Every grant reserving to the city the right to acquire the plant as well as the property, if any, of the grantees situated in, on, above or under the public places of the city, or elsewhere, used in connection therewith, shall in terms specify the method of arriving at the valuation therein provided for and shall further provide that upon the payment by the city of such valuation the plant and property so valued, purchased and paid for, shall become the property of the city by virtue of the grant and payment thereunder and without the execution of any instrument of conveyance; and every such grant shall make adequate provision by way of forfeiture of the grant, or otherwise, for the effectual securing of efficient service and for the continued maintenance of the property in good order and repair throughout the entire term of the grant. 
Whenever any plant or property shall become the property of the city of White Plains, the city shall have the option at any time then or thereafter, either to operate the same on its own account, or by ordinance to lease the same or any part thereof, together with the franchise or right to use the streets or other public property in connection therewith for periods not exceeding twenty-five (25) years under such rules and regulations as it may prescribe, or by ordinance to sell the same to the highest bidder at public sale. 
(Laws 1945, Ch. 839, § 70; L.L. No. 1-2019, § 1 )  
Sec. 34. - Ordinances, publication. 
No ordinance of the common council shall become operative until it has been enrolled and attested by the clerk, and whenever the same may be necessary, promulgated according to law; provided that in case of insurrection, riot, pestilence, conflagration or other public necessity requiring immediate operation of such ordinance, it shall take effect as soon as proclamation thereof has been made by the mayor and it, with such proclamation, has been posted in five (5) public places in each ward of the city. Except as aforesaid, no violation of an ordinance imposing a penalty or forfeiture for such violation shall be punishable until a notice setting forth the title of such ordinance, together with a statement that such ordinance is on file with the city clerk, shall have been published once in each week for two (2) successive weeks in the official newspaper of the city. Except as otherwise provided by law, or in the absence of an express provision in said ordinance to the contrary, any provision of an ordinance imposing or increasing fees shall take effect seven (7) days after adoption of such ordinance or on the effective date of such ordinance, whichever is later. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 322, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1960, § 9; L.L. No. 1-1966, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1997, § 1)  
Sec. 35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 35 was omitted in the numbering of the Charter, Laws 1915, Ch. 356. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 36. - Record of ordinances; evidence. 
Every ordinance shall, within a reasonable time after it becomes a law as herein provided, be recorded in a book kept for that purpose by the clerk. Such record shall include the attestation of the clerk, and as soon as the due publication is complete a certificate thereof shall be added to such record. Such record, or a certified copy thereof, shall be presumptive evidence of the passage of an ordinance. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 322, § 2)  
Sec. 37. - Penalties for violation of ordinances; actions to restrain violations. 
The common council may provide by a general ordinance, or in any ordinance, that any person guilty of a violation of such ordinance shall be liable to a fine which shall not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in amount, or imprisonment not exceeding one year, or to pay to the city a penalty not exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to be recovered in a civil action, or to both fine and imprisonment. Each and every day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation. The city may maintain an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to restrain by injunction the violation of any ordinance of the common council, or an order of the commissioner of public safety or of the commissioner of building, notwithstanding that an ordinance may provide a penalty or fine for its violation. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 10; L.L. No. 3-1984, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 5) 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for penalties, forfeitures, General City Law, § 20(22).  
Sec. 38. - Functions of city officers; how performed. 
Whenever an executive or administrative function shall be required by an ordinance of the common council to be performed, the same shall be performed by the proper executive or administrative officer or department to be designated in the ordinance, and in case no such designation be thus made, the mayor shall make the same.  
Sec. 39. - Regulation of powers and duties of officers. 
The common council may, by ordinances passed by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of all its members, not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, or other laws of the state, regulate the powers and duties of any city officer or department.  
Sec. 40. - Official newspaper; bills for printing. 
At the annual meeting of the common council, it shall designate one daily newspaper published in the city, to be the official newspaper of the city, and such designation shall be of such daily paper as will print all such proceedings and ordinances of the common council, boards or offices of the city, as may be by law required to be published, and all demands and legal notices of said city, or any board or officer thereof, required to be published. No bid shall be accepted for a sum in excess of the fees as allowed by law. For the purpose of so letting the public printing, the city clerk shall, at least two (2) weeks before such annual meeting, give notice to the publishers of all daily papers within the city, of the fact of such letting, at the time above stated; but no papers shall be eligible to bid unless published as a bona fide daily paper of general circulation for at least one year previous to such bidding. The city clerk of the city of White Plains, first appointed pursuant to this act shall immediately upon his appointment publish the notice above required of the letting of such contract, and upon the receipt of bids therefor the common council shall immediately designate one daily newspaper published in the city to be the official newspaper of the city until the first annual meeting of the common council. If, for any reason, a designation of an official paper shall not be made at the annual meeting of the common council, the official paper previously designated shall continue to be the official paper of said city until a designation shall be made, as herein provided. Such paper shall publish the proceedings and ordinances of the common council and all other matters required by law or by ordinances of the city to be published. In case the official paper shall refuse or fail to act or perform as such or in case there shall be no bids received from a newspaper qualified to be designated as the official newspaper under this act, the common council may designate any newspaper published in the county of Westchester as the official newspaper of the city. All bills and accounts for publication in the official newspaper, and all city printing and advertising shall be a city charge. 
(L.L. No. 1-1942, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1960, § 11)  
Sec. 41. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 41 was repealed by L.L. No. 2-1960, Sec. 12. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 42. - Minutes of meetings. 
The minutes of each meeting of the common council shall be printed in full within thirty (30) days after its adjournment and immediately distributed, one to the mayor, one to each member of the common council, one to the head of each department. At the end of the year the printed minutes shall be indexed and bound in such number as shall have been provided in the original letting of the official printing. 
(L.L. No. 2-1960, § 13)  
Sec. 43. - Powers of members to incur expenses. 
No member or committee of the common council has power to employ any person, incur any expense or purchase any material for or on behalf of the city or any of its officers, boards or commissions, except as expressly provided in this act.  
Sec. 44. - Special reports to the common council. 
All officers of said city who have any power as such officers to collect, receive or disburse money shall, when requested by the common council, render to it a verified statement and account of all moneys received or disbursed by them, and shall also, whenever required by the common council, personally appear and submit to an examination under oath by the common council or any committee thereof. A willful refusal or neglect to obey any such order of the common council shall be deemed a neglect of duty and a sufficient cause for removal from office.  
ARTICLE IV. - THE MAYOR; PRESIDENT OF COMMON COUNCIL; CITY CLERK[5] 
Section 
45.
Executive power. 
46.
Acting mayor. 
46-a.
Procedure in event of an extraordinary emergency. 
46-b.
Disability of mayor. 
46-c.
Vacancy in the office of mayor.

Duties.
