Consultation with heads of departments. 
49.
Examination of accounts. 
50.
City clerk; additional powers and duties. 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Code reference— Officers and employees, Ch. 2-5. 
 
Sec. 45. - Executive power. 
The executive power of the city is vested in the mayor, and in such executive officers and departments as are or may be created by law, or by the ordinances of the common council.  
Sec. 46. - Acting mayor. 
Whenever by reason of disability, or sickness, or absence from the city, the mayor shall be prevented from or unable to attend to the duties of the office, or if the office of mayor is vacant and until a new mayor takes office, the president of the common council shall act as mayor and possess all of the rights of mayor, except entitlement to fees or compensation of any kind as may be prohibited by a general law of the state applicable to the city. The acting mayor shall not exercise any power of appointment or removal from office unless the mayor's sickness or absence shall have continued for a period of thirty days. In the event that the mayor and the president of the common council shall be prevented from attending to the duties of the office of mayor, by reason of disability, sickness, or absence from the city, or that the president of the common council informs the common council immediately of an inability to serve as acting mayor, a majority of the then-members of the common council, any other section of this charter notwithstanding, shall designate one of their number to act as mayor. Such person who acts as mayor shall be the acting mayor until the disability, sickness, absence, or vacancy no longer exists. 
(L.L. No. 2-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1957, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1960, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1976, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Succession to certain city offices, General City Law, § 2-a; continuity of political subdivision, Unconsol. L., § 9134-a (McKinney).  
Sec. 46-a. - Procedure in event of an extraordinary emergency. 
If, as a result of an attack, actual or imminent, or series of attacks by an enemy or a foreign nation upon the United States, causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the city of White Plains in any manner by sabotage or by the use of bombs, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological or biological means or other weapons or processes, or if as a result of a natural or peacetime disaster, the office of mayor becomes vacant, or the mayor by reason of disability or absence from the city shall be prevented from attending to the duties of the office of mayor, and the president of the common council is unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office of mayor or be absent from the city, and there shall not be a majority of the members of the common council able, because of disability or absence from the city, to select one of their number to act as mayor, or if for any other reason, they are unable to select one of their number to act as mayor, then the councilman longest in service as such councilman shall act as mayor during such vacancy, disability or absence. Should such councilman longest in service be unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office of mayor, or be absent from the city, the councilman next longest in service shall so act as mayor during such disability or absence, and if he is unable to discharge such powers and duties or be absent from the city, the councilman next longest in service shall so act as mayor during such disability or absence, and such progression shall continue so long as such disability or absence continues and there be councilmen to act as mayor. Such person shall have for such period the same powers and be subject to the same limitations as are hereinbefore specified for the president of the common council acting as mayor. A councilman acting as mayor under the aforesaid circumstances shall not receive the salary of the mayor while so acting nor shall he receive any compensation for so acting other than the salary of the office of councilman. Should two (2) or more councilmen able to so act have the same length of service as such councilman, the one to act as mayor shall be selected by lot. If a vacancy shall occur in any elective office of the city, in the event of such extraordinary emergency, the common council, or if vacancies have reduced its membership to less than a majority then a majority of the remaining members of the common council, shall appoint a person to fill such vacancy until the commencement of the political year next succeeding the first annual election after the happening of the vacancy. If any city officer except the mayor, councilman or supervisor, shall, from sickness, absence, suspension from office by the common council or from any other cause, be unable to discharge the duties of his office, in the event of or during such extraordinary emergency, the common council, or if vacancies have reduced its membership to less than a majority then a majority of the remaining members of the common council, shall appoint some suitable person to discharge such duties during such disability and the person so appointed shall have and exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties and be subject to all the provisions of law applicable to the officer whose place he shall supply, or to the officer or the duties of the office to which he is appointed and shall receive such salary as shall be fixed by the members of the common council making such appointment. 
(L.L. No. 7-1960, § 1) 
State Law reference— Succession to certain city offices, General City Law, § 2-a; continuity of local governments in event of public disaster, General Municipal Law, § 60; continuity of political subdivisions, Unconsol. L., § 9134-a (McKinney).  
Sec. 46-b. - Disability of mayor. 
(a)  In the event that the mayor is temporarily disabled, the provisions relating to the acting mayor shall become operative. 
(b)  The mayor shall be deemed temporarily disabled upon delivery by the mayor to the city clerk of a writing stating that the mayor is unable to perform the duties of the office. 
(c)  A vacancy in the office of mayor shall exist upon the effective date of permanent disability of the mayor. 
(d)  The mayor shall be deemed to be permanently disabled effective: 
(1)  Upon delivery by the mayor to the city clerk of a writing stating that the mayor is unable to resume the duties of office; or 
(2)  Upon the expiration of any consecutive period of ninety days during which, without notification to the city clerk of temporary disability as hereinabove provided, the mayor has been absent from each meeting of the common council; or 
(3)  Upon the expiration of a consecutive period of one hundred twenty days, without notification to the city clerk of temporary disability as hereinabove provided, during any ninety of which the mayor is absent from the mayor's office or fails to perform the duties of office; or 
(4)  Upon the adoption by the common council of a resolution approved by the affirmative votes of at least five members declaring that, for the reasons stated in said resolution relating to the mayor's inability to discharge, or nonperformance of, the duties of office, the mayor is permanently disabled. 
(e)  The effective date of permanent disability shall be stayed if, before the expiration of the ninety days of absence from meetings of the common council or from office, or within ten days after the adoption by the common council of a resolution of permanent disability, the mayor presents to the common council a request for a physical examination by the city medical board of the mayor's ability to resume the duties of office: 
(1)  Immediately after such request the physicians who comprise the city medical board, appointed by the common council pursuant to this charter, shall cause to be made a physical examination of the mayor in connection with the mayor's ability to resume the duties of office. As promptly as possible thereafter the medical board, acting by a majority, shall report to the common council whether the mayor will be able to resume the duties of office within sixty days from the date of the mayor's request for such examination. 
(2)  If the medical board reports that the mayor will not be able to resume the duties of office within such sixty days, the mayor's permanent disability shall become effective as of the date of said report. 
(3)  If the medical board reports that the mayor will be able to resume the duties of office within such sixty days, the effective date of permanent disability shall remain stayed for such sixty days and the mayor shall be continued in office during such period as temporarily disabled. 
(4)  If the mayor fails to resume the duties of office within such sixty days then, notwithstanding the medical board report, the mayor's permanent disability shall become effective upon the expiration of such sixty day period. 
(L.L. No. 3-1976, § 3)  
Sec. 46-c. - Vacancy in the office of mayor. 
If a vacancy shall occur in the office of mayor, the common council shall initiate the proceedings available to it for the purpose of ordering a special election to be held within sixty days of the occurrence of the vacancy, unless such vacancy arises within six months of a general election and prior to September twentieth of any year, in which case the vacancy shall be filled at the general election. If the vacancy is filled either by special election or at the general election, the person elected mayor shall take office upon election and shall serve as mayor for the balance of the unexpired term. 
(L.L. No. 3-1976, § 4)  
Sec. 47. - Duties. 
The mayor shall be responsible for the enforcement of the laws of the state applicable to the city, the provisions of this charter and the ordinances of this city; he shall execute in the name of the city all contracts or other instruments requiring the assent of the city except as otherwise provided by the local finance law; he shall be charged with the general oversight of all departments, boards and commissions of the city; he shall have such other rights and powers as may be provided by ordinance or assigned to him by said council and not in conflict with this charter. He shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by this act or by law or by ordinance of the common council not inconsistent with law. He shall not engage in any other business or occupation conflicting with the performance of the mayor's duties. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, Pt. 3, Title 62, § 1040; Laws 1945, Ch. 839, § 71; L.L. No. 2-1976, § 1) 
State Law reference— Removal or suspension of appointive officer requires approval of mayor, General City Law, § 4; provisions as to city civil defense forces, authority of mayor, General Municipal Law, §§ 209-n, 209-o.  
Sec. 48. - Consultation with heads of departments. 
The mayor shall call together the heads of the city departments for consultation and advice upon the affairs of the city as often as he may deem advisable; and at such meetings he may call upon the heads of the departments for such reports as to the subject-matters under their control and management as he may deem proper, which it shall be their duty to prepare and submit at once to him.  
Sec. 49. - Examination of accounts. 
The mayor shall have authority at all times to examine the books and papers of any officer, employee, court, department or board of the city, and as often as he may deem proper, to appoint one or more competent persons, whose compensation shall be fixed by the common council, to examine, without notice, the accounts of any city officer, department, board, court or employee, and the money, securities and property belonging to the city in the possession or charge of any officer, department, board, court, or employee, and to report to the common council the result of such examination; and he may administer oaths to witnesses and take affidavits in all cases relating to the affairs of the city.  
Sec. 50. - City clerk; additional powers and duties. 
The city clerk shall have an office in the city hall. In addition to the other duties herein prescribed he shall have custody of the corporate seal; carefully index, file and arrange in his office, for convenient use, all books and papers required by law or the common council; see that all matters requiring publication are promptly and correctly published; except as otherwise provided by law or by ordinance, sign all licenses and enter in an appropriate book the name of every person to whom a license shall be granted, the date and particulars thereof, and the sum paid therefor. At the end of each week he shall pay the amount so received to the commissioner of finance, and report to the commissioner of finance the amount so received. Within twenty-four (24) hours after any resolution directing the payment of any money shall take effect, he shall furnish to the commissioner of finance, certified copies of such resolution, with a statement of the proceedings of the common council relating thereto. He shall immediately notify every person appointed to any office, and shall give notice to all members of the common council, of special meetings thereof. He shall serve, or cause to be served, all notices required by the common council, and perform such other duties as it may require. His office is hereby declared a town clerk's office for the purpose of depositing and filing therein all books and papers required by law to be filed in a town clerk's office, and he shall possess all the powers and perform all the duties of a town clerk not inconsistent with this act or the Local Finance Law. Copies of all such papers duly filed in his office and of the records of the proceedings of the common council and of any board of which he is clerk or secretary, certified by him under the corporate seal of the city, shall be evidence in all courts and places the same as the originals. When required to make copies of records he shall be entitled to twenty cents ($0.20) a folio therefor, except from the city. In case of the temporary absence or disability of the clerk, if there be no deputy clerk, the common council may appoint a clerk for the time being, who, on taking the required oath, shall possess the powers and perform the duties of the clerk during the continuance of such absence or disability. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, Pt. 3, Title 62, § 1041; L.L. No. 4-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1960, § 14)

Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; assessment, levy and collection of taxes generally, § 74 et seq.; collection of water charges, § 199; monies, funds, received by the public library to be paid over and delivered to commissioner of finance, § 271; annual reports of departments, § 287; capital projects board, § 238-p et seq..

Sec. 51. - Duties of commissioner of finance; department accounts; drafts. 
The commissioner of finance shall superintend the fiscal concerns of the city and manage the same pursuant to law and ordinances of the common council. He shall receive and have the care and custody of all moneys of the city, and he shall pay them out as hereinafter provided. He shall be receiver of all taxes and assessments assessed or collected in said city, and shall demand, collect and receive all claims and moneys due to the city from any source. All moneys of the city received by the commissioner of finance shall be deposited by him daily in one or more incorporated banks or trust companies to the credit of the city. The interest on such deposits shall belong to the city. The commissioner of finance shall require each bank, trust company or other banking depositary in which the funds of the city are deposited, to provide collateral for such funds in accordance with the investment policy of the city of White Plains. Such collateral shall be subject to the approval of, and shall be deposited in such place and held under such conditions as the commissioner of finance may determine. In lieu of such collateral, the commissioner of finance may, in his discretion, accept a bond, with a bonding or surety company authorized to conduct business in the state of New York, as surety, for the security of such deposit of city funds. He shall keep bank books in which shall be entered his account of deposits in, and moneys drawn from the banks in which such deposits shall be made; no money shall be drawn out of a city depositary except on checks or drafts signed by the commissioner of finance, and such checks or drafts shall always be made payable to the person entitled to receive the money, unless such money be drawn for public use in the office of the commissioner of finance, in which case the checks, so signed, shall be payable to the order of the commissioner of finance. The commissioner of finance shall keep a separate account with every department for which funds are specially raised by tax, or for which funds are raised by assessment for local or other improvements, and in every check or draft drawn by him he must state particularly against which of such funds the check or draft is drawn (unless money is drawn for use in the office); he shall at no time permit any fund to be overdrawn, or draw upon one fund to pay a claim chargeable to another; and no money shall be paid out by him unless upon a bill, claim, draft or warrant audited or drawn by the proper officer, board or department, except for principal and interest upon the bonds or notes of the city. 
The commissioner of finance shall establish and maintain a system of accounts which is in conformity with generally accepted municipal accounting principals, and such system of accounts shall be used in each office, department, board, commission and other expending agency, after approval thereof by the common council. He shall perform such other and further duties pertaining to his office, not inconsistent with the provisions of this act or of law, as may from time to time be prescribed by ordinance of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 1-1932, § 1; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, Pt. 3, Title 62, § 1042; L.L. No. 8-1961, § 2; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 7) 
Cross reference— Payment of taxes to commissioner of finance, § 85; sale of tax liens to be conducted by commissioner of finance, § 91. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to levy and collect taxes, General City Law, § 20(4); to spend money for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(5); to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 52. - Form, approval and presentation of claims. 
The commissioner of finance shall prescribe the form of all claims to be presented against the city, and the form and substance of any certification, or verification procedure to accompany the claim. Whenever any person intends to present for payment a claim against the city, he shall prepare and certify or verify it, in accordance with the prescribed procedure, if any and the same shall then be presented to the commissioner of finance, for his examination and audit. 
(Laws 1953, Ch. 878, § 316; L.L. No. 3-1960, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 8)  
Sec. 53. - Notice of claims; audit. 
The commissioner of finance shall, twice in every month, cause all claims which have been presented to him for audit, to be tabulated and numbered consecutively, and the number, date of presentation, name of claimant and brief statement of the character of each claim shall be entered in a book kept for such purpose, which shall at all times during office hours, be so placed as to be convenient for public inspection and examination. The commissioner of finance shall audit such claims, and shall cause a report thereof, listing the claims as to those approved and those rejected or disallowed, in whole or in part, with any reason for such action which he may have to give, to be sent to the common council, and if he has rejected or disallowed any claim or part of any claim he shall cause notice of such rejection or disallowance to be sent to the claimant. 
(L.L. No. 1-1962, § 1) 
Code reference— Corporation counsel to keep records of notices of claims, § 2-1-5. 
State Law reference— Filing of claims against city, General Municipal Law, § 50-e.  
Sec. 54. - Appeal from audit of claim. 
If the claimant be dissatisfied with the audit, or if the commissioner of finance refuses or neglects to audit, the claimant may appeal to the common council, by serving notice of appeal, in writing, upon the commissioner of finance and the common council at any time before the second stated meeting of the common council that is held after he received notice of the audit of the commissioner of finance, except in the case where the commissioner of finance has neglected or refused to audit such claim an appeal may be taken at any time. The common council shall make rules for the procedure upon the hearing of such appeals, and the decision and audit of the common council, after hearing upon the appeal by it, shall be final and conclusive as to the amount of the claim; but if there be no appeal from the original audit, it shall in like manner be final and conclusive. The commissioner of finance, and the common council, upon an appeal to it as herein provided, shall have authority to take evidence and examine witnesses in reference to the claim, and for that purpose may issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses. 
(L.L. No. 1-1962, § 2)  
Sec. 55. - Allowed claims to be filed. 
When a claim has been finally allowed, it, with the certificate of the commissioner of finance, or, in case of appeal, with the certificate of the common council indorsed thereon, shall be filed in the office of the commissioner of finance and remain a public record in his office, and the commissioner of finance shall pay such claim. 
(L.L. No. 1-1962, § 3)  
Sec. 56. - Custody of sinking funds. 
The commissioner of finance shall have, under the direction of the ordinances of the common council, the custody and management of any sinking fund. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, Pt. 3, Title 62, § 1043) 
State Law reference— Authority to establish, maintain sinking fund, General City Law, § 20(6).  
Sec. 57. - Name of claimant; complaints against claims. 
(1)  All claims against the city shall be in the names of the claimants. No member of a board, or any officer of the city shall knowingly approve or pay any claim presented in a name other than that of the claimant. 
(2)  The commissioner of finance, upon receipt of a complaint under oath and in writing, signed by any citizen, stating that he has reason to believe that any illegal claim has been presented, shall withhold payment of the claim until satisfied of its legality. If he shall be satisfied of its legality, he shall approve the same, and give notice to the claimant and the citizen who made the complaint, and after fifteen (15) days after giving such notice, he shall pay such claim, unless such citizen shall have appealed to the common council in the manner hereinafter set forth. If the commissioner of finance shall not be satisfied of the legality of such claim, he shall disallow the claim, in whole or in part, or reject the claim. He shall give notice of his action thereon to the claimant and the citizen who made the complaint, and after fifteen (15) days after giving such notice, he shall pay the part of the claim which he allowed, if any, unless either the claimant or the citizen who made the complaint shall have appealed to the common council, in the manner hereinafter set forth. 
(3)  The appeals provided for in this section shall be taken within the time provided in paragraph two above, by serving notice of appeal in writing, upon the commissioner of finance and the common council. The common council may make rules for the procedure upon the hearing of such appeals, and the decision and audit of the common council, after hearing upon the appeal by it, shall be final and conclusive as to the amount of the claims. The commissioner of finance, and the common council, upon an appeal to it as herein provided, shall have authority to take evidence and examine witnesses in reference to the claim, and for that purpose may issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses. 
(4)  When a claim has been finally allowed, pursuant to this section, it, with the certificate of the commissioner of finance, or, in case of appeal, with the certificate of the common council indorsed thereon, shall be filed in the office of the commissioner of finance and remain a public record in his office, and the commissioner of finance shall pay such claim. 
(5)  A violation of any of the provisions of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(L.L. No. 1-1962, § 4) 
State Law reference— Punishment for violations, Penal Law, § 55.10.  
Sec. 58. - Annual financial statement of commissioner of finance. 
The commissioner of finance shall, as soon as practicable after the thirtieth day of June in each year, but in no event later than the stated meeting of the Common Council in December in the same year, publish in book or pamphlet form, verified by his or her oath or affirmation, and audited by a certified public accountant, a full and accurate report of the financial position of the city as of the thirtieth day of June in such year, and the result of operations of all of the several funds of the city for the fiscal year then ended; such publication to include, but not be limited to, the amount of receipts and expenditures for each fund, the sources from which the funds have been derived and for what purpose expended, and a listing of the several debts of the city, when the same are payable and the rate of interest on each. The commissioner of finance shall file a copy of every such report in the office of the state comptroller. 
(Laws 1916, Ch. 167, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1951, § 2; L.L. No. 8-1961, § 3; L.L. No. 2-2004, § 1) 
Cross reference— Annual report of departments, § 287.  
Sec. 59. - Commissioner of finance as custodian of certain city property; transfer to successor. 
The commissioner of finance shall keep maps, deeds, leases and all other evidence of title and debt, and other valuable papers belonging to the city. He shall pay or transfer to his successor all moneys belonging to the city in any bank or in his hands or control, and shall also deliver all books, vouchers, papers and property belonging to the city or appertaining to the affairs of the city held by him as commissioner of finance.  
Secs. 60, 61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977, sec. 1, renumbered former secs. 60 and 61 as secs. 68 and 69, respectively. L.L. No. 1-1980, sec. 1, repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus reinstating the former numbering sequence. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 1, renumbered former secs. 60 and 61 as secs. 68 and 69 respectively. Secs. 60 and 61 have been reserved by the editors to maintain numerical sequence.  
Sec. 62. - State, county and special district taxes. 
When there has been received by the city from the county of Westchester a certificate of apportionment of state, county and special district taxes, together with a certified copy of the act of the county board of legislators as to such apportionment, the amount so certified shall be assessed on all real estate in the city (except property exempt by law) and shall be extended on the assessment roll by the commissioner of finance of the city of White Plains. Such assessment of taxes shall be extended on the assessment roll of the city which becomes final on March first immediately following the date of the certificate of apportionment referred to herein. The assessment roll so extended shall become the tax roll for the state, county and special district taxes which shall become due and payable on the first day of April immediately thereafter. The same fees and penalties shall apply to the collection thereof and the lien thereof may be sold the same as the lien of city taxes. Taxes so collected shall be paid by the city to the county in accordance with the real property tax law. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 2; L.L. No. 8-1961, § 10; L.L. No. 3-1967, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1980, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 9) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977, sec. 4, renumbered former § 73 as § 62. L.L. No. 1-1980, sec. 1, repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus reinstating the former numbering sequence. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 4 renumbered former sec. 73 as sec. 62. See also Westchester County Administrative Code, Article 9, Title C, Sewers. 
State Law reference— Payment of taxes to county by cities in Westchester County, Real Property Tax Law, § 1512; levy and collection of taxes generally, Real Property Tax Law, Art. 9.  
Sec. 63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Former § 63 is now § 73.  
Sec. 64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 64 as sec. 70. L.L. No. 1-1980, sec. 1, repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus reinstating the former numbering sequence. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 64 as sec. 70. The editors have reserved sec. 64 to maintain numerical sequence.  
Sec. 65. - Investment of capital funds. 
Unexpended balances in any funds of the city of White Plains for capital improvements financed other than by the issue of obligations may be invested in accordance with the investment policy of the city of White Plains. Such investment shall be made by the common council or by the mayor and the commissioner of finance if the common council shall delegate such duty to them. Such obligations shall be registered or inscribed in the name of the city of White Plains. Only such obligations shall be so purchased as shall be payable or redeemable at the option of the city of White Plains within such time as the proceeds shall be needed to meet expenditures for the object or purpose of the fund in which such moneys are contained, but such obligations, in any event, shall be payable or redeemable at the option of the city of White Plains within two (2) years of the date of purchase. Any interest earned or capital gain realized on the moneys so invested shall accrue to and become part of each such fund. The separate identity of each such fund shall be maintained at all times whether its assets consist of cash or investments or both. The commissioner of finance shall require each bank, trust company or other banking depositary in which the funds of the city are deposited, to provide collateral for such funds in accordance with the investment policy of the city of White Plains. 
(L.L. No. 3-1939, § 5; L.L. No. 11-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1961, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 10) 
State Law reference— Capital reserve funds generally, General Municipal Law, § 6-c; investment of moneys in reserve funds, General Municipal Law, § 6-f; temporary investments, General Municipal Law, § 11.  
Sec. 66. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 66 was repealed by L.L. No. 3-1936, sec. 6. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain numerical sequence.  
Sec. 67. - Bonds not to be issued for certain purposes. 
No bonds shall be issued for current operating expenses, repairs or supplies, or for the city's share of the cost of curbs, gutters or sidewalks. 
(Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 2; Laws 1935, Ch. 146, § 1; Laws 1945, Ch. 839, § 72) 
Code reference— Budget notes, § 2-4-3.  
ARTICLE V-A. - DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET[7]

--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Official and fiscal year of city defined, § 5; payment of judgments against city from tax budget, § 278. 
Code reference— Annual budget, § 2-14-16 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority to levy and collect taxes for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(4); to spend money for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(5); annual budget defined, Local Finance Law, § 2.00(10). 
 
Sec. 68. - Budget. 
(1)  Description. The budget for the city of White Plains shall present a complete financial plan for the ensuing fiscal year. It shall set forth all proposed expenditures and all anticipated revenues according to the terms and conditions herein set forth. 
The terms used to designate different fiscal years mentioned hereinafter in paragraphs two to eight inclusive are defined as follows: 
(a)  The term "budget year" shall be used to describe the fiscal year for which the budget is being prepared. 
(b)  The term "current year" shall be used to describe the fiscal year during which the budget is being prepared. 
(c)  The term "preceding year" shall be used to describe the fiscal year immediately preceding that during which the budget is being prepared. 
(2)  Preparation of the Budget. Not later than February fifteenth in the current year, all heads of departments, officers and other spending agencies of the city shall prepare and submit to the budget director estimates of the expenditure requirements and their estimated revenues for the budget year, compared with the corresponding actual figures of the preceding year and the actual figures for the expired portion and their estimates of figures for the unexpired portion of the current year. Revenue and expenditure estimates shall be classified in a manner and in such detail as may be prescribed by the budget director. 
The budget director shall review the estimates, altering, revising, increasing or decreasing the items of said estimates as he shall deem necessary in view of the needs of the various spending agencies and the probable total available revenue of the city. The budget director may call upon the city officers, heads of departments and other spending agencies of the city for information and details of the estimates submitted by them and it shall be the duty of such officers, heads of departments and other spending agencies to furnish such information and details to the budget director. The budget director shall then prepare a proposed budget in the form required by law and he shall transmit this proposed budget in writing to the common council at the stated meeting of the common council in April of the current year. Copies of the proposed budget shall be available to the public immediately following such transmission to the common council. 
(3)  Budget Document. The budget document, setting forth the financial plan of the city for the budget year, shall embrace three (3) parts as follows: 
PART I 
A budget message prepared by the budget director shall outline the financial plan of the city for the budget year, to wit: the important features of the proposed budget, a general summary of the budget setting forth the aggregate figures in such manner as to show the balanced relations between the total proposed expenditures and the total anticipated revenues and other means of financing the budget for the budget year, contrasted with the budget figures for the current year, the actual figures for the expired portion of the current year and the actual figures for the preceding year. 
PART II 
The general budget summary shall be supported by explanatory schedules or statements, classifying the expenditures contained therein by organization units, objects and funds and the revenue by organization units, sources and funds. 
PART III 
There shall also be included a statement of the indebtedness of the city showing the debt redemption requirements, the debt authorized and unissued, the condition of any sinking funds and the borrowing capacity. In addition, there shall be included any statements relative to the financial plan which the budget director may deem pertinent. 
(4)  Budget Hearing. Final action shall not be taken on the proposed budget until a public hearing has been held thereon after notice of such hearing has been published in the official newspaper for three (3) days, the first publication of which shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing. It shall be the duty of the common council to arrange for and hold such a hearing. 
(5)  Adoption of the Budget. 
(A)  The common council shall consider the proposed budget as submitted to it. Such body may revise, alter, increase or decrease the items of proposed expenditures and may decrease the estimated amounts of revenues contained in the proposed budget. The common council may call upon the city officers, heads of departments and other spending agencies of the city for information and details of the estimates submitted by them and it shall be the duty of such officers, heads of departments and other spending agencies to furnish such information and details to the common council. 
(B)  On or before the thirtieth day of May in the current year, the common council shall adopt a budget for the budget year which shall include the following: 
(a)  The full amount required for interest on the indebtedness of the city and for sinking funds and for principal of bonds, bond anticipation notes and capital notes maturing during the budget year; 
(b)  The detailed amounts required during the budget year for the expense of conducting or operating each department, division, office or board and the subdivision of each; 
(c)  The amount of any estimated deficit at the close of the current year, and the plan for funding that deficit; 
(d)  The itemized amounts of revenues, which it is estimated by the budget director, will be recognized during the budget year, such estimates being made in the manner consistent with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(C)  In computing revenues estimated to be available during any budget year for the purposes of an annual budget, the following conditions shall be observed: 
(a)  With the exception of additional revenues resulting from increases of fees or intergovernmental assistance, or the additional revenue to be derived from sources other than those which furnish revenues in the current year, miscellaneous revenues from sources other than the property tax levy shall in no instance nor as to any item be estimated at an amount in excess of the amount of such miscellaneous revenues estimated to be recognized in the current year; 
(b)  An amount not to exceed the undesignated fund balance as of the close of the preceding fiscal year may be appropriated for use in the budget year. 
(D)  The common council shall annually cause to be levied and raised by general tax on all the taxable property in the city, according to the valuation upon the assessment roll for the budget year, such an amount as may be required to produce sufficient cash receipts necessary to balance the budget basing such levy upon the percentage of taxes estimated to be collected during the current year on account of the levy for the current year as hereinafter described. In computing the tax levy for the purposes of such annual budget the following conditions shall be observed: 
(a)  The sum necessary to balance such budget shall be ascertained by deducting from the total appropriations made under items (a), (b), (c) of subdivision (B) of this paragraph (numbered five) the total amount of receipts estimated under the limitations prescribed under subdivision (C) of this paragraph (numbered five); 
(b)  The tax levy for the budget year shall then be determined by dividing the sum necessary to be raised in order to balance the budget by a fraction the denominator of which shall be one hundred and the numerator of which shall be an amount not exceeding the percentage estimated to be collected in the current year on account of the levy for the current year; 
(c)  The several amounts specified in the ordinance adopting the budget as finally enacted shall be and become appropriated in the amounts and for the several departments, offices, boards and other spending agencies for the budget year. The revenue estimated in the budget and as provided for by the said ordinance shall be and become applicable in the amounts and according to the funds specified in the budget for the purpose of meeting the expenditures authorized by the said ordinance; 
(d)  Within thirty days after final action has been taken on the budget by the common council, it shall make public, by publication or otherwise, a summary statement which shall be in the form of the general budget summary provided for in paragraph numbered two in this section. The common council shall also make public, by publication or otherwise, at this time, the tax levy and rate necessary or estimated to be necessary to finance the budget as adopted. 
(6)  Allotments. Immediately before the beginning of the budget year, the budget director shall require the head of each spending agency to submit a work program for that year, which program shall include all appropriations for such spending agency and the required allotments of said appropriations by quarters for the entire year. The budget director shall have authority to revise, alter or change such allotments as he deems necessary. However, the aggregate of such allotments shall not exceed the total appropriations available to said spending agency, except as otherwise provided in section seventy of this act. The budget director shall transmit a copy of the approved allotments to the head of the spending agency concerned. The budget director shall authorize expenditures to be made from the appropriation on the basis of such allotments, and not otherwise except as otherwise provided in section seventy of this act. 
The head of any spending agency of the government may submit a revised allotment program to the budget director at the beginning of any quarter during the fiscal year, with his request for a revision of the allotments for the remaining quarters of the fiscal year not to exceed the unexpended appropriation balance. The budget director may grant such revision by notifying the head of the spending agency. 
In order to provide funds for possible emergencies arising during the budget year in the various spending agencies, the budget director may at any time set aside up to twenty per centum of the total remaining amount appropriated as a reserve, or any portion of it, may be returned to the appropriation to which it belongs and be added to any one or more of the allotments, provided the budget director shall deem such action necessary. Any unused portion thereof shall remain at the end of the budget year as an unexpended balance of appropriation. 
(7)  Additional Appropriations. The council may, during a fiscal year, make additional appropriations or increase existing appropriations to meet emergencies such as epidemics, floods, fires or other catastrophes, the funds therefor, to be provided from unappropriated revenues or unappropriated surplus, if any, or from the proceeds of budget notes issued pursuant to the local finance law. 
(8)  Transfers. Each department, division, officer and board of the city and the subdivisions of each shall limit its or his expenditures for the various purposes set forth in the budget unless the common council shall prior to the indebtedness being incurred expressly authorize a transfer from one major object of expenditure to another major object of expenditure. The budget director upon the request of the appropriate department head, board or commission may transfer funds not exceeding five thousand dollars from one major object of expenditure to another major object of expenditure without the authorization of the common council. 
(Laws 1916, Ch. 167, § 2; L.L. No. 3-1939, § 1; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, §§ 1044, 1045; L.L. No. 3-1945, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 2-1949, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1951, §§ 3, 4; L.L. No. 3-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1953, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 8-1961, §§ 4, 5, 6, 7; L.L. No. 3-1967, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 5-1968, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1977, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 1-1980, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1982, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 3-1982, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, §§ 1, 2; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 11) 
Editor's note— Subdivision 2 amended by L.L. No. 3-1951 and L.L. No. 4-1953; subdivision 4 by L.L. No. 4-1953; subdivision 5 by L.L. No. 3-1945, L.L. No. 3-1951 and L.L. No. 3-1952; subdivision 7 by Laws 1943, Ch. 710; subdivision 9 as added by L.L. No. 2-1949, L.L. No. 5-1968. Section 1 of L.L. No. 1-1977 renumbered former sec. 60 as sec. 68; sec. 2 of said local law amended the section in its entirety. Section 1 of L.L. No. 1-1980 repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus renumbering this section sec. 60; L.L. No. 7-1982, renumbered former sec. 60 as sec. 68; sec. 2 of said local law amended the section in its entirety.  
Sec. 69. - Appropriation for hospital purposes; pavements; sewers, sidewalks and curbs; park purposes; celebrations. 
The common council may include in the tax budget such sums as they shall deem necessary and proper for the following purposes in addition to the purposes herein otherwise provided for: For the purpose of a city hospital; for the purpose of the city library; to defray the city's portion of the construction of pavements; to defray the city's portion of the construction of sewers; to defray the city's portion of the construction of sidewalks and curbs; for the maintenance of parks; for the decoration of public buildings and incidental expenses upon the occasion of any public celebration in which the officers of the city shall participate. 
(L.L. No. 1-1934, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1935, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1939, § 3; L.L. No. 3-1951, § 5; L.L. No. 8-1961, § 8; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1982, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977 renumbered former sec. 61 as sec. 69. L.L. No. 1-1982, sec. 1 repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus restoring the original numbering. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 61 as sec. 69. 
State Law reference— Authority to spend money for any public or municipal purpose, General City Law, § 20(5).  
Sec. 70. - Expenditures, debts or contracts in excess of appropriation. 
The several officers, boards and departments of the city shall not incur any debts, expenses or liabilities, either in excess or independent of the several sums respectively allotted to them. It shall not be lawful for the city, or an officer, board or department thereof, to expend or contract to be expended, or to incur any liability in the current fiscal year for a greater sum than is so estimated for such officer, board or department, and so provided for by the common council in the final estimate and tax levy of such year as aforesaid. It shall not be lawful for any officer, board or department of the city to make or enter into any contract for work, labor or service, or the hiring of employees, or for the purchase of any supplies, materials or apparatus, or the making of improvements or repairs, which, by the terms of such contract, involves an expenditure of money or liability therefor, which, after taking into account the expenditure and liabilities already made or incurred, shall be in excess of the amount which has been estimated and allowed to such officer, board or department, in the final estimate adopted by the common council for the current fiscal year in which such contract shall be made. Any contract, oral or written, made in violation of this section, shall be null and void as to the city, and no money belonging to the city shall be paid thereon, but this section shall not prevent the making of contracts for light for periods exceeding one year, provided no such contracts shall be made for a longer period than three (3) years, nor the making of contracts for water supply for periods exceeding one year, providing no such contracts shall be made for a longer period than ten (10) years, nor the making of contracts for public improvements where the whole or any portion of the expense thereof is met by assessments, nor the making of contracts for insurance, fidelity bonds, servicing and professional services, for periods exceeding one year, provided no such contracts shall be made for a period longer than five (5) years. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the expenditure of such sums as may be necessary for unforeseeable public emergencies for which the issuance of budget notes is permissible pursuant to the local finance law. Any officer, or any member of any board or department of the city, making or voting for any contract prohibited by this section, or allowing any accounts or claims thereunder, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, or by both, in the discretion of the court before which such conviction shall be had. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 2; Laws 1923, Ch. 570, § 2; L.L. No. 1-1925, § 2; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1047; L.L. No. 1-1962, § 5; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1982, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 64 as sec. 70. L.L. No. 1-1982, sec. 1 repealed L.L. No. 1, 1977, thus restoring the original numbering. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 64 as sec. 70. 
State Law reference— Budget notes for unforeseeable public emergencies, Local Finance Law, § 29.00.  
Sec. 71. - Additional management control; duties of budget director. 
In addition to and in furtherance of the duties of the budget director with respect to the preparation of the city budget and the management of expenditures thereunder, the following duties and functions of said director are prescribed: 
(1)  Analyze the true condition of the city by balancing its management resources and physical and financial assets, against its statutory obligations and delivery of service commitments, and make recommendations for improved management of the city's operations. 
(2)  Prepare management control systems, including requirements for reports from any entity receiving funds from or through the city government so as to enable the mayor and common council to monitor compliance with legislative actions, and to assist the mayor in carrying out the mayor's duties. 
(3)  Prepare management studies of departmental organizations, functions, procedures, productivity and cost control as will tend to furnish information for the improvement of city operations or in effecting economy in operations. 
(L.L. No. 1-1977, § 3; L.L. No. 1-1980, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1982, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 3) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1980 repealed L.L. No. 1-1977; L.L. No. 2-1982 enacted a new section 71.  
Sec. 72. - Sinking funds. 
The common council may create a sinking fund or sinking funds to provide for the redemption of any bonded indebtedness heretofore existing or hereafter created, and if the amounts thus derived shall not be sufficient to provide for the sinking fund for that purpose may raise annually by taxation a sum which will produce at their maturity an amount equal to the sum of the principal of the bonds to retire which the sinking fund is created. 
A sinking fund created for the purpose of amoritizing an indebtedness covered on account of a waterworks system, light plant, or other property or means of accommodation through which a profit is realized by the city, may be maintained out of the surplus earnings of such system, plant or property, and if the revenues thus derived shall not be sufficient to provide for the sinking fund requirement said common council may provide for such deficiency and pay the same in the same manner as it may provide for the payment of the principal and interest on other bonded indebtedness of said city. 
The city of White Plains, in addition to the power which it possesses to raise money for all purposes by taxation, shall have power to raise by a general tax annually, upon the real and personal property assessed for taxation in said city, such sum as may be necessary to provide for the payment to meet such sinking fund requirements, as may have been authorized by the common council. All taxes collected and funds set apart for sinking fund requirements shall be kept in a separate fund and may be invested in such securities as the commissioner of finance and the common council may agree. The amount raised by taxation in any year, to be used for sinking fund payments, shall not exceed one-fourth of one per centum (¼ of 1%) of the total assessed valuation of said city. Sinking funds may be invested in bonds or other obligations of the city evidencing such debt. 
Cross reference— Custody and management of sinking fund, § 56. 
State Law reference— Authority to create, maintain sinking fund, General City Law, § 20(6).  
Sec. 73. - Transfers of capital funds. 
The common council may authorize the transfer to the credit of another capital fund of all or part of: 
(a)  The unexpended balance remaining in a fund established for a specific capital improvement or a specific item or specific items of equipment, which improvement has been completed or acquired, or which equipment has been acquired, after deducting from such balance a sum sufficient to satisfy all outstanding claims arising from the construction, reconstruction or acquisition of such capital improvement or the acquisition of such equipment. 
(b)  The unexpended balance remaining in a fund established for a specific item or specific items of equipment which have not been acquired or a specific capital improvement which has not been completed or acquired, or remaining in a fund established for a type of capital improvement or a type of equipment. 
(c)  No transfer shall be made to a capital fund established for a purpose other than that of the capital fund from which a transfer is proposed to be made unless prior thereto the proposed transfer shall be referred to the capital projects board for its recommendation and, if the amount proposed to be transferred exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), a public hearing shall be had on such proposed transfer, of which hearing public notice shall be given. 
(d)  The budget director upon the request of the appropriate department head, board or commission may transfer funds not exceeding seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) to a capital fund from another capital fund, without reference to the capital projects board, providing the conditions of either subdivision (a) or subdivision (b) of this section are complied with. 
(L.L. No. 2-1949, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1949, § 1; L.L. No. 9-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1956, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1968, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1982, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 12) 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32; capital projects board, § 238-p et seq. 
Code reference— Annual budget, § 2-4-16. 
State Law reference— Capital improvement defined, General Municipal Law, §§ 6-c(1b), 6-g(1); planning for future capital improvements, capital program, General Municipal Law, §§ 99-d, 99-g. 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1977, sec. 1, renumbered former sec. 73 as sec. 62. L.L. No. 1-1982, sec. 1 repealed L.L. No. 1-1977, thus restoring the original numbering. L.L. No. 7-1982, sec. 7, renumbered former sec. 73 as sec. 62. L.L. No. 1-1990, sec. 12, renumbered former sec. 63 as sec. 73.
