Whenever any lands are sold or conveyed within the city of White Plains and described in the deed or conveyance thereof as abutting upon or bounded by any street, park or square, which is owned wholly or partly by the grantor in such deed or conveyance, and such street shall not be one of the public streets of said city, as defined in the preceding section but one, or such park or square shall not be one of the public parks or squares of said city, the fact of such sale or conveyance of lands so described shall be deemed a dedication to the public use by the grantor of the street, park or square, as so described, in the description of the land so sold or conveyed or in any map, plan or survey referred to in such description, and filed in the office of the clerk of the county of Westchester, division of land records. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 3)  
Sec. 123. - Acceptance of dedication. 
Whenever any street, park or square shall have been dedicated to the public use, the common council may, by ordinance, adopted by the affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of all its members, taken by ayes and nays and recorded in its minutes, accept such dedications. Thereupon the street so dedicated and accepted shall be a public street within said city, and the park or square so dedicated and accepted shall be one of the public parks or squares of said city.  
Sec. 124. - Survey and description of streets dedicated. 
Whenever any street, park or square shall have been accepted, as in the preceding section [§ 123] provided, the common council shall cause a survey, map and description thereof to be made by the commissioner of public works and by him reported to the common council, stating the course, distance, width and boundaries of the street, park or square so accepted. Such survey shall be entered at length in the minutes of the common council, and a copy thereof duly certified by the city clerk shall be presumptive evidence in any proceeding, of the location of said street, park or square.  
Sec. 125. - Record of streets, parks and squares. 
The common council may, by ordinance, cause such streets, public parks or squares in said city as shall have been used for twenty (20) years, and are not sufficiently described, or have not been duly recorded, to be ascertained, described and entered of record in its minutes, and the record thereof, and of such as shall hereafter be laid out, or of such as have been dedicated and accepted by the common council, or a copy thereof, certified by the city clerk, shall be evidence of the existence and location of such streets, parks and squares, as therein described.  
Sec. 126. - Power of common council as to street improvements. 
Under the restrictions and limitations hereinafter prescribed the common council may, by ordinance, provide for: 
(1)  The laying out, opening, constructing and making of streets, public grounds, squares, parks, drains, culverts, arches and bridges in said city. 
(2)  Widening, narrowing, altering or discontinuing of any street, public ground, square or park or any part thereof in said city. 
But no street, or any part thereof, shall be discontinued, except upon the written petition, duly signed, and acknowledged, of all persons owning the lands fronting upon the street, or upon the part thereof so discontinued or on motion of the common council. The discontinuance of any street shall be subject to the applicable provisions of section one hundred fifty-two of this charter and no street, or any part thereof, shall be discontinued by the common council except upon compliance with said section one hundred fifty-two. 
(Laws 1927, Ch. 653, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 4) 
Cross reference— Corporate powers defined, § 4; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32. 
State Law reference— Authority to lay out, establish, maintain, vacate, etc., streets, General City Law, § 20(7).  
Sec. 127. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 127 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 5. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 128. - Procedure for land acquisition. 
Whenever the common council shall consider it proper and expedient to acquire land, including buildings, if any, to lay out, open, widen, alter or construct any street, public ground, square, park, culvert, arch or bridge, it shall proceed as follows: the common council shall cause the commissioner of public works to make a map and survey, showing the location of such proposed improvement, and the particular lots or parcels of land, if any, required therefor, and the names of the owners or occupants thereof, so far as the same can be ascertained, and report to the common council his opinion as to the propriety of the proposed improvement, with an estimate, in items, of the probable cost and expense of such acquisition, including the amount of damages which, in his judgment, will be sustained in consequence thereof, by the owners and occupants of lands and buildings, if any, required to be taken for such improvement. Such report shall also designate the district of assessment, including that portion of the city which, in his judgment, will be benefited by such improvement, and should be assessed for the cost and expense thereof. Such survey and map shall be presented with such report. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 6) 
State Law reference— Authority to acquire property for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(2); Statute of Local Governments, § 10(2).  
Sec. 129. - Notice of proposed improvement; hearing and action thereon by common council. 
The common council, upon the presentation of such report, [provided for in section 128] unless it shall determine not to proceed with such proposed improvement, shall direct the city clerk to give notice by publication thereof, for at least four (4) successive days in the official newspaper of the time and place at which the common council will consider the matter of such proposed improvement, which time shall be not less than ten (10) days from the first publication of such notice. At the time and place mentioned in such notice, the common council shall meet, and then, or at such other time as a majority of its members then present may appoint, shall hear all persons desiring to be heard upon the matter of said proposed improvement and with reference to the district of assessment, and shall take such action as it shall deem proper. No such improvement shall be ordered except by an ordinance, adopted by the affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of all the members of the common council. The ordinance directing such improvement shall require and direct that the cost and expense thereof shall be defrayed by local assessment, unless said ordinance requires and directs that all or a portion of such cost and expense shall be charged to the city at large, and the remainder thereof defrayed by local assessment, and shall designate that portion if any of the city which shall be assessed therefor. The ordinance shall also contain a description of the lots or parcels of land, if any, required for such improvement. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 7)  
Sec. 130. - Acquisition of land by contract. 
After the adoption of such ordinance [§§ 128, 129] the commissioner of public works may contract with the owner or owners of any of the lands required for said improvement for the sale thereof, to said city, at a price to be stated in said contract, which price shall be approved by the common council, and shall be payable at such time or times as shall be determined by the common council, provided that the lands conveyed by the deeds shall be in fee and shall be free and clear of all liens and encumbrances, except as may be otherwise determined by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 3-1963, § 1) 
State Law reference— Authority to acquire property for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(2); Statute of Local Governments, § 10(2).  
Sec. 131. - Acquisition of land by legal proceedings. 
Whenever any lands are required for such improvement, for the purchase of which no contract shall be made, as provided for in the last preceding section, [§ 130] the city of White Plains shall have the right to acquire fee title to the same by condemnation. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 8) 
Cross reference— Manner of acquisition of lands when not otherwise provided, § 203; condemnation, § 207. 
State Law reference— Authority to acquire property for municipal purposes by condemnation, General City Law, § 20(2), General Municipal Law, § 74; Condemnation proceedings, Eminent Domain Procedure Law, § 1 et seq.  
Sec. 132. - Report to be filed. 
Whenever any report of commissioners appointed in any condemnation proceedings shall be confirmed in whole or in part, the corporation counsel shall cause a copy thereof, and of the order confirming the same, each duly certified by the clerk of the court, to be filed in the office of the commissioner of finance and a duplicate thereof in the office of the city clerk. Thereupon the said report, or so much thereof as has been confirmed, and the confirmation thereof, shall be final and conclusive, unless an appeal be taken therefrom within the time and in the manner provided by law.  
Sec. 133. - Statement of cost; apportionment and assessment. 
Whenever an ordinance directing such improvement shall have been adopted, and the necessary land including buildings, if any, has been acquired, the commissioner of public works shall file with the common council an itemized statement of the actual and complete cost thereof which shall include the amount of compensation to be paid for such land including buildings, if any, and including the amount of damages which have been sustained in consequence of said land acquisition, by the owners and occupants of such land and buildings, if any, all costs incurred by the city for surveyors', printers', commissioners' and witnesses' fees, and the costs and disbursements of the corporation counsel for and on account of such land acquisition, and all other expenses incidental thereto. Such statement shall thereupon be entered in full in the minutes of the common council, and the common council shall thereupon consider the said statement presented by the commissioner of public works and shall by ordinance direct the city assessor to apportion and assess said actual and complete cost, or such portion as has been determined by the common council, pursuant to section one hundred twenty-nine of this charter, upon the several lots or parcels of land within the district of assessment designated in such ordinance in proportion to the benefits derived by such lots or parcels respectively from the making of such improvement. Said actual and complete cost, or such portion thereof as has been determined by the common council, shall be borne by the owners or occupants of the lots or parcels of land benefited thereby and shall be apportioned, assessed and collected according to the provisions herein contained and shall be a lien upon such property from and after the time of the confirmation of the apportionment and assessment thereof. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 9) 
Cross reference— Right to review assessment for local improvement limited, § 77; procedure on review, § 78; consolidation of separate proceedings, § 79; collection of local assessments, § 115; collection of local assessment by suit, § 116. 
State Law reference— Authority to assess for improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 134. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 134 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 10. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 135. - Duties of assessor; report. 
The assessor shall thereupon give five (5) days' notice, in the official newspaper, of the time and place at which he will attend to enter upon his duties, at the time and place so appointed, or at any other time within thirty (30) days to which he may adjourn, he shall view the location of the land which has been acquired, and the lands upon which said land acquisition cost is to be apportioned and assessed, and apportion and assess the amount so fixed and determined as aforesaid, upon the several lots or parcels of land within the district of assessment in proportion, as near as may be, to the benefit which each of said lots or parcels of land shall be deemed by him to acquire thereby, and make a written report hereof to the common council. Such report shall contain his apportionments and assessments and a designation or description of the several lots or parcels of land assessed and the names, if known, of the owners thereof, or if such owners be unknown, that fact shall be so stated; and the amount by him assessed upon each of such lots or parcels. Such lots or parcels may be designated by their numbers upon any city map adopted by the common council, or by any other definite description thereof. Such report shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 11)  
Sec. 136. - Notice of filing report; objections; confirmation; reapportionment. 
The common council shall give notice, to be published in the official newspaper, that such report is filed with the city clerk, and that at a time to be specified therein, which shall not be less than ten (10) days from the first publication thereof, it will proceed to a consideration of such report. Prior to said day any person may file with the city clerk written objections to such report, or any part thereof, which objections shall be read before the common council before any action shall be taken on such report. At the time so appointed, or at such other time, to which it may adjourn, for that purpose, the common council may hear the allegations of any person interested, who shall have filed such objections, and may take proof in relation thereto. Such allegations and proofs shall be confined to the matters stated in such written objections. The common council may thereupon confirm such report, without alterations, or with such alterations therein as they may deem proper. The confirmation of such report by the common council shall be final and conclusive unless an appeal be taken therefrom, as hereinafter provided, and the common council shall direct the proper warrant for collection to be attached to a certified copy of such report.  
Sec. 137. - Payment of assessment. 
The city clerk shall deliver a copy of such report, together with a copy of the ordinance of the common council confirming the same, each duly certified by him, with the proper warrant attached thereto, to the commissioner of finance, and such certified copy of report and ordinance of confirmation shall be deemed the assessment roll for said land acquisition, and the amounts stated therein, as chargeable to the respective persons or properties, shall be collected by the commissioner of finance in the same manner as other local assessments are directed to be collected by the provisions of this charter relating to the collection of assessments for local improvements as set forth in section one hundred thirty-seven-a and sections one hundred thirty-eight to one hundred forty-four inclusive of this charter. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 12)  
Sec. 137-a. - Collection of assessments for local improvements. 
Assessments for local improvements shall be collected by the commissioner of finance at the times, in the manner, and in the amounts, together with interest if any, as provided in the ordinance adopted by the common council either levying the assessment or confirming the assessment or the assessment roll. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 13) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 138. - Recovery of payment erroneously paid. 
When any such assessment shall be paid by or collected of any person, and by agreement or law the same ought to have been borne or paid by any other person, it shall be lawful for the person so paying to sue for and recover of the person bound to pay the same the amount so paid with interest and costs.  
Sec. 139. - Appeals from assessments for benefits. 
Any person affected by any assessment report apportioning and assessing the cost and expense of any such local improvement, or by the confirmation thereof by the common council, as herein provided, may, at any time, within ten (10) days after the confirmation thereof, appeal to the special term of the supreme court from such assessment, report and confirmation, as hereinafter provided. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 14)  
Sec. 140. - Notice of appeal; undertaking or bond. 
Any appeal mentioned in the last preceding section [§ 139] shall be made by serving upon the corporation counsel, or the mayor, and upon the city clerk, a notice of appeal to the special term of the supreme court from the report and determination appealed from, with an undertaking to said city, duly executed and acknowledged by two (2) or more individual sureties or with a surety bond from a company authorized to do business in the state of New York, to be approved by the mayor, corporation counsel, or a justice of the supreme court in Westchester county, in a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00), conditioned for the diligent prosecution of said appeal and for the payment of all damages, costs and charges which may be awarded against him on such appeal; and by payment to the city clerk of his fees for making returns on such appeal, which fees shall be ten cents ($0.10) per folio of the matter to be returned. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 11; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 15)  
Sec. 141. - Stay of proceedings. 
The service of such notice of appeal and undertaking or bond, with payment of the fees as aforesaid, shall stay all further proceedings by the common council and by the officers of said city in relation to the subject-matter of such appeal until decision thereon. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 16)  
Sec. 142. - Return on appeal. 
The city clerk shall forthwith, after any such appeal is perfected as aforesaid, make a copy of the report and determination appealed from, copies of all papers on file in his office, and of all the proceedings of the common council relating to the subject-matter of such appeal. The city clerk shall attach such papers to the notice of appeal and affix thereto his certificate that they are true and correct copies of all such papers, and file the same in the office of the clerk of Westchester county. Such papers shall constitute the return on appeal.  
Sec. 143. - Hearing on appeal; rehearing before common council. 
Either party may bring such appeal to a hearing before special term of the supreme court held in the county of Westchester, upon a notice of eight (8) days. Such court shall hear and consider the appeal, and examine all questions of law and fact that may be presented by the return of such appeal, and may by its order, confirm, reverse or modify such report and determination in whole or in part. In case of a reversal, the court may direct a rehearing before the common council. Upon such rehearing the same proceedings shall be had as hereinbefore provided for upon the original hearing of the matter. If upon such appeal it shall appear to the said court that any party, other than the appellant, has an interest in the subject-matter of such appeal, which will be affected by the determination thereof, such court may direct that such party be given an opportunity to be heard on such appeal in such manner as it shall direct, before the decision thereof.  
Sec. 144. - Costs on appeal. 
In case the court shall affirm the report and determination appealed from, the obligors in the undertaking or bond on appeal above mentioned shall be liable to pay to the city the same costs as are allowed upon appeals to the appellate division of the supreme court from a judgment in a civil action, and the necessary disbursements upon such appeals, to be adjusted by the clerk of Westchester county. In case of a determination of such appeal, other than an affirmance, the court shall direct the costs to be awarded, and to and against whom. If such costs be awarded against the city, they shall be paid by the city after adjustment and entry of judgment in the same manner as other judgments against the city are paid under the provisions of this charter. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 17)  
Sec. 145. - Payment of awards; deposit in certain cases. 
Whenever the amount of compensation for lands, if any, required to be taken for such land acquisition shall be finally ascertained and fixed, and the assessment for such land acquisition shall have been finally made and confirmed, the common council may, and within four (4) months after such assessments have been so finally fixed and determined, shall cause the compensation and damages so ascertained and fixed to be paid or tendered to the respective parties to whom they are awarded. But if any of such parties are infants, idiots, lunatics or persons judicially declared to be incompetent to manage their affairs, or unknown, or non-residents of the county of Westchester, or if the right of any person to the compensation or damages awarded to him shall, in the opinion of the common council, be in doubt, the common council, instead of paying or tendering to such parties the compensation or damages so awarded to him or them, may deposit the same with the commissioner of finance of Westchester county to the credit of whomsoever may be entitled thereto accompanied with the description of the land, for the taking of which such compensation or damages were awarded, and a statement of the facts in each case. The moneys so deposited shall be held by said commissioner of finance as moneys paid into court, and as to such moneys he shall be subject to all the duties imposed upon him by law or by the rules of the supreme court in relation to moneys paid into court and held by him. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 18)  
Sec. 146. - Payment or deposit of excess of award over assessment. 
Whenever the compensation for lands acquired for a street improvement has been finally determined and awarded and an assessment has been finally levied in connection with said lands, the city may offset said assessment against said award and pay the excess to the parties entitled thereto or may deposit the same as provided for in section one hundred forty-five of this charter. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 19)  
Secs. 147—149. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 147—149 were repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 20. Said section numbers are retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 150. - City's share; how paid. 
The remainder of said expense not collected by local assessments as hereinbefore provided may be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law as may be determined by the common council. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1048; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 21) 
Cross reference— Budget generally, § 60.  
Sec. 151. - Establishment and alteration of grades and names of streets; damages for change of grade. 
The common council may, by ordinance, establish the grade of any street, and may, by vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of all its members change the grade of any street theretofore established whenever, in its opinion, the public interest will be promoted by such change, but where such change shall involve the raising or lowering of any walk or curb which shall have been placed on the former grade, the expense incident to such change shall be borne by the city and paid out of funds made available therefor. The common council shall not alter the name of any street, except by ordinance adopted after a public hearing thereon. 
A person claiming damages from a change of grade must present to the common council a verified claim therefor within sixty (60) days after such change of grade is effected. The common council may agree with such person upon the amount of damages to be allowed him. If no agreement be made within thirty (30) days after the presentation of the claim, the person presenting it may apply to the supreme court for the appointment of three (3) commissioners to determine the compensation to which he is entitled. Notice of the application must be served upon the mayor at least ten (10) days before the hearing thereof. All proceedings subsequent to the appointment of commissioners shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of the condemnation law so far as applicable. The common council or such commissioners shall, in determining the compensation, consider the fair value of the work done or necessary to be done, in order to place the claimant's lands or buildings, or both, in the same relation to the changed grade as they stood to the former grade, and make awards accordingly, except that said common council or said commissioners may make an allowance for benefits derived by the claimant from such improvement. The amount agreed upon for such damages, or the award therefor, together with the cost, if any, allowed to the claimant, shall be a charge against the city and shall be paid out of funds made available therefor. 
This section shall not apply to the change of grade of a street which is under the control, supervision or jurisdiction of the state, nor to the change of grade of a street which is under the control, supervision or jurisdiction of the county of Westchester. 
No proceeding or action under this section shall be maintained against the city unless the same shall be commenced within one year after the change or alteration of grade is effected. 
(L.L. No. 1-1929, § 1; L.L. No. 11-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 22) 
State Law reference— Authority to lay out, establish, maintain, vacate, etc., streets, General City Law, § 20(7).  
Sec. 152. - Discontinuance of streets. 
Whenever the common council shall contemplate the discontinuance of any street, it shall cause a notice to be published for ten days in the official newspaper of the city of its intention so to do, and that all persons interested may be heard in reference thereto at a time stated in such notice. If it shall be determined to discontinue the street, and any person shall claim to be damaged by such discontinuance, such alleged damages, unless agreed to by the commissioner of public works and approved by the common council, must be ascertained and determined in the manner provided by law for ascertaining damages for lands taken for the opening of streets. An ordinance discontinuing any street shall require the affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of all the members of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 23)  
Sec. 153. - Sidewalks, curbs, sidewalk drains and appurtenances; how to be constructed, repaired and maintained; cutting grass and weeds. 
Except as hereinafter provided, the construction, repairing and maintaining in good order of all sidewalks, curbs and sidewalk drains, the grading and trestling therefor, and the building of necessary retaining walls to prevent the earth from caving from underneath said walks, and piers for the support thereof, and the grading, maintenance and repair of the area between curb line and property line, including the cutting of grass, weeds and other rank growth exceeding six inches in height, shall be done at the expense of the premises adjoining thereto, or at the expense of the owners thereof. 
(L.L. No. 1-1931, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1947, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1953, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 153)  
Sec. 154. - Commissioner of public works to order work to be done. 
Whenever in the opinion of the commissioner of public works any of the work specified in the foregoing sections shall be necessary to be done, he shall order the same to be done within a specified time, and in case said premises shall be in actual occupation of any person, such person, or the owner of the premises, shall be served with a notice in which shall be stated in general terms what has been ordered to be done and the time within which it has been required. Such notice shall state that unless the order is complied with within the time required, the commissioner of public works shall cause it [such work] to be done and the expense thereof will be charged or assessed against the property as provided in this charter. Whenever the construction of a sidewalk shall be ordered, said sidewalk shall be constructed of concrete, except that sidewalks constructed in front of properties in the R-0, R-1, R-2 and R-3 districts, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city, may be constructed of concrete or bituminous type material in the discretion of the commissioner of public works. 
(L.L. No. 3-1958, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 25)  
Sec. 155. - Notice and service; proof of service. 
The notice specified in the foregoing section [§ 154] shall be signed by the commissioner of public works, and shall be served personally or by leaving it with some person of suitable age at the place of residence of such occupant or owner, or it may be served by depositing it in the post office properly enclosed in a postpaid wrapper and directed to such occupant or owner, at his place of residence, if known, or if not, then at White Plains, New York. An affidavit stating the time and manner of the service of such notice shall be made by any person having knowledge thereof, and filed in the office of the commissioner of public works, which affidavit, when so filed, shall be presumptive evidence in all courts of the facts therein contained. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 26)  
Sec. 156. - If owner fails, commissioner of public works to cause work to be done. 
If any work shall not be done within the time limited therefor, the commissioner of public works shall, by contract or otherwise, cause it to be done, and the expense thereof to be paid as hereinafter set forth. 
(L.L. No. 1-1931, § 3; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 27)  
Sec. 156-a. - Apportionment and assessment of expense. 
Upon the completion of the work specified in section one hundred fifty-three of this charter when the cost thereof shall be ascertained, the premises adjoining the streets where the work shall have been done shall be subject to charges to be fixed and determined by the commissioner of public works with the approval of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 1-1931, § 5; L.L. No. 2-1947, § 2; L.L. No. 2-1953, § 2; L.L. No. 2-1958, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1958, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 28; L.L. No. 3-1971, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 3-1971, sec. 1, amended sec. 156-a by substituting provisions that the commissioner of public works shall fix and determine the charges, for provisions prescribing the amounts of the assessments based upon the types of improvements. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 157. - Expense thereof; how collected. 
The commissioner of public works shall enter in a book to be kept for that purpose the name of the owner or occupant of the adjoining premises, a brief description of said premises and the amount of such charges apportioned against each owner or occupant, and a bill or statement of the amount of such charges shall be sent by mail or be presented personally to such owner or occupant, if his address be known, otherwise the same shall be mailed to such owner or occupant, at White Plains, New York. Any person or the owner of any premises so charged may pay such charges and upon such payment the record of such charges shall be cancelled. 
(L.L. No. 7-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 29)  
Sec. 158. - List of unpaid charges for sidewalks, curbs, etc.; assessment roll therefor. 
During the month of January in each year the commissioner of public works shall make up a list of all unpaid charges to the time of the making of said list, and shall thereupon give public notice in the official newspaper for one week of the completion of said list, and that the same will remain in the office of the commissioner of public works for the term of ten (10) days from the date of the notice, during which time any person interested may examine said list; and at the expiration of said ten (10) days, and on a day and hour and at a place to be specified in said notice, the commissioner of public works will attend and hear any objections to said charges, and shall decide upon all objections, and shall, if need be, alter and correct said list, and when complete, the said commissioner of public works shall sign said list and file the same with the city clerk. Thereupon and within one week any party deeming himself aggrieved may file with the clerk a written appeal therefrom to the common council, briefly stating therein the grounds of such appeal. Whereupon the common council shall proceed to hear and determine such appeal or appeals. In case such appeal is denied, or if there is no appeal, the common council shall, by ordinance, order said list to be filed with the city clerk which list shall thereupon be deemed to be the confirmed assessment roll, and the proper warrant shall be attached by the city clerk and the assessment roll shall be delivered to the commissioner of finance for the collection of the assessments thereon in the same manner as other assessments for local improvements are directed to be collected under the provisions of this charter. In the event such appeal is sustained, the commissioner of public works shall proceed to make out a new list in accordance with the determination of the common council and file the same with the common council for further action. The common council may thereupon, by ordinance, order that said list be filed with the city clerk or it may take such other action as it may deem proper and expedient. In the event such ordinance directs the filing of said list with the city clerk, said list shall be deemed to be the confirmed assessment roll and the city clerk and the commissioner of finance shall proceed in the same manner as hereinbefore directed where there is no appeal or where an appeal is denied. Every assessment made as aforesaid upon lands and buildings, together with the fees for the collection thereof, shall be and remain a lien and charge on such lands or buildings on which or in respect to which such assessment shall have been made from the time such assessment roll shall have been deemed to be confirmed. 
(L.L. No. 7-1950, § 3; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 30) 
Cross reference— Right to review assessments for local improvement limited, § 77. 
State Law reference— Authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 158-a. - Disposition of excess of assessments for sidewalks and curbs; city to pay deficiency. 
In case the assessments so collected shall exceed the total cost of the sidewalks and curbs for which the assessments are made, the excess shall be paid into the general funds of said city. In case the assessments so collected shall fall short of the amount necessary to defray the total cost of constructing such sidewalks or curbs, the deficiency may be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law as may be determined by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 1-1931, § 6; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1049; Laws 1945, Ch. 839, § 73; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 31)  
Sec. 159. - Cleaning streets. 
The cleaning and keeping clean of streets, alleys, public squares, crosswalks and gutters may be done by contract, if the commissioner of public works deems proper, in which case the work shall be let annually. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 32)  
Sec. 160. - Cleaning snow and ice from walks. 
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any lot fronting upon any public street, alley, park or place within the city (irrespective of the street the buildings, structures or other improvements may front upon) to clean and keep free from snow and ice in such manner as the ordinances of the city shall provide the entire width of the sidewalk in front of or adjoining the premises of such owner or occupant. Upon failure of said owner or occupant so to do within the time prescribed by the said ordinances, the commissioner of public works shall cause the same to be done and shall charge such expense as hereinafter set forth. Upon the completion of the cleaning under the direction of the commissioner of public works of snow and ice from sidewalks, the premises in front of which such work shall have been done (irrespective of the street the building, structures or other improvements may front upon) shall be subject to a charge to be fixed and determined by the commissioner of public works with the approval of the common council. During the month of May in each year the commissioner of public works shall make a list of all such charges and file the same in his office, and give public notice of such filing by publication in the official paper, two (2) insertions, that said list has been made and filed and that for ten (10) days from the date of the first publication of said notice said list may be examined by any person interested therein, and that upon a day and hour stated in such notice, and at least ten (10) days after the first publication thereof, he will attend at his office to hear any objections to said list, and pass upon all objections, and, if need be, alter and correct said list. After said hearing and making the necessary corrections, if any, he shall attach thereto his certificate that such hearing has been had and that such list is now complete, and file the same with the commissioner of finance, whereupon the commissioner of finance shall mail to each owner of real property included in such list whose name and address he is able to ascertain a statement of the amount of charges against his property. Upon the filing of the said list with the commissioner of finance the several sums mentioned in said list shall be deemed to be assessed against the several persons named therein, and the commissioner of finance shall, when extending the next general tax upon the city assessment roll, place unpaid amounts thereon as against the property of the person named in said list, and such amounts shall be collected at the same time, in the same manner and by the same proceedings as other taxes on said roll. The failure to mail any statement or failure of the addressee to receive the same shall not in any manner affect the validity of the assessment or the penalties imposed by law with respect thereto. 
(L.L. No. 1-1946, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 6-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1961, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1963, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1964, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 33; L.L. No. 4-1971, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 4-1971, sec. 1, amended sec. 160 by substituting provisions that the commissioner of public works shall fix and determine the charges, for provisions fixing a basic charge of $0.20 per lineal foot, subject to adjustment, with a minimum charge of $3.00. 
Code reference— Duty of abutting property owner to remove snow, § 7-2-1. 
State Law reference— Power of city to fix levy, impose, collect and administer fees, charges, etc., and liens on local property in connection therewith, Statute of Local Governments, § 10.  
Sec. 161. - Sanitary sewers; preliminary ordinance for construction; power of city to enter private lands. 
Whenever the common council shall, by ordinance, declare its intention to construct a sanitary sewer or sewers, it shall specify in such ordinance the size and points between which the same is or are intended to be made for the purpose of sewering any street or streets in said city, whether said street or streets have been dedicated to the city or accepted or not, it shall have the power to cause the same to be sewered, and the said council is empowered and authorized, when necessary for the purpose of sewering any street or streets, to construct a sewer upon and through the land of any owner in said city, and for that purpose the common council, and those acting by its direction, shall have power to enter upon any grounds in said city. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 34) 
Code reference— Amount in annual budget for snow removal, § 2-14-16. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority as to construction, operation, maintenance of sewer and drainage system, General City Law, § 20(2), (7), (26), (26-a); supervision, regulation of plumbing, drainage, General City Law, § 40 et seq.  
Sec. 162. - Survey and plan. 
By direction of the common council, the commissioner of public works shall make a survey and plan for the proposed sanitary sewer, which survey and plan shall be submitted to the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 35)  
Sec. 163. - Notice of intention. 
The city clerk shall forthwith give notice in the official newspaper of the intention to construct such sanitary sewer or sewers, and of the size, length and the points between which such sanitary sewer or sewers is or are intended to be constructed. The first publication of such notice shall be at least ten (10) days before the work shall be ordered. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 36)  
Sec. 164. - Objections; hearing; order for construction. 
At any time after the first publication, provided in the last preceding section [§ 163], any person interested, aggrieved or liable to be assessed for the construction of said sewer, may present, in writing, objections to the common council against the construction of such sewer or sewers. The common council shall hear all objections so presented with the evidence which may be offered, and after such hearing, if it shall dismiss such objections, or if no objections are presented, it may order the construction of such sewer or sewers, with all necessary connections, to the curb line.  
Sec. 165. - Advertisement for proposals. 
The city clerk shall deliver a copy of the ordinance of the common council determining to construct such sewer, to the commissioner of public works, who shall advertise for proposals for the construction of such sewer, as hereinafter provided.  
Sec. 166. - Council may temporarily borrow funds. 
In case there shall not be sufficient of said funds for the purpose aforesaid [of constructing sanitary sewers] then the common council may temporarily borrow, upon the certificates of indebtedness of said city, the necessary moneys, said certificates of indebtedness to be paid out of the moneys raised in the annual tax budget for paying deficiencies on sewers or from the proceeds of bonds to raise such deficiencies. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 12; Laws 1943, Ch. 712; Laws 1945, Ch. 339)  
Sec. 167. - Frontage assessment; amount: lien of. 
Upon the completion of the construction of a sanitary sewer, whether by contract or days' work, the lands fronting upon the street where such sewer is constructed and the lands fronting upon a strip where such sewer is constructed through private lands, (irrespective of the street the buildings, structures or other improvements may front upon), and which lands are provided with sewage facilities by the construction of such sewer shall be subject to a frontage assessment per lineal foot upon the line of such street or strip of land upon or in which said sewer shall be constructed at the rate of the average cost per lineal foot for the construction of such sewer, as determined and certified by the commissioner of public works except however that the common council, in the event it shall deem it equitable, may direct in said ordinance that all or a portion of the cost and expense of the construction of said sewer shall be charged to the city at large and the remainder, if any, be assessed against the owners of the said lands fronting upon the street or strip of land upon or in which said sewer shall be constructed, except that corner lots shall be credited with any frontage assessment previously paid for the construction of a sanitary sewer in one intersecting street or strip of land in the event that a frontage assessment is levied for the construction of a sewer in the other intersecting street or strip of land; and where lands fronting upon any street (irrespective of the street the buildings, structures or other improvements may front upon) are furnished with sewer facilities by the construction of a sewer through private lands, the said lands shall be subject to the same frontage assessment upon the street upon which said lands front, as in the case of the construction of a sanitary sewer along such street for the accommodation of said lands. In the case of a sanitary sewer constructed through or terminating in the turnaround portion of a cul-de-sac street, the frontage of a parcel of land facing on such turnaround portion shall be considered as the distance measured along a line within said parcel twenty-five (25) feet from, and concentric with, the street line of such parcel of land. Only one frontage assessment shall be levied upon any lands, except as aforesaid for corner lots, and except that any lot extending through from street to street and exceeding one hundred (100) feet in depth shall be subject to a frontage assessment upon each street at the average cost per lineal foot computed as aforesaid. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 6; Laws 1921, Ch. 322, § 3; L.L. No. 2-1946, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1947, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 9-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1951, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1953, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1957, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 37; L.L. No. 5-1971, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1972, § 1) 
State Law reference— Authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 168. - Assessment roll for sanitary sewers and proceedings thereon. 
The commissioner of public works shall, upon the order of the common council, proceed to make out an assessment roll of said frontage assessment, and shall set forth on said roll the ward, block and lot numbers, the name of the owner, the number of front feet, the rate per foot and the total assessment for each of the parcels involved and shall file the same in his office, and shall thereupon give public notice in the official paper for one week, that the same has been filed in his office, and will remain in his office for the term of ten (10) days from the date of such notice, during which time any persons interested may examine said roll, and at the expiration of said ten (10) days, and on a day and hour and at a place to be specified in said notice, he shall attend and hear any objections to said assessment, and shall decide upon all objections, and shall, if need be, alter and correct said roll, and when complete the said commissioner of public works shall sign and file the same with the city clerk; thereupon and within one week any party deeming himself aggrieved may file with the clerk a written appeal therefrom to the common council briefly stating therein the grounds of such appeal. Whereupon the common council shall proceed to hear and determine such appeal or appeals. In case such appeal is denied, or if there is no appeal, the common council shall, by ordinance, confirm said assessment roll and order the same filed with the city clerk. In the event such appeal is sustained, the common council shall direct that such assessment roll be referred to the commissioner of public works to make out a new assessment roll in accordance with the determination of the common council, which said new assessment roll shall, upon completion thereof by the commissioner of public works, be submitted to the common council for further action. The common council may thereupon confirm said assessment or take such further action as it may deem proper or expedient. In the event such assessment roll is confirmed the same shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(L.L. No. 17-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 38) 
Cross reference— Right to review assessments for local improvement limited, § 77. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 169. - Payment of assessment. 
The city clerk shall deliver a copy of such assessment roll, together with a copy of the ordinance of the common council confirming the same, each duly certified by him with the proper warrant attached thereto, to the commissioner of finance, and such certified copy of report and ordinance of confirmation shall be deemed the assessment roll for said improvement, and the amount stated therein as chargeable to the respective persons or properties shall be collected by the commissioner of finance in the same manner as assessments for local improvements are directed to be collected by the provisions of this charter. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 39)  
Sec. 170. - Disposition of excess of assessment; city to pay deficiency. 
In case the assessments so collected shall exceed the total cost of the sanitary sewer or sewers for which the assessments are made, the excess shall be paid into the general funds of the city. In case the assessments so collected shall fall short of the amount necessary to defray the total cost of constructing such sanitary sewer or sewers, the deficiency may be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local Finance Law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 40)  
Secs. 171, 172. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 171, 172 were repealed by Laws 1943, Ch. 712, as amended by Laws 1945, Ch. 339. Said section numbers are retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 173. - Sanitary sewer through private lands; cost of, how paid. 
When, in the opinion of the common council, it shall become necessary in order to abate a nuisance, or the public interests require, said council may order that a sanitary sewer or sewers be constructed through the private lands of any person, persons, corporations or associations, upon the assessment and payment of damages, if any, as in the case of taking of private lands for streets, and where such sewer or sewers do not furnish sewage facilities for street lots along its routes, the whole expense of the construction of such sewer shall be borne by the city, and shall be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 41)  
Sec. 174. - Proceedings to obtain right of way. 
Whenever the common council shall order a sanitary sewer to be made through the lands of any person, corporation or association, such proceedings shall be had to appoint commissioners to ascertain and assess the damage to the parties interested as is provided by the sections of this title relating to the taking of private lands for streets, and said sections are hereby declared to apply to proceedings under this section, and by such proceedings the city of White Plains shall acquire a permanent right of way for a sanitary sewer of any size or depth, with the right to repair or relay such sewer at any time. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 42)  
Sec. 175. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 175 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 43. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 176. - City's share; how paid. 
The remainder of said expense [in construction of sanitary sewers] not collected by local assessments as hereinbefore provided, shall be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 14; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1051; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 44) 
Cross reference— Budget, generally, § 60.  
Sec. 177. - Council may compel connection. 
The common council may, whenever deemed expedient, order any person whose property has been provided with sewage facilities, by the construction of any sanitary sewer, to make connections of such property with such sewer, and whenever it shall be necessary to do any such work, the common council shall order it done within a time specified and pursuant to the requirements of the plumbing code of the city of White Plains and in case said premises shall be in the actual occupation of any person, such person, or the owner of the premises, shall be served with a notice in which shall be stated in general terms what has been ordered to be done, and the time in which it has been required; such notice shall be signed by the city clerk, and shall be served personally or by leaving it with some person of suitable age at the place of residence of said occupant or owner, or it may be served by depositing it in the post office, properly enclosed in a postpaid wrapper and directed to such owner or occupant at his last known address. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 15; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 45)  
Sec. 178. - Procedure to compel connection. 
An affidavit stating the time and manner of the service of such notice [to connect to a sanitary sewer] shall be made by any person having knowledge thereof, and filed with the clerk, which affidavit, when so filed, shall be presumptive evidence in all courts of the facts therein contained. If any work shall not be done within the time limited therefor, the commissioner of public works shall, by contract or otherwise, cause the same to be done, and for that purpose he or those designated by him shall have the right to enter such premises. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 46)  
Sec. 179. - Procedure to collect expense of connection. 
Upon the completion of such connection, [connection to a sanitary sewer], the commissioner of public works shall forthwith present a statement of the expense thereof, with a description of the premises upon which the work was done, to the common council, which shall assess the expense of said work, with ten per centum (10%) additional, upon said premises, or upon the owner thereof. The assessment roll shall be made and the same proceedings as to objections to and appeals from said assessments shall be had as in this charter provided, in the case of assessments for the construction of sewers and the same proceedings as to collection of said assessments shall be had as in this charter provided in the case of assessments for local improvements. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 47) 
Cross reference— Right to review assessment for local improvement limited, § 77.  
Sec. 180. - Street or other improvements; common council may direct construction or improvement. 
The common council may, by ordinance, direct and require any street or public ground, square, park, culvert, arch or bridge in said city, or any part of either of them, to be graded, paved, surfaced, constructed, regraded, repaved, resurfaced, reconstructed or otherwise improved or repaired at the cost and expense of the owners of the lots or parcels of land adjacent to such street or public ground, square, park, culvert, arch or bridge, or part thereof so graded, paved, surfaced, constructed, regraded, repaved, resurfaced, reconstructed or otherwise improved or repaired, and at the expense of the city at large except, however, that the common council, in the event it shall deem it equitable, may direct in said ordinance that all or a portion of the cost and expense of such grading, paving, surfacing, constructing, regrading, repaving, resurfacing, reconstructing, improving or repairing, which portion shall be not less than one-half (½) of such entire cost and expense, shall be charged to the city at large, and the remainder, if any, be assessed against the owners of such adjacent lots or parcels of land, which cost and expense shall be determined, apportioned, assessed and collected as hereinafter provided and shall be a lien upon such property from and after the time of the confirmation of the apportionment and assessment thereof. 
(L.L. No. 12-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 48) 
State Law reference— Authority as to sewers and drainage systems, water supply systems, streets, etc., General City Law, § 20(7); as to other public works, General City Law, § 20(2), (7-a), (11).  
Sec. 181. - Ordinance and notice to be published; hearing; action thereon. 
If it is proposed to levy an assessment for the work to be done under an ordinance to be adopted pursuant to the last preceding section [§ 180] the common council shall cause the proposed ordinance for an improvement specified in the last preceding section [§ 180] to be published for at least five (5) successive days in the official newspaper with a notice that at the time and place to be stated therein, which shall not be less than five (5) days from the first publication thereof, it will meet to consider such ordinance, and that at such meeting all parties interested may be heard. The common council at the time and place stated in such notice, or at such other time and place as shall be then appointed for such purpose, shall hear all parties interested in the matter of such ordinance who shall desire to be heard, and by a majority of the members then present may adopt, modify or reject such proposed ordinance. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 49)  
Sec. 182. - Sewer, water mains and conduits in streets to be improved. 
When the common council shall determine to construct, pave, surface, reconstruct, repave, resurface, or otherwise improve one or more streets, pursuant to the provisions of this title, it shall cause a notice to be published for five (5) days in the official newspaper of said city, particularly specifying the street or streets, or part thereof, intended to be so improved, and requiring all persons, corporations and companies, and city departments, within the time limited in said notice, which shall not be less than thirty (30) days, to do excavating, lay new mains, sewers and pipes and make such repairs to, and connections with, existing gas and water mains, sewers and pipes as may be necessary or liable to be required, within a period of two (2) years next thereafter, in and through the street or streets, or parts thereof, to be so improved, and the actual paving, surfacing, repaving or resurfacing thereof shall not be commenced until the expiration of the time stated in such notice. Copies of such notice shall be served by mail, within five (5) days from the date of the first publication of said notice, upon all companies and municipal departments owning or having charge of pipes, mains or conduits laid in said street or streets, or parts thereof, to be so improved. After such improvement is completed, no person, corporation or company, shall be authorized, permitted or allowed, for the period of two (2) years, to excavate for any purpose whatever in the street or streets, or part or parts thereof, so improved, except under such conditions and restrictions as the common council may provide by ordinance or otherwise. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 50)  
Sec. 183. - Expenses of improvement; how apportioned and assessed. 
Upon the completion of any work of construction or improvement provided for in section one hundred eighty of this charter and the entire cost and expense thereof, including but not limited to assessing, printing, advertising, surveying, engineering, inspecting and superintending, and the cost resulting from the construction or improvement of spaces within street intersections, including incidental construction and improvement within such intersecting street, and any increased cost of such construction and improvement incident to guaranty, shall be computed and ascertained by the commissioner of public works. One-half (½) of such entire cost and expense or such part as may have been determined by the common council pursuant to section one hundred eighty of this charter shall be charged to the city at large and the remainder thereof, if any, shall be assessed by the commissioner of public works upon and among the owners of the lots or parcels of land adjoining such street or public ground or part thereof so constructed or improved in proportion to the number of feet front which each owns thereon. 
When the cost to the city of any state or county highway constructed or improved under the provisions of the Highway Law shall be ascertained, one-half (½) of such cost or such part thereof as may have been determined by the common council pursuant to section one hundred eighty of this charter shall be charged to the city at large and the remainder thereof, if any, shall be assessed by the commissioner of public works upon and among the owners of the lots or parcels of land adjoining such state or county highway or part thereof so constructed or improved in proportion to the number of feet of frontage which each owns thereon. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 322, § 4; Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 8; L.L. No. 12-1950, § 3; L.L. No. 2-1954, § 3; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 51) 
State Law reference— Authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 183-a. - Assessment of cost of sidewalks and curbs in connection with improvements. 
Where the construction or improvement provided for in section one hundred eighty of this charter requires the relaying or reconstruction of existing sidewalks or the resetting or reconstruction of existing curbs, in new locations, no assessment shall be made against the lands fronting thereon, or against the owners of said lands, for such relaying, resetting or reconstruction, provided that such existing sidewalks and/or curbs were substantially in compliance with the standards of the department of public works, anything to the contrary contained in section one hundred fifty-three or any other section of this charter notwithstanding. No assessment shall be made against lands fronting on a county road, or against the owners of said lands, for the construction of new curbs in connection with the construction or improvement of a county road, as provided for in section one hundred eighty of this charter, anything to the contrary contained in section one hundred fifty-three or any other section of this charter notwithstanding. 
(L.L. No. 2-1956, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1960, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 52) 
State Law reference— Authority to assess for public improvements, General City Law, § 20(11).  
Sec. 184. - Assessment roll for improvements. 
The commissioner of public works shall make out an assessment roll, and when so made out shall give public notice in the official paper for one week that the same is on file in his office and will remain with him for the term of ten (10) days, during which time any persons interested may examine said roll, and at the expiration of said ten (10) days, and on a day and hour and at a place to be specified in said notice, said commissioner of public works will hear any objections to said assessment and shall decide upon all objections, and shall, if need be, alter and correct said roll, and when complete shall sign the same and file it in the office of the city clerk, and the same proceedings as to objections to and appeals from said assessments shall be had as in this charter provided in the case of assessments for the construction of sewers, and the same proceedings as to collection of said assessments shall be had as in this charter provided in the case of assessments for local improvements. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 53)  
Sec. 185. - City's share of cost of improvement. 
The remainder of said expense [for improvements] not collected by local assessments as hereinbefore provided, may be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(Laws 1921, Ch. 322, § 5; Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1052; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 54)  
Sec. 186. - [Street improvements and special assessments—Generally.] 
The common council may, by ordinance, direct and require a program of street improvements for designated streets or portions thereof in the city of White Plains which may include, but is not limited to, the installation of sidewalks, lighting fixtures, street furnishings, passageways, parking lot improvements, at the expense of the city at large, except that the common council may, in the event that it shall deem it equitable direct in said ordinance that all, or a portion of the cost of the aforesaid improvements, which portion shall not be less than twenty-five percent of such entire cost and expense, shall be charged to the city at large to be financed from current revenues, and the remainder, if any, shall be financed by bonded indebtedness, the annual amount for redemption of which shall be assessed against the owners of adjacent lots or parcels of land; or by special assessment of said adjacent lots or parcels for said remainder in a single year. The annual assessment or special assessment shall be determined, apportioned, assessed and collected as hereinafter provided and shall be a lien upon such adjacent lots or parcels of land from and after the time of the confirmation of the apportionment and assessment thereof. Any program of street improvements directed pursuant to this section shall include a listing of streets in precedence which shall be used in determining the annual assessment or special assessment as hereinafter set forth. Any program of street improvements directed pursuant to this section shall not be subject to section sixty-seven of this charter. Any ordinance adopted pursuant to this section shall be subject to the procedures set forth in sections one hundred eighty-one, one hundred eighty-two and one hundred eighty-four of the city charter. 
(L.L. No. 1-1979, § 1) 
Editor's note— Sec. 186 as originally enacted was repealed by Laws 1943, Ch. 712, as amended by Laws 1945, Ch. 339. L.L. No. 1-1979, sec. 1, enacted a new sec. 186.  
Sec. 187. - [Same—Apportionment of special assessment costs.] 
The annual assessment or special assessment provided for in section one hundred eighty-six of this charter shall be assessed by the commissioner of public works upon and among the owners of the lots or parcels of land adjoining the streets directed to be improved by the common council, by assessing one-half of the said assessment against the aforesaid parcels in proportion to the number of feet of frontage which each owns on the streets to be improved, except that where a lot or parcel of land has frontage on two or more streets, then the frontage on the street of higher precedence as determined by the common council pursuant to section one shall be considered to be the number of feet of frontage on said streets, and the frontage of the street or streets of lower precedence shall be considered one-half the number of feet of frontage; and by assessing one-half of the annual assessment against the aforesaid parcels in the proportion that the assessed valuation for each lot or parcel of land bears to the assessed valuation of all such lots or parcels of land adjoining the street to be improved. 
(L.L. No. 1-1979, § 1) 
Editor's note— Sec. 187 as originally enacted was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, § 55. L.L. No. 1-1979, sec. 1, created a new sec. 187.  
Sec. 188. - Waterworks; powers of commissioner of public works. 
The commissioner of public works, subject to the provisions of this act, the other laws of the state and the ordinances of the common council, has the direction and control of the operation, construction, maintenance, extension and repair of the city waterworks; he shall see that the city has abundant supply of pure and wholesome water for public and private use; he shall devise the plans and sources of water supply, plan and supervise the distribution of water through the city, protect it against contamination and prescribe rules and regulations for its use, which, when ratified and approved by the common council, shall have the same force and effect as ordinances enacted by the common council. 
Code reference— Waterworks, Ch. 7-8. 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to establish, construct, maintain water supply system, General City Law, § 20(7), (7-a).  
Sec. 189. - Extension or improvement of waterworks system; increase in supply. 
The commissioner of public works may adopt plans and specifications for the extension or improvement of the waterworks system, or for the acquisition of an additional supply of water for public and private use. A plan so adopted by him shall be submitted to the common council for its approval. If such plan is approved by the common council, the commissioner of public works shall cause such work to be done, and necessary lands and water rights to be acquired, in accordance therewith. The contracts for such work shall be let in accordance with such plan, in the same manner as other contracts for public improvements. Subject to the approval of the common council, the commissioner of public works may contract for water supply, provided no such contract shall be made for a longer period than ten (10) years. 
(L.L. No. 1-1925, § 3)  
Sec. 190. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 190 was repealed by Laws 1943, Ch. 712 as amended by Laws 1945, Ch. 339. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 191. - Acquisition of lands and water rights. 
The commissioner of public works or those designated by him may enter into or upon any land or water for the purpose of making surveys. The commissioner may agree, subject to the approval of the common council, with the owner of any property which in his judgment may be required for such extension, improvement or increase in supply, or which may be injuriously affected by such work connected with such improvement, as to the amount of compensation to be paid to such owner. If the commissioner of public works shall agree with any owner for the purchase of any lands or easement in the same, or for the taking of any water or water rights, all such agreements and conveyances shall be made and taken in the name of the city of White Plains. When any lands are required for such improvement, for the purchase of which no contract shall be made, as provided herein, the city of White Plains shall have the right to acquire title to the same by condemnation. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 56) 
State Law reference— Authority to acquire property for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(2); Statute of Local Governments, § 10(2); condemnation proceedings, Eminent Domain Procedure Law, § 1 et seq.; limitation on acquisition of water rights in Westchester County, General Municipal Law, § 76.  
Sec. 192. - Use of streets and highways. 
The commissioner of public works or those designated by him may use the grounds or soil under any street, highway or road, in the county of Westchester, for the purpose of laying pipes, conduits and introducing water in and through any portion of the city of White Plains, on condition that he shall cause the surface of said street, highway or road to be restored to its former state, or to such state as shall not unnecessarily have impaired its usefulness. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 57)  
Sec. 193. - Extension of mains in streets. 
The common council may, by ordinance, direct the commissioner of public works to cause the line of water mains or pipes for the city waterworks to be extended in any street in such city. The expense may be paid from funds available in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, § 1054; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 58)  
Sec. 194. - Willful injury to waterworks system a misdemeanor. 
Any person who shall willfully do or cause to be done any act whereby any work, material or property erected or used by the said city or by the commissioner of public works or by any person acting under his authority, for the purpose of procuring or furnishing water, shall in any way be injured, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference— Penalty for violations, Penal Law, § 55.10.  
Sec. 195. - Hydrants. 
The commissioner of public works shall procure and set hydrants for the supply of water for the extinguishment of fires, of such kind, in such manner and at such places in the public streets of said city as the common council shall direct.  
Sec. 196. - Connecting of supply lines. 
The connecting of supply pipes leading from the mains or distributing pipes to dwellings or other private property shall be inserted and kept in repair at the expense of the owners or occupants of the premises and shall not be inserted or connected with the main pipe until a permit therefor shall be obtained from the commissioner of public works. All such connecting or supply pipes and fixtures shall be constructed and placed under and according to the direction of the commissioner of public works.  
Sec. 197. - Establishment of water rates and charges. 
The commissioner of public works, with the approval of the common council, is hereby authorized and empowered to make such rules and regulations in relation to the use of water as he may from time to time deem to be necessary, and shall have the right, with the approval of the common council, to fix and determine the price to be paid by the consumer for water and the time and manner of such payment; to fix and determine charges and rates for "stand by" service, hydrant rental and fire line charges, and the said commissioner of public works, with the approval of the common council, shall have full power to establish all charges for the use of water, including meter charges, and stop the use thereof upon any premises when the use of the water shall not have been paid for and when any rules and regulations provided in this section have not been complied with, and the common council shall have the power, upon the recommendation of the commissioner of public works, to enforce the penalties for the violation of any rules and regulations established, as provided in this section. The commissioner of public works, with the approval of the common council, shall have power to enter into contracts for the sale of water to individuals, corporations or municipalities outside the limits of the city of White Plains, which contracts shall provide that the water sold shall be metered at the city line through a meter approved by the commissioner of public works and provided and maintained by the individual, corporation or municipality purchasing said water, provided, however, that all such contracts which, by their terms exceed a period of one year, shall contain a provision that the same may be terminated by the city, at its option, upon one year's notice of its intention so to do. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 7; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 59) 
Code reference— Water rates and charges, § 7-8-121.  
Sec. 198. - Record of water rates and other water charges. 
The commissioner of public works shall cause to be entered in an appropriate record information relative to water rates and other water charges, which said record shall contain: 
(1)  Location of the property to be charged, stating such location by ward, block and lot number as shown on the tax assessment map of the city and also stating such location by street and by street number, if any; 
(2)  The name of the owner of such property according to the latest information in the department of public works; 
(3)  Description of meter and identification number for billing purposes; 
(4)  Last previous reading and current reading of the meter and net consumption of water for the period for which the charge is to be made; 
(5)  Other water charges which may be applicable against such property; 
(6)  Such other information as the commissioner of public works may deem advisable. 
At least fifteen days prior to the dates fixed for the collection of water charges as determined by the rules and regulations made and adopted pursuant to section one hundred ninety-seven of this charter, the commissioner of public works shall cause to be delivered to the commissioner of finance the aforesaid record. Based on the information set forth in said record, the commissioner of finance shall thereupon cause to be prepared and mailed, individual water bills, setting forth for each consumer the information set forth in the record of water charges prepared by the commissioner of public works, as aforesaid, and the water charges applicable thereto and shall simultaneously or otherwise cause to be prepared a water charges assessment record, which record shall include: 
(a)  A complete listing of all billings for the applicable period, readily identifiable as to each consumer by account number. 
(b)  Such other information or data as the commissioner of finance may deem advisable. 
(L.L. No. 1-1953, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 60; L.L. No. 1-1971, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 1-1971, sec. 1, amended sec. 198 by adding reference to the identification number in (3), deleting reference to the amount due in (4), changing the time for delivering the record from 10 to 15 days prior to the dates fixed for collection and revising the billing procedure in the second unnumbered paragraph, and deleting reference to a summary of billings in (a).  
Sec. 199. - Collection of water charges. 
Beginning with the dates fixed for the collection of water charges, as determined by the rules and regulations made and adopted pursuant to section one hundred ninety-seven of this charter, the commissioner of finance shall proceed to collect the water charges as shown on the aforesaid record in the office of the commissioner of finance. The commissioner of finance shall give public notice in the official newspaper on receiving such record, the first publication of which notice shall be prior to or on the dates fixed for the collection of water charges, as determined by the rules and regulations made and adopted pursuant to section one hundred ninety-seven of this charter. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 8; Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 17; L.L. No. 2-1931, § 9; L.L. No. 1-1953, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 61)  
Sec. 200. - Enforcement of collection of water charges. 
All water charges which shall remain unpaid at the expiration of thirty (30) days from the dates fixed for the collection of water charges, as determined by the rules and regulations made and adopted pursuant to section one hundred ninety-seven of this charter, shall have added to them one per centum (1%) of the amount for each month or part of a month that the same shall remain unpaid after thirty (30) days, the collection of which shall be enforced with the original assessment. All water charges are hereby declared to be a lien from the date when the water is furnished and a tax upon the premises in connection with which said water is used, and water charges which shall remain unpaid on the first day of December in each year shall be collected in the same manner or manners as are provided herein for the collection of a general tax, and all preceding remedies herein provided for the collection of such general tax shall be applicable and apply to the collection of water charges. It shall be the duty of the commissioner of finance on or before the first day of December in each year to make out a list or roll in which he or she shall set out the amount of water charges accrued or chargeable upon each lot, part of lot or building and which shall not have been paid or collected in a preceding like list or roll, and file the same in his or her office, and he or she shall, in the preparation of the next tax roll for the general city taxes, in a separate column thereof, assess such amount upon such property, and the same shall be levied, enforced and collected in the same manner, by the same proceedings, at the same time, under the same penalties and having the same lien upon the property assessed as the general city tax and as a part thereof. The commissioner of finance at such other times as he or she may be requested, shall report to the commissioner of public works all water charges and special rates uncollected.
