(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 9; L.L. No. 2-1931, § 11; L.L. No. 1-1953, § 3; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 62; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 16; L.L. No. 1-2001, § 4)  
Sec. 201. - Sewer rents. 
A.  Purpose, applicability. A scale of rents, to be called "sewer rents," is hereby levied and assessed against every lot, parcel of land, building or premises now or hereafter having any connection with the sewer system of said City or otherwise discharging domestic sewage, commercial and industrial waste, water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly, into the sanitary sewer system of such City, based on the metered consumption of water to the premises connected with and served by said sewer system or any part or parts thereof, the revenue from which rents shall be used for the payments of costs of operation, maintenance and repairs of the sewer system or such part or parts thereof for which sewer rents have been established and imposed, the interest on and amortization of or payment of indebtedness which has been or shall be incurred for the construction of the sewer system or such part or parts thereof for which sewer rents have been established and imposed (other than indebtedness and the interest thereon, which is to be paid in the first instance from assessments upon benefitted real property) and for the construction of sewage treatment and disposal works with necessary appurtenances, including pumping stations, or for the extension, enlargement or replacement of or additions to such sewer systems or part or parts thereof. 
B.  Duty of owner. In addition to any and all fees and charges provided by law, the owner of any parcel of real property within the City limits connected with the sewer system of the City of White Plains shall pay a sewer rent for the use of such sewer system based upon the metered consumption of water to said premises in an amount to be fixed and determined from time to time by the Commissioner of Public Works of the City of White Plains with the approval of the Common Council by resolution after a public hearing on five days notice. In order that property lying outside the corporate limits of the City of White Plains being served by its sewage disposal system shall bear a proportionate share of the cost of such system, the charge made for such property shall be apportioned by the Commissioner of Public Works in addition to the base rate charged to property located within the City, such charge to be collected and the collection enforced as herein provided for other sewer rental charges. For the purpose of determining the charge to be rendered premises using the sewerage system whereon the water used is derived in whole or in part from sources independent of the City, the water used thereon supplied from private sources shall be measured by a City water meter or by a meter acceptable to the Department of Public Works, to be installed and maintained by the owner or occupant thereof at his/her own cost and subject to supervision and inspection by said Department of Public Works. The sewer rental charged against such property shall be determined by the metered consumption of water used on said premises, regardless of the source from which supplied, according to the schedule herein and hereinafter adopted by the Commissioner of Public Works. Whenever the owner or occupant fails to install such meter and in cases where the Commissioner of Public Works finds it impractical to insist upon a special meter, said Commissioner may accept the report of said property owner as to the amount of water used on said premises or said Commissioner may fix and determine the amount ordinarily consumed upon said premises by such method as it may find practicable in the light of the conditions and attendant circumstances of the case in order to determine the sewer rental charge, all in accordance with corresponding rates assessed against other similar property. 
C.  Collection. In the case of premises whereon the water used is supplied by the City of White Plains through its Commissioner of Public Works, the sewer rental charge herein provided shall be added to the water bills rendered to the owners, lessees or occupants of such property and shall be paid at the time the water bill is payable at the office of the Commissioner of Finance and shall be collected with and in addition to the water charge for water service, and no part of the charge for water service shall be accepted without including therewith the sewer rental charge. Such sewer rental charge shall be subject to the same penalty provided for delinquent water bills as provided in section two hundred of this charter, and it is hereby made the duty of said Commissioner of Finance to collect such penalty for failure to pay the sewer rental charge when due. In cases of premises whereon water used is not supplied by the City, said Commissioner of Public Works will render quarterly to the owners, lessees or occupants of such property bills for the amount of the sewer rental charged as herein set forth. All sewer rental charges are hereby declared to be a lien upon the premises from the first date of the period for which the rental charges are incurred and a tax upon the premises which utilities the sewer system. If such charge is not paid when due, it shall be subject to said same penalty as is provided for delinquent water bills, and the Commissioner of Finance is hereby required to collect such penalty. In the event that said bills for sewer rentals rendered for premises whereon water is supplied by the City of White Plains are not paid within 30 days and remains due on the first day of December in each year after the rendering thereof, the Commissioner of Finance shall proceed to collect said unpaid sewer rental in the same manner as detailed for unpaid water charges in section two hundred of this charter. The Commissioner of Finance at such times as may be requested shall report to the Commissioner of Public Works all sewer rental charges uncollected. 
D.  Effect of nonpayment. All sewer rents for premises using City water shall be payable, collectible and enforceable in the manner provided by law for the payment, collection and enforcement of water charges and, if unpaid, shall be collected in the same manner provided for the collection of water charges and City taxes and, when remaining unpaid, shall be added to the annual City tax in a separate column on the property to and for which sewer service was furnished and rendered as provided for in section two hundred of this charter. 
E.  Authority of Commissioner. The Commissioner of Public Works shall have the power to make and enforce such general rules and regulations, both as to Public and private water supply, for the collection, rebating, refunding or adjustment of such charges for any reason, including diversion of water from the sewer system, as may be reasonably necessary to avoid injustice, to the end that all property discharging sewage in the sewer system will bear its equitable proportionate share with other property of the cost of operation, maintenance and repairs of said sewerage system or any extension, enlargement, replacement or additions to such sewer system or any part or parts thereof. 
F.  Sewer Rent Fund. Pursuant to section 453 of the general municipal law, all revenues derived from the sewer rents imposed hereunder, together with all penalties and interest thereon, shall be kept by the Commissioner of Finance of the City of White Plains in a separate account to be known as the "Sewer Rent Fund" and disbursements therefrom shall be made pursuant to said section of the general municipal law. 
G.  Existing contracts. The provisions of this Charter shall be subject in any event to any and all existing contracts between the City of White Plains and present contract users of its sewer system and to any and all renewals, extensions and modifications, if any, of said contracts. 
H.  The section is enacted pursuant to subdivision 26-a of section 20 of the General City Law and Article 14-F of the General Municipal Law. 
(L.L. No. 1-2010, § 1) 
Editor's note— Formerly, Sec. 201 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 63. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 202. - Establishment of boundaries of watercourses; publication of description; hearing. 
The common council may, by ordinance, determine, fix and establish the boundaries, limits and grade at the bed thereof, of the natural streams or watercourses within said city, or of any part of such streams or watercourses. Whenever any such boundaries, limits or grade of such stream or watercourse shall be so fixed or established, the common council shall make such description thereof as shall definitely describe and locate the boundaries and grade as so fixed and established, and enter the same at length in their minutes, and cause the same to be published in the official newspaper of the city for at least once a week for two (2) successive weeks, which publication shall be due and sufficient service upon the owners, occupants and other persons interested therein, of all the lands through which such stream shall pass or which abut thereon. If such owner, occupant, or other persons interested, shall within fifteen (15) days after the first publication of such ordinance, file with the city clerk his objections thereto in writing, he shall be entitled to be heard by and before said common council at its next meeting after the filing of such objections or at such other time as the common council may appoint in reference to such ordinance or the determination therein stated, or the facts upon which it was based. Upon such hearing, the common council shall receive such legal evidence as may be offered which is relevant to the matter. The common council shall thereupon pass upon the objections so filed, and may confirm the ordinance previously adopted, or modify or rescind the same. The ordinance as confirmed or modified shall be final and conclusive upon all parties interested therein, and the boundaries, limits and grade of such stream as thereby and therein described and designated shall thereafter be the legal boundaries, limits and grade of said stream or watercourse, but none of the riparian rights of any of the owners of land abutting on such watercourse or stream shall be impaired or affected. Nothing contained in this section shall supersede the provisions of chapter eight hundred fifty-three of the laws of nineteen hundred fifty-six, entitled "An act to amend the Westchester county administrative code in relation to the power of the county commissioner of public works with respect to stream control", and which is known as title D, article nine of the Westchester county administrative code, but the provisions of this section shall be considered to be in addition thereto. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 64)  
Sec. 203. - Manner of acquisition of lands when not otherwise provided. 
(a)  Whenever any real estate or interest therein shall be required by the city of White Plains for any municipal purpose, when the manner of the acquisition is not otherwise provided for in this charter, the commissioner of public works may acquire for the city the necessary lands and real estate by gift or by purchase at a price approved by the common council, or if no contract for the purchase of the same shall be made, the city of White Plains shall have the right to acquire title to the same by condemnation. 
(b)  Anything in this charter to the contrary notwithstanding, the commissioner of public works, with the approval of the common council, may acquire for the city at the expense of the city at large, lands or real estate or any interest therein, necessary for any municipal purposes, by gift or by purchase, provided that the purchase price thereof shall not exceed the sum of seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) for any one parcel. 
(L.L. No. 2-1929, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1961, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 65) 
State Law reference— Acquisition of property for municipal purposes, General City Law, § 20(2); condemnation proceedings, Eminent Domain Procedure Law, § 1 et seq.  
Sec. 204. - Correction of errors in assessments. 
Every assessment authorized by this article shall be valid and effectual notwithstanding any irregularity, omission or error in any of the proceedings relating to the same, and the common council may, in its discretion, correct any such irregularity, error or omission, or any error or mistake in the description of the lands assessed, or intended to be assessed, or in the designation of the owners or occupants thereof; and the original assessment upon such lands, after such corrections are made, may be enforced and collected in the same manner as though no error, irregularity or mistake had been made. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 66)  
Sec. 205. - Evidence of assessments generally. 
Every assessment authorized by the common council under this article or a copy of the ordinance making the same, certified by the city clerk, or the minutes of the common council containing such ordinance, or a printed copy of such minutes, published under authority of the common council, shall be presumptive evidence in all courts and places that such assessment was legally imposed, and that all the notices and proceedings required for such assessment were duly given and taken, and that the lands thereby assessed are legally subject to the lien of such assessment. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 67)  
Sec. 206. - Lien of assessments. 
Every assessment made as provided in this article upon lands or buildings, together with the fees for the collection thereof and interest thereupon, shall be and remain a lien and charge on such lands or buildings on which or in respect to which such assessment shall have been made, from the time the confirmation of the assessment report or roll shall become final and conclusive until the same shall be paid, unless otherwise herein provided.  
Sec. 206-a. - Installment payments of assessments. 
Whenever assessments for local improvements are authorized by this article to be levied to pay the cost or a portion of the cost of land acquisition for street or other improvement, for construction or repair of sidewalks, curbs, etc., for sanitary sewers and for street or other improvements, at the time of or before the confirmation of the assessments, the common council, at its option, may, by resolution or ordinance, provide that the owner of any property assessed therefor may pay said assessment in five (5) equal installments, the first installment to be payable on a date to be fixed by the common council not more than three (3) years after the date of such confirmation, the next installments to be payable annually thereafter, whereupon the city clerk shall file such notice and subdivide such assessment upon the assessment roll accordingly, and said five (5) installments of assessments shall bear interest at the rate of one per centum (1%) per month or any part thereof from the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date that the first installment is due and payable as fixed by the common council. Said assessments and installments together with such interest thereon and fees for the collection thereof shall be and remain a lien and charge on such lands or buildings on which or in respect to which such assessment shall have been made from the time the confirmation of the assessment report or roll shall become final and conclusive until the same shall be paid. 
In case of default in payment of any installment within thirty (30) days after the same becomes due and payable as above provided, the whole amount of such assessment then remaining unpaid with all accrued interest shall at once become due and collectible, and the commissioner of finance shall, without further notice proceed to collect by the sale of tax liens as directed for the collection of the city taxes, and such tax lien shall be subject to the same fees, charges and penalties as in the case of city taxes. 
In the event that the common council determines to permit the payment of such assessments in installments the notice as to amount and purpose of the assessment provided for in section one hundred fifteen of the charter of the city of White Plains, shall, in addition to other requirements, state that such privilege will be granted and the times when such installments will be payable and the rate of interest such deferred assessments will bear. 
(L.L. No. 3-1931, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1933, § 1; L.L. No. 8-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 68; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 17; L. L. No. 1-2001, § 5) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate manner of conducting its affairs, General City Law, § 20(19).  
Sec. 207. - Condemnation; when title vests; interest on awards; excess condemnation. 
In any case in which the city of White Plains shall begin a proceeding for the condemnation of any land or easement therein, the city of White Plains shall upon the filing of the oaths of the commissioners appointed in any such condemnation proceeding in the office of the clerk of the county of Westchester be and become seized in fee title of all such parcels of real estate and easements and the said city of White Plains may immediately or at any time thereafter take possession of the same, or of any part or parts thereof, and the said city or any officer or employee thereof may enter upon and use and occupy in perpetuity all the parcels of real estate described in the proceedings for the acquisition thereof. Interest upon any award made for the acquisition of real estate or any easement therein shall be computed from the date of the filing of the oaths of such commissioners in the office of the county clerk of Westchester county, and shall be paid to the owner or owners of such real estate when the award for the acquisition of the land or easement shall be paid. The city is authorized to take more land and property than is needed for actual construction in the laying out, widening, extending or relocating parks, public places, highways or streets; provided, however, that the additional land and property so authorized to be taken shall be no more than sufficient to form suitable building sites abutting on such park, public place, highway or street. 
(Laws 1953, Ch. 64, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 69) 
State Law reference— Condemnation proceedings, Eminent Domain Procedure Law, § 1 et seq.  
Sec. 207-a. - Sale of excess property acquired by the city. 
When the city has acquired more land and property than is needed for the actual construction in the laying out, widening, extending or relocating parks, public places, highways or streets, and the common council shall by ordinance determine that such land so acquired is not needed for public use, the common council may direct that such land or property be sold at private sale to an adjoining property owner for a stipulated sum determined by the common council as a fair and reasonable price and upon such terms and conditions as the common council may deem appropriate, provided, however, that the additional land and property so authorized to be sold is not of sufficient size to create a suitable building lot in compliance with the zoning ordinance of the city of White Plains in those districts which impose minimum lot size requirements and in districts which have no minimum lot size requirements, such additional land or property to be sold shall not have a street frontage in excess of fifteen (15) feet, except that corner lots shall not have a street frontage in excess of fifteen (15) feet on one street but may have a street frontage in excess of fifteen (15) feet on the other street. 
(L.L. No. 7-1968, § 1) 
Editor's note— Sec. 2 of Intro. L.L. No. 7-1968 provided that any provision of General City Law, § 23, subdivision 2, paragraph (b) in conflict with said local law be superseded.  
Sec. 208. - Preparation of assessment map for local improvements not required. 
Whenever any assessment for a local improvement is to be levied upon the city of White Plains at large, or upon any part thereof, a separate assessment map shall not be required to be made, notwithstanding any provisions of this charter, but in such case, the official city map shall be and it shall be construed as being such assessment map and such assessment shall be made according to the ward, block and lot numbers shown upon the tax map authorized by this charter or by the real property tax law. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 70)  
Sec. 209. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 209 was repealed by sec. 18 of L.L. No. 1-1990.  
Sec. 210. - Partial payments. 
The commissioner of finance, upon the certification of the commissioner of public works pursuant to section two hundred eleven of this charter, of the value of the work done from time to time during the construction, may pay the contractor, to apply upon the contract price of the work, not to exceed the following percentages of the total value of the work done: seventy-five per centum (75%) when the total value of the work done is not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), eighty per centum (80%) when such value is more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), eighty-five per centum (85%) when such value is more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), and not more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), ninety per centum (90%) when such value is more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and not more than one hundred thousand dollars and ninety-three per centum (93%) when such value exceeds one hundred thousand dollars; but such payment shall not be used as evidence against the city that the work already done has been completed according to contract, nor shall it preclude the city from contesting the claims of the contractor that the work has been completed according to contract. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 73; L.L. No. 2-1971, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 2-1971, sec. 1, amended sec. 210 by establishing an upper limit of $100,000.00 for the 90% payment, and adding the 93% payment.  
Sec. 211. - Partial completion of public work to be certified; partial estimates; semi-final estimates. 
Before the claim of a contractor for the doing of any portion of any public work for the city of White Plains shall be paid, the engineer designated by the commissioner of public works, or other representative of such commissioner, shall certify to the commissioner of public works the amount of work performed and the value thereof and the commissioner's partial estimate shall state the amount of work performed by the contractor and also the value of the work according to the terms of the contract and he shall certify the same. Whenever, in the opinion of the engineer designated by the commissioner of public works, or other representative of such commissioner, a contractor furnishing public work to the city of White Plains shall have substantially performed his contract, such engineer, or representative, shall so certify to the commissioner of public works and the commissioner may issue a semi-final estimate which shall state the amount of work performed and to be performed and shall provide for withholding a sufficient sum of money to cover the value of any incompleted work and such other monies as, by the terms of the contract, are to be retained during the period of maintenance if any such maintenance is required. The date of the semi-final estimate shall be the date of substantial completion of the work, and, in the discretion of the commissioner of public works, shall be the date upon which the period of maintenance shall begin. Within ten (10) days after certification of a partial or semi-final estimate, the commissioner of public works shall file such certificate of partial or semi-final estimate with the commissioner of finance. Such certificate of partial or semi-final payment and any payment pursuant thereto shall in no wise conclude and bind the city in any action or proceedings against the contractor, or his sureties, to recover for damages on account of the failure of the contractor to perform said contract according to its true intent and meaning. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 75)  
Sec. 212. - Completion of work to be certified; final estimate. 
Whenever in the opinion of the engineer designated by the commissioner of public works, or other representative of such commissioner, a contractor furnishing public work to the city of White Plains shall have completely performed his contract except maintenance, such engineer, or representative, shall so certify to the commissioner of public works and the commissioner's final estimate shall state from actual measurements the whole amount of work performed by the contractor and also the total value of work performed under and according to the terms of the contract, and he shall certify the same. All prior certificates upon which partial or semi-final payments have been made, being merely approximate estimates, shall be subject to correction in the final estimate, which final estimate may be made without notice to the contractor or of notice of the measurements upon which it is based. The final estimate shall act as and have the same force and effect as the engineer's or representative's certificate of completion. The date of the final estimate shall be the date of completion of the work and shall be the date upon which the period of maintenance shall begin, except as otherwise provided in section two hundred eleven for a semi-final estimate. Within ten (10) days after certification of the final estimate, the commissioner of public works shall file such certificate of final estimate with the commissioner of finance. Such certificate of final estimate, and any payment pursuant thereof, shall in no wise conclude and bind the city in any action or proceedings against the contractor or his sureties to recover for damages on account of the failure of the contractor to perform said contract according to its true intent and meaning. The acceptance of payment by the contractor of the final estimate shall operate as and shall be a release to the city and the commissioner of public works and his agents from all claims and liability from anything done or furnished for or relating to the work, or from any act or neglect of the city, or of any agent, relating to or affecting the work, excepting a claim against the city for the remainder, if any, of the amounts kept or retained. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 77)  
Sec. 212-a. - Period of maintenance; acceptance of work. 
Any contractor furnishing public work to the city of White Plains shall be responsible for the entire work until the time of its acceptance as hereinafter provided and shall also keep and maintain every portion of it in perfect order and repair for a period of six (6) months after the completion of said work or, in the discretion of the commissioner of public works, after substantial completion of said work, excepting in regard to such damages as may be directly caused by the city of White Plains, its agents or servants, and excepting in cases where in the opinion of the commissioner of public works, by the nature of the work, no maintenance is involved. If the termination of said six (6) month period shall fall within the months of December, January, February, March or April, the period of maintenance shall extend to the first day of May next thereafter. At the conclusion of the said period of maintenance or, if there be no period of maintenance as provided hereinabove, then upon the completion of the work as provided hereinabove the work may be accepted provided it be then in good order and repair, that it conform entirely with the required lines, grades, and dimensions, and if all other obligations on the part of the contractor under his contract have been fulfilled. If at any time during the period of maintenance the contractor, after notice by the engineer, shall fail to promptly repair and/or make good any defect or damage in the work, then and in that case the commissioner of public works shall have the right to cause such defect or damage to be repaired and made good by the city's own forces or by such other parties as may be selected by said commissioner, and to charge to the contractor the cost of all labor, materials, plant, equipment and other incidental expenses necessary to such repair and making good. Said cost shall be deducted from the contractor's retained percentage. All questions or disputes in regard to repairs required during the period of maintenance shall be resolved by the commissioner of public works, whose determination shall be conclusive. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 78)  
Sec. 213. - Contracts to be let. 
Except as otherwise provided by law, all contracts for public work involving an expenditure of more than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000) and all purchase contracts for any city department, board or officer involving an expenditure of more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder, who will give adequate security for the performance of his contract, after public notice, and in accordance with the regulations to be prescribed by general ordinances of the common council unless by an ordinance passed by a vote of at least five (5) members of the common council, it is determined, for the reason set forth in such ordinance, for the best interests of the city, to procure the work or materials by contract, or, unless in case of accident or other injury, by which the heating or plumbing system of any of the public buildings, or by which any of the fire engines or hook and ladder trucks, or any machinery used in connection with the department of public works, shall become disabled, or unless a severe snow fall shall occur, in which emergency the commissioner of the appropriate department shall cause such repairs thereto to be made, or hire trucks and other equipment for snow removal, upon filing with the mayor a certificate, showing such emergency and the necessity for such repairs or the hiring of equipment for snow removal; provided, however, that the mayor endorses his approval on such certificate. The officer or employee of the city receiving bids shall reject all bids if, in his opinion, the lowest bid is excessive. Should the commissioner of public works deem bids for the construction of the public improvements excessive he may readvertise or, if he deems it best for the interests of the city to reject all bids offered and undertake said work by day labor, he shall withhold action on said bids and refer the matter to the common council for further consideration and in case said common council shall deem it best for the interests of the city that said bids be rejected and the work done by day labor, it may do so, and in such case the work shall be done by the commissioner of public works. The public notice above mentioned must describe the work and materials for which contracts will be let, and the day, hour and place of such letting. Specifications for every public improvement must be prepared and set forth with such detail as will adequately inform all persons proposing to bid, of the nature of the work to be done and of the materials to be supplied, and the same shall be printed or typewritten, and copies thereof shall be delivered to applicants therefor. All materials and supplies required in any office, court, board or department, except as otherwise provided by law, shall be called for in writing and shall be contracted for in the manner above provided, but where any work or repairs needed to be done or materials or supplies to be furnished shall not exceed the limitations heretofore specified in this section in cost, the officer or employee of the city in charge of purchasing such materials and supplies may authorize the head of the department, or officer, as the case may be, to give written orders therefor, and the bills so incurred shall be presented to the commissioner of finance for examination and audit accompanied with such orders. But no work or repairs to be done or materials or supplies to be furnished as above provided shall be subdivided so as to make the cost not to exceed the limitations heretofore specified in this section, if the total of such works or repairs needed to be done or materials or supplies to be furnished shall exceed the limitations heretofore specified in this section in cost. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 18; L.L. No. 6-1951, § 1; L.L. No. 8-1952, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1956, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1972, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1973, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1978, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1984, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1992, § 1; L.L. No. 2-2010, § 1) 
State Law reference— Public contracts, General Municipal Law, § 100 et seq.; letting of contracts, General Municipal Law, § 103.  
Sec. 214. - Contracts to be based upon estimates. 
Every contract for public improvement within the city shall be based upon estimates of the whole cost of such improvement furnished by the proper officer, board or department having charge of the improvement. No contract shall be let except after the receipt of bids, except as otherwise provided by law. All bids must in addition be endorsed with the title of the work to which they relate, the name of the bidder and his residence. 
(L.L. No. 5-1933, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 79)  
Sec. 215. - Bid security. 
Each bid shall be accompanied by a certified check or draft accepted by a New York state bank, payable to the city of White Plains, and by such other security, in the form and in the amount which shall be specified in the advertisement therefor and which instruments shall be held by the city as security that the person or persons to whom the contract shall be awarded shall enter into a contract therefor and give security required for the performance thereof. All such instruments shall be in a form acceptable to and approved by the commissioner of finance. 
(L.L. No. 4-1967, § 81; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 19) 
State Law reference— Security required, General Municipal Law, § 103.  
Sec. 216. - Opening of bids. 
Bids shall be received by the commissioner of public works at the place and up to the time mentioned in the public notice required by this charter. At such time and place all bids shall be opened by the commissioner of public works and shall be read aloud, and an abstract of all of them, with the prices and security offered, shall be copied in a book kept for that purpose without any change, correction or addition whatever in the bids as received. All bidders shall have the privilege of being present when the bids are opened. The commissioner of public works may refuse all bids received and may advertise again for new bids to be received at another date as above provided. No bidder shall have the right to withdraw or cancel his bid until the commissioner of public works shall have awarded the contract for which such bid is made and the same shall have been duly executed, except that the check or draft of all bidders, except the three (3) lowest, shall be returned within three (3) business days after the formal opening of bids, and the check or draft of the three (3) lowest bidders shall be returned within two (2) business days after the city and accepted bidder have executed the contract or if no contract has been so executed within forty-five (45) days after the opening of bids, upon demand of the bidder at any time thereafter, so long as he has not been notified of the acceptance of his bid. 
(L.L. No. 1-1951, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 82) 
State Law reference— Opening of bids, General Municipal Law, § 103(2); disposition of deposit accompanying bid, General Municipal Law, § 105.  
Sec. 217. - Bonds for performance of contract. 
The bonds to be given for the performance of any contract for any public work awarded under the provisions of section two hundred thirteen of this charter shall be: (a) a performance bond and a labor and material payment bond and each bond shall be in the penalty of one hundred per centum (100%) of the contract price, and shall be executed by the party to whom the work is awarded, and by a solvent fidelity, insurance or surety company authorized by the laws of this state to transact such business, or (b) such other performance security in like amount in a form acceptable to and approved by the commissioner of finance. All such performance security shall meet with the approval of the corporation counsel of the city of White Plains as to adequacy, form and correctness, provided however that the common council may, in its discretion waive said security requirements for contracts which are not in excess of fifteen thousand dollars in amount. If said security requirement is waived, no monies shall be paid by the city under the contract until the Commissioners of Public Works and Finance take reasonable steps in accordance with the provisions of the Labor Law to ascertain that the labor and material expenses as incurred pursuant to the performances of the contract are paid. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 19; L.L. No. 4-1967, § 83, L.L. No. 1-1978, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 20)  
Sec. 218. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 218 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1967, sec. 84. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 218-a. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 218-a as added by Laws 1928, Ch. 425 was repealed by L.L. No. 9-1952, sec. 1. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.

Sec. 219. - Commissioner of public safety. 
The commissioner of public safety shall have charge and supervision of the fire and police departments and the bureaus of control of animals, bus terminal and weights and measures of the said city and shall provide in all ways possible for the safety, care, comfort and protection of the inhabitants of the city and of their property; and he shall have such further powers and duties as may be provided by ordinance of the common council. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 10; L.L. No. 2-1932, § 3; L.L. No. 7-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 1)  
Sec. 220. - Powers and duties of commissioner of public safety. 
The commissioner of public safety shall have jurisdiction, supervision and control of the government, administration, disposition and discipline of the officers and members of the fire and police departments; and shall possess and exercise fully and exclusively all powers and perform all duties pertaining to the government, maintenance and direction of the fire department, and the apparatus and property thereof, and buildings furnished therefor and of the police department and equipment furnished therefor, and shall have the general direction and supervision of the expenditure of all moneys appropriated to the department of public safety. He shall have authority to administer oaths and take evidence, affidavits and acknowledgments in all matters and proceedings pertaining to the department of public safety. He shall have the power to make rules and regulations, approved by the common council in regard to the government, administration, disposition and discipline of the fire department and the police department. Such rules and regulations may provide for the hearing, examination, investigation, trial and determination of charges made or prepared against any officer or member of said departments for neglect of official duty or incompetency or incapacity to perform his official duties, or some delinquency seriously affecting his general character or fitness for the office, and may, in his discretion, punish any officer or member found guilty thereof by reprimand, imposition of fines or by the forfeiture and withholding pay for a specified time, suspension during a fixed period or dismissal from office; but no officer or member of said departments shall be removed or otherwise punished for any other cause, until specified charges in writing have been preferred against and served upon him and he shall have been found guilty thereof, after reasonable notice and upon due trial by the aforesaid commissioner of public safety in the form and manner prescribed by the rules and regulations of his department. He shall have power to appoint all officers and members of the fire department and the police department, subject to civil service rules and regulations, to such positions in said departments as are established by the common council, either by special ordinance or by incorporation in the city budget and to fill all vacancies therein and to remove the officers and members thereof for cause, pursuant to law. He may also appoint special police officers for such purposes and upon such occasions as may seem to him proper and not inconsistent with this charter. The persons so appointed shall exercise their powers in accordance with the rules and regulations of the police department of the city of White Plains. He shall have general supervision over the records of the department of public safety and its officers and employees and shall possess such other powers and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law or by resolution of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 2-1932, § 5; L.L. No. 7-1952, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 2; L.L. No. 1-1990, § 21)  
Sec. 221. - Constitution of fire department and the police department. 
The fire department shall consist of the paid division and the volunteer division, and shall be supervised by the chief of the fire department and such other officers as the common council shall authorize. The police department shall consist of the paid division and the auxiliary police division and shall be supervised by the chief of the police department and such other officers as the common council shall authorize. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 3)  
Sec. 222. - Election and approval of officers of the volunteer fire division. 
The volunteer fire division shall be constituted of the existing volunteer fire companies and with the approval of the commissioner of public safety, shall have the power to elect a first assistant chief and a second assistant chief, to be elected from the several companies. Each company shall have power to elect a captain, lieutenants, a president and such other officers as are necessary and to select members to fill any vacancies which may occur in their ranks. They may adopt by-laws, subject to the approval of the commissioner of public safety for the government of their respective companies, and may impose fines and forfeits for the violation of the same. The commissioner may remove any member on the ground of incompetence or misconduct after a hearing upon due notice and upon stated charges with the right of such officer and member to a review pursuant to article seventy-eight of the civil practice law and rules. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1981, § 1)  
Sec. 223. - Powers and duties of the chief of the fire department. 
The chief of the fire department, under the direction and control of the commissioner of public safety, shall have the supervision and management of the officers, employees and members of the department. He shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by law, by the direction of the commissioner or by ordinance of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 5)  
Sec. 224. - City not liable for acts or omissions. 
The chief of the fire department, officers, employees and members of the fire department are not officers or agents of the municipal corporation known as the city of White Plains, for whose acts or omissions the said corporation shall be held liable in a civil action for injuries to person or property. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 6)  
Sec. 225. - Destruction of buildings to prevent spread of fire. 
The commissioner or deputy commissioner of public safety, or the chief or a deputy chief of the fire department, may cause to be pulled down or destroyed any building which he shall, in relation to such fire, deem hazardous or likely to communicate fire to any other building or buildings, and no action shall be maintained against the city of White Plains, or against any person therefor, except as set forth in this section. 
A person claiming damages as a result of any building so pulled down or destroyed, or in any personal property therein destroyed, shall present to the common council a verified claim therefor within ninety (90) days after such building is pulled down or destroyed. The common council may agree with such person upon the amount of damages to be allowed him. If this agreement is not made within thirty (30) days after the presentation of the claim, the person presenting it may apply to the supreme court for the appointment of three (3) commissioners to determine the compensation to which he is entitled. Notice of the application must be served upon the mayor at least ten (10) days before the hearing thereof. All proceedings subsequent to the appointment of the commissioners shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of the condemnation law so far as applicable. The common council or such commissioners shall, in determining the compensation, reduce the amount of compensation as finally determined by the amount recoverable by the claimant under any fire or other insurance policies. The amount agreed upon for such damages, or the award therefor, together with the costs, if any, allowed to the claimant, shall be a charge against the city and shall be paid out of funds available or made available. 
No proceeding or action under this section shall be maintained against the city unless the same shall be commenced within one year after such building is so pulled down or destroyed. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 7) 
State Law reference— Notice of claim condition precedent to commencement of suit, General Municipal Law, § 50-e; commencement of suit one year and ninety days after the happening of the event on which claim is based, General Municipal Law, § 50-i.  
Sec. 226. - Powers of the commissioner of public safety over abandoned vehicles. 
The commissioner of public safety shall have the authority to administer the provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law with respect to abandoned vehicles. He is authorized to convert to the use of the city unclaimed abandoned and/or scofflaw vehicles to the extent permitted by state law and city ordinance. 
(L.L. No. 3-1979, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 22)  
Secs. 227—229. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 226—229 were repealed by L.L. No. 2-1932, sec. 7. Said section numbers are retained by the editors to maintain sequence. Subsequently, L.L. No. 3-1979, sec. 1, added a new § 226.  
Secs. 230—238. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 230—238 were repealed by L.L. No. 4-1968, sec. 8. Said section numbers are retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
ARTICLE VIII-B. - DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION[13] 
Section 
238-b.
Commissioner of recreation and parks. 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32. 
Code reference— Parks and recreation, Tit. VI. 
State Law reference— Authority to lay out, construct, establish, operate and maintain parks and playgrounds, General City Law, § 20(7); to provide for swimming pools, General Municipal Law, § 242. 
 
Sec. 238-b. - Commissioner of recreation and parks. 
The commissioner of recreation and parks, subject to the supervision and control of the common council, shall manage and have charge of public recreation and the equipment, and operation of playgrounds, recreation centers and all other recreation areas in the city. He shall also, subject to the supervision and control of the common council, have charge of all public parks and other park lands in the city. He shall also exercise such other powers and perform such other duties as may be conferred or imposed upon him from time to time by the common council. The commissioner of recreation and parks may make such rules and regulations not inconsistent with any general, special or local law or ordinance for the government and discipline of the department of recreation and parks and its staff. 
(L.L. No. 4-1940, § 2; L.L. No. 4-1961, § 3; L.L. No. 2-2003, § 2) 
Cross reference— City officers generally, § 6 et seq.  
ARTICLE VIII-D. - DEPARTMENT OF PERSONNEL[15] 
Section 
238-f.
Department of personnel; purpose. 
238-g.
Personnel officer; term of office, duties and prerogatives. 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32; annual reports of departments, § 287. 
Code references— Officers and employees, Ch. 2-5; civil service rules, § 2-5-171 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to determine and regulate number, mode of selection, qualifications, etc., of officers and employees; to create a municipal civil service, General City Law, § 20(17), (18). 
 
Sec. 238-f. - Department of personnel; purpose. 
A department of personnel is hereby established in the city of White Plains. The purpose of the department is to assist the common council in establishing a comprehensive personnel policy covering recruitment, employee safety, training, compensation, labor relations management and salary, and fringe benefits, administration; to establish standards for and to develop procedures thereon covering individual job performance with the objective of counseling and utilizing personnel to the best advantage, improving efficiency and effectiveness, to recommend to the common council standards and procedures with reference to city personnel, and to exercise such powers and perform such duties as may be conferred and imposed by or pursuant to the civil service law. 
(L.L. No. 6-1952, § 1; Laws 1972, Ch. 843, § 1)  
Sec. 238-g. - Personnel officer; term of office, duties and prerogatives. 
The term of office of the personnel officer shall be for six years. 
The personnel officer shall be in charge of the personnel department. The duties and prerogatives shall be as follows: 
(a)  To have all the powers and duties of a municipal civil service commission. 
(b)  To have general supervision over the department and its personnel, and when authorized by the common council, to appoint members of the staff of the personnel department. 
(c)  To carry out the stated purposes of the personnel department. 
(L.L. No. 6-1952, § 1; Laws 1972, Ch. 843, §§ 2, 3; L.L. No. 4-1976, § 5) 
Code reference— Personnel officer authorized to appoint representative, § 2-5-1.  
ARTICLE VIII-E. - DEPARTMENT OF PURCHASE 
Section 
238-h.
Department of purchase; purpose. 
238-i.
Commissioner of purchase; duties and prerogatives. 
 
Sec. 238-h. - Department of purchase; purpose. 
A department of purchase is hereby established in the city of White Plains. The purpose of the department, so far as is consistent and not in conflict with any general, special or local law, is that said department shall have sole power to purchase, store and distribute all supplies, materials and equipment required by any department, office, board, body or commission of the city and, if authorized by the common council, to establish and maintain one or more city storehouses and to maintain on hand a sufficient stock of staple commodities to supply the estimated current needs of the agencies for which the department is authorized to purchase. In addition, the department shall be empowered to sell, trade or otherwise dispose of, all surplus or obsolete supplies, materials and equipment no longer required by the city. 
(L.L. No. 11-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1969, § 1)  
Sec. 238-i. - Commissioner of purchase; duties and prerogatives. 
The department of purchase shall be in charge of the commissioner of purchase. The duties and prerogatives of the commissioner of purchase shall be as follows: 
(a)  To have general supervision over the department and its personnel. 
(b)  To make rules and regulations for the conduct of the department and for the requisition for and distribution of supplies, materials and equipment, and the disposition of surplus or obsolete supplies, materials and equipment no longer required by the city. 
(c)  Such other powers and duties as may be prescribed by law or by ordinance or resolution of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 11-1952, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1969, § 2)  
ARTICLE VIII-F. - TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION[16] 
Section 
238-j.
Transportation commission. 
238-k.
Duties of the commission. 
238-l.
Commission meetings and support. 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative powers of city vested in common council, § 32; department of public safety, § 219 et seq.; department of planning, § 238-x et seq. 
Code references— Traffic and street regulation, Tit. VIII; highway safety committee, § 8-1-1; basic traffic ordinance, Ch. 8-2. 
State Law reference— Authority to create traffic commission; composition, duties of same, General City Law, § 20(32). 
 
Sec. 238-j. - Transportation commission. 
(a)  It is hereby declared as a matter of public policy that the effective regulation and control of vehicular, bicycle, and pedestrian traffic is necessary to promote public safety; to protect human life, health, and property; and to serve the public convenience. 
(b)  The Transportation Commission ("the Commission") is established and given certain specific duties, specified below, to enable the Common Council to more effectively administer transportation-related matters; respond to the citizenry; and to insure the provision of safe, accessible, and efficient transportation systems to meet the needs of the City. 
(c)  The Mayor shall appoint ten persons as members of the Transportation Commission, including, serving ex officio , the Commissioner of Public Safety, the Commissioner of Public Works, the Commissioner of Planning, the Commissioner of Parking, the Deputy Commissioner of Parking responsible for transportation engineering, the Chair of the Capital Projects Board, and the Corporation Counsel, and three members who represent the diversity of the users of the transportation network with respect to modes of travel ( e.g. walkers, bicyclists, transit riders, drivers of motor vehicles), special needs ( e.g. , schoolchildren, senior citizens, persons with disabilities) and tenure ( e.g. , residents, business owners, commuters). The Mayor shall designate any one of the members to be the Chair of the Commission. 
(d)  The appointment of members shall be for a term expiring at the end of the term of the Mayor, and the terms of office of their successors shall also expire on the same day as the expiration of the term of the Mayor who appoints them. Each member shall continue to serve until the appointment and qualification of his or her successor. Vacancies on the Commission occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term and the appointment must be made in accordance with the criteria established for original appointments. The members of the Commission shall choose from their number a vice chair who shall preside over the meetings in the absence of the Chair. The ex officio members of the commission shall serve without additional compensation and the other members shall serve without pay for their services rendered pursuant to this article, but all members shall be allowed their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties under this article. The powers of the Commission shall be vested in and exercised by a majority of the members of the Commission then in office. 
(L.L. No. 1-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 10-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1968, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 6; L.L. No. 4-1979, § 3; L.L. No. 2-2006, § 3; L.L. No. 3-2012, § 3; L.L. 4-2014, § 1 )  
Sec. 238-k. - Duties of the commission. 
The duties of the Commission shall be to: 
(1)  Make such procedural rules and regulations as necessary to conform with law and to properly conduct business. 
(2)  Collect and compile transportation-related data, engineering studies, planning studies, and surveys in regard to vehicular, bicycle, public transit, and pedestrian traffic in the City. 
(3)  Prepare and submit to the Mayor detailed reports in regard to transportation conditions in the City. 
(4)  Make recommendations to the Mayor in regard to methods of ameliorating transportation conditions which adversely affect the welfare of the City and which cannot be remedied by traffic ordinances or regulations. 
(5)  Submit to the Mayor, for consideration and forwarding to the appropriate City departments and agencies, specific proposals for amendments of ordinances, rules and regulations of the City and City agencies which affect transportation conditions in the City, and proposed legislation which the Commission deems necessary or proper to implement and effectuate its proposals. 
(6)  Prepare and submit to the Mayor, for consideration and forwarding to the Common Council, the Planning Board, the Parking Department and to other appropriate agencies and departments of the City, recommendations and proposals in regard to the improvement of existing streets, street widening, alterations, traffic calming measures, and the location of new streets, avenues and highways; the location and establishment of off-street public parking area and garages; and of off-street loading and unloading and parking facilities; sidewalks, bike lanes, and bus and rail facilities; and other matters relating to traffic control. 
(7)  Coordinate the efforts of and consider the reports, recommendations and suggestions of public and private agencies and civic groups or citizens regarding issues related to all modes of transportation and take action or make recommendations to the Common Council as appropriate. 
(8)  Collaborate with other City departments and agencies in promoting traffic safety and the free movement of all modes of transportation. 
(9)  Obtain and consider analyses of traffic collisions involving all modes of transportation with a view to determining their causes and means for their prevention. 
(10)  Study and make recommendations to the Mayor, for consideration and forwarding to the Common Council, and City departments and agencies on the location and use of street parking meters and the location and erection of traffic signs, signals, markings and devices, and as to type and intensity of illumination of streets and highways. 
(11)  Review and consider traffic matters relating to planned development and make recommendations to the Common Council regarding these issues. 
(L.L. No. 1-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 2-2006, § 4; L.L. 4-2014, § 1 )  
Sec. 238-l. - Commission meetings and support. 
(a)  The Commission shall schedule stated meetings, as determined by its own rules. All meetings of the Commission are open to the public. Any member of the public who wishes to present matters or suggestions for consideration of the Commission may do so, provided that he or she gives the required notice to the Commission staff coordinator, and further provided that such item is placed on the agenda of the Commission for discussion at such meeting. 
(b)  The staff of the Transportation Commission shall consist of the Commissioner of the Parking Department or his or her appointed representative, a Deputy Commissioner of Public Works, the senior officer in charge of the traffic division of the Police Department, the assistant traffic engineer or other designee of the Deputy Commissioner of Parking responsible for transportation engineering who shall serve as staff coordinator, and one member appointed by the Mayor from the Department of Parking. Said staff members shall attend the meetings of the Transportation Commission and the staff as a whole shall be responsible for staff reports requested by the Commission, and for the preparation and distribution of minutes of Commission meetings. 
(c)  The Commission, when authorized by the Common Council, may engage in transportation engineers or other expert assistants on a consulting basis to supplement said staff when necessary for effectuation of the Commission's duties. 
(L.L. No. 1-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 3-1956, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1958, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1972, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 7; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 26; L.L. No. 2-2006, § 5; L.L. No. 3-2012, § 4; L.L. 4-2014, § 1 )  
ARTICLE VIII-H. - CAPITAL PROJECTS BOARD[18] 
Section 
238-p.
Definitions. 
238-q.
Capital projects board. 
238-r.
Estimates and reports of city departments and agencies. 
238-s.
Board of recommendations. 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative powers of city vested in common council, § 32; department of finance, § 51 et seq. 
State Law reference— Capital improvement defined, General Municipal Law, §§ 6-c(1b), 6-g(1); planning for future capital improvements, capital program, General Municipal Law, §§ 99-d, 99-g. 
 
Sec. 238-p. - Definitions. 
As used in this article the term "capital project" shall mean: (a) any physical public improvement or betterment, or any preliminary studies, surveys or plans relative thereto; (b) the acquisition of property of a permanent nature; (c) the purchase of equipment for any public improvement or betterment when first erected or acquired; and (d) the allocation of reserve funds for acquisition of vehicles and major equipment for all departments. The term "pending" shall mean appropriated, reserved or authorized but not yet completed. 
(L.L. No. 8-1954, § 1)  
Sec. 238-q. - Capital projects board. 
The capital projects board shall consist of ten persons, seven of whom shall be the commissioner of finance, the commissioner of public works, the commissioner of public safety, the commissioner of planning, the commissioner of recreation and parks, the commissioner of parking and the budget director, or a respective deputy of any such commissioner to be designated by the mayor, ex officio, and the mayor shall appoint a member of the planning board and two members of the common council. The mayor shall appoint one of the said councilmen as the chairman of the board. The term of each member appointed by the mayor shall be for two years. Each member shall continue to serve until the appointment and qualification of his successor. Vacancies in such board, except for ex officio members, occurring otherwise than by expiration of the term shall be filled by appointment by the mayor for the unexpired term. The members of the board shall choose from their number a vice-chairman and a secretary from their number or from the staff of the department of budget. The ex officio members of the board shall serve without additional compensation and the other members shall serve without pay for their services rendered pursuant to this article, but all members shall be allowed their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties under this article. The powers of the board shall be vested in and be exercised by a majority of the members of the board then in office. 
(L.L. No. 8-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 10; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 8; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 6; L.L. No. 8-1979, § 1; L.L. No. 7-1982, § 6; L.L. No. 1-1986, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 27; L.L. No. 3-2012, § 6)  
Sec. 238-r. - Estimates and reports of city departments and agencies. 
Not later than the first day of October in each year all heads of departments, officers and other agencies of the city shall submit to the budget director and to the capital projects board, on forms to be supplied by said board: 
(a)  estimates and details of their capital project expenditures proposed for the ensuing fiscal year; 
(b)  detailed reports of all pending capital projects; 
(c)  recommendations for new capital undertakings within the six (6) succeeding fiscal years; and 
(d)  any other information deemed pertinent by the board. 
Said heads of departments, officers and agencies shall have the right, and it shall be their duty, when requested by the board, to appear and to be heard. The board may consult with the board of education of the city school district of the city of White Plains in order to consider and correlate their respective capital project programs insofar as may be practicable. 
(L.L. No. 8-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 11; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 7; L.L. No. 1-1982, § 3; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 28)  
Sec. 238-s. - Board of recommendations. 
Not later than the first day of February in each year, the board shall submit its report and recommendations to the budget director of new capital projects for the city to be included in the budget of the city for the ensuing fiscal year. Between the first day of October and the thirty-first day of January in each year, the board shall review the recommendations for new capital undertakings proposed for the ensuing fiscal year and for the six (6) succeeding fiscal years. The board shall include in its report to be made to the budget director not later than the first day of February in each year its recommendations as to such new capital undertakings, and the commissioner of budget shall include such report in his annual budget message. The board shall meet from time to time during the fiscal year and review the actual expenditures being made for capital projects under construction and compare such actual expenditures with the estimates of cost thereof made by the head of a department, officer or other agency of the city, or as revised by the capital projects board or the common council, both as to separate capital projects and as to the total of all capital projects whether financed in the budget or by capital notes or bonds and the board shall thereafter make such further recommendations, if any, to the common council as it may determine to be advisable. The common council may refer back to the capital projects board any capital projects under construction which it believes are exceeding the estimates of cost thereof made by the head of a department, officer or other agency of the city, or as revised by the capital projects board or the common council. In addition to reporting on such reference, the board may from time to time report and recommend with respect to any changes or modifications or other disposition of pending projects. 
(L.L. No. 8-1954, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 12; L.L. No. 1-1977, § 8; L.L. No. 1-1982, § 4; L.L. No. 1-1991, § 29)  
ARTICLE VIII-I. - DEPARTMENT OF BUILDING[19] 
Section 
238-t.
Department of building; purpose. 
238-u.
Commissioner of building; duties. 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative powers of city vested in common council, § 32; department of planning, § 238-x et seq.; annual reports of departments, § 287. 
Code reference— Zoning, planning, building and structures, Title IX. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate height, bulk, location of buildings, General City Law, § 20(24); uses thereof, General City Law, § 20(25); to provide for repair, removal of unsafe buildings, structures, General City Law, § 20(35). 
 
Sec. 238-t. - Department of building; purpose. 
A department of building is hereby established in the city of White Plains. Said department shall have jurisdiction over, and shall issue the permits for, all excavations, materials, manner of erection, construction, maintenance, alteration, repair, demolition, use, occupancy, sanitary conditions, safety, inspection, and all other work and matters concerning or relating to all buildings, exterior signs, structures, appurtenances and land in the city of White Plains, exclusive of public streets, and shall issue the certificates of occupancy, permits or licenses for the erection, repair and use of all such buildings, land, structures, signs and appurtenances except as may be otherwise provided for in this charter or by ordinance of the common council or any controlling state law or agency having jurisdiction. Said department shall have such other jurisdiction and powers as may from time to time be prescribed by law or be granted by ordinance or resolution of the common council. The purpose of said department shall be to secure the public safety, health and general welfare, and secure life and property from all hazards incident to design, construction, use, occupancy or work upon lands, buildings and structures in the city of White Plains, exclusive of public streets. Except as otherwise expressly provided in this charter or by controlling statute, or ordinance of the common council, the said department shall enforce all laws, ordinances, codes, rules and regulations as may govern said matters within the jurisdiction and powers of said department of building. 
(L.L. No. 4-1957, § 1) 
Code references— Building code, Ch. 9-5; plumbing code, Ch. 9-7; minimum housing standards, Ch. 9-8; special residence facilities, Ch. 9-9; signs, Ch. 9-10.  
Sec. 238-u. - Commissioner of building; duties. 
There shall be a commissioner of building who shall have jurisdiction, supervision and control of the department of building and of its operations and functions, records and files, and of all personnel of said department and the discipline thereof. He shall have authority to administer oaths and to take evidence, affidavits and acknowledgments in all matters and proceedings pertaining to the department, and shall have such other powers and duties as may be prescribed by law, or by ordinance or resolution of the common council. He shall have general direction and supervision of the expenditure of all monies appropriated to the department of building. 
(L.L. No. 4-1957, § 1)  
ARTICLE VIII-K. - DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING[21] 
Section 
238-x.
Department of planning; purposes. 
238-y.
Commissioner of planning; duties. 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Cross reference— Corporate powers of city, § 4; legislative power of city vested in common council, § 32; department of public safety, Art. VIII; traffic commission, Art. VIII-F; department of building, Art. VIII-I; annual reports of departments, § 287. 
Code references— Zoning, Ch. 9-2; planning, Ch. 9-3; subdivisions, Ch. 9-4. 
State Law reference— Planning boards generally, General City Law, § 27 et seq. 
 
Sec. 238-x. - Department of planning; purposes. 
A department of planning is hereby established in the city of White Plains. The purposes of the department, so far as is consistent and not in conflict with the general city law and the general municipal law of the state of New York and with any other general, special or local law are: To plan for the present and future development and improvement of the city of White Plains in any and all phases of its activities, whether governmental, proprietary or otherwise. Such activities shall include but not be limited to transportation planning, mass transportation routes, playgrounds, parks, public buildings, housing, public monuments, works of art, public streets and public utilities. 
Said planning department shall, through its commissioner of planning, advise the mayor and the common council with respect to the planning affairs of the city and shall furnish to the mayor and the common council at any time upon request such information and particulars as to planning as may be desired. Said department shall act upon all matters referred to it by the mayor or the common council and shall, if required or deemed necessary, report thereon to the mayor or the common council. Said department, through its commissioner of planning, shall be the adviser and consultant to the city planning board and shall prepare and furnish to the city planning board such reports, studies, plans, surveys or other data as may be necessary to aid and assist said planning board in the discharge of its duties. Said department shall have such other powers and duties as may be prescribed by law or by ordinance or resolution of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 2-1962, § 1; L.L. No. 5-1967, § 2; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 2)  
Sec. 238-y. - Commissioner of planning; duties. 
There shall be a commissioner of planning who shall have jurisdiction, supervision and control of the department of planning and of its operations and functions, records and files and of all personnel of said department and the discipline thereof. He shall have general direction and supervision of the expenditures of all moneys appropriated to the department of planning. He shall have such other powers and duties as may be prescribed by law or by ordinance or resolution of the common council. 
(L.L. No. 2-1962, § 1; L.L. No. 5-1967, § 3; L.L. No. 1-1976, § 3) 
Cross reference— City officers generally, Art. II.  
ARTICLE IX. - DEPARTMENT OF LAW[23]

Corporation counsel.

Powers and duties of corporation counsel.

Certification and approval of contracts and real property documents. 
242.
Compromises.

Counsel and advice.

Employment of special counsel.

Police to aid corporation counsel.
