Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Editor's note— Article X of Ch. 356, Laws 1915 entitled "Department of Public Instruction" and consisting of secs. 257—268 was repealed by Laws 1917, Ch. 786. The city school district is now a separate entity created by Laws 1950, Ch. 762 and having its own taxing powers (Education Law, § 2501 et seq.). The section numbers from Article X, Ch. 356, Laws 1915 were subsequently used in amending Article IX, Ch. 356, Laws 1915 entitled "Department of Judiciary." Article IX, together with amendments thereto, with the exception of sec. 267-x, was subsequently repealed by Laws 1944, Ch. 783, enacting "The City Court Act for the city of White Plains," sec. 267-x specifying the duties of the corporation counsel appears to be repealed by implication in the new Article IX added by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1968, sec. 14 and entitled "Department of Law." 
Code reference— Corporation counsel to keep records of notices of claims, § 2-1-5. 
 
Sec. 239. - Corporation counsel. 
There shall be a department of law, the head of which shall be the corporation counsel. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14) 
Cross reference— Qualifications, terms, etc., of city officers generally, Art. II.  
Sec. 240. - Powers and duties of corporation counsel. 
The corporation counsel shall have charge of and conduct all of the legal business of the municipal corporation which is the city of White Plains, including all of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions. 
He shall prepare contracts and other instruments in writing in which the city, its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions are concerned. 
He shall have charge of and conduct all legal actions and proceedings instituted for and on behalf of or against the city, including all of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions. He shall have authority to defend actions or proceedings against the city, including all of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions and take all steps and procedures necessary or advisable to protect the rights of the city, including all of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions. The corporation counsel shall not institute any actions or proceedings or take any appeals therein, without specific authorization of the common council, unless time limits are involved, or there is an emergency, in which event he may institute any such action, proceeding or appeal, provided that he apply at the next scheduled meeting of the common council to continue such procedure, unless the right to do so has been given by general authorization of the common council. All matters in which the city of White Plains or any of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards or commissions is a party in the city court of White Plains, and any appeals taken from a decision of the city court of White Plains in which the city is an interested party, including its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions, may be prosecuted, defended or appealed in the discretion of the corporation counsel. The corporation counsel may also institute actions or proceedings to enforce or defend ordinances or local laws of the city, without any general or specific authorization of the common council. 
In the conduct of the trial of any action or proceeding, the corporation counsel shall have all of the powers and privileges customarily exercised in the course of litigation by attorneys and counselors at law when acting for private clients. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Sec. 241. - Certification and approval of contracts and real property documents. 
No agreement providing for the payment of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more shall be entered into by the city or any of its officers, departments, bureaus, boards or commissions or shall be executed on behalf of the city until there shall be endorsed thereon by the corporation counsel or an attorney in the law department an approval as to form. The corporation counsel or an attorney in the law department shall approve all deeds, conveyances, leases and other documents affecting real property purchased, sold, leased or otherwise dealt in by the city prior to their execution. Any agreements or any real property documents made or executed in violation of this section shall be null and void as to the city and no money belonging to the city shall be paid thereon. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Sec. 242. - Compromises. 
The corporation counsel shall, whenever he considers that the best interests of the city will be served thereby, enter into an agreement in writing, subject to the approval of the common counsel [council], to compromise, settle, or adjust any rights, claims, demands, or causes of action in favor of or against the city of White Plains, its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions, and when so approved by the common council shall constitute a valid obligation against or in favor of the city, as the case may be. Any such obligations may be paid from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law as may be determined by the common council. The common council, may from time to time, adopt ordinances granting the corporation counsel such general or specific authorization. The corporation counsel shall not permit, offer or confess judgment against the city, its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions nor accept any offer of judgment in favor of the city, its officers, departments, bureaus, boards and commissions unless previously duly authorized, either generally or specifically, so to do by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Sec. 243. - Counsel and advice. 
The corporation counsel shall be the legal adviser to the common council and to each officer, department, bureau, board or commission of the city and shall, when requested, issue legal opinions. He shall furnish to the said common council, officer, department, bureau, board or commission all such advice and assistance as counsel and attorney, in and out of court, as may be required by them in their official capacity. 
No officer, department, bureau, board or commission of the city shall have or employ any attorney or counsel at the expense of the city unless specifically authorized so to do by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Sec. 244. - Employment of special counsel. 
The corporation counsel, with the written consent of the mayor, may employ counsel and experts at such compensation as may be agreed upon by the common council, to assist in the prosecution, defense, argument and conduct of actions or proceedings in which the city is interested or is a party. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Sec. 245. - Police to aid corporation counsel. 
It shall be the duty of every member of the police force of the city, observing or having any knowledge of any accident from which a cause of action might arise against the city, to forthwith report the facts of such accident in writing to the corporation counsel; and upon the request of the corporation counsel the commissioner of public safety shall detail some member of the force to aid the corporation counsel in the investigation of claims against the city for injuries to person or property. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 14)  
Secs. 246—249. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— See editor's note following title of Article IX.  
ARTICLE X. - DEPARTMENT OF PARKING[24] 
Section 
250.
Department of parking; commissioner of parking duties. 
251.
Civil service status of officers and employees. 
252—268. Reserved. 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note— Fomerly, Article X, consisting of secs. 268-a and 268-b, was repealed by Laws 1953, Ch. 878. Said article number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence. For a more complete explanation, see the editor's note following title of Article IX. 
 
Sec. 250. - Department of parking; commissioner of parking duties. 
There shall be a Department of Parking, the head of which shall be the Commissioner of Parking, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Common Council. Said position shall be in the unclassified service as defined in the civil service law. The Commissioner of Parking shall be under the general direction and supervision of the Mayor and shall manage the Department of Parking. The Commissioner of Parking is authorized to appoint a Deputy Commissioner of Parking I and a Deputy Commis sioner of Parking II who shall be in the exempt class of the classified service as defined in the civil service law. The Commissioner of Parking shall have the following powers and duties: 
a.  Appoint, direct and have authority to discharge all Department of Parking staff, and to coordinate the activities of the enforcement staff with the Department of Public Safety; 
b.  Prepare the annual budget for the Department of Parking; 
c.  Monitor and evaluate parking income and expenses and make recommendations on parking rates to the Common Council; 
d.  Direct and supervise the expenditure of Department of Parking funds; 
e.  Formulate policies and procedures for the operation of the Parking Department; 
f.  Plan for present and future parking facilities; 
g.  Direct and participate in comprehensive parking studies, developed internally or by outside consultants and make recommendations for future development or changes in existing facilities; 
h.  Make studies and recommendations and participate in decisions concerning location and use of street parking meters for the regulation of traffic, or restrictions in cooperation with other City departments and agencies; 
i.  Analyze and upgrade operational activities continually to respond to changing parking demands; 
j.  Research and recommend to the Mayor and Common Council on the types of parking operations and security and types of devices used for parking control; 
k.  Manage and have charge of maintenance and installation of all traffic control devices authorized by law for the control of pedestrian and vehicular traffic in highways, streets and other public places, including but not limited to signs, signals and markings, subject to the requirements of law for referral to the Transportation Commission and Common Council; 
l.  Authorize the deputy commissioner of parking responsible for transportation engineering to manage and be responsible for the design and operation of all traffic control devices authorized by law for the control of pedestrian and vehicular traffic in highways, streets and other public places, including but not limited to signs, signals and markings, subject to the requirements of law for referral to the Transportation Commission and Common Council; 
m.  In coordination with other planning agencies of the City and upon the recommendation of the deputy commissioner of parking responsible for transportation engineering, have charge of the planning for traffic and transportation, including but not limited to, development of traffic and transportation studies, surveys and reports and plans for both current and future needs; 
n.  Act upon all matters referred to him or her by the Common Council; 
o.  In addition thereto, with the recommendations of the deputy commissioner of parking responsible for transportation engineering, advise the Common Council, the Mayor and other agencies of the government as to the City's traffic requirements and the general provision of the welfare of the public with respect to traffic problems requiring assistance and guidance of other agencies of the City; 
p.  Enforce parking rules and regulations, including, but limited to, authorizing the issuance of appearance tickets by enforcement staff; and 
q.  Enforce concurrently with other designated City department officials and personnel, quality of life laws relating to littering, noise, graffiti, refuse disposal, dumping, peddling, bicycling/skateboarding on sidewalks or municipal parking facilities, shopping carts, signage, handbills, removal of snow and ice, dirt, debris, or foreign matter on sidewalks, obstructing or encumbering public streets, highways, or sidewalks, and custody and control of dogs, including but not limited to, authorizing the issuance of appearance tickets by enforcement staff assigned to same; and 
r.  Perform such other and further duties pertaining to his or her office, as from time to time be prescribed by law. 
(L.L. No. 1-2004, § 1; L.L. No. 2-2006, § 2; L.L. No. 3-2012, § 2; L.L. No. 3-2013, § 1; L.L. 4-2014, § 2 )  
Sec. 251. - Civil service status of officers and employees. 
Officers and employees of the White Plains Parking Authority shall be transferred to the Department of Parking in accordance with the provisions of the civil service law and shall be eligible for such transfer and appointment without examination to offices and positions in the Department of Parking. Such officers and employees who are members or beneficiaries of any existing pension or retirement system shall continue to have the rights, privileges, obligations and status as are now prescribed by law, and as they had under their original appointments. 
(L.L. No. 1-2004, § 1)  
Secs. 252—268. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC LIBRARIES[25] 
Section 
269.
City to maintain a public library. 
270.
Board of library trustees. 
271.
General powers of library trustees. 
272.
Appointment of library trustees. 
273.
Duties of the trustees. 
274.
Reports of library trustees. 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Cross reference— Funds for city library to be included in tax budget, § 61; annual reports of departments, § 287. 
State Law reference— Establishment, maintenance of free public library by municipality, General Municipal Law, § 79; Education Law, § 255 et seq. 
 
Sec. 269. - City to maintain a public library. 
The said city shall provide for and maintain a public library within its boundaries, said library to be known as the White Plains Public Library. Said library and its branches, if any, shall be entitled to all rights, powers, privileges, public moneys and other benefits conferred upon public libraries by law or other state authority and shall, except as otherwise provided in this act, be subject to all the rules, regulations, powers of inspection and superintendence prescribed by law, applicable to public libraries in the state of New York. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 16)  
Sec. 270. - Board of library trustees. 
The affairs of the White Plains public library shall be managed by a board of nine (9) members, eight (8) of whom shall be appointed in the manner provided elsewhere in this act, and the ninth shall be the superintendent of public schools acting ex-officio, which board shall be known and designated as the board of trustees of the White Plains public library. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 17; L.L. No. 2-1995, § 1)  
Sec. 271. - General powers of library trustees. 
Said board shall possess all the powers conferred, and discharge all the duties imposed by this act or by any general law of this state relating to public libraries and not inconsistent with the purpose of this act. All moneys and funds belonging to or received by said public library shall be paid over and delivered to the commissioner of finance. All the rights, powers, privileges, obligations and liabilities of said White Plains public library shall be vested in and be imposed upon this board except as otherwise provided for in this act. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 18)  
Sec. 272. - Appointment of library trustees. 
The common council shall annually in the month of January appoint two (2) residents of said city as members of the board of trustees of the White Plains public library. The common council may, at any time, appoint a resident of said city to fill any vacancy in the membership of said board caused by death or otherwise, whenever such vacancy shall occur. Each person so appointed shall, after due qualification, hold office during the term of three (3) years as measured from the first day of January preceding such appointment or until his successor has duly qualified, except when appointed to fill a vacancy and in such case to fill the unexpired term caused by such vacancy. 
(Laws 1917, Ch. 381, § 15; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 19)  
Sec. 273. - Duties of the trustees. 
Subject to the provisions of this act and to laws and regulations pertaining to public libraries in the state of New York, and subject to the control of the common council of said city, said board of trustees shall have power and it shall be its duty: 
(1)  To elect one of its members to serve as president of the board and another member to serve as secretary. Such elected officers shall perform the duties usually pertaining to their respective offices, subject to the provisions of this act and to the laws and regulations pertaining to public libraries in the state of New York. 
(2)  To have the exclusive care, custody, management and control of the public library of said city and all property pertaining thereto. 
(3)  To provide, with the approval of the common council, suitable rooms and buildings for said library and to supervise their care and maintenance. 
(4)  To appoint a director and to employ, subject to civil service rules and regulations and other applicable rules, regulations and other laws pertaining to city employment, such other persons as may be necessary to properly care for and maintain the public library and its service to the public. 
(5)  To promulgate rules and regulations for the adequate service of the library to the public. 
(6)  To adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business and the performance of its duties. 
(7)  To prepare budget estimates for library expenditures as required by law and applicable rules and regulations and subject to all applicable provisions of law, rules and regulations to control appropriations made by the common council for the support and maintenance of the library. 
(8)  To purchase, sell, or exchange, improve and repair books and other library materials required for the proper operation of the library as well as library appurtenances and equipment, except those items which may appropriately be performed by the department of purchase. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 21)  
Sec. 274. - Reports of library trustees. 
The board shall make such reports, annual and special, as are required by law and applicable rules and regulations. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 22)  
ARTICLE XII. - DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY 
Section 
275.
Department of information technology; [director of information services] chief information officer duties.

Sec. 275. - Department of information technology; chief information officer duties. 
There shall be a Department Of Information Technology, the head of which shall be the Chief Information Officer, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Common Council. The Chief Information Officer shall be under the general direction and supervision of the Mayor. The Chief Information Officer shall have the following powers and duties: 
a.  Plan and develop City-wide information technology policies; 
b.  Coordinate and support information systems technology for all user departments, and develop methods of multi-agency or multi-departmental use of centralized information systems to achieve efficiency and economy of operation. 
c.  Direct and coordinate development and management of new automated information and communication systems and technology, as well as enhancements to existing automated systems in the City; 
d.  Review and analyze proposals for new technology or systems enhancements, and make recommendations as to the cost/benefit, applicability, compatibility and needed resources; 
e.  Serve as chief technology advisor to the Mayor, Department Heads and as a representative of the City with other municipalities and agencies in coordinating information technology related functions; 
f.  Direct and coordinate the day-to-day operations of the Department Of Information Technology to insure optimal utilization of staff resources both for on-going operations and assigned projects; 
g.  Prepare the annual budget for the Department Of Information Technology and review the information technology component of all Department budgets, Requests for Information (RFI's), Requests for Proposals (RFP's), and capital project submissions, and monitor spending throughout the fiscal year to insure adequate funding and cost containment; and 
h.  Plan, coordinate and implement measures to safeguard and insure the security of data and computer files through authorized systems access and information disclosure or modification, taking necessary actions for security violations and breaches. 
(L. L. No. 2-1999, § 1; L.L. No. 3-2014, § 1)  
Sec. 276. - Reserved.

Sec. 277. - Actions for damages or injuries to person or property. 
No civil action shall be maintained against the city and the city shall not be liable for damages or injuries to person or property sustained in any way or manner in consequence of: (a) any street, highway, bridge, culvert, sidewalk, crosswalk or public parking area being out of repair, defective, unsafe, dangerous or obstructed, or the existence of snow or ice upon any street, highway, bridge, culvert, sidewalk, crosswalk, city tree or public parking area unless written notice thereof relating to the particular place and condition was actually given to the commissioner of public works or filed in his office prior to such damage or injury and there was a failure or neglect within a reasonable time after the receipt of such notice to repair or remedy the condition, or to cause such snow or ice to be removed, or to make the place otherwise reasonably safe; and (b) any traffic control light, signal or sign being out of repair, defective, removed or not operating, unsafe, dangerous or obstructed, unless actual notice thereof relating to the particular place and condition was given to the commissioner of public safety or to the desk officer at police headquarters prior to such injury or damage and there was a failure or neglect within a reasonable time after the receipt of such notice to repair or remedy the condition or to make the place otherwise reasonably safe. No action shall be brought upon any claim against the city, and the city shall not be liable, for damages or injuries to person or property alleged to have been caused by or founded upon the misfeasance, negligence or tort of the city, or any of its officers, appointees or employees, unless a written notice of such claim sworn to by or in behalf of the claimant, setting forth the particulars of place, time, injuries and damage, and the cause, nature and extent thereof, so far as then practicable, shall have been made and served. Such notice of claim shall be made and served in compliance with section fifty-e of the general municipal law. Nothing contained in this section shall be held to repeal or modify or waive any existing requirement or statute of limitations which is applicable to these classes of actions, but, on the contrary, shall be held to be additional requirements to the right to maintain such action; nor shall anything herein contained be held to modify any existing rule of law relative to the question of contributory negligence, nor to impose upon the city any greater duty or obligation than that it shall keep its streets and public places in a reasonably safe condition for public use and travel. Except as otherwise provided by law, the place of trial of all actions or proceedings against the city or any of its officers, appointees, employees, boards or departments, shall be the county of Westchester. 
(L.L. No. 5-1953, § 1; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 25; L.L. No. 1-1990, § 30) 
Cross reference— City not liable for acts or omissions of fire department, § 224; damages for building destroyed to prevent spread of fire, § 225. 
State Law reference— Negligence and malfeasance of public officers; taxpayers' remedies, General Municipal Law, § 50 et seq.  
Sec. 278. - Judgments against city. 
The amount of any judgment recovered against the city, and payable by it and remaining unpaid, with the interest due thereon, in case no appeal is intended to be taken, or in case such judgment is finally affirmed on an appeal taken, shall be reported by the corporation counsel immediately after the same shall have become payable to the common council; and such amount shall be raised in the next levy of taxes for the expenses of the city, unless execution upon such judgment shall be stayed. Such judgments shall be paid out of the moneys paid to the commissioner of finance on account of such levy, in the order of their recovery. Until the money so raised shall be paid to the commissioner of finance and payment of judgments refused, no execution shall issue against the city, unless the amount of such judgments shall not have been included in the tax levy; provided, nevertheless, said judgments may be paid, in order of their recovery, from funds available therefor in the tax budget or may be financed pursuant to the local finance law, as may be determined by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 26)  
Sec. 279. - Additional allowances. 
No allowance or compensation, in addition to the salary or compensation prescribed by law or authorized by this act or otherwise by law shall be paid to any officer or employee of the city or to any person paid out of city funds, nor shall any amount in excess of the sum payable under any contract be paid on account thereof. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 27) 
State Law reference— Increasing compensation of officer during fiscal year prohibited, General City Law, § 25.  
Sec. 280. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 280 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1968, sec. 28. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 281. - Inhabitants not incompetent. 
Upon the trial of any issue or the prosecution of any proceeding, or upon the taking or making of any inquisition, appraisal or award, or upon the judicial investigation of any fact whatever, to which issue, proceedings, inquest, investigation or award the city is a party, or in which the city may, in any way, be interested, no person shall be deemed incompetent as a judge, referee, commissioner, witness or juror by reason of his being an inhabitant, resident or taxpayer of the city. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 29)  
Sec. 282. - Witnesses not to be excused from testifying. 
In any criminal proceeding before a court, magistrate or grand jury or in any investigation or inquiry before the common council, or any committee thereof, or before any officer conducting an investigation, touching the knowledge of such witness as to any offense committed in violation of the provisions of this chapter or ordinance of the city, the court, magistrate or grand jury, or the common council, committee or officer, may confer immunity in accordance with the provisions of the code of criminal procedure; provided, however, that no immunity shall be conferred except upon twenty-four (24) hours prior written notice to the district attorney of the county of Westchester. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 31)  
Sec. 283. - City boundaries may be marked; no adverse title obtained by encroachments. 
The common council shall have power to cause the boundaries of the city to be surveyed and permanent monuments to be placed to indicate the same, and a map to be made thereof. Except as otherwise provided by law, no encroachment on any sidewalk, alley, street, highway or public grounds in said city shall operate to confer any right upon any person or corporation adverse to the city, but such encroachment shall be deemed a nuisance, and the city may, at any time, cause the same to be removed. 
(L.L. No. 4-1968, § 32)  
Sec. 284. - Notice to one owner, notice to all. 
Whenever any real estate in said city shall be owned by two (2) or more persons jointly, or as tenants in common, a notice served on one of such persons shall be sufficient notice to all, for any purpose requiring a notice under this act.  
Secs. 285, 286. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 285 and 286 were repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1968, sec. 33. Said section numbers are retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 287. - Annual reports of departments. 
The several heads of departments shall present to the mayor, annually, on or before the first Monday of August, a report of the proceedings of such department during the preceding fiscal year, and he shall transmit the same to the common council with any recommendation he may think proper to make. But nothing in this section contained shall be so construed as to relieve such heads of departments from furnishing information required by the mayor or common council at any other time. 
(L.L. No. 4-1956, § 1)  
Sec. 288. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 288 was repealed by Intro. L.L. No. 4-1968, sec. 33. Said section number is retained by the editors to maintain sequence.  
Sec. 289. - Creation of debt. 
No person shall have power to make any purchase or contract any debt on the part of the city, unless especially authorized by the provisions of this act or the Local Finance Law. 
(Laws 1943, Ch. 710, Pt. 3, Title 62, § 1056)  
Sec. 290. - Public act. 
This act is intended to be and shall be deemed and held in all courts and jurisdictions to be a public act, of which the courts shall take judicial notice. This act shall be construed not as an act in derogation of the powers of the state, but as one intended to aid the state in the execution of its duties, and shall be liberally construed so as to carry into effect the objects and purposes thereof.  
Sec. 291. - Bonded debt of village and town of White Plains. 
The city of White Plains shall be liable for the bonded debt of the village and town of White Plains, and shall pay and discharge the principal as the same shall fall due, and the annual interest accruing thereon, and such bonded debt for all purposes shall be deemed the bonded debt of the city of White Plains. 
(Laws 1945, Ch. 839, § 74)  
Sec. 292. - Apportionment of state and county taxes. 
The board of supervisors of Westchester county shall, at its first annual session after the passage of this act, fix and determine the proportional amounts of the state and county and town charges to be equitably paid by the city of White Plains, and also the proportional shares of amounts thereof to be paid by the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, not included within the boundaries of said city. Said board of supervisors shall also, at their first annual session after the passage of this act, fix and determine the proportional share or amount of the floating and bonded indebtedness of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, incurred and existing at the time of the passage of this act, to be chargeable upon the city of White Plains, and the proportional share or amount thereof to be chargeable to the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, not included within the boundaries of said city. Said board of supervisors in determining the proportion which shall be paid by said city and towns respectively, shall be governed by the proportion of the assessed valuation of the property of said city and towns, and the amount chargeable to the city of White Plains shall bear such proportion to the whole amount of such floating and bonded indebtedness as the assessed valuation of the property formerly in such town but now in said city of White Plains upon the assessment roll of the city of White Plains for that year, as equalized by said board bears to the aggregate amount of the assessment roll of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh respectively, for that year as equalized by said board and the assessment roll of said city so equalized. Said board of supervisors, shall also, at their first annual session after the passage of this act, fix and determine the proportional share or amount of the floating and bonded indebtedness of the several school districts, part of which are included in said city, incurred and existing at the time of the passage of this act, to be chargeable upon the city of White Plains, and the proportional share or amount thereof chargeable to the part of each of such several school districts, not included in the boundaries of said city. 
Said board of supervisors, in determining the proportion which shall be chargeable to said city and school districts not included in the boundaries of said city, shall be governed by the proportion of the assessed valuation of the property of said city and several school districts not included in the boundaries of said city, and the amount chargeable to the city of White Plains shall bear such proportion to the whole amount of such floating and bonded indebtedness as the assessed valuation of the property in said city of White Plains, formerly in such school district, bears to the aggregate amount of the assessment roll of such school districts, respectively, on the last preceding assessment roll of such school district. The portion of the indebtedness so apportioned shall become a charge for principal and interest upon the city of White Plains and the respective towns and school districts as though the same had been incurred by said city, towns and school districts separately. After the passage of this act the said city of White Plains, shall, for all purposes relating to the assessment and collection of taxes, be and constitute a separate and distinct township in said county of Westchester.  
Sec. 293. - Adjustment of leases and certificates of sales. 
Immediately after the appointment of a city clerk of the city of White Plains, as herein provided, the town clerk, town receiver of taxes and the supervisor, of the town of White Plains shall deliver all books, papers and other property in his possession belonging to the town of White Plains to the city clerk of the city of White Plains, and upon such delivery of the right, title and interest of the town of White Plains in and to tax leases, tax sales and tax certificates of sales, shall be vested in the city of White Plains with the same purpose and effect as though they had been actually assigned by the town of White Plains to the city of White Plains. The supervisors of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, shall continue to keep the record of tax sales and retain the custody and ownership of tax leases and certificates of sale for taxes within that portion of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh hereby included within the city of White Plains, as though such portions had not been included within the city of White Plains, and upon the payment of any tax now due upon land lying within such portions of said towns the same shall be placed to the credit of such towns. The board of supervisors of Westchester county shall, at its first annual session after the passage of this act, fix and determine the proportionate amount of back taxes so collected to be retained by each town and the proportionate amount to be paid by each of said towns to the said city of White Plains. Such apportionment shall be made by said board of supervisors on a basis of the assessment roll in effect when this act takes effect, and the supervisors of the several towns shall annually, upon a basis or proportion, fixed as aforesaid, pay on or before the first day of January in this year to the commissioner of finance of the city of White Plains the part or proportion of taxes to which said city is entitled.  
Sec. 294. - Enforcement of taxes and assessments already levied. 
All proceedings taken or which shall be taken prior to the time this act takes effect, for the collection of taxes, under the provisions of chapter six hundred and ten of the laws of eighteen hundred and seventy-four, and the amendments thereto, and chapter six hundred and fifty-six of the laws of nineteen hundred and thirteen, shall be concluded under the provisions of those acts, and all acts required to be done and performed by the supervisor shall be performed by the commissioner of finance and all acts required to be done and performed by the town clerk shall be performed by the city clerk, with the same force and effect as though such acts had been done and performed by such supervisor and town clerk, and the collection of all taxes and assessments which have been or shall have been imposed before this act takes effect shall be concluded in the manner prescribed by law at the time such taxes and assessments were imposed by the commissioner of finance.  
Sec. 295. - Collection of taxes. 
This act shall in no wise apply to or affect the collection of the town, county or state, village or school taxes, the warrant for collection of which may be in the hands of the receiver of taxes of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, and all steps and means now provided by the statute for the collection of said taxes may at any time hereafter be taken and enforced as is now provided by statute for delinquent taxes, and when the same shall be collected they shall be disposed of in the same manner as though this act had not become a law, except as otherwise provided by this act.  
Sec. 296. - Village ordinances, et cetera, continued. 
The existing ordinances, bylaws, resolutions and regulations of the trustees of the village of White Plains as the same shall be in force when this act takes effect, shall be and continue in force, and shall have the same force and effect over the entire limits of the city of White Plains, as in and by this act established, and shall be and continue in force and effect over the whole city as if duly adopted, passed and published by the common council of said city until the same shall be repealed by the common council of said city.  
Sec. 297. - Towns of North Castle and Greenburgh and school districts continued. 
The balance of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh not included within the bounds of the city of White Plains, shall be separate and distinct towns with all the rights and privileges of a town as provided by law and shall be known as the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh; and the portions of the several school districts not included in the boundaries of said city shall be separate and distinct school districts with all the rights and privileges of a school district as provided by law; all officers of said towns and school districts who shall be residents of the same as hereby altered shall continue to hold their offices for the time and in the manner prescribed by law; all officers holding office either by election or appointment, who shall cease to be residents of the towns of North Castle and Greenburgh, or of the several school districts, in consequence of the alteration of said towns and school districts hereby shall be deemed to have vacated their offices from the day when this act shall take effect, as if they had removed from the towns or school districts, except as in this act otherwise provided. All vacancies caused as above stated shall be filled by the respective town board and school districts as provided by law.  
Sec. 298. - Village and town corporations dissolved. 
The corporations known as the village of White Plains and the town of White Plains, and included in the boundaries hereinbefore described, are hereby dissolved, and all offices elective and appointive, existing under the government of the village and town of White Plains, are hereby abolished, and all such village and town offices shall immediately deliver and turn over all books, papers, money and property of every description to the city of White Plains, and the title thereto and also the title of said town and village of, in and to any and all real estate, leases, tax leases and any interest in real estate and personal property belonging to the village or town of White Plains is hereby vested in the city of White Plains.  
Sec. 299. - State insurance law to apply. 
The provisions of section one hundred and thirty-three of chapter thirty-three of the consolidated laws of nineteen hundred and nine of the state of New York, known as the insurance law of the state of New York, shall apply to the city of White Plains and be a portion of this act.  
Sec. 300. - Trustees of police pension fund. 
The common council of the city of White Plains are hereby constituted a board of trustees of the police pension fund created by this act. The commissioner of finance shall be the treasurer of such board of trustees. Such board of trustees shall have charge of and administer said fund, and from time to time invest the same, or any part thereof, as they shall deem most beneficial to said fund, and are empowered to make all necessary contracts and take all necessary and proper actions and proceedings in the premises, and to make payments from said fund of pensions granted in pursuance of this act. And the fund now in the possession of the board of police commissioners as trustees of the police pension fund of the village of White Plains shall be transferred to the trustees of the police pension fund hereby created. The said trustees shall from time to time establish such rules and regulations for the administration of the police pension fund as they may deem best. The commissioner of finance shall report in detail to the common council of the city of White Plains annually on or before the first day of August, in which report shall be stated the condition of the police pension fund, how invested and the items of their receipts and disbursements on account of the same. No payments whatever shall be allowed or made by said trustees as reward, gratuity or compensation to any person for salary or services rendered by or for said board of trustees.  
Sec. 301. - Police pension fund; how constituted. 
The police pension fund shall consist of: 
(1)  The police pension fund now in the possession of the board of police commissioners of the village of White Plains as trustees of the police pension fund. 
(2)  All fines imposed by the commissioner of public safety upon members of the police force. 
(3)  All rewards, fees, gifts, testimonials, proceeds of entertainments and emoluments that may be presented, paid or given to the police department or any member of the police force for or on account of police services, except such as shall be allowed by the commissioner of public safety to be retained by said member. 
(4)  All lost or stolen money remaining in the custody of the city for the space of one year, and for which there shall be no lawful claimant, and moneys arising from the sale of unclaimed property, which the commissioner of public safety is hereby authorized to sell after said property shall have been without lawful claimant for the space of one year. 
(5)  All moneys, pay, compensation or salary, or any part thereof, deducted or withheld from any member of the police force for or on account of absence or suspension from duty. 
(6)  Two per centum (2%) of the salary of each of the members of said police force, who may, by their consent in writing to be filed with the board of trustees of the police pension fund, consent to its being taken for the police pension fund. Twenty-five per centum (25%) of all license money. 
(7)  All fees received and paid for the inspection and testing by the police department of combustible and dangerous materials and received and paid for licenses in connection therewith, as shall be provided by the laws and ordinances of said city. 
(8)  A sum of money annually equal to, but not greater than five per centum (5%) of an amount not exceeding the revenue estimated upon a basis of the number of liquor tax licenses granted in the last year in which the excise tax was received, and any other moneys that the Common Council shall pay into such fund any other source as may be necessary to fund all future obligations to beneficiaries. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 24; L.L. No. 4-1925, § 1; Laws 2003, Ch. 278)  
Sec. 302. - Pensions, to whom granted. 
The board of trustees of the police pension fund created by this act shall have power to grant pensions as hereinafter provided to any member of the police force of said village at the time of the passage of this act, or to any person who became a member of the police force prior to June twenty-ninth, nineteen hundred and forty, who may have signed the consent in writing as hereinbefore provided, as follows: 
(1)  To the widow of any member of the police force at the time of the passage of this act, or who became a member of the police force prior to June twenty-ninth, nineteen hundred and forty, who shall have been killed while in the actual performance of police duty, or shall have died from the effects of any injury received while in the actual discharge of such duty, provided such death shall not have been caused by misconduct on his part, such sum per annum as may in the discretion of the board of trustees of said fund be deemed proper. 
(2)  To any child or children under sixteen (16) years of age of such member of the police force killed or dying as aforesaid, but leaving no widow, or if a widow, then after her death to such child or children being yet under sixteen (16) years of age, such sum as the board of trustees of said fund may deem proper. 
(3)  To any such member of the police force who, while in the actual performance of police duty, and by reason of the performance of such duty, and without fault or misconduct on his part, shall have become permanently disabled physically or mentally so as to be unfitted to perform full police duty, such sum per annum as the board of trustees of the pension fund shall deem proper. 
(3-a)  To any such member of the police force who, while in the military, naval or air force service of the United States, has become permanently disabled physically or mentally so as to be unfit to perform the full duty of his employment in the police force, such sum per annum as the board of trustees of the pension fund shall deem proper, not exceeding an amount equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said police force of the rank of the member so retired. 
(4)  Any such member of the police force who has or shall have performed police duty for a period of twenty (20) years or upwards upon his own application or upon the certificate of a majority of the members of the medical board certifying that such member is permanently disabled so as to be unfit for police duty may, in the discretion of the board of trustees of the said fund with the approval of the commissioner of public safety, and any such member of the police force who attains age sixty-two (62) shall (except as hereinafter set forth) be retired from service and placed upon the police pension roll, and therefrom, shall be awarded, granted and paid from said police pension fund by the trustees thereof an annual sum during his lifetime, equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said police force of the rank of the member so retired. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision relative to the compulsory retirement of a member of the police force who attains age sixty-two the board of trustees of the said fund with the approval of the commissioner of public safety may permit the continuance in service of such member for periods not to exceed one year each; provided, however, that no such permission shall be given (a) without the certification of a majority of the members of the medical board that such member of the police force is physically and mentally fit to perform the duties of his position, and (b) such member of the police force is less than sixty-five (65) years of age. The board of trustees of the said fund may award, grant and pay from said pension fund to a member of the police force who has served as such for a period of at least thirty-three (33) years such sum as they may deem proper; provided such sum shall not be less than an amount equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said police force of the rank of the member so retired and shall not be in excess of three-fourths (¾) thereof. Pensions granted under this section shall be for the natural life of the officer, and, except as otherwise provided by law, shall not be revoked, repealed or diminished. In case any retired member of said police force shall die leaving a widow, such widow shall be entitled to receive three hundred dollars ($300.00) per annum during her life. In case such retired member shall leave a minor child, or children, and no widow, then the board of trustees of such pension fund shall pay to the guardian of such minor child or children such pension per annum as the board may deem proper, not to exceed in all three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(4-a)  To the widow of any member of the police force who at the time of his death was a member of such police force, the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per annum during her lifetime. In case such member shall leave a minor child, or children, and no widow, then the board of trustees of such pension fund shall pay to the guardian of such minor child or children such pension per annum as the board may deem proper, not to exceed in all three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(5)  Pensions to widows shall terminate when the widow shall remarry and pensions to children shall terminate whenever the children shall, respectively, arrive at the age of sixteen (16) years. The common council may, in its discretion, order any pension granted or any part thereof to cease, except to members of the police force retired after twenty (20) years' service, as hereinbefore provided; but in all such cases the said common council shall file with the city clerk a written statement of the causes which determined them in ordering any pension to so cease, and nothing herein contained shall render the granting or payment of such pension obligatory on the common council, as the trustees of the police pension fund, except as hereinbefore provided. 
(6)  No member of the police force shall be awarded, granted or paid a pension on account of physical or mental disability or disease unless upon the certificate of a majority of the members of the medical board, which shall set forth the cause, nature and extent of the disability, disease or injury of each member of the police force who may be placed upon the pension roll, and said certificate shall distinctly state whether or not such disability, disease or injury was incurred or sustained by said member of the police force in the performance of police duty, and such certificate shall in each case be filed with and entered upon the minutes of the common council. 
(7)  No member of the said police force shall be entitled to any benefits of this act in any way whatever unless he shall have signed a consent in writing to the effect that two per centum (2%) of his salary shall be taken for the benefit of the police pension fund, as hereinbefore provided, nor unless he shall continue to permit the same to be taken so long as he shall remain an active member of said force. The time for the commencement of the two per centum (2%) to run shall be at the date of the passage of this act as to members then on the force, and as to those members who were subsequently appointed it shall commence as of the date of their appointment. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 25; Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 9; L.L. No. 2-1943, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1948, § 1; L.L. No. 5-1950, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1959, § 2; L.L. No. 2-1965, § 1) 
Code references— Supplemental police and fire death benefits, § 2-5-92; supplemental pensions for retired policemen and retired paid firemen and widows of certain firemen, § 2-5-93; supplemental pension payments to widows and orphan minor children of retired policemen and retired paid firemen, § 2-5-94. 
State Law reference— Minimum retirement benefits for policemen who are members of police pension or retirement system maintained by cities, General Municipal Law, § 207-e; ordinary death benefits of members of police retirement systems, § 207-g thereof; death benefits for beneficiaries, § 208-b thereof.  
Sec. 303. - Trustees of fire department pension fund. 
The common council of the city of White Plains are hereby constituted a board of trustees of the fire department pension fund created by this act. The commissioner of finance shall be the treasurer of such board of trustees. Such board of trustees shall have charge of and administer said fund, and from time to time invest the same, or any part thereof, as they shall deem most beneficial to said fund, and are empowered to make all necessary contracts and take all necessary and proper actions and proceedings in the premises, and to make payments from said fund for pensions granted in pursuance of this act. The said trustees shall from time to time establish such rules and regulations for the administration of the fire department pension fund as they may deem best. The commissioner of finance shall report in detail to the common council of the city of White Plains annually on or before the first day of August, in which report shall be stated the condition of the fire department pension fund, how invested and the items of the receipts and disbursements on account of the same. No payments whatever shall be allowed or made by said trustees as reward, gratuity or compensation to any person for salary or services rendered by or for said board of trustees. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 28)  
Sec. 304. - Firemen's pension fund; how constituted. 
There shall be established and maintained in the city of White Plains a firemen's pension fund for the paid officers and paid members of the fire department of such city. Such pension fund shall consist of: 
(1)  All fines imposed by the commissioner of public safety upon paid members of the fire department. 
(2)  All rewards, fees, gifts, testimonials, proceeds of entertainments and emoluments that may be presented, paid or given to the paid fire department or to any member thereof, for or on account of the services of such department or the members thereof. 
(3)  All moneys, pay, compensation or salary, or any part thereof, deducted or withheld from any paid member or members of said fire department for or on account of absence or suspension from duty. 
(4)  Two per centum (2%) of the salary of each of the paid members of said fire department, who may, by their consent in writing to be filed with the board of trustees of the fire department pension fund, consent to its being taken for said pension fund. 
(5)  Any other moneys that the common council may from time to time pay into said fund from any other sources. 
(6)  All fees received and paid for the inspection and testing by the fire department of combustible and dangerous materials, and received and paid for licenses in connection therewith, as shall be provided by the laws and ordinances of said city. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 28; L.L. No. 2-1925, § 1)  
Sec. 305. - Pensions, to whom granted. 
The board of trustees of the fire department pension fund created by this act shall have power to grant pensions as hereinafter provided to any member of the paid fire department of said city at the time of the passage of this act, or to any person who became a member of the paid fire department prior to June twenty-ninth, nineteen hundred and forty, who may have signed the consent in writing as hereinbefore provided, as follows: 
(1)  To the widow of any member of the paid fire department at the time of the passage of this act, or who became a member of the paid fire department prior to June twenty-ninth, nineteen hundred and forty, who shall have been killed while in the actual performance of fire duty, or shall have died from the effects of any injury received while in the actual discharge of such duty, provided such death shall not have been caused by misconduct on his part, such sum per annum as may in the discretion of the board of trustees of said fund be deemed proper. 
(2)  To any child or children under sixteen (16) years of age of such member of the paid fire department killed or dying as aforesaid, but leaving no widow, or if a widow, then after her death to such child or children being yet under sixteen (16) years of age, such sum as the board of trustees of said fund may deem proper. 
(3)  To any such member of the paid fire department who, while in the actual performance of fire duty, and by reason of the performance of such duty, and without fault or misconduct on his part, shall have become permanently disabled physically or mentally, so as to be unfitted to perform full fire duty, such sum per annum as the said board of trustees of the pension fund shall deem proper. 
(3-a)  To any such member of the paid fire department who, while in the military, naval or air force service of the United States, has become permanently disabled physically or mentally so as to be unfit to perform the full duty of his employment in the paid fire department, such sum per annum as the board of trustees of the pension fund shall deem proper, not exceeding an amount equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said paid fire department of the rank of the member so retired. 
(4)  Any such member of the paid fire department who has or shall have performed duty as a paid fireman for a period of twenty (20) years or upwards upon his own application or upon the certificate of a majority of the members of the medical board certifying that such member is permanently disabled so as to be unfitted for fire duty may, in the discretion of the board of trustees of the said fund with the approval of the commissioner of public safety, and any such member of the paid fire department who attains age sixty-two (62) shall (except as hereinafter set forth) be retired from service and placed upon the fire department pension roll, and therefrom shall be awarded, granted and paid from said fire department pension fund by the trustees thereof an annual sum during his lifetime, equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said fire department of the rank of the member so retired. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision relative to the compulsory retirement of a member of the paid fire department who attains age sixty-two (62), the board of trustees of the said fund with the approval of the commissioner of public safety may permit the continuance in service of such member for periods not to exceed one year each; provided, however, that no such permission shall be given (a) without the certification of a majority of the members of the medical board that such member of the paid fire department is physically and mentally fit to perform the duties of his position, and (b) such member of the paid fire department is less than sixty-five (65) years of age. The board of trustees of the said fund may award, grant and pay from said pension fund to a member of the paid fire department who has served as such for a period of at least thirty-three (33) years such sum as they may deem proper; provided such sum shall not be less than an amount equivalent to one-half (½) the full pay of a member of said paid fire department of the rank of the member so retired and shall not be in excess of three-fourths (¾) thereof. Pensions granted under this section shall be for the natural life of the member, and, except as otherwise provided by law, shall not be revoked, repealed or diminished. In case any retired member of said fire department shall die leaving a widow, such widow shall be entitled to receive three hundred dollars ($300.00) per annum during her life. In case such retired member shall leave a minor child, or children, and no widow, then the board of trustees of such pension fund shall pay to the guardian of such minor child or children such pension per annum as the board may deem proper, not to exceed in all three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(4-a)  To the widow of any member of the paid fire department who at the time of his death was a member of such paid fire department, the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per annum during her lifetime. In case such member shall leave a minor child, or children, and no widow, then the board of trustees of such pension fund shall pay to the guardian of such minor child or children such pension per annum as the board may deem proper, not to exceed in all three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(5)  Pensions to widows shall terminate when the widow shall remarry and pensions to children shall terminate whenever the children shall, respectively, arrive at the age of sixteen (16) years. The common council may, in its discretion, order any pension granted or any part thereof to cease, except to members of the paid fire department retired after twenty (20) years' service, as hereinbefore provided; but in all such cases the said common council shall file with the city clerk a written statement of the causes which determined them in ordering any pension to so cease, and nothing herein contained shall render the granting or payment of such pension obligatory on the common council, as the trustees of the fire department pension fund, except as hereinbefore provided. 
(6)  No member of the paid fire department shall be awarded, granted or paid a pension on account of physical or mental disability or disease unless upon the certificate of a majority of the members of the medical board, which shall set forth the cause, nature and extent of the disability, disease or injury of each member of the paid fire department who may be placed upon the pension roll, and said certificate shall distinctly state whether or not such disability, disease or injury was incurred or sustained by said member of the paid fire department in the performance of fire duty, and such certificate shall in each case be filed with and entered upon the minutes of the common council. 
(7)  No member of the said paid fire department shall be entitled to any benefits of this act in any way whatever unless he shall have signed a consent in writing to the effect that two per centum (2%) of his salary shall be taken for the benefit of the fire department pension fund, as hereinbefore provided, nor unless he shall continue to permit the same to be taken so long as he shall remain an active member of said paid fire department. The time for the commencement of the two per centum (2%) to run shall be the first day of January, nineteen hundred and nineteen, as to members then in said fire department, and who are now members thereof, and as to those members who were subsequently appointed it shall commence as of the date of their appointment. 
(Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 28; Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 10; L.L. No. 2-1943, § 3; L.L. No. 2-1948, § 2; L.L. No. 5-1950, § 2; L.L. No. 2-1959, § 2; L.L. No. 2-1965, § 2) 
Code references— Supplemental police and fire death benefits, § 2-5-92; supplemental pensions for retired policemen and retired paid firemen and widows of certain firemen, § 2-5-93; supplemental pension payments to widows and orphan minor children of retired policemen and retired paid firemen, § 2-5-94. 
State Law reference— Minimum retirement benefits for firemen who are members of fire department pension or retirement system, General Municipal Law, § 207-e; ordinary death benefits of members of fire department systems of cities, § 207-f thereof; death benefits for beneficiaries, § 208-b thereof.  
Sec. 306. - Liability of city and trustees; medical board. 
Notwithstanding any inconsistent provisions of this act, no member of the police force or paid fire department of the city appointed on or after June twenty-ninth, nineteen hundred and forty, shall be or become a member of the pension systems of the city or shall be required to pay any money or part of any salary or compensation to the aforesaid pension funds and no such person, his widow or children, shall be entitled to receive or be granted or paid any pension, annuity, allowance or moneys from said pension funds. The common council shall appoint three (3) physicians as members of and to constitute the medical board. The term of office of the present members of the medical board shall expire on the thirty-first day of December, nineteen hundred sixty-nine. In the month of January, nineteen hundred seventy, and in such month every two (2) years thereafter, the common council shall make similar appointments to said medical board for a term expiring on the thirty-first day of December in the year following such appointments. The members of the medical board shall continue as such members until the appointment and qualification of their successors. Vacancies in the board shall be filled by the common council for the unexpired term. The members of the medical board shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed by the common council. The medical board shall arrange for and shall pass upon all medical examinations required under the provisions of this act, shall investigate all essential statements and certifications by or on behalf of a member of the pension systems of the city, shall make a physical examination of any member of the pension systems of the city, in connection with an application for retirement, when requested to do so by the common council, and shall certify to the common council its suggestions and recommendations thereon. 
(Renumbered § 306 by Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 26; Amended by Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 26; Laws 1922, Ch. 521, § 11; L.L. No. 1-1940, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1943, § 5; L.L. No. 4-1968, § 34)  
Secs. 307, 308. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Secs. 307, 308 were repealed by secs. 31, 32 of L.L. No. 1-1990.  
Sec. 309. - First assessment roll—How prepared. 
The assessor of the city of White Plains shall, on or before the twenty-second day of January, nineteen hundred and sixteen, make up an assessment roll of the taxable property, real and personal, in the said city by copying so much of the last preceding assessment roll of the towns of White Plains, Greenburgh and North Castle as relate to persons residing in and property included and taxable within the city of White Plains. Upon the completion of the said assessment roll the said assessor shall annex thereto a certificate under his hand that the said assessment roll contains so much of the assessment rolls of the aforesaid towns of White Plains, Greenburgh and North Castle as relates to persons residing in and property included and taxable within the said city of White Plains and shall deposit the same in his office. He shall immediately have published the notice and perform the duties required by section seventy-four of this act, except that such assessment roll, as corrected and completed shall be filed by said assessor in the office of the city clerk on or before the twelfth day of February, nineteen hundred and sixteen. On or before the twenty-ninth day of February, nineteen hundred and sixteen, the city clerk shall deliver said assessment roll to the commissioner of finance for the purpose of extending the tax thereon. The filing of such roll with the board of supervisors of the county of Westchester shall not be required. The sums adopted by the common council in the tax budget for the fiscal year beginning January first, nineteen hundred and sixteen, shall be assessed on all real and personal estate in the city (except city property and property exempt by law) according to the valuation of the same in the assessment roll for said year, and shall be extended by the commissioner of finance. The amount thus extended shall be regarded and known in all proceedings as "tax" and become due in one installment on the first day of April, nineteen hundred and sixteen. The commissioner of finance shall complete the roll and deliver it to the city clerk on or before the twenty-ninth day of March, nineteen hundred and sixteen. The city clerk shall re-deliver said roll to the commissioner of finance on or before the thirty-first day of March, nineteen hundred and sixteen, with a warrant in the form and executed in the manner prescribed by section eighty-four of this act. All of the provisions of this act relating to the collection and enforcement of taxes shall apply, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(Renumbered § 309 by Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 27)  
Sec. 310. - Acts repealed. 
Except for the purposes otherwise provided in this act the following acts are hereby repealed:

Sec. 311. - Saving clause. 
Nothing contained in this act shall be construed to repeal any statute of the state or ordinance of the village, or rule or regulation of the board of health or the rules or regulations adopted by the water commissioners of the village not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, and the same shall remain in full force and effect when not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, to be construed and operated in harmony with the provisions of this act. The powers which are conferred and the duties which are imposed upon any officer or department of the village under any statute of the state or any village ordinance which is in force at the time of the taking effect of this act, shall, if such office or department be abolished by this act, be thereafter exercised and discharged by the officer, board or department upon whom is imposed corresponding or like functions, powers and duties under the provisions of this act. Where any contract has been entered into by the village, prior to the time of taking effect of this act, or any bond or undertaking has been given to or in favor of the city, which contains provisions that the same may be enforced by some officer, board or department therein named, but by the provisions of this act such office, board or department is abolished such contracts, bonds and undertaking shall not in any manner be impaired, but shall continue in full force and the powers conferred and the duties imposed with reference to the same upon the office, board or department which has been abolished shall thereafter be exercised and discharged by the officer, board or department upon whom is conferred or imposed like powers, functions or duties under the provisions of this act. 
(Renumbered § 311 by Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 27)  
Sec. 312. - When act takes effect. 
This act shall take effect January first, nineteen hundred and sixteen, except for the provisions for preparing for and holding the election as provided in section twenty-five of this act, as to which provisions this act shall take effect immediately. 
(Renumbered § 312 by Laws 1919, Ch. 124, § 27)
