(Laws 1966, Ch. 600, § 6)  
DIVISION 15. - AUTHORIZATION TO GRANT, CONVEY, LEASE OR LICENSE AIR AND BED RIGHTS IN HALE AVENUE[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note— This subpart is derived from Chapter 1011 of the Laws of 1970 which became a law March 18, 1970. 
Charter reference— Public works, § 117 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1. - [Authorization.] 
Notwithstanding any provision contained in the charter of the city of White Plains, as amended, or in any other act, general, special or local, the city of White Plains is hereby permitted, authorized and empowered to grant, convey, lease or license such right, title, easement or interest at public or private sale of, in and to such part of the spaces over and in the surfaces of Hale Avenue between the westerly projection of the southerly line of Hiram Street and the easterly projection of the southerly line of lot 5, block 24, ward 5, as shown on the current tax assessment map of the city of White Plains. 
The city of White Plains in its sole discretion, may grant its consent to the grantee or grantees for the construction of an office building, parking structure and other facilities incidental thereto which will bridge such street together with any rights of support in the bed of said street for the private use of said grantee or grantees, and for the maintenance of such building, parking structure and other facilities in perpetuity or for the term of such consent and rights. 
Such consent and right, title and interest may be granted to the owner of all or part of the property immediately adjoining or adjacent to said portion of Hale Avenue and shall cover such areas in the spaces over and in the surface of said street and shall be in perpetuity or for such term of years, duration or period and upon such terms and conditions and shall be transferable and/or mortgageable to such extent as the city of White Plains, in its sole discretion, may deem expedient. 
(Laws 1970, Ch. 1011, § 1)  
Sec. 2. - [Condemnation of other land permitted.] 
The city of White Plains is further authorized and empowered to condemn or take any other necessary action to acquire title to any land in the bed of Hale Avenue in the city of White Plains and any or all public or private easements in said street, notwithstanding that said acquisition is for the purposes set forth in section one hereof. 
(Laws 1970, Ch. 1011, § 2)  
Sec. 3. - [Effective date.] 
This act shall take effect immediately. 
(Laws 1970, Ch. 1011, § 3)  
DIVISION 16. - DISCONTINUING THE USE FOR PARK PURPOSES OF CERTAIN LANDS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note— This subpart is derived from Chapter 28 of the Laws of 1968 which became a law March 12, 1968. 
 
Sec. 1. - [Authorization.] 
Notwithstanding any inconsistent general, special or local law, the city of White Plains may by ordinance or local law discontinue as park lands the lands, hereinafter described, and heretofore acquired by such city for park purposes and no longer necessary for park purposes. For the purpose of this act sale thereof may be made at public or private sale in whole or in part and in conjunction with or without other city property for such consideration and upon such terms and conditions as the city council may deem proper and for the best interests of such city. 
(Laws 1968, Ch. 28, § 1)  
Sec. 2. - [Description.] 
The lands referred to in section one of this act are located, bounded and described as follows: 
BEGINNING at a point on the northerly side of Main Street distant 146.91 feet easterly from the intersection of the northerly side of Main Street with the easterly side of Church Street; thence running northerly forming an interior angle of 91° 51' 54? a distance of 258.86 feet; thence running easterly forming an interior angle of 97° 52' 40? a distance of 49.56 feet; thence running southerly forming an interior angle of 92° 09' 40? a distance of 258.63 feet to the northerly side of Main Street; thence running westerly along the northerly side of Main Street forming an interior angle of 88° 05' 46? a distance of 49.73 feet to the point and place of beginning. 
(Laws 1968, Ch. 28, § 2)  
Sec. 3. - [Effective date.] 
This act shall take effect immediately. 
(Laws 1968, Ch. 28, § 3)  
ARTICLE B. - LOCAL LAWS AND ACTS OF WESTCHESTER COUNTY  
DIVISION 1. - ESTABLISHMENT OF BOUNDARY LINE BETWEEN CITY OF WHITE PLAINS AND TOWN OF NORTH CASTLE[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note— Act No. 85 of 1931 of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors was passed pursuant to Section 37 of Chapter 16 of the Laws of 1909, as amended, at a regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County held on December 7, 1931, thirty-eight votes (being the votes for more than two-thirds of the members elected to said board) being in favor thereof and no votes against its passage. 
Charter reference— City boundaries established, § 2; city boundaries may be marked; no adverse title obtained by encroachment, § 283. 
Related laws references— Boundary line between City of White Plains, city school district, Town of Harrison in the Cross-Westchester right-of-way, between the former Central Westchester Parkway and Maplemoor Golf Course, Art. A, Div. 9; boundary line between city, city school district and Town of Harrison between a point in the center line of the Cross-Westchester Expressway and a point in Silver Lake, Art. A, Div. 11. 
 
Sec. 1. - [Boundary line established.] 
The boundary line between Town of North Castle and the City of White Plains, in said County of Westchester, be and hereby is established and defined as follows: 
BEGINNING at a point on the center line of the original location of the Bronx River; bearing thence south 70° 52' 27? east and crossing monumented center line of the New York and Harlem Railroad Co. at Station 1279-69.10 and crossing Broadway at its intersection with Virginia Road and thru the location of the stump of an old oak tree; thence continuing on the same bearing and crossing the westerly boundary of Seneca Avenue at a point 8.69 feet southerly from the northerly line of the premises designated on Map of North White Plains, the Terminal City, filed in the office of the Register of Westchester County as Map No. 1749, at Lot No. 23, in Block 10; and thence continuing on the same bearing and crossing the westerly boundary of Cloverdale Avenue at a point 1.35 feet southerly from the northerly line of property designated on the last mentioned map as Lot No. 24, Block 12; thence continuing on the same bearing and crossing the easterly boundary line of lands belonging to the County of Westchester at a point 36.15 feet northerly from lands of the City of White Plains; thence continuing on the same bearing to a point on the easterly boundary of lands belonging to Thomas Rahily at a point 146.50 feet northerly from lands belonging to the City of White Plains which easterly boundary line of property of Thomas Rahily is also the westerly boundary line of lands belonging to the City of White Plains. 
The above described line passes thru stone monuments set in the ground, and located as follows: 
(1)  A distance of 5.05 feet and south 67° 52' 27? east from the westerly side of Broadway. 
(2)  A distance of 6.18 feet and north 67° 52' 27? west from the southeasterly side of Broadway, as established in 1931. 
(3)  A distance of 5.23 feet and south 67° 52' 27? east from the westerly side of Seneca Avenue. 
(4)  A distance of 5.23 feet and south 67° 52' 27? east from the westerly side of Cloverdale Avenue, both of said last mentioned streets being shown on a Map of North White Plains, filed in the office of the Register of Westchester County as Map No. 1749, all of which is shown on a map entitled, "Map Showing Boundary Line Between Town of North Castle and City of White Plains," made by Chas. H. Sells, Inc., Engineers and Surveyors, Pleasantville, N. Y., completed March 4, 1931. 
(Act. No. LXXXV of 1931, Westchester County Board of Supervisors)  
Sec. 2. - [Copies of act and map to be filed.] 
The Clerk of this Board [of supervisors] is hereby directed to file a certified copy of this Act and the map showing the boundary line between said municipalities in the office of the Secretary of State at Albany, New York. 
(Act No. LXXXV of 1931, Westchester County Board of Supervisors)  
Sec. 3. - [Effective date.] 
This Act shall take effect immediately. 
(Act No. LXXXV of 1931, Westchester County Board of Supervisors)

WHITE PLAINS MUNICIPAL CODE[1] 
Title I.
General Provisions 
Title II.
Administration 
Title III.
Environmental Conservation 
Title IV.
Licenses, Permits and Business Regulations 
Title V.
Offenses and Miscellaneous Provisions

Parks and Recreation

Public Works 
Title VIII.
Traffic and Street Regulation 
Title IX.
Zoning, Planning, Buildings and Structures 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— This is the White Plains Municipal Code and consists of ordinances, local laws adopted by the common council which do not amend the city charter, resolutions of the common council and rules and regulations promulgated by various departments and agencies of the city. The source of each section is indicated in the parenthetical history note, except as otherwise stated. The user of this Code should be aware that only the ordinances embraced in this Code are actually adopted by the adopting ordinance for this Code. Local laws, resolutions, rules and regulations have been classified according to the format of this Code and are included for the convenience of the user of this Code. Minor wording changes have been made in such resolutions, rules and regulations to facilitate incorporation into the Code. In each case, however, no substantive change has been made and the text accurately reflects the substance of the law. 
 
TITLE I. GENERAL PROVISIONS 
CHAPTER 
 1-1  GENERALLY  
Chapter 1-1 - GENERALLY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Official map or plan, § 9-3-1. 
 
Sec. 1-1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "White Plains Municipal Code" and may be so cited or cited as the "WPMC." A section of this Code may be cited by chapter and section number, to wit "WPMC 7-1-1," without being preceded by the word "section" or the symbol "§."  
Sec. 1-1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the common council: 
(1)  Generally. The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expression thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular mischiefs for which the provisions were enacted. The provisions of the General Construction Law, as now or hereafter amended shall apply in the interpretation of the provisions of this Code and of all ordinances. 
State Law reference— Computation of time, General Construction Law, §§ 20, 25, 25-a; gender of words, General Construction Law, § 22; number of words, General Construction Law, § 35; meaning of terms "oath," "affidavit" or "swear," General Construction Law, § 36; definition of personal property, General Construction Law, § 39; definition of property, General Construction Law, § 38; definition of real property, General Construction Law, § 40; definition of signature, General Construction Law, § 46; tense of words, General Construction Law, § 48; definition of terms "writing" or "written," General Construction Law, § 56; effect of repeal of statutes, General Construction Law, § 90 et seq. 
(2)  In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(3)  Charter. The terms "Charter" or "City Charter" shall refer to The Charter of the city of White Plains. 
Editor's note— The city's Charter is Chapter 356 of the Laws of 1915, as amended. 
(4)  City. The term "city" shall refer to the city of White Plains, Westchester County, New York. 
(5)  City limits, city boundaries or corporate limits. These terms shall refer to territory included within the legal boundaries of the city. 
(6)  Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the "White Plains Municipal Code." 
(7)  Common council or council. The terms "common council" or "council" shall mean the common council of the city as established by the Charter. 
(8)  County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the county of Westchester in the state of New York. 
(9)  Delegation of authority. Unless governed by other applicable law, whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designates otherwise. 
(10)  Mayor. Whenever the word "mayor" is used, it shall mean the mayor of the city as established by the Charter. 
(11)  Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the words "of the city of White Plains" were added. 
(12)  Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
(13)  NYCRR: The term "NYCRR" shall refer to the "Codes, Rules and Regulations of the State of New York." 
(14)  Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
(15)  State. The words "the state" shall be construed to mean the state of New York. 
Charter reference— What are deemed public streets, § 120.  
Sec. 1-1-3. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules or regulations passed subsequent to this Code, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules or regulations, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules or regulations until such time that this Code and subsequent laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules or regulations numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the common council. 
(b)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the White Plains Municipal Code is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered _____, which said section shall read as follows: …." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. In lieu of designating the number of the section to be added, the ordinance adding the section to the Code may provide that said section may be appropriately numbered for inclusion in said Code. 
(c)  In any law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation amending this Code, or repealing a portion thereof, the first section shall state the chapter and section numbers to be amended in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  If the portion to be amended has not been amended since the adoption of this Code only the identifying section, subsection or subdivision number shall be stated. 
(2)  If the portion has been amended since the adoption of this Code only the identifying section, subsection or subdivision number together with the date of the last amendment shall be stated.  
Sec. 1-1-4. - Severability of parts of Code. 
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of the court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code.

Chapter 2-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 2-1-1. - Election districts. 
(a)  The following election districts are created and established in the city which districts shall be bounded and described as follows: 
(1)  Election District No. 1. Beginning at a point formed by the intersection of the center line of Richbell Road with the center line of Sammis Lane; running thence in an easterly direction along the center line of Sammis Lane to the center line of Maplemoor Lane; running thence in an easterly direction along the center line of Maplemoor Lane to the center line of North Street; running thence in a southerly direction along the center line of North Street to the division line between the Town of Harrison and the City of White Plains; running thence in a northeasterly and northerly direction along said division line to the center line of the Corporate Park Drive Bridge; running thence in a westerly direction along the center line of the Corporate Park Drive Bridge to the center line of Havilands Lane; running thence in a westerly and northerly direction along the center line of Havilands Lane to the center line of Ridgeway; running thence in a westerly direction along the center line of Ridgeway to the center line of Richbell Road; running thence in a southerly direction along the center line of Richbell Road to the center line of Sammis Lane at the point or place of beginning. 
(2)  Election District No. 2. Beginning at a point formed by the intersection of the center line of Mamaroneck Avenue with the center line of Heatherbloom Road; running thence in an easterly, northerly and easterly direction along the center line of Heatherbloom Road to the center line of Hathaway Lane; running thence in a northerly direction along the center line of Hathaway Lane to the center line of Bryant Avenue; running thence in an easterly direction along the center line of Bryant Avenue to the center line of Westchester or Avenue (eastbound lane); running thence in a northwesterly direction along the center line of Westchester Avenue (eastbound lane) to the center line of the William Butcher Bridge if it were extended; running thence in a northeasterly direction along the extended center line of the William Butcher Bridge and the William Butcher Bridge to the division line between the Town of Harrison and the City of White Plains; running thence in a southerly direction along the division line between the Town of Harrison and the City of White Plains to the center line of the Corporate Park Drive Bridge; running thence in a westerly direction along the center line of the Corporate Park Drive Bridge to the center line of Havilands Lane; running thence in a westerly and northerly direction along the center line of Havilands Lane to the center line of Ridgeway; running thence in a westerly direction along the center line of Ridgeway to the center line of Hathaway Lane; running thence in a northerly direction along the center line of Hathaway Lane to the center line of Gedney Esplanade; running thence in a westerly direction along the center line of Gedney Esplanade to the center line of Mamaroneck Avenue; running thence in a northerly direction along the center line of Mamaroneck Avenue to the center line of Heatherbloom Road at the point or place of beginning.

Charter reference— Election districts, § 12. 
State Law reference— Election districts required, Elections Law, § 4-100.  
Sec. 2-1-2. - Municipal office and business hours. 
Municipal office buildings shall be open for the transaction of business from Monday to Friday, both inclusive, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. except such portions of said buildings as are required for city court, police, fire fighting, caretakers and similar services or for emergency services. The mayor may, by proclamation, designate a day, or a portion of a day, immediately preceding or succeeding a holiday, when municipal office buildings shall be closed. 
(Ord. of 2-15-47, § 301; Ord. of 12-16-74, § 1) 
Charter reference— Power of council to determine office hours, § 19. 
State Law reference— Operating hours of public offices, Public Officers Law, § 62.  
Sec. 2-1-3. - Waiver of certain fees for public agencies. 
(a)  The commissioner of public works may waive all fees specified in chapter 7-3 of this Code in connection with permits issued to or for any department or board of the city, the White Plains Parking Authority and the White Plains City School District, provided the commissioner of public works is satisfied that such waiver of fees will inure to the benefit, respectively, of the city, the White Plains Parking Authority and the White Plains City School District and not to the benefit of any contractor involved in such construction work. 
(b)  The commissioner of building is hereby authorized, in his discretion, to waive all fees specified in chapters 9-5 and 9-7 of this Code (the building code and the plumbing code) in connection with permits issued to or for any department or board of the city, the White Plains Parking Authority and the White Plains City School District, provided the commissioner of building is satisfied that such waiver of fees will inure to the benefit, respectively, of the city, the White Plains Parking Authority and the White Plains City School District and not to the benefit of any contractor involved in such construction work. 
(Res. of 3-20-67)  
Sec. 2-1-4. - Public housing agency designated. 
The city, acting through its commissioner of planning, is hereby designated as the public housing agency for the city in connection with the existing housing program of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development pursuant to Section 8 of Title II of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 (Public Law 93-383). 
(Res. of 5-3-76)  
Sec. 2-1-4.1. - Municipal housing authority. 
The city, acting through its duly elected common council, for and on behalf of the city, hereby elects to have and exercise the rights, powers and privileges of a municipal housing authority, pursuant to the provisions of section 55 of the Public Housing Law, and, in connection therewith, to be subject to the duties and obligations granted to or imposed on such authorities by such law, with respect to projects designed to provide housing for eligible persons and families as defined in the United States Housing Authority Act of 1967. 
(Res. of 6-7-82, § 1)  
Sec. 2-1-5. - Corporation counsel to keep records of notices of claims. 
The corporation counsel is designated as the officer to make and keep records of notices of claim filed against the city. 
(Res. of 6-4-56) 
State Law reference— Filing of claims against city, General Municipal Law, § 50-e; designation of officer to keep record of claims filed, General Municipal Law, § 50-f.  
Sec. 2-1-6. - Enclosure of notices of newspaper pickup and glass salvaging in water and tax bills. 
When requested by the commissioner of public works, the commissioner of finance shall enclose with city tax and water bills, notices relating to the city's program of glass salvage and newspaper pickup and recycling. 
(Res. of 11-4-74) 
State Law reference— Power of council to require that notices relating to various municipal services be included in tax bill, Tax Law, § 5.  
Sec. 2-1-7. - Aid by fire department to other political subdivisions. 
The chief of the fire department may authorize and permit fire companies of the city to go to aid another city, village, town or fire district or territory outside of a city, village or fire district in extinguishing fires therein; provided, however, that no more than two companies shall be authorized and permitted to leave the city at one time without the consent of the commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. of 8-3-31, § 1) 
State Law reference— Authority of council to restrict service by fire department outside of corporate limits, General Municipal Law, § 209.  
Sec. 2-1-8. - [Authority to grant, request police assistance from and to other local governments—Delegated to chief of police.] 
The powers granted to the mayor of the city of White Plains pursuant to section 209-m of the general municipal law of the state of New York relating to the requesting and granting of police assistance from and to other local governments is hereby delegated to the chief of police. 
(L.L. No. 1-1968, § 1)  
Sec. 2-1-9. - [Same—Definition.] 
The term "chief of police" as used herein shall include any police officer in command of the police department of the city of White Plains during the absence, illness or disability of the chief of police or who is authorized by the rules and regulations of the police department of the city of White Plains to exercise the powers of the chief of police in emergency situations. 
(L.L. No. 1-1968, § 2)  
Sec. 2-1-10. - [Sale of city-owned real property—Generally.] 
Except as otherwise provided by sections 105 and 207-a of the Charter of the city of White Plains, real property owned by the city of White Plains may be sold only pursuant to the provisions of this local law [sections 2-1-10—2-1-16]. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 1)  
Sec. 2-1-11. - [Same—Council resolution generally.] 
Real property owned by the city of White Plains must be sold at a public auction pursuant to the provisions of section 23(2)(b) of the General City Law unless the common council by resolution determines that: 
(a)  a private sale of a certain parcel of city-owned real property is in the best interests of the city; and 
(b)  said private sale will enhance and promote the economic well-being of the city. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 2)  
Sec. 2-1-12. - [Same—Contents of resolution.] 
A resolution adopted pursuant to section 2 of this local law [division] which authorizes a private sale of certain city-owned real property shall authorize the mayor: 
(a)  to solicit proposals or to list the property with a broker for the purchase and development of said real estate; 
(b)  to receive said proposals, and to negotiate the proposed purchase price and other details of each proposal with each applicant. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 3)  
Sec. 2-1-13. - [Same—Report to common council upon negotiations.] 
Upon completion of the negotiations with each applicant the mayor shall submit to the common council a report which shall contain: 
(a)  an analysis of the proposals submitted by each applicant and as changed, altered or amended thereafter; and 
(b)  a recommendation to accept one proposal or to reject all proposals, which recommendation states the reasons therefor. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 4)  
Sec. 2-1-14. - [Same—Approval by common council.] 
The common council, by resolution, may approve the recommended proposal and authorize the mayor to execute any and all necessary documents on behalf of the city as may be needed to complete the sale of the premises, subject to: 
(a)  the applicant complying with all codes, ordinances and zoning procedures of the city of White Plains; and 
(b)  satisfaction of such other conditions as may be imposed by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 5)  
Sec. 2-1-15. - [Same—Payment of recording tax, etc.] 
The purchaser or purchasers on any such sale shall pay the mortgage recording tax and recording fees and pay for and affix to such instruments any and all revenue stamps that may be necessary. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 6)  
Sec. 2-1-16. - [Same—Mortgage, etc.] 
As a part of the purchase price for the sale of real property, the city, when so authorized by the common council, shall have the right and it is hereby authorized to take, in the name of the city, a purchase money bond and mortgage or bonds and mortgages in an amount or amounts not to exceed sixty per centum of the sale price, due as to principal not more than five years from the date of the closing of title, to bear interest at a rate to be stated, and upon such other terms and conditions as may be authorized and fixed by the common council. 
(L.L. No. 8-1982, § 8)  
Sec. 2-1-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— At the discretion of the city, § 2-1-17 is hereby repealed. Said provisions pertained to authorizing the corporation counsel to employ special counsel to provide services relating to the disposition of cases involving injuries or long term illness in the department of public safety and derived from Ord. of 7-5-16 , §§ 1, 2.  
Chapter 2-2 - PUBLIC RECORDS  
ARTICLE I. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted Apr. 3, 1989, repealed §§ 2-2-1, 2-2-2, relating to retention of records, derived from Ordinances adopted Feb. 26, 1975, and July 10, 1978, and a resolution adopted June 16, 1975, and added new §§ 2-2-1—2-2-7. Section 2 renumbered former § 2-2-3 as § 2-2-8. 
 
Sec. 2-2-1. - Records management officer. 
The city clerk is hereby designated the Records Management Officer of the City of White Plains; and he shall be responsible for administering the City of White Plains' non-current and archival public records and records storage facilities in accordance with local, state and federal laws and guidelines. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-2. - Powers and duties. 
The records management officer shall carry out the efficient administration, determination of value, use, preservation, storage and disposition of the non-current and archival public records kept, filed or received by the offices and departments of The City of White Plains. 
The records management officer shall: 
(a)  Continually survey and examine public records to recommend their classification so as to determine the most suitable methods to be used for the maintaining, storing and servicing of archival material. Records shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Obsolete and unnecessary records according to New York State Records Retention and Disposition Schedules, thereby subject to disposition; or 
(2)  Information containing administrative, legal, fiscal, research historical or educational value which warrant their permanent retention; or 
(3)  Records not subject to disposition according to state law. 
(b)  Establish guidelines for proper records management in any department or agency of the City of White Plains in accordance with local, state and federal laws and guidelines. 
(c)  Report annually to the chief executive official and the governing body on the powers and duties herein mentioned. 
(d)  Operate records management centers for the storage, processing and servicing of all non-current and archival records for all departments and agencies. 
(e)  Establish a City of White Plains Archives and perform the following functions: 
(1)  Advise and assist departments in reviewing and selecting material to be transferred to the archives for preservation. 
(2)  Continually survey and examine public records to determine the most suitable methods to be used for the creating, maintaining, storing and servicing of archival materials. 
(3)  Establish and maintain an adequate repository(ies) for the proper storage, conservation, processing and servicing of archival records. 
(4)  Promulgate rules governing public access to and use of records in the archives, subject to the approval of the records advisory board. 
(5)  Develop a confidentiality policy for archival records designated confidential, providing such policy does not conflict with any federal or state statutes. 
(6)  Provide information services to other city offices. 
(7)  Collect archival materials which are not official City of White Plains records but which have been associational value to the city or a close relationship to the existing archival collection. Such collecting shall be subject to archive space, staff, and cost limitations, and to the potential endangerment of such materials if they are not collected by the archives. 
(8)  Develop a procedure whereby historically important records are to be identified at the point of generation. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-3. - Records advisory board. 
There shall be a records advisory board designated to work closely with and provide advice to the records management officer. The board shall consist of the city clerk, corporation counsel, commissioner of finance, commissioner of public safety, and the mayor or his designee. The board shall meet periodically and have the following duties: 
(a)  Provide advice to the records management officer on the development of the records management program. 
(b)  Review the performance of the program on an ongoing basis and propose changes and improvements. 
(c)  Review retention periods proposed by the records management officer for records not covered by state archives' schedules. 
(d)  Provide advice on the appraisal of records for archival value and to be the final sign-off entity as to what is or is not archival. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-4. - Custody. 
(a)  Non-Current Public Records: Each department is the legal custodian of its records and shall retain custody of records deposited in the records center. 
(b)  Archival Public Records: Records transferred to or acquired by the archives shall be under the custody and control of the archives rather than the department which created or held them immediately prior to being transferred to the archives. 
(1)  Records shall be transferred to the archives upon the recommendation of the records management officer, with approval of the head of the department which has custody of the records and the approval of the records advisory board. 
(2)  Records may be permanently removed from the archives at the request of the records management officer or the head of the department which had custody of the records immediately prior to the transfer of those records to the archives, subject to the approval of the records advisory board. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-5. - Replevin. 
The law department may take steps to recover local government records which have been alienated from proper custody, and may, when necessary, institute actions of replevin. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-6. - Disposal of records. 
No records shall be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by a department of the City of White Plains unless approval has been obtained from the records management officer. No records shall be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the records management officer without the express written consent of the department head having authority. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1) 
Editor's note— By a resolution adopted Apr. 3, 1979, the city adopted the Records Retention and Disposition Schedule MU-1 pursuant to Art. 57-A of the Arts & Cultural Affairs Law.  
Sec. 2-2-7. - Definitions. 
(a)  Archives means those official records which have been determined by the records management officer and records advisory board to have sufficient historical or other value to warrant their continued preservation by the government. 
(b)  Records means any documents, books, papers, photographs, sound recordings, microforms, computer tapes/disks, or any other materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in connection with the transaction of official city business. 
(c)  Records management means the planning, controlling, directing, organizing, training, promotion and other managerial, use and records disposition, including records preservation, records disposal and records center or other storage facilities. 
(d)  Records disposition means: 
(1)  The removal in accordance with approved records control schedules, of records no longer necessary for the conduct of general municipal business by methods which may include: 
(i)  The disposal of temporary records by destruction or donation; or 
(ii)  The transfer of records to the records center/archives for temporary storage of inactive records and permanent storage of records determined to have historical or other sufficient value warranting continued preservation; and 
(2)  The transfer of records from one city department or agency to any other city department or agency. 
(e)  Records center means an establishment(s) maintained by the City of White Plains for the storage, servicing, security and processing of non-current or archival public records. 
(f)  Servicing means making information in records available for official or public use. 
(Ord. of 4-3-89, § 1)  
Sec. 2-2-8. - Fee for obtaining certain documents from department of public safety. 
(a)  The following fees are hereby established for the issuance of transcripts of such police & fire records as are available to the public, non-criminal multiple record searches, accident reports, aided cases, detective reports, photographs, good conduct certificates, miscellaneous public safety reports, incident reports (UF-6's), processing gun permits, non-criminal fingerprinting and basic field incident reports, etc.: 
Non-criminal multiple record searches ..... $25.00 
Copy of accident report ..... 10.00 
Each additional copy ..... 2.00 
Copy of aided case ..... 5.00 
Copy of statements or reports in the detective division ..... 10.00 
Each additional copy ..... 2.00 
Photographs—per print ..... 20.00 
Each additional print (copy) ..... 5.00 
Good conduct certificates ..... 25.00 
Miscellaneous public safety reports ..... 3.00 
Incident reports (UF-6) ..... 5.00 
Each additional copy ..... 1.00 
Processing pistol permits (original) ..... 100.00 
Amending pistol permits ..... 20.00 
Non-criminal fingerprinting (per card) ..... 25.00 
Basic field incident report ..... 10.00 
(b)  The department of public safety shall daily report to the commissioner of finance as to the issuance of such transcripts, letters, prints or photographs and remit the fees therefor to the commissioner of finance. 
(c)  Such fees shall be waived by the department of public safety for transcripts, prints or photographs furnished to departments, boards or offices of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-1-61, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 8-3-64, § 1; Ord. of 1-16-67, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-71, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 8-3-82, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 5-16-83; Ord. of 4-3-89, § 2; Ord. of 5-22-08, § 1; Ord. of 5-17-16 , § 5)  
Secs. 2-2-9—2-2-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Rules and regulations for public access to records required, Public Officers Law, § 87. 
 
Sec. 2-2-16. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  This article is established pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, known as the Freedom of Information Law. 
(b)  This article provides for the procedure by which records of the city may be obtained for inspection and copies thereof obtained. It does not apply to the White Plains Parking Authority, White Plains Housing Authority, the White Plains Urban Renewal Agency, the City Court of White Plains or the White Plains Public Schools all of which are subject to their own or other regulations. 
(c)  Personnel of the city shall furnish to the public the information and records required by law and those which were furnished to the public prior to enactment of the Freedom of Information Law, subject to the conditions contained in subdivisions 3 and 7 of Section 88 of the Freedom of Information Law, or other provisions of law. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 1) 
State Law reference— Freedom of Information Law, Public Officers Law, § 84 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2-17. - Records access officer. 
(a)  The mayor shall be responsible for assuring compliance with this article and shall designate one or more persons, by name or by specific job title, and official address, as records access officers. 
(b)  The records access officer shall be responsible for assuring appropriate response to public requests for access to records. The records access officers shall assure that appropriate personnel are adequately instructed in and properly perform the functions described in sections 2-2-21 and 2-2-22 of this Code, and shall supervise the administration of this article. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 2)  
Sec. 2-2-18. - Fiscal officer. 
The mayor shall designate some person who is charged with certifying the payroll as the "fiscal officer" for the purposes of the Freedom of Information Law. Such officer shall: 
(a)  Respond in accordance with section 2-2-21 of this Code, to written requests for an itemized record setting forth the name, address, title and salary of every officer or employee of the city; and 
(b)  Make the payroll items listed above available to any person including bona fide members of the news media as provided in Sections 88(1)(g) and 88(10) of the Freedom of Information Law. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 3) 
State Law reference— Freedom of Information Law, Public Officers Law, § 84 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2-19. - Location. 
Records shall be available for public inspection and copying at: City Hall, 255 Main Street, White Plains, N. Y.; Municipal Building Annex, rear of City Hall; Public Safety, 279 Hamilton Avenue, White Plains, N. Y.; Police Headquarters, 279 Hamilton Avenue, White Plains, N. Y.; Department of Recreation, Gedney Way, White Plains, New York; Fire Headquarters, Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, N. Y.; Public Library, Martine Ave., W. P., N. Y. or at the location where they are kept. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 4)  
Sec. 2-2-20. - Hours for public inspection. 
Requests for public access to records shall be accepted and records produced during all hours regularly open for business except that all records must be returned to their proper custodian at least five (5) minutes before closing time. 
Hours regularly open for business are 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 5)  
Sec. 2-2-21. - Requests for public access to records. 
(a)  All requests for records pursuant to the provisions hereof shall be in writing. A records access form will be provided to the requester by the records access officer. Such form may provide for the signature, name and address of the requester. 
(b)  Except under extraordinary circumstances, officials shall respond to a request for records no more than five business days after receipt of the request, whether the request is oral or in writing. 
If, because of extraordinary circumstances, more than five business days are required to respond to a request, receipt of the request shall be acknowledged within five (5) business days after the request is received. The acknowledgement shall state the reason for delay and estimate the date when a replay will be made. A request for voluminous records or any request which would, in the opinion of the appropriate records access officer disrupt or interrupt the regular functioning of the city agency to whom such request is directed if complied with within five (5) days, shall be considered an extraordinary circumstance. 
(c)  A request for access to records shall be sufficiently detailed to identify the records. Where possible, the requester should supply information regarding dates, titles, file designations or other information which may help identify the records. The records access officer may in his discretion, require that a request for any or all records falling within a specific category be revised to provide the details referred to above, and shall aid the requester in complying. 
(d)  A current list, by subject matter, of all records produced, filed, or first kept or promulgated after September 1, 1974 shall be available for public inspection and copying. The list shall contain sufficient detail to permit the requester to identify the file category of the records sought. The list may also specify those categories of records of any agency which are not publicly available, by reason of any statute, rule, regulation or privilege not in conflict with the Freedom of Information Law. 
The subject matter list shall be updated periodically and the date of the most recent updating shall appear on the first page. The updating of the subject matter list shall not be less than semiannual. 
(e)  Appropriate personnel of the city shall assist the requester in identifying requested records. 
(f)  Upon locating the requested records the appropriate personnel of the city shall, as promptly as possible, and within the time limits set in subsection (b) above, either: 
(1)  Make the records available for inspection, or, 
(2)  Deny access in whole or part, and explain in writing the reasons therefor. 
(g)  Upon failure to locate records the appropriate official shall certify that: 
(1)  The city is not the legal custodian of the requested records; or, 
(2)  The requested records, after diligent search, cannot be found. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 6) 
State Law reference— Freedom of Information Law, Public Officers Law, § 84 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2-22. - Inspection and copying of records. 
(a)  A person who has requested access to the public records of this city shall be given full opportunity to see and inspect such records, unless access is denied as provided in section 2-2-23 of this Code. 
(b)  The requester may also make a copy of the records he inspects, but no record may be removed from the office where it is located without the written permission of the person in charge of the office at that time. 
(c)  Upon request and payment of the established fee, if any, the appropriate officer or employee shall prepare and deliver a transcript of such records. 
(d)  Upon request and payment of the established fee, if any, an appropriate official of the city shall certify as correct a transcript prepared by the custodian of the records. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 7)  
Sec. 2-2-23. - Denial of access to records. 
(a)  Denial of access to records shall be in writing stating the reason therefor and advising the requester of the right to appeal to the individual or body established to hear appeals. 
(b)  If requested records are not provided promptly, as required in section 2-2-21, subsection (b) of this Code, such failure shall also be deemed a denial of access. 
(c)  The mayor shall designate a person or body to hear appeals from denial of access to records. 
(d)  The time for deciding an appeal by the individual or body designated to hear appeals shall commence upon receipt of written appeal identifying: 
(1)  The date of the appeal. 
(2)  The date and location of the requests for records. 
(3)  The records to which the requester was denied access. 
(4)  Whether the denial of access was in writing or was by failure to provide records promptly as required by such section 2-2-21, subsection (b). 
(5)  The name and return address of the requester. 
(e)  The individual or body designated to hear appeals shall inform the requester of its decision in writing within seven business days of receipt of an appeal. 
(f)  A final denial of access to a requested record, as provided for in subdivision (e) of this section, shall be subject to court review, as provided for in Article 78 of the Civil Practice Law and Rules. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 8)  
Sec. 2-2-24. - Fees. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically authorized by law, including but not limited to, those fees established by section 2-2-8 or 2-3-21 of this Code, and section 50 of the Charter or by established practice prior to September 1, 1974, there shall be no fee charged for: 
(1)  Inspection of records; 
(2)  Search for records; 
(3)  Any certification pursuant to this part. 
(b)  The fee for a photocopy transcript of records shall be twenty-five cents ($0.25) per page for pages not exceeding eight and one-half (8½) by fourteen (14) inches. 
(c)  The fee for photocopies of records exceeding eight and one-half (8½) by fourteen (14) inches per page shall be the actual cost of such photocopies, which shall be deemed to be the average unit cost for making such a photocopy, excluding fixed costs such as operator salaries. 
(d)  The fee for a transcript that is typed, hand-written, or otherwise prepared by hand shall cover the clerical time involved in making the transcript, including comparison for accuracy. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 9)  
Sec. 2-2-25. - Public notice. 
A notice containing the job title or name and business address of the records access officers and "fiscal officer"; the name, job title, business address and telephone number of the appeal person or persons or body; and the location where records can be seen or copies [copied], shall be posted in a conspicuous location wherever records are kept, and/or published in a newspaper. 
(Res. of 6-16-75, § 10)  
Secs. 2-2-26—2-2-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CYBER INFORMATION SECURITY BREACH AND NOTIFICATION POLICY 
 
Sec. 2-2-41. - Cyber information security breach and notification policy. 
This policy is consistent with the State Technology Law § 208 as added by Chapters 442 and 491 of the Laws of 2005. This policy requires notification to affected New York residents and non-residents. New York State and the City of White Plains value the protection of private information of individuals. The City of White Plains is required to notify an individual when data, which is maintained by the city and contains the individual's private information, has been, or is reasonably believed to have been, compromised. 
The city, after consulting with the state's office of cyber security and critical infrastructure coordination (CSCIC) to determine the scope of the breach and restoration measures of its compromised data, must notify an individual, when it has been determined that there has been, or is reasonably believed to have been, a compromise of the individual's private information through unauthorized disclosure. 
A compromise of private information means the unauthorized acquisition of unencrypted computerized data with private information. 
If encrypted data is compromised along with the corresponding encryption key, the data is considered unencrypted and thus falls under the notification requirements. 
Notification may be delayed if a law enforcement agency determines that the notification impedes a criminal investigation. In such case, notification will be delayed only as long as needed to determine that notification no longer compromises any investigation. 
The city will notify the affected individual directly by one of the following methods: 
a.  Written notice; 
b.  Electronic notice, provided that the person to whom notice is required has expressly consented to receiving notice in electronic form and a log of each notification is kept by the city that notifies affected persons in such form; 
c.  Telephone notification, provided that a log of each notification is kept by the city that notifies affected persons; or 
d.  Substitute notice, if the city demonstrates to the state attorney general that the cost of providing notice would exceed two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00), that the affected class of persons to be notified exceeds five hundred thousand (500,000), or that the city does not have sufficient contact information. The following constitute sufficient substitute notice: 
i. E-mail notice when the city has an e-mail address for the subject persons: 
ii. Conspicuous posting of the notice on the city's web site page, if the city maintains one; and 
iii. Notification to major statewide media. 
The city must notify, CSCIC as to the timing, content and distribution of the notices and approximate number of affected persons. 
The city must notify the attorney general and the consumer protection board, whenever notification to a New York resident is necessary, as to the timing, content and distribution of the notices and approximate number of affected persons. 
Regardless of the method by which notice is provided, the notice must include contact information for the city making the notification and a description of the categories of information that were, or are reasonably believed to have been, acquired by a person without valid authorization, including specification of which elements of personal information and private information were, or are reasonably believed to have been, so acquired. 
This policy applies not only to information maintained by the city itself, but also to information maintained on behalf of the city by a third party. 
When more than five thousand (5,000) New York residents must be notified at one time, then the city must notify the consumer reporting agencies as to the timing, content and distribution of the notices and the approximate number of affected individuals. This notice, however, will be made without delaying notice to the individuals. 
Definitions: 
a.  Consumer reporting agency: Any person which, for monetary fees, dues, or on a cooperative nonprofit basis, regularly engages in whole or in part in the practice of assembling or evaluating consumer credit information or other information on consumers for the purpose of furnishing consumer reports to third parties, and which used any means or facility of interstate commerce for the purpose of preparing or furnishing consumer reports. The state Attorney General is responsible for compiling a list of consumer reporting agencies and furnishing the list, upon request, to the city. 
b.  Data: Any information created, stored (in temporary or permanent files), filed, produced or reproduced, regardless of the form or media. Data may include, but is not limited to, personally identifying information, reports, files, folders, memoranda, statements, examinations, transcripts, images, communications, electronic or hard copy. 
c.  Information: The representation of facts, concepts, or instructions in a formalized manner suitable for communication, interpretation, or processing by human or automated means. 
(Res. of 4-3-06, §§ I—XII)  
Chapter 2-3 - COMMON COUNCIL[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference— Common council generally, § 28 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 2-3-1—2-3-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Power of council to determine its rules of procedure, § 29. 
State Law reference— Open Meetings Law, Public Officers Law, § 95 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-3-16. - Stated meetings. 
Stated meetings of the common council shall be held on the first Monday of each month, except that should the first Monday be a holiday, the meeting shall be held on the next day. Stated meetings shall be called to order at 7:30 p.m., and the common council shall attempt to adjourn no later than 12:00 a.m. (midnight). If there is any unfinished business still remaining, the common council shall reconvene the following evening at 7:30 p.m. to take up such unfinished business, unless an alternative date and/or time certain is voted upon by a majority of the members of the common council prior to the adjournment of the stated meeting. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 1; Res. of 11-21-77; Res. of 3-7-88; Res. of 9-6-01) 
Charter reference— Power of common council to set meeting date, § 28.  
Sec. 2-3-17. - Special meetings. 
Special meetings may be called by the mayor, as provided for in the city charter, and shall be called by him at the request of any two (2) councilmen by their giving the mayor written notice thereof, which such written notice shall contain a statement of the object for which the special meeting shall be called and also shall state the time and place for the holding of such meeting. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 2) 
Charter reference— Calling of special meetings, § 28.  
Sec. 2-3-18. - Notice of special meetings. 
The mayor shall cause written notice of a special meeting to be left at the residence or place of business of each member of the common council at least six (6) hours before the time for which the meeting is called. Such notice shall state the object for which such special meeting is called and shall also state the time and place of the holding of such meeting. In lieu of the aforesaid method of service of notice of a special meeting, the mayor may cause written notice of such special meeting to be sent to each member of the common council by special delivery mail, directed to the residence or place of business of the member, at least twenty-four (24) hours before the time for which the meeting is called. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 3) 
Charter reference— Council to designate notice of special meetings, § 28.  
Sec. 2-3-19. - Transaction of business at special meetings. 
At special meetings the business to be transacted thereat shall be only that stated in the notice of such meeting, except that any other business may be transacted at such special meeting by the unanimous consent of all of the members of the common council. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 4)  
Sec. 2-3-20. - Calendar. 
(a)  The clerk shall prepare a calendar for each stated meeting of the common council, which shall list the matters to be considered by the council at such meeting and which shall include a reference to all communications and other matters in writing which shall have been received by the clerk not later than noon of the seventh business day preceding the date of the meeting. Said calendar shall list the matters to be considered by the council insofar as is possible in the order set forth in section 2-3-22 of this Code. The clerk shall arrange for the delivery of a copy of the calendar to each member of the council not later than the morning of the third day preceding the date of the meeting. No matters shall be considered at a stated meeting of the council unless listed in the calendar, except by unanimous consent of all members of the council present at the meeting. 
(b)  Requests by members of the public to address the common council may be in writing, stating: (i) name and address of the applicant; (ii) subject matter; and (iii) approximate time requested to address the council which shall not exceed five (5) minutes. At the council meeting, it is recommended that the applicant submit to the city clerk a written copy of his or her statement to the common council. 
(Res. of 5-4-64, Rule 5; Res. of 3-7-88)  
Sec. 2-3-21. - Copies of calendar matters. 
At any time after 9:00 a.m. of the third day preceding the date of each stated meeting, the city clerk shall during his regular office hours furnish to any person appearing personally at his office and requesting the same, a copy of any communication or other written document which accompanies or is part of any item appearing on the common council calendar, which has not yet been adopted by the common council. The person appearing and making such request shall pay to the clerk the sum of twenty-five cents ($0.25) for each page or part thereof of each copy of the communication or other written document which is requested by and furnished to him. 
This section is not to be construed to require the city clerk to reproduce any documents, communications or matters which contain pictures or other items not readily reproduced by the average reproduction machine. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 5A; Res. of 11-4-68; Res. of 3-7-88)  
Sec. 2-3-22. - Order of business. 
The order of business at stated meetings of the common council shall be as follows: 
(a)  Roll call. 
(b)  Action upon date and time for adjournment of meeting. 
(c)  Introduction of local laws. 
(d)  Messages from the mayor in relation to local laws. 
(e)  Reports of committees in relation to local laws. 
(f)  Public hearings in relation to local laws. 
(g)  Discussion and action on local laws. 
(h)  Public hearings in relation to matters other than local laws. 
(i)  Correction or amendment of minutes. 
(j)  Action upon ordinances introduced at a prior meeting. 
(k)  Action upon ordinances not previously introduced. 
(l)  Action upon resolutions. 
(m)  Communications from the mayor and heads of departments and reports of committees. 
(n)  Miscellaneous business. 
(o)  Consideration of matters not listed on calendar, if unanimous consent given by members of council present at meeting. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 6; Res. of 3-7-88)  
Sec. 2-3-23. - Suspension of regular order of business. 
The regular order of business at a stated meeting may at any time be suspended by the affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members of the common council present at such meeting. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 7)  
Sec. 2-3-24. - Order of business at special meetings. 
The order of business at special meetings of the common council shall be as follows: 
(a)  Roll call. 
(b)  Consideration of business specified in the notice of the special meeting. 
(c)  Consideration of other business, if unanimous consent given by all members of the council. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 8)  
Sec. 2-3-25. - Every member present to vote. 
Every member of the common council present at any meeting thereof, when a question is put, shall vote for or against the same unless excused by the council. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 9)  
Sec. 2-3-26. - Withdrawal of member from meeting. 
No member shall withdraw from a meeting of the common council without the permission of the mayor. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 10)  
Sec. 2-3-27. - Robert's Rules of Order Revised for Deliberative Assemblies to be used. 
All questions of order or procedure of the common council not herein provided for shall be decided in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order Revised for Deliberative Assemblies. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 11)  
Sec. 2-3-28. - Local laws generally. 
In introducing, presenting and transmitting local laws, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(a)  Every local law shall be introduced by a member or on the report of a committee. 
(b)  If a local law purports to change or supersede any provision of an act of the legislature or to amend an existing local law it shall show all the new matter underscored and all the matter to be eliminated in brackets and when such local law is printed or reprinted all new matter must appear in italics and all matter to be eliminated in brackets. 
(c)  Every local law introduced shall be deposited with the city clerk and shall be read in its order of introduction when the order of business "Introduction of local laws" shall be reached. 
(d)  The clerk shall cause every local law immediately upon its introduction to be copied (or printed) and placed on the desks of the members; he shall number them consecutively as received. Such number shall be retained as an introductory number. Each local law shall also have a print (or draft) number, and if the same is printed (or redrafted), the original print (or draft) number shall be retained and there shall be added its new print (or draft) number. 
(Res. of 12-6-43)  
Sec. 2-3-29. - [Notice of hearing on enactment of local laws.] 
When a proposed local law shall be in its final form, the common council shall fix a day for a public hearing before it concerning such local law. The city clerk shall cause public notice of the time of such hearing to be published in the official newspaper for at least three (3) days. Such hearing shall be had not earlier than five (5) days after the day of the last publication of such notice. Such notice shall contain the title of such local law and an explanatory statement thereof prepared by the city clerk. 
(L.L. No. 1-1924, § 1; L.L. No. 2-1939, § 1)  
Sec. 2-3-30. - Procedure relative to retirement from police force and fire department. 
(a)  An application to the common council, as the board of trustees of the police pension fund or of the fire department pension fund, by a member of the police force or of the fire department for retirement shall be in writing and shall contain as a minimum the following: 
(1)  Name of applicant. 
(2)  Address of applicant. 
(3)  Rank in the police force or in the fire department, as the case may be. 
(4)  Present salary (on an annual basis). 
(5)  Date of birth. 
(6)  Date of becoming a member of the police force or of the fire department. 
(7)  If and when applicant signed a consent that two (2) per centum of his salary be taken for the benefit of the pension fund and whether he continued to permit the same to be taken so long as he has been an active member of the police force or fire department. 
(8)  Whether applicant has been continuously a member of the force or department since he became a member thereof and, if not, specific information as to the dates of service. 
(9)  Whether applicant is applying for retirement because of physical or mental disability and if so the nature and extent of the disability. 
(10)  If application is made for retirement because of permanent physical or mental disability caused while in the actual performance of police or fire duty full particulars with reference to same. 
(11)  When applicant desires retirement to be effective. 
(12)  Whether any previous application has been made by applicant for retirement and if so date or dates when application or applications made and disposition thereof. 
The application must be signed by the person applying for retirement and it must be verified by him before an officer duly authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(13)  An agreement by applicant that, upon request of the medical board, said applicant will furnish a statement of the names and addresses of all physicians who have been consulted by and all hospitals and institutions which have rendered treatment to said applicant, with a brief statement of the nature of the condition which required each consultation or treatment. Applicant shall also furnish a consent and waiver authorizing and directing such physicians, hospitals and institutions to disclose to the medical board of the city any and all information and records relating to diagnosis, treatment or case history that they may have concerning said applicant, said consent and waiver to further provide that the medical board may disclose to the common council, as trustees of the police pension fund or of the fire department pension fund, as the case may be, and/or to the commissioner of public safety of the city all or such part of said information as said board may deem advisable. 
(b)  A request by the commissioner of public safety for retirement from service of a member of the police force or of the fire department because of permanent disability of such member must be in writing and must contain such matters as are set forth in the preceding paragraph as are pertinent. Such request must state with sufficient detail the nature and extent of the disability and shall be accompanied by a certificate of the surgeon of the police force or fire department, as the case may be, or of a duly licensed physician or surgeon, certifying that the member is physically or mentally unfit for duty and the reasons therefor. Such request of the commissioner need not be verified. 
(c)  An application for retirement of a member of the police force or of the fire department, when received by the common council, shall be referred to the commissioner of public safety and to the corporation counsel for investigation and report. The report of the commissioner of public safety shall indicate whether the application meets with his approval. The common council may refer an application of a member for retirement or a request of the commissioner of public safety that a member be retired to the medical board established pursuant to the provisions of Local Law Number Two of The City of White Plains of 1943, for appropriate action pursuant to such law. 
(Res. of 12-6-43) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 2-1943 is embodied in sec. 302 of the Charter.  
Sec. 2-3-31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Res. of 7-5-06, rescinded § 2-3-31, which pertained to recording proceedings of meetings and derived from Res. of Dec. 6, 1943, Rule 15; Res. of Oct. 7, 1963.  
Sec. 2-3-32. - Executive sessions. 
Executive sessions of the common council shall be held in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Public Officers Law. 
(Res. of 12-6-43, Rule 16; Res. of 4-7-75; Res. of 3-7-88) 
State Law reference— Executive sessions of public bodies, Public Officers Law, § 100.  
Secs. 2-3-33—2-3-50. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-3-51. - Established; composition. 
There is established a personnel committee of the common council which shall consist of a total of five (5) members as follows: 
(1)  The personnel officer; 
(2)  The mayor or a representative of the mayor;

Members shall serve for two (2) year terms. 
(Res. of 8-8-75)

The personnel committee shall review such personnel matters as the mayor from time-to-time refer to it.

Chapter 2-4 - TAXATION AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Related laws reference— Capital notes, Art. A, Div. 8. 
Cross reference— Notice of newspaper pickup and glass salvaging authorized to be placed in tax bill, § 2-1-6. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-4-1. - Distribution of tax on fire insurance companies. 
(a)  The commissioner of finance is hereby authorized and directed to receive all sums of money known as the fire department tax on premiums on foreign and alien fire insurance companies pursuant to section 553 of the Insurance Law and all sums of money known as the fire insurance premium tax; foreign mutual fire insurance companies, pursuant to section 554 of the Insurance Law. 
(b)  The commissioner of finance is further authorized and directed to distribute the total amount of the aforementioned sums of money as follows: The total amount of all money received pursuant to both section 553 and section 554 of the Insurance Law in each calendar year shall be divided by the total number of paid members of the fire department, as certified by the commissioner of public safety, plus the total number of active volunteer members of the fire department as certified by the commissioner of public safety. The result of the aforesaid division shall be designated one share. 
(c)  The commissioner of finance shall, on or before July 1 of each calendar year, pay to the treasurer of the Uniformed Firemen's Benevolent Association, Inc., of White Plains such sum of money for the use and benefit of the paid members of the fire department as shall be equal to one (1) share as previously defined for each paid member of the fire department. The commissioner of finance shall pay to the treasurer of each of the seven (7) presently existing volunteer fire companies for the use and benefit of the active volunteer members of the fire department a sum of money equal to one (1) share as previously defined for each active volunteer member in that company as certified by the commissioner of public safety. 
(Res. of 6-3-68) 
Related laws reference— Tax on fire insurance companies, Art. A, Div. 4.  
Sec. 2-4-2. - Power of city to issue bonds, notes, etc. 
Neither Local Law Number 3 of the city of White Plains for the year 1939, entitled "A local law to amend the charter of the city of White Plains in relation to annual estimate; tax budget; reserve for uncollected taxes; surplus revenues; expenditure of money raised other than by municipal tax; estimates of expenditures by officers and departments; discount on prepayment of second half of city tax; disposition of water rents" nor any other local law of the city shall in any way or manner be deemed to restrict or limit in any way the power of the city to issue its bonds, notes, certificates of indebtedness or other obligations for any purpose under the charter of the city, being chapter 356 of the laws of 1915, as amended, or any general or special law. 
(L.L. No. 4-1939, § 1) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 3-1939 is embodied in §§ 60, 61, 65 and 84 of the Charter.  
Sec. 2-4-3. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-4-4. - Conversion of unregistered bonds to registered bonds. 
(a)  All serial bonds of the city authorized by the common council on or prior to April 24, 1972, shall be issued in bearer coupon form with the privilege of conversion into bonds registered as to both principal and interest and shall be payable as to both principal and interest in lawful money of the United States of America at The County Trust Company, in White Plains, New York, or, at the option of the holder, at Bankers Trust Company, in New York, New York, which by contract are the paying agents of the issuer. Such bonds shall be signed in the name of the city by its mayor and commissioner of finance; and a facsimile of its corporate seal shall be imprinted thereon and attested by its city clerk. The interest coupons shall bear the facsimile signature of the commissioner of finance. Such bonds shall contain substantially the recital of validity clause provided for in section 52.00 of the Local Finance Law and shall otherwise be in such form and contain such recitals, in addition to those required by section 51.00 of the Local Finance Law, as the commissioner of finance shall determine. 
(b)  All other matters relating to serial bonds of the city duly authorized by the common council thereof, including, but not limited to, the date, denominations, maturities and interest payment dates, within the limitations prescribed by the common council, and also including the consolidation with other issues, shall be determined by the commissioner of finance. 
(c)  The powers and duties of advertising such bonds for sale, conducting the sale and awarding the bonds are hereby delegated to the commissioner of finance, who shall advertise such bonds for sale, conduct the sale and award the bonds in such manner as he shall deem best for the interests of the city; however, in the exercise of these delegated powers, he shall comply fully with the provisions of the Local Finance Law and any order or rule of the state comptroller applicable to the sale of municipal bonds. The receipt of the commissioner of finance shall be a full acquittance to the purchaser of such bonds, who shall not be obliged to see to the application of the purchase money. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, §§ 1—3) 
State Law reference— Serial bonds, Local Finance Law, § 21.00; conversion of coupon bonds into registered bonds, § 71.00.  
Sec. 2-4-5. - Check images in lieu of cancelled checks. 
The commissioner of finance is authorized to receive, retain and/or produce check images in lieu of cancelled checks for examination or audit. 
(Ord. of 11-3-97, § 1) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Nov. 3, 1997, which pertained to check images did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion as § 2-4-5 has been at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 2-4-6—2-4-15. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-4-16. - Amount in annual budget for snow removal. 
There shall be included in the annual budget for each fiscal year an amount equal to at least the average of all expenditures for the removal of snow and ice, exclusive of salaries and wages of regular employees, except for overtime work and work on Sundays and holidays, during each of the five (5) preceding fiscal years.

ARTICLE III. - TAXATION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference— Taxation generally, § 74 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-4-41. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
(a)  From and after February 1, 1981, the City of White Plains elects to adopt the provisions of titles 2 and 3 of article 11 of the Real Property Tax Law for the purpose of enforcing the collection of delinquent taxes in such tax district. 
(b)  The four-year period referred to in subdivision 1 of section 1120 of the Real Property Tax Law be reduced to a period of two (2) years; however, for the first calendar year for which the resolution is to be effective, a tax lien owned by the tax district may be foreclosed as provided in title 3 of article 11 of the Real Property Tax Law only if there has been due and unpaid for a period of at least three (3) years from the date on which the tax on other legal charges represented thereby became a lien. 
(Res. of 2-2-81)  
Sec. 2-4-42. - Special exemption for person sixty-five years of age or older. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 467 of the Real Property Tax Law, as amended, real property in the city owned by a person or persons who qualify under that law and meet the requirements for obtaining an exemption set forth in such law, as amended, shall be exempt from general taxes levied under section 84 of the Charter of the City of White Plains to the extent of fifty (50) percent of the assessed valuation thereof, provided that the income of the owner or the combined income of the owners of the property for the income tax year immediately preceding the date of making application for exemption is less than the sum of twenty-one thousand five hundred dollars ($21,500.00). 
(b)  Pursuant to section 467 of the Real Property Tax Law for assessment rolls prepared on the basis of a taxable status date occurring on or after December 1, 2002, the exemptions provided by section 467 of the Real Property Tax Law shall be as follows:
