Pursuant to the provisions of Section 18 of the Public Officers Law, the common council hereby agrees to be held liable for costs incurred under the provisions of such section, by conferring upon the officers and employees of such city the benefits of Section 18 of such law. Such benefits shall supplement, and be available in addition to, defense or indemnification protection conferred by section 2-5-8. 
(Ord. of 10-5-81, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-9. - Assignment of policemen or firemen to public events. 
The chief of the police department or the chief of the fire department, as the case may be, may upon written request of an individual citizen or organization, provide police officers or fire fighters for special duty assignments in public or quasi-public places within the city subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  All such police officers or fire fighters shall be volunteers whose presence is not required for other police department duties, such determination to be made by the chief of police or chief of the fire department in his sole discretion. 
(b)  The chief of police or chief of the fire department, in his sole discretion, shall approve the specific location and type of duty assignment for such police officers or fire fighters. 
(c)  All such police officers or fire fighters so assigned shall be considered to be on duty for all purposes, including without limiting the generality of the foregoing, being listed on duty rosters, being subject to the supervision and direction of all their superior officers, including reassignment and relocation. 
(d)  All such police officers or fire fighters so assigned shall be paid by the city at time and one-half the regular pay rate for their individual grade and shall receive no payment from nor shall they be subject to any direction or supervision from the requesting citizen or organization. Each police officer or fire fighter so assigned shall receive a minimum of four (4) hours' pay, regardless of the time actually worked. 
(e)  The commissioner of public safety shall cause to be kept an accurate record of the time devoted to such special duty assignments by the police officers or fire fighters and shall promptly report the same to the commissioner of finance. The commissioner of finance shall, as soon as practicable, render a bill in the name of the city to the individual citizen or organization which requested such special duty assignment, in accordance with the fee schedule set forth herein. All fees set forth in such bills shall be promptly paid to the city. 
(f)  The fee schedule for such special duty assignments shall be established by the commissioner of public safety at the beginning of each fiscal year. In any event, the minimum fee payable hereunder shall be for four (4) hours. 
(Ord. of 10-21-74, § 1; Ord. of 5-5-86, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-10. - [Platoon system for fire department established; duty and off-duty hours—Designated.] 
The members of the paid fire department in the city of White Plains shall be under a two (2) platoon system. The chief of the fire department, with the approval of the commissioner of public safety, shall assign said firemen into such platoons. The day tour shall be for ten (10) hours, from eight ante meridian to six post meridian (8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.) being ten (10) hours per day and sixty (60) hours per week when on day duty, and the night tour shall be for fourteen (14) hours, from six post meridian to eight ante meridian (6:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m.), being fourteen (14) hours per night and eighty-four (84) hours per week when on night duty. There shall be granted to each officer and member of the fire department one twenty-four (24) hour day off duty each week of seven (7) days, which shall be in addition to his platoon hours off duty. Each officer and member of the fire department shall receive an additional period of twenty-four (24) consecutive hours off duty following each period of fourteen (14) days. The tours of captains, lieutenants and firemen shall be changed once in each week of seven (7) days. Officers above the rank of captain, telegraph dispatchers, electricians and firemen on special service shall not be included as working under the platoon system. 
(L.L. No. 4-1974, § 1; L.L. No. 1-1943, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-11. - [Same—Suspension of schedule during time of emergency.] 
In the event of riots, serious or multiple fires or other department emergency, the above schedule may be temporarily suspended by the officer in command of the department and the hours of duty of all members shall be as directed by the officer in command of the department. 
(L.L. No. 4-1941, § 2; Ord. of 1-1943, § 2)  
Sec. 2-5-12. - [Attendance at conferences, conventions, schools, etc.] 
The power to authorize attendance of officers or employees of the city of White Plains at official or unofficial conventions or conferences of municipal officers or employees, or to attend schools conducted for the betterment of municipal government if believed to be of benefit to the city of White Plains, is hereby delegated to the mayor, as chief executive officer of the city. 
(L.L. No. 1-1955, § 1) 
State Law reference— Expenses of public officers attending conferences, schools, etc., General Municipal Law, § 77-b.  
Sec. 2-5-13. - [Overtime pay for police—Authorized.] 
The commissioner of public safety is hereby authorized to certify overtime compensation for police patrolmen, exclusive of detectives, who volunteer to work extra hours, during times when the police force is not up to full strength, and are then required to work in excess of their regularly established hours of employment, provided that such police patrolmen are not assigned to such duty. Said overtime compensation shall be at the regular basic pay rate for each such police patrolman. 
(L.L. No. 5-1961, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-14. - [Same—Provisions inconsistent superseded.] 
The provisions of section one of chapter three hundred sixty of the laws of nineteen hundred eleven, entitled "An act to promote the health and efficiency of policemen in cities of the first and second class," as last amended by chapter nine hundred sixty-four of the laws of nineteen hundred fifty-seven insofar as they restrict or are inconsistent with the provisions of this local law, are hereby to such extent superseded. 
(L.L. No. 5-161, § 2) 
Editor's note— The above cited law is embodied in sec. 971 of the Unconsolidated Laws (McKinney).  
Sec. 2-5-15. - Judicial review committee. 
(a)  At least one month prior to the appointment of city judge, acting city judge or associate judges a judicial review committee shall be appointed by the mayor to interview candidates and review and report on their qualifications. 
(b)  Said committee shall be bi-partisan, and shall be comprised of attorneys either resident in or practicing in the city. 
(c)  The appointment of the members of the committee shall be announced to the common council. 
(d)  The committee shall receive from any source the names of candidates and shall interview qualified and eligible candidates requesting consideration. The committee shall transmit its full and complete written report on all candidates considered to the mayor who shall distribute it to the common council at least five (5) days before the appointments appear on the council agenda. 
(e)  The written report of the review committee shall be held in absolute confidence; any breach of this confidence shall nullify this section. 
(f)  The committee may adopt such procedures and policies as it may deem appropriate to its functions, including standards for evaluating the best qualified candidates for appointment. 
(Res. of 4-7-80, §§ 1—6)  
Sec. 2-5-16. - [Retirement incentive program, 1991.] 
1.  The City of White Plains hereby elects to provide all its eligible employees with a retirement incentive program authorized by Chapter 178, Laws of 1991. 
2.  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be October 1, 1991. 
3.  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit shall be ninety (90) days in length. 
4.  The actuarial present value of the additional retirement benefits payable pursuant to the provisions of this local law [section] shall be funded over a five-year period. The amount of the annual payment in each of the five (5) years shall be determined by the Actuary of the New York State and Local Employees Retirement System, and it shall be paid by The City of White Plains for each employee who receives the retirement benefits payable under this local law [section]. 
(L. L. No. 3-1991, §§ 1—4) 
Editor's note— The editor has included §§ 1—4 of L. L. No. 3-1991 as § 2-5-16.  
Sec. 2-5-16.1. - [Retirement incentive program, 1999.] 
1.  The City of White Plains hereby elects to provide all of its eligible employees with a retirement incentive program authorized by Chapter 70, Laws of 1999. 
2.  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be October 3, 1999. 
3.  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit, shall be ninety (90) days in length. 
4.  The actuarial present value of the additional retirement benefits payable pursuant to the provisions of the local law shall be paid as one (1) lump sum, or in five (5) annual installments. The amount of the annual payment shall be determined by the retirement actuary of the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System, and it shall be paid by the City of White Plains for each employee who received the benefits payable under this local law [section]. 
(L. L. No. 1-1999, §§ 1—4) 
Editor's note— L. L. No. 1-1999, §§ 1—4, has been included as § 2-5-16.1 by the editor.  
Sec. 2-5-16.2. - [Retirement incentive program, 2000.] 
1.  The City of White Plains hereby elects to provide all of its eligible employees with a retirement incentive program authorized by Chapter 86, Laws of 2000. 
2.  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be October 1, 2000. 
3.  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit, shall be ninety (90) days in length. 
4.  The actuarial present value of the additional retirement benefits payable pursuant to the provisions of the local law shall be paid as one (1) lump sum, or in five (5) annual installments. The amount of the annual payment shall be determined by the retirement actuary of the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System, and it shall be paid by the City of White Plains for each employee who received the benefits payable under this local law [section]. 
(L.L. No. 2-2000, §§ 1—4) 
Editor's note— L. L. No. 2-2000, §§ 1—4, has been included as § 2-5-16.2 by the editor.  
Secs. 2-5-17—2-5-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EXPENSES OF APPLICANTS FOR CITY POSITIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Traveling expenses for city job applicants, General Municipal Law, § 77-c. 
 
Sec. 2-5-21. - [Certification; payment by city.] 
The commissioner of finance is hereby authorized, after certification by the personnel director, to pay the expenses of job applicants who have been granted a position interview with the personnel director for municipal positions. 
(L.L. No. 2-1966, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-22. - [Enumeration of expenses; maximum amount payable by city generally.] 
Authorized payment by the commissioner of finance, after certification by the personnel director, shall be for mileage, if private conveyance is used, at the rate of eight cents ($.08) a mile, provided the mileage traveled by the job applicant is in excess of thirty-five (35) miles, or the actual fare paid to a public conveyance, provided the distance is greater than thirty-five (35) miles, the reasonable cost of lodging, if necessary, and for meals while the job applicant is in the City of White Plains or en route to and from the City of White Plains. No payment of expenses to a job applicant for mileage, lodging and meals shall exceed the total sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(L.L. No. 2-1966, § 2)  
Sec. 2-5-23. - [Payment of expenses in excess of fifty dollars.] 
The commissioner of finance is authorized to pay, after certification by the personnel director, to a job applicant, for expenses, a sum greater than fifty dollars ($50.00) provided the specific job applicant's expenses are approved by the mayor. 
(L.L. No. 2-1966, § 3)  
Secs. 2-5-24—2-5-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IIA. - EXPENSES OF CITY APPOINTED OFFICERS INCURRED IN MOVING TO CITY 
 
Sec. 2-5-27. - [Reimbursement authorized.] 
The common council shall have the power at the time of appointment to authorize reimbursement of appointed officers of the city for moving expenses incurred in transporting such officers, their families and household effects to a place of abode within the city, subject to agreement by any such officer to return to the city monies received for such expenses in the event of resignation or voluntary separation from the position to which such officer is appointed within one year after such appointment. 
(L.L. No. 5-1979, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-28. - [Same—Rules and regulations.] 
The commissioner of finance shall prescribe and amend such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this local law [sections 2-5-27 and 2-5-28], including but not limited to establishing standards, criteria and procedures for determining eligibility for such reimbursement, fixing the maximum dollar limitation on such reimbursement, establishing a minimum distance for eligibility for such reimbursement, and defining the types of expenses which may qualify for such reimbursement. 
(L.L. No. 5-1979, § 2)  
Secs. 2-5-29, 2-5-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COMPENSATION AND LEAVE PLAN[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Power of governing body to provide for vacations, sick leaves and leaves of absence for officers and employees, General Municipal Law, § 92. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-5-31. - Office and business hours. 
Municipal office buildings shall be open for the transaction of business from Monday to Friday, both inclusive, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. except such portions of said buildings as are required for city court, police, fire fighting, caretakers and similar services or for emergency services. The mayor may, by proclamation, designate a day, or a portion of a day, immediately preceding or succeeding a holiday, when such municipal office buildings shall be closed. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83 § 1(Art. III, § 1); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-32. - Common council work day. 
The standard work day for the position of common council member shall consist of six (6) hours. 
(Ord. of 3-4-91; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Secs. 2-5-33—2-5-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - COMPENSATION, ETC. 
 
Sec. 2-5-41. - Applicability. 
This division shall apply to all officers and employees of the city designated as appointed officials, managerial/confidential employees, persons serving in positions funded by grants or contracts, members of boards and commissions, employees designated as hourly workers, student workers and seasonal/part-time workers, who are not covered by the terms of a collective bargaining agreement with any one of the city's labor organizations and whose salary is not otherwise provided for by the City Charter. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 1); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-42. - Determination of salaries. 
The annual salaries for all officers and employees designated in section 2-5-41 of this Code shall be limited to the salary range for each position title within its respective salary group as hereinafter set forth in the Appendices: 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. Such salaries shall be adjusted only at the beginning of the fiscal year, except in the case of promotions. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 2); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-43. - Appointments. 
Appointments and other personnel changes made to the positions in the city service shall be made in accordance with the Civil Service Law and the personnel procedures as promulgated by the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-88, § 1(Art. I, § 3); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-44. - Managerial/confidential employees. 
The following conditions apply only to employees designated as managerial/confidential: 
(1)  New appointees. A new employee appointed to a position in a salary group shall be paid the minimum rate of pay for such salary group, except as follows: 
a.  A new employee upon original appointment who has had previous experience in the duties of his position exceeding the experience required for appointment at the minimum salary may be appointed at a salary equal to the minimum rate plus one (1) or more increments of a sum not to exceed seven (7) percent for each of previous experience as determined by the personnel officer. 
b.  In the event that the personnel officer determines that there is an acute shortage of qualified candidates for a position title, the personnel officer may certify the existence of such acute shortage in writing, which certification shall be effective for a period not to exceed the current fiscal year in which it is made. When such a certification has been made, an appointment to that position title may be made at a salary step above the minimum to be determined by the personnel officer, which salary shall not exceed that paid to any present employee in that position title. 
(2)  Promotions. When an employee's position is reallocated to a higher salary group, an employee shall receive a salary increase to the step in the new salary group which is closest but not less than the employee's salary in the lower salary group, unless specifically authorized at a higher step by the Personnel Officer. In no event shall the employee be paid in excess of the maximum of the higher group. 
(3)  Transfers. There shall be no immediate change in the salary of an employee who retains the same position title but is transferred from one department or bureau to another. There shall be no immediate change in the salary of an employee who is transferred from one position title to another position title in the same numerical salary group. 
(4)  Demotions. When an employee is demoted for cause to a position title in a lower salary group, he shall be paid a salary to be determined by the personnel officer upon the recommendation of the department head at a step which is within the range for the lower position title. 
(5)  Reallocation upward. When an employee's position is reallocated to a higher salary group, the employee shall receive a salary increase of seven (7) percent above his regular rate of pay, and then be placed on the salary scale of his new group level at the next highest scheduled step or minimum, which step or minimum shall be no less than the employee's prior salary plus seven (7) percent. In no event shall the employee be paid in excess of the maximum of the higher group. 
Reallocation downward. When an employee's position is reallocated to a position title in a lower salary group, the employee shall be permitted to continue at this present rate of pay during the period of incumbency (except in event of general service-wide reductions), but shall not be entitled to a salary increase in the fiscal year of reallocation or until the salary for said group shall equal or exceed the salary for the reallocated position. 
(6)  Part-time employment. All rates prescribed in the salary range schedule are the standard rates of pay authorized for full-time employment. When employment is on a part-time basis, only the proportionate part of the rate for the time actually employed shall be paid. The rate of compensation for part-time employees shall be computed on the basis of the minimum annual salary for the position as provided in this division, divided by the annual hours normally worked for full-time employees in such position. However, employees with a minimum of thirty-six (36) continuous months of service shall be proportionately entitled to all benefits accruing to full-time employees, including proportionately such salary adjustments as are set forth in this division. 
(7)  Additional compensation. Employees shall receive overtime pay or additional compensation as follows: 
a.  The employer shall pay time and one-half the employee's rate of pay (except as hereinafter referred to) for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours per week, and for all hours worked on the employee's sixth day of work in a work week as may be authorized by the mayor; however: 
1.  Employees who normally work less than forty (40) hours per week shall be paid straight time or given compensatory time off, at the employer's option, for all hours worked in excess of their normal week up to forty (40) hours. 
2.  Upon mutual agreement between the department head and the employees, compensatory time off may be allowed instead of payment of time and one-half for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours. 
3.  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions to the contrary, any employee who is promoted to an appointed official position shall be paid for or use all compensatory time balances prior to the effective date of such promotion. 
b.  Time and one-half the employee's rate of pay shall be paid for work performed on a holiday (except as provided in paragraph c below). In such cases, if requested by the employee, the employer will make a reasonable effort to schedule the employee for another day off with pay and, if none is scheduled, then the employee will get paid for one (1) additional day not worked. 
c.  The employer shall pay double time the employee's rate of pay for: 
1.  All hours worked in excess of sixteen (16) consecutive hours irrespective of the forty-hour provision. 
2.  Work performed on Christmas, Thanksgiving Day and New Year's Day. In such cases, if requested by the employee, the employer will make a reasonable effort to schedule the employee for another day off with pay; and if none is scheduled, then the employee will get paid for one (1) additional day not worked. 
d.  Call-back pay. Employees recalled to work after leaving the job at the end of their regular hours shall receive a minimum of four (4) hours' pay at the applicable overtime rates unless they work into their regular starting time, in which case they shall be paid at the applicable overtime rate for all hours worked prior to their regular starting time. 
e.  Longevity. Employees shall receive the following longevity pay: 
1.  After (12) years of continuous service with the city or its agencies, paid at the annual rate of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), effective July 1, 2002; seven hundred seventy-five dollars ($775.00), effective July 1, 2003; eight hundred dollars ($800.00), effective July 1, 2005, and nine hundred dollars ($900.00), effective July 1, 2006. 
2.  After fifteen (15) years of continuous service with the city or its agencies, paid at the annual rate of nine hundred dollars ($900.00), effective July 1, 2005; and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), effective July 1, 2006. 
3.  After twenty (20) years of continuous service with the city or its agencies, paid at the annual rate of nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00) effective July 1, 2002; nine hundred seventy-five ($975.00) effective July 1, 2003; one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) effective July 1, 2005; and one thousand one hundred dollars ($1,100.00) effective July 1, 2006. 
4.  Employees completing the required amount of continuous service in the fiscal year are eligible for the longevity payments commencing the first pay period of the fiscal year. These payments will be included in the employee's biweekly or weekly paychecks as the case may be. 
f.  Merit increases. Employees who are below maximum of their salary group may, at the discretion of the department head, receive a merit increase annually, not to exceed that which would equal a scheduled "increment" as those are reflected on the salary schedule, or so much of such an increment as would bring them up to maximum. Employees appointed or reinstated less than four (4) months prior to the beginning of the fiscal year will not be eligible for such a merit increase. 
(8)  Out-of-title work. When an employee is assigned to work in a higher classification for more than fifteen (15) work days out of forty-five (45) work days, then such employee shall receive the minimum rate for such higher classification work retroactive to the first day of such work but not less than seven (7) percent above his regular rate. When employees are temporarily assigned to perform the duties of a lower classification at a lower rate of pay, they shall be guaranteed their regular rate of pay. 
(9)  Reinstatement. An employee may be reinstated within one (1) year of the employee's termination of service with the city and shall be paid a salary step to be fixed by the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 4); Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-91, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-94, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-96, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-00, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 9-27-04, § 1; Ord. of 10-4-04, § 1; Ord. of 5-30-18, § 1 )  
Sec. 2-5-45. - Tuition assistance. 
The city shall assist full-time employees in the pursuit of such formal educational programs as will mutually benefit the employee and the efficiency of the city operations in which the employee is engaged. This policy shall operate within the limitations of the budget and the guidelines of the personnel officer for such payment. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 5); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-46. - Mileage allowance. 
All officers and employees will be reimbursed for mileage, as set forth in Appendix 7, where a private car is authorized for use for the city's business, and when the employee has been certified eligible for reimbursement by the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 6); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-47. - Position titles and salary groups. 
(a)  Position titles and the allocation of such titles to salary groups shall be as set forth in Appendices 2-b, 3, 5 and 6. 
(b)  Position titles with fixed salaries shall be as set forth in Appendices 1 and 4. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 7); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-48. - Disbursement of funds. 
The mayor hereby authorizes and directs the commissioner of finance to disburse funds to pay the annual salaries and hourly wages in accordance with the provisions of this division and its appendices and upon receipt of documentation as prescribed by the commissioner of finance and the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. I, § 8); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-49. - Deferred compensation plan. 
The New York State Deferred Compensation Plan, presently administered by Copeland Associates, adopted February 2, 1987, is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-50. - Dental plan. 
The Mayor is hereby authorized to direct the Commissioner of Finance to disburse funds for individual and family dental insurance for elected, appointed and managerial/confidential employees and other eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement as follows: 
Annual Employer Contribution per Person 	Effective Date 
$1,396.50 	July 1, 2018 
$1,436.50 	July 1, 2019 
$1,476.50 	July 1, 2020
