Sec. 2-5-52. - Employee assistance plan. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to direct the commissioner of finance to disburse funds for the payment of the per-person cost, as contracted by the city with Westchester County, for the provision of the employee assistance program on behalf of elected, appointed, managerial/confidential, and other eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. of 3-5-91, § 4; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 9-8-09, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-53. - Health insurance buyout. 
(a)  The health insurance buyout program shall be offered to elected and appointed officials and other eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement as follows: 
(1)  Elected and appointed officials and other eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement may opt out of the city's health insurance program in whole or in part by waiving coverage for themselves and their eligible dependents or for their eligible dependants only for periods of a full calendar year by completing and submitting the appropriate waiver agreement form furnished by the city to the commissioner of finance. In order to be eligible for this option, the official or employee must certify that he or she has health insurance through a source other than the city. 
(2)  Newly elected or appointed officials and newly hired employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement upon commencing service may elect to waive the city's health insurance coverage, with the provisions of this section taking effect on the normal effective date for their health benefits. Payments under the buyout schedule shall be made to the official or employee on a pro rata basis for the remaining months available in the waived calendar year. All other provisions of this section shall remain in effect. 
(b)  Waivers for the health insurance buyout program must be submitted in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Officials and employees electing to waive coverage must do so by filing their forms no later than the close of the annual open enrollment period prior to the beginning of the waived calendar year. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, officials and employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement who obtain health insurance through a source other than the city, within the calendar year may elect to waive the city's health insurance coverage, with the provisions of this section taking effect on or after the effective date the official or employee obtained health insurance through a source other than the city. Payments under the buyout schedule shall be made to the employee on a pro-rata basis for the remaining months available in the waived calendar year. All other provisions of this section shall remain in effect. 
(c)  Officials and employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement who participate in the health insurance buyout program will be paid the following dollar amounts, provided he or she maintains his or her waiver (remains opted out) for a full calendar year: 
Waiver of individual coverage: 	$1,500.00 
Waiver of dependent coverage: 	$1,650.00 
Waiver of family coverage: 	$3,200.00 
 
Payments shall be subject to all usual payroll deductions and shall be made on the first Friday in December of the waived calendar year, which is not a payday for city employees. 
(d)  Once an official or employee has waived coverage for a particular calendar year, he or she may not reinstate coverage for that calendar year, unless the official or employee experiences a "qualifying event" as defined by Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code. Reinstatement of coverage for the succeeding calendar year may be made by notifying the city in writing no later than the close of the annual open enrollment period to be effective the succeeding calendar year. This deadline will not apply to reinstatement due to a qualifying event. If reinstatement occurs during a waived calendar year due to a qualifying event, the official or employee will be paid on a pro rata basis for the actual months waived in that calendar year. All other provisions of this section shall remain in effect. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing to the contrary, the right of any city official or employee to participate in the health insurance buyout program or to reinstate city health insurance coverage, is and will be subject to the conditions imposed by the city's carrier(s) at that time. 
(Ord. of 3-5-91, § 5; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-94; Ord. of 7-1-96, § 4; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 1; Ord. of 10-7-13, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-53.5. - Health insurance. 
(a)  For elected and appointed officials, managerial/confidential and other eligible employees who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, the city shall contribute eighty-five (85) percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby authorized to direct the commissioner of finance to deduct from the salaries of those officials or employees enrolled in any of the health insurance programs offered by the city, an amount equal to the difference between the city's contribution and the actual premium charged by the health insurance program in which the individual is enrolled. 
(Ord. of 2-1-10, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 2)  
Sec. 2-5-54. - Retirees health insurance. 
(a)  Employees hired before July 1, 1995, who are otherwise eligible to receive health insurance benefits in retirement from the city, shall continue to be entitled to maintain the level of health insurance benefits (individual or family) provided by the city to current employees and to have the city contribute eighty-five (85) percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees. The provisions of this section shall not apply to retired employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement at the time of their retirement, during the term said collective bargaining agreement is in effect. 
(b)  Employees hired on or after July 1, 1995, who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement and who are otherwise eligible to receive health insurance benefits in retirement from the city, shall be entitled to maintain the level of health insurance benefits (individual or family) provided by the city to current employees and to have the city contribute the percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees pursuant to the following schedule: 
Completed Years 
of City Service 	City 
Contribution 
20 or more 	85% 
15-19 	65% 
10-15 	50% (individual) 
35% (family) 
fewer than 10 	0% 
 
The city shall waive the twenty-year service requirement in the case of an employee who is eligible for, retires, and receives benefits pursuant to, Retirement and Social Security Law Section 63 (accidental). 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subdivisions (a) and (b) hereinabove, employees whose employment with the city commenced prior to July 1, 2010, who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, and who have been continuously employed full time by the city from that time until at least July 1, 2017, and who are otherwise eligible to receive health insurance benefits in retirement from the city, shall be entitled to maintain the level of health insurance benefits (individual or family) provided by the city to current employees and to have the city contribute the percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees pursuant to the following schedule: 
Completed Years 
of City Service 	City 
Contribution 
20 or more 	100% 
15-19 	80% 
10-15 	50% (individual) 
35% (family) 
fewer than 10 	0% 
 
The city shall waive the twenty-year service requirement in the case of an employee who is eligible for, retires, and receives benefits pursuant to, Retirement and Social Security Law Section 63 (accidental). 
(d)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions to the contrary, the above schedules shall not apply to employees whose positions are designated in Appendix 1, Appointed Officials and Appendix 1c, Elected Officials. Such employees who are otherwise eligible to receive health insurance benefits in retirement from the city, shall continue to be entitled to maintain the level of health insurance benefits (individual or family) provided by the city to current employees and have the city contribute eighty-five (85) percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions, employees whose positions are designated in Appendix 1, Appointed Officials, and whose employment with the city commenced prior to July 1, 2010 and who have been continuously employed full time by the city from that time until at least July 1, 2017, and who are otherwise eligible to receive health insurance benefits in retirement from the city, shall continue to be entitled to maintain the level of health insurance benefits (individual or family) provided by the city to current employees and have the city contribute one hundred (100) percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees. 
(Ord. of 7-1-96, § 5; Ord. of 4-5-99, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 3; Ord. of 5-30-17, § 3 )  
Sec. 2-5-55. - Flexible spending plan. 
(a)  Name; purpose. This plan shall be known as the "City of White Plains Flexible Spending Plan." This plan is intended to be a "cafeteria plan" within the meaning of section 125(d) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(b)  Definitions. [For the purposes of this section, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
Administrator means the commissioner of finance or person(s), or corporation appointed by the commissioner of finance to carry out the administrative duties of all or part of the plan. 
Benefits means the benefits available under the plan that are described in subsection (d)(1). 
Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended from time to time. 
Compensation means the total cash remuneration received by an eligible employee from the employer during a plan year prior to any reductions pursuant to a salary redirection agreement under the terms of this plan. It shall include overtime, differentials, bonuses and any form of remuneration to the eligible employee for services rendered to the employer as an employee. 
Dependent means an individual who qualifies as a dependent of an eligible employee within the meaning of section 152 of the code. In the case of health benefits provided under an insurance policy, the "dependent" must also be defined as dependent(s) under the policy. 
Election period means the period beginning sixty (60) days and ending thirty (30) days immediately before the beginning of each plan year for the election of benefits and salary redirection. 
Eligible employee means any current employee of the employer who is eligible to participate in the plan under subsection (c)(1). 
Employer means the City of White Plains. 
Insurer means an insurance company or health maintenance organization organized or incorporated in any one of the states of the United States which is licensed or authorized by the State of New York to provide a health insurance policy or city self insured programs. 
Insurance policies means the city's self insured programs or the agreements between the employer and the various insurers under which the insurer(s) provide health coverage to support in whole or in part the medical benefits agreed to by the employer to eligible employees and/or their dependents. 
Participant means an eligible employee who voluntarily agrees to participate in the plan. 
Plan contribution means the amounts paid by plan participants or on their behalf during the plan year either by foregoing cash options or by reducing salary to pay for health benefits or dependent care benefits. 
Such plan contributions may be made on a pretax basis in which case the plan contributions are not included in the participants taxable income for the plan year or on an after-tax basis in which case the plan contributions are included in the participant's taxable income for the plan year. 
Plan year means the twelve-month period starting on January 1 and ending December 31. The plan year shall be the coverage period for the benefits provided for under this plan. 
If an eligible employee begins participation under the plan after the first date of the plan year, the first period of coverage shall begin with the date of participation and shall end on the last date of the plan year. 
Premiums means the participant's cost for insurance policy benefits. 
Premium reimbursement account means an account to which plan contributions are allocated for each participant and from which the premiums of the participant may be paid or reimbursed. 
Salary redirection means plan contributions made by the employer for a participant. These are allocated to the premium reimbursement account as authorized by a participant's election of benefits under the plan. 
Salary redirection agreement is an agreement between the participant and the employer in which the participant agrees to reduce his compensation which has not yet been earned by a certain amount and the employer agrees to contribute that amount to the plan on behalf of the participant. 
(c)  Eligibility and participation. 
(1)  Existing plan participants and eligibility. All employees on the effective date of this plan and any future employees who are employed by the employer during a plan year who are eligible to participate in the city's health insurance program and in the employer's group medical plan, (the terms of which are incorporated herein by reference) and the applicable collective bargaining agreement between the employer and a union representing a unit of employees including the subject employees or, in the case of a nonunion employee, common council ordinance. In order to be eligible to receive the declination bonus, the employee must certify that he or she has health insurance through another source other than the city. 
(2)  Participation. Each employee who is eligible to participate in the plan and who does not become ineligible to participate in the plan for any reason shall become a plan participant in this plan on the effective date of his or her employment. 
(3)  Terms of participation. Before the plan is utilized by a particular eligible employee, he or she shall first agree to indemnify and save the city harmless against any and all claims and/or liabilities including attorney's fees, that may arise out of or by reason of action taken or not taken by the city for the purposes of complying with Internal Revenue Code section 125 and other relevant law. Participation in the plan ends if a Participant becomes ineligible, terminates or is discharged from employment, dies or if the plan is terminated. All benefits under the plan will cease at that time except that any rights which the participant may have under Title X of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 as amended ("COBRA") and any other state or federal law shall survive to the extent provided by these laws. 
(d)  Benefits under the plan. 
(1)  Benefit options. 
a.  Declination bonus. Each eligible employee may select one of the two (2) options in this subsection (a): 
1.  Declination in lieu of a specific level of health insurance coverage with payment of declination cash as set forth in the applicable collective bargaining agreement; or 
2.  No declination of health insurance coverage. 
b.  Health care reimbursement account. 
1.  Generally. Each participant will be entitled to receive for each plan year reimbursement of qualifying health care expenses incurred during the plan year, which are not reimbursed by other medical plans, and which are not taken as a deduction on the participant's income tax return, up to the dollar amount of coverage elected by the participant for that plan year. This election may be any whole dollar amount of coverage from one hundred dollars ($100.00) to thirty-five hundred dollars ($3,500.00). 
2.  Benefits limited to expenses incurred in plan year. The coverage elected is available only to reimburse expenses which are incurred during the plan year consistent with IRS regulations. Except that participants are permitted to use excess contributions from one plan year in the first two and one-half (2½) months of the following plan year, consistent with the grace period as authorized by IRS Notice 2005-42. 
3.  Qualifying health care expenses. Qualifying health care expenses shall include only amounts which are for "medical care" within the meaning of code section 213(d), of the participant or dependents. 
Expenses allowed under the code and IRS regulations must be substantiated consistent with the requirements of the IRS regulations and plan administrator. 
c.  Dependent care reimbursement account. 
1.  Generally. Each participant will be entitled to receive for each plan year reimbursement of qualifying dependent care expenses which are incurred during the plan year for which a dependent care tax credit is not taken on the participant's income tax return, up to the dollar amount of coverage elected by the participant for that plan year. In no event shall the sum of the reimbursements made to the participant under this plan and the amount of dependent care tax credit taken by the participant exceed the maximum amount set in accordance with IRS regulations. 
2.  Benefits limited to expenses incurred during plan year. The coverage elected for a plan is only available to reimburse expenses which are incurred during the plan year. Except that participants are permitted to use excess contributions from one plan year in the first two and one-half (2½) months of the following plan year, consistent with the grace period as authorized by IRS Notice 2005-42. Expenses shall only be reimbursed in accordance with IRS regulations and the plan administrator. 
3.  Qualifying dependent care expenses. Qualifying dependent care expenses shall include only amounts paid which constitute "employment related expenses" within the meaning of code section 21. Specifically, qualifying dependent care expenses must be incurred for the care of a qualifying individual and for household services incurred to enable the participant to be gainfully employed or attend school as authorized by and in accordance with IRS regulations. 
Expenses allowed under the code and IRS regulations must be substantiated consistent with the requirements of the IRS regulations and plan administrator. 
d.  Salary redirection. 
1.  Right of election. An eligible employee may elect to receive full salary in cash or to participate in a salary redirection agreement. Unless the eligible employee affirmatively states that he wishes to participate in salary redirection, the employee will receive full salary in cash. 
2.  Salary redirection agreement. Under the terms of a salary redirection agreement a participant agrees to have deducted from his salary an amount which is equal to the participant's premium costs for health insurance under insurance policies agreed to by the employer. The employer agrees to contribute to the plan as a plan contribution allocated for that participant an amount equal to the amount deducted from the participant's salary for that purpose. Premiums will be paid on behalf of the participant from the amount of plan contributions allocated to the participant. If more than one (1) insurance benefit is selected, sub-accounts for each of the participants's elections will be made. 
3.  Term of election. A participant shall determine changes in salary redirection prior to the beginning of the plan year during the election period. 
The first term of the salary redirection agreement for new employees who were not on the payroll of the employer during the election period shall be from the first day of the pay period following the date of participation until the end of the plan year. 
4.  Rules and regulations. The plan administrator may establish reasonable rules and regulations for the determination of amounts of salary redirection for each payroll period and for the implementation of this benefit. 
5.  Application of premium. As soon as practicable after each payroll period, the employer shall apply the salary redirection to provide the participant's premium expense. 
6.  Changes in premium rates. The amount of salary redirection shall be determined by premium costs which may increase or decrease during a plan year and the rate of contribution to be made by a plan participant under the terms of a collective bargaining agreement or by virtue of the rate of contribution required of nonunion employees. If insurance costs charged by the insurer increase or decrease during the plan year, the amount of salary redirection shall be adjusted accordingly. 
7.  Medical benefits. The medical coverage provided, the types and amounts of benefits, the eligibility for participation and all rights and obligations concerning the terms and conditions of medical coverage and benefits shall be determined by the medical plan that is in effect from time to time. Neither the employer or the plan make any representations or assume any responsibility for the determination of medical coverage, benefit, eligibility for participation or any other terms and/or conditions of the medical coverage. Total premium costs shall be determined by the insurer providing the medical coverage. 
(2)  Benefit process. For any plan year, a participant who is an eligible employee may elect to receive a benefit listed in a, b, c, and d in subsection (1) above by completing and signing an election form during the election period. The plan administrator shall provide the forms. After the form has been properly submitted and received and accepted by the employer the initial election shall become effective on the first day of the first pay period beginning after the election form is received. 
Once effective, an election under this section shall remain in effect throughout the plan year in which it was made and, with regard to salary redirection, throughout all subsequent plan years unless a change is made pursuant to subsection (3) below. 
An eligible employee will be deemed to have elected compensation in the form of direct salary if the employee does not submit a written election form on a timely basis. 
(3)  Change in benefit elections. Each eligible employee will have the opportunity to change his or her benefit election effective on the first date of the subsequent plan year. The election shall be made on an election form provided by the plan administrator and must be made during the election period before the start of the plan year. 
An eligible employee will not be permitted to change any benefit election for a plan year, except as provided (1) under section 125 of the code and the rules and regulations issued thereunder and (2) the insurance policy. 
(4)  Change in participation. All benefit election changes under the plan must be submitted to the plan administrator in writing. 
(5)  Forfeiture of unused benefits. A participant shall receive no reimbursement for benefits elected but unused during a plan year for any reason. Forfeitures may be used to pay plan administration expenses or costs. 
(e)  Declination of health insurance benefits. 
(1)  Right of election. An eligible employee may elect to receive health insurance coverage at a specific level, i.e., individual or family, or elect to receive health insurance declination cash ("declination") instead of health insurance coverage, provided the employee meets the terms of the collective bargaining agreement which offers the health insurance or the declination cash or for nonunion employees the terms established by the common council for the declination cash. 
(2)  Declination cash. A participant who elects declination cash instead of health insurance coverage under the terms of a collective bargaining agreement or by virtue of this being a benefit offered to a nonunion employee shall have an amount equal to the amount of the declination cash contributed to the plan by the employer. The plan shall pay said cash to the participant provided the participant meets all of the requirements for said declination cash under the terms of the collective bargaining agreement or for nonunion employees as established by the employer. 
(3)  An eligible employee who does not elect declination cash shall be deemed to have retained the current level of health insurance coverage. 
(f)  Plan contributions. Plan contributions made on a pretax basis shall be deemed employer contributions. Plan contributions made on an after-tax basis shall be deemed employee contributions. 
(g)  Benefit claims procedure. 
(1)  Insurance claims. Claims for benefits which are provided by an insurance contract shall be made to the insurer. If the claim is denied the participant shall follow the insurer's claim procedure. Under no circumstances shall the plan, the plan administrator or the employer be liable for any insurance claim benefit which is denied. 
(2)  Noninsurance claims review. A review of a denial in whole or in part of a noninsurance claim for benefits under this plan shall be made to the plan administrator. Such claims shall be made within sixty-five (65) days after denial unless special circumstances require an extension of time. The plan administrator shall determine the validity of the claim within sixty (60) days after its receipt. If the plan administrator does not make a determination within sixty (60) days, the claim shall be deemed denied. 
(3)  Plan administrator authority. The plan administrator shall have full authority to resolve any and all disputes under this plan. The plan administrator shall have full authority to interpret plan language and to resolve any ambiguities and to determine the application of this plan. 
(4)  Notice of claim denial. In the event the plan administrator denies a claim in whole or in part, the plan administrator shall furnish the claimant with a written notice giving the claimant the following information: 
a.  The specific reason for the denial; 
b.  Reference to the specific plan provisions upon which the denial is based; 
c.  Information or material which the claimant must submit to perfect his claim and why such information or material is necessary; 
d.  An explanation of the plan appeal procedures as set forth in subsection (5) below. 
(5)  Appeal procedure. Within sixty (60) days of denial of a claim, the claimant may submit in writing to the plan administrator a request for a review of the denial by the plan administrator. The claimant shall have the right to examine all pertinent documents, submit issues and comments in writing, have counsel of his or her own choice, and to submit any relevant evidence. 
No later than sixty (60) days after receipt of a request for a review, the plan administrator shall render a decision in writing. It shall state the reasons for the decision and shall refer to relevant plan provisions or code sections upon which it is based. The decision of the plan administrator is final and binding. 
(h)  Plan administrator. 
(1)  Appointment. The commissioner of finance may appoint a third party to be the plan administrator to administer all or a portion of the plan. 
(2)  Authority and responsibility of the plan administrator. The plan administrator shall have authority and responsibility to take any reasonable actions necessary to control and manage the operation and administration of this plan. The plan administrator shall have authority to establish rules and regulations which shall be applied on a uniform and nondiscriminatory basis to all participants to fulfill the purposes of this plan. 
The plan administrator shall have authority to resolve all disputes under this plan and to resolve all claims disputes. 
The plan administrator shall have authority to interpret the language of this plan and to resolve any and all ambiguities. These determinations shall be final. 
The plan administrator shall have authority to take any action or not take any action to effectuate the purposes of this plan. Any rules, regulations or procedures which may be necessary for the proper administration or functioning of this plan that are not covered by the plan shall be the responsibility of the plan administrator. 
(3)  Removal of plan administrator. The commissioner of finance may remove any third party appointed as the plan administrator for all or part of the plan at any time for any reason. 
(i)  Amendment or termination. 
(1)  Amendment. The employer reserves the right to amend this plan at any time or from time to time in any manner the common council deems appropriate or advisable subject to subsection (3) herein. 
(2)  Termination. The employer established this plan with the bona fide intention that it remain in effect indefinitely. Nevertheless, the employer has no obligation to continue the plan for any given length of time and it may terminate the plan without any liability at any time subject to subsection (3) herein and except for liability which may accrue independent of this plan under the terms of a collective bargaining agreement. 
(3)  Participants rights. No plan amendment or termination may affect the right of any participant to collect a benefit for that portion of the plan year or coverage period prior to amendment or termination to the extent such amounts are payable under the terms of the plan as in effect before the calendar month in which the plan is amended or terminated. 
(4)  Effective date of plan amendment or termination. Any amendment or termination shall take effect only at the end of a pay period. 
(j)  Miscellaneous. 
(1)  Personal liability. Nothing in this plan shall impose or create any personal liability for any common council member or the chief city executive or their agents acting within the scope of their authority. 
(2)  Gender and number. Reference to any gender shall include the masculine, feminine and gender neutral. The plural shall include the singular and the singular the plural where appropriate. 
(3)  Construction. The terms of this plan shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of New York except to the extent that such laws are preempted by ERISA or any other federal statute or by the laws of any other state. 
(4)  Rights. Participants shall be allowed to examine plan documents at the employer's office without charge upon written request. The participant may have a copy of plan documents and the employer may make a reasonable charge for making copies. 
The plan shall be operated prudently on a nondiscrimination basis and solely in the interest of participants and beneficiaries under the plan. 
Participants may not be discriminated against in any manner to prevent them from obtaining a benefit rightly due to the participant under the plan or from exercising rights if any, available to the participant under ERISA. 
(5)  No employment contract rights. Neither the establishment of the plan or any amendment thereto shall create any right for any employee to continued employment nor shall this be construed as a contract of employment between the employer and the employee. 
(k)  Entire plan agreement. 
(1)  This document sets forth the entire plan and except as provided in this plan no other employee benefit plan which is now in existence or may be created shall be part of this plan. 
(Ord. of 7-1-96, § 6; Ord. of 7-7-97, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-05, § 1) 
Editor's note— At the instruction of the city the flexible spending plan has been set forth herein, designated by the editor as § 2-5-55.  
Sec. 2-5-56. - Disability insurance. 
(a)  The mayor is hereby authorized to direct the commissioner of finance to make the necessary arrangements to enable the city to participate in the New York State Disability Insurance Plan. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby further authorized to direct the commissioner of finance to disburse funds for the New York State Disability Insurance Plan for eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement. 
(c)  The mayor is still further authorized to direct the commissioner of finance to deduct from the salary of individuals enrolled in the program an amount not to equal the maximum employee contribution permitted by law (see Workers Compensation Law §209). 
(Ord. of 12-4-00, § 5)  
Sec. 2-5-57. - Attendance bonus. 
(a)  Effective December 1, 2001 all managerial/confidential employees and other eligible employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement shall receive a bonus for excellent attendance for the prior year payable at the following rate: 
Number of Days Absent from Work 
December 1—November 30 	Bonus 
0 	$500.00, effective July 1, 2003; 
	600.00, effective July 1, 2006; 
1 	400.00, effective July 1, 2005; 
	500.00, effective July 1, 2006; 
2 	300.00, effective July 1, 2005; 
	400.00, effective July 1, 2006. 
 
Absences are defined to include any absences from work other than employer approved FMLA, vacation, personal and compensatory leave time, jury leave, that part of military leave that must be compensated by the employer pursuant to the New York Military Law, and up to two instances of bereavement leave. Bonuses shall be paid in a lump sum by separate check during January. 
(Ord. of 12-4-00, § 6; Ord. of 9-27-04, § 4; Ord. of 10-4-04, § 4)  
Sec. 2-5-58. - Retired city employees health insurance buyout program. 
(1)  Retired elected and appointed officials and city employees participating in the health insurance program by receiving health insurance for which the city contributes at least eighty-five (85) percent of the premium charged by the New York State Empire Health Insurance Program toward the cost of providing individual or family coverage under any of the health insurance programs the city makes available to its employees, may opt out of the health insurance program provided by the city in whole or in part by waiving coverage for themselves and their eligible dependents or for their eligible dependents only for periods of a full calendar year by completing and submitting the appropriate waiver agreement form furnished by the city to the finance commissioner on or before the 30 th day of November prior to the beginning of the calendar year the employee will waive coverage. In order to be eligible for this option a retired city employee must certify that he or she has health insurance through a source other than the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply to retired employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement at the time of their retirement, during the term said collective bargaining agreement is in effect. 
(2)  Effective January 1, 2011, a retired city employee or official opting out of the health insurance program provided by the city in whole or in part by waiving coverage for themselves and their eligible dependents or their eligible dependents only shall be paid the following, provided he or she maintains his or her waiver (remains opted out) for a full calendar year: 
Waiver of individual coverage: 	$1,500.00 
Waiver of dependent coverage: 	$1,650 
Waiver of family coverage: 	$3,200.00 
 
[(a)]  Payments under the buyout schedule shall be made to such participating retired city officials and employees in the December following the effective date specified in the waiver agreement between the city and participating retired city employee. The December payment will be made on the first Friday of the month that is not a payday for city employees. 
(b)  Newly eligible retired city officials and employees electing to waive coverage may do so upon the date of their eligibility, with the provisions of this section taking effect on the effective date specified in the waiver agreement between the city and participating retired city employee. 
(c)  Retired city employees who obtain health insurance through a source other than the city, within the calendar year may elect to waive coverage, with the provisions of this section taking effect on or after the effective date the employee obtained health insurance through a source other than the city. Payments under the buyout schedule shall be made to the retired employee on a pro-rata basis for the remaining months available in the current calendar year. 
(3)  It is understood that once a retired city official or employee has waived coverage for a particular year, he or she may not reinstate coverage for that year except in the event of an emergency causing the loss of insurance through another source. Emergency shall not include the change of any such alternative insurance from a non-contributory to a contributory plan, or the voluntary declination of such alternative insurance by the spouse of insurance offered by the spouse's employer. If reinstatement occurs during a waiver year due to emergency, the retired city employee will repay, pro-rata, any amount already forwarded to him or her in return for the waiver prior to reinstatement. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any of the forgoing to the contrary, the right of any retired city official or employee to reinstate the health insurance coverage provided by the city is, and will be, subject to the conditions imposed by the city's carrier(s) at that time. 
(Ord. of 11-7-94, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 4)  
Secs. 2-5-59—2-5-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LEAVES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Power of governing board of city to provide for vacation, sick leaves and leaves of absence of officers and employees, General Municipal Law, § 92. 
 
Sec. 2-5-61. - Generally. 
The following provisions shall apply to leaves for personal illness or injury, childbearing and child rearing, serious illness or death in family, absences covered by workers' compensation, absences for jury and court attendance, and military and personal leave, for appointed officials and employees designated in Appendices 1, 2b, 2c, 2d and 3a as follows: 
(1)  No employee shall be absent from duty on any working day except for one of the reasons outlined above, unless permission shall have been obtained in advance from the department head. 
(2)  All earned but unused leave credits shall be transferred with the employee from one city department or agency to another. For purposes of this division, "department or agency" includes the White Plains Cable Television Access Commission, White Plains Parking Authority, and the White Plains Urban Renewal Agency. Leave credits shall not be transferred from any other jurisdictions. 
(3)  Days' allowance for absences mentioned in these rules shall be considered as meaning working days. 
(4)  As payrolls are made up from five (5) to six (6) days preceding the issuance of checks, absences occurring during that period will be deducted from the payroll issued approximately two (2) weeks later where applicable. 
(5)  At the time of employment, an employee, except those employed on a per diem basis, may be required to furnish a certificate from a physician as to the physical condition of the employee. 
(6)  In any case where a physical examination or a certificate is required from a physician or surgeon, as to an employee's physical condition, the city reserves the right to require the employee to submit to a physical examination by a physician or surgeon selected by the department head or the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(A); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-62. - Computation of service. 
For the purpose of this division, service shall be computed from the first day of employment. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 1); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-63. - Vacations. 
(a)  The following provisions shall apply to appointed officials as designated in Appendix 1: 
(1)  Effective January 1, 1994, all appointed officials designated in Appendix 1, at the time of appointment or on their anniversary date, shall be granted twenty (20) days vacation with full pay annually. 
(2)  All appointed officials appointed after July 5, 1994, shall be granted ten (10) days' vacation with full pay for their first twelve (12) months of service. Any unused portion of this ten (10) days' vacation shall not be carried forward beyond the first twelve (12) months of service and shall be forfeited. Thereafter they shall be granted twenty (20) days vacation with full pay annually. 
(3)  Notwithstanding the above provisions (1) and (2), all appointed officials as designated in Appendix 1, hired on or after January 1, 2010, shall be granted twenty (20) days vacation with full pay annually, at the time of appointment and on each successive anniversary date thereof. 
(b)  The following vacation schedule shall apply to all employees as designated in Appendices 2b and 3a, provided that at the time of hire, the personnel officer may give credit for previous experience in setting the period of continuous service for employees designated in Appendix 2b. 
(1)  All employees with six (6) months of continuous service on the payroll of the city shall be granted a vacation with full pay in accordance with the schedule set forth below: 
a.  Effective upon completing six (6) months of continuous full-time service all officers and employees shall be eligible for five (5) working days of vacation. 
b.  One (1) year's continuous service, but less than five (5) years' continuous service, all officers and employees shall be eligible for ten (10) working days of vacation. 
c.  Five (5) years' continuous service, but less than twelve (12) years' continuous service, all officers and employees shall be eligible for fifteen (15) working days of vacation provided that no more than ten (10) working days shall be taken consecutively, except upon approval of the department head. 
d.  Twelve (12) or more years' continuous service, all officers and employees shall be eligible for twenty (20) working days of vacation provided that no more than ten (10) working days of vacation shall be taken consecutively, except upon approval of the department head. 
(2)  Public library. Full-time public library employees in the professional job classification who, on June 30 of any calendar year shall have no less than six (6) calendar months of continuous service on the payroll of the city shall be granted a vacation with full pay in accordance with the schedule set forth below: 
a.  Six (6) months' continuous service on June 30, but less than one (1) year's continuous service, one (1) working day of vacation for each calendar month of service. 
b.  After one (1) year's continuous service, four (4) calendar weeks of vacation. 
(c)  The following vacation procedures shall apply to all appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b, and 3a: 
(1)  If a legal holiday is observed by the city on any day except Saturday or Sunday, and such holiday occurs during an officer's or employee's vacation period, such officer or employee shall be entitled to an additional day of vacation. 
(2)  An officer or employee who has taken sick leave, a childbearing leave or child rearing leave in excess of sixty (60) working days in any anniversary year shall only be entitled to a vacation accrual of one (1) working day per calendar month of active service on the job in the anniversary year in which the leave was taken (if employed one (1) year or more) or one and one-half (1½) working days per month (if employed five (5) years or more), or two (2) working days per month (if employed twelve (12) years or more). 
(3)  The choice of vacation periods shall be given employees with the longest periods of continuous service, provided that such choice shall not, in the opinion of the department head, adversely affect the operation of the department. Vacation preference schedule shall be prepared and approved by the department head in order of employees' starting dates of last continuous employment. 
(4)  If an officer or employee intends to terminate employment with the city for reasons other than a dismissal from service, he shall be granted his earned vacation, with full pay, provided sufficient advance notice of such termination is submitted to the department head or in the case of a department head to the mayor to enable such vacation, with full pay to be scheduled prior to the effective date of termination, and provided that at least two (2) weeks' notice is given to the department head or mayor prior to commencing such vacation. 
(5)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions to the contrary, when an officer or employee intends to terminate employment with the city, for reasons other than a dismissal from service, prior to June 30 of any fiscal year in which he has earned a vacation, and said officer or employee has had continuous service for six (6) months or more during such fiscal year, he shall be granted vacation, with full pay, based on his length of continuous service prior to such fiscal year, pro-rated on the number of months of such continuous service, during such fiscal year, provided at least two (2) weeks' notice of such termination of service is given to the department head or to the mayor in the case of a department head prior to commencing such vacation. 
(6)  After one (1) year of continuous service, an officer or employee who intends to terminate his employment with the city for reasons other than dismissal from service, provided such employee has given sufficient advance notice to his department or to the mayor in the case of a department head of such termination of service, may elect to receive compensation for his currently earned and unused vacation in lieu of taking such vacation as provided above. Upon certification thereof by the department head or mayor, the commissioner of finance is authorized to pay such compensation to such officer or employee. If at the time of the death of any officer or employee, there is currently earned and unused vacation standing to his credit, the monetary value of the same shall be paid to his beneficiaries by the commissioner of finance upon certification thereof by this department head or mayor and with the approval of the corporation counsel. 
(7)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions to the contrary, vacation leave is to be used during the twelve-month period immediately following the end of the qualifying service period, at times approved by the department head, or the mayor in the case of department heads, and shall not be accumulated except pursuant to the specific approval of the department head. In any event, carry over of unused vacation leave credits earned after July 5, 1994 shall be limited to a maximum of ten (10) days. Unused vacation leave credits in excess of ten (10) days, earned after July 5, 1994 shall not be carried forward beyond the twelve (12) month period immediately following the end of the qualifying service period, and shall be forfeited. 
(8)  All officers and employees must reduce unused accrued vacation balances in excess of ten (10) days, existing as of July 5, 1994, and must reduce such accrued vacation balances to zero at a rate of at least five (5) days per year. If an officer or employee fails to reduce his or her unused accrued vacation balance by the required five (5) days per year, that portion of the required five-day reduction shall be deducted from the officer's or employee's unused accrued vacation balance and forfeited. The above time periods shall run from July 5, 1994. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 1); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 1-6-97, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-00, § 7; Ord. of 1-4-10, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-18, § 1 )  
Sec. 2-5-64. - Holidays. 
The following holiday schedule shall apply to all appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a. 
An employee shall be entitled to thirteen (13) paid holidays as follows: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King's Birthday, Lincoln's Birthday, Washington's Birthday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day, Veterans' Day, Election Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and Good Friday. These shall be guaranteed regardless of the day on which they fall. Holidays falling on a Saturday will be observed on the preceding Friday. Holidays falling on Sunday will be observed the following Monday. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 2); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-00, § 8)  
Sec. 2-5-65. - Personal illness or injury. 
The following provisions shall apply to leaves for personal illness or injury for appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a as follows: 
(1)  Officers and employees shall be allowed twelve (12) days' absence at full pay during any calendar year credited at one (1) day a month because of personal illness or injury. Those employed for less shall be given a proportionate allowance. 
a.  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions to the contrary, an appointed official, not promoted or transferred from another position in The City of White Plains Cable Television Access Commission, White Plains Parking Authority, or the White Plains Urban Renewal Agency, will be allowed twelve (12) days of personal illness or injury leave for their first twelve (12) months to be credited upon the effective date of their appointment. 
b.  Beginning with their thirteenth month of service appointed officials referred to in (a) above will be credited with personal illness or injury leave as provided in (1) above. 
(2)  Additional allowance for absence with full pay due to personal illness or injury shall be given after the first year of employment, depending upon the number of days of sick leave allowance which may be accumulated in accordance with the following plan: At the end of each year the unused portion of the twelve (12) days' allowance for that year shall be accumulated as an allowance for additional days of absence at full pay. Accumulation of sick leave shall be unlimited. 
(3)  In cases of extreme hardship, provided such officer or employee has been in the employ of the city for more than one (1) year, in the discretion of the department head, with the approval of the personnel officer, an additional thirty (30) days may be allowed irrespective of accumulations provided that the employee has exhausted all personal illness, vacation and any other accumulated leaves first. 
(4)  At the discretion of the department head and with the approval of the personnel officer, leave of absence at half pay for a period not to exceed three (3) calendar months may be granted because of serious illness or injury to an officer or employee whose sick leave credits have been exhausted provided that the employee has exhausted all personal illness, vacation and any other accumulated leaves first. 
(5)  In order that absence because of personal illness may be charged to accumulated sick leave, it must be reported by the officer or employee on the first working day of such absence within such time limit as the department head may fix. Absence for illness on Saturday shall not be charged unless Saturday is a designated working day for the employee. If an employee is designated to work a half-day, then only a half-day shall be charged for absence on such day. 
(6)  The minimum unit for computation of personal illness or injury leave shall be one (1) hour, unless the department head determines that it is preferable to use a half day as the minimum unit for computation of personal illness or injury leave. Credits cannot be earned for the period an employee is on leave of absence without pay. For the calculation of sick leave credits, the time recorded on the payroll at the full rate of pay shall be considered as time "served" by the employee. 
(7)  An officer or employee who has exhausted his sick leave allowance and who is absent at the end of the calendar year shall not receive any sick leave allowance for the new year until he returns to duty. On the first payroll following his return he may receive compensation for his absence to the extent of his sick leave allowance for that year, upon application made to his department head. 
(8)  The department head may require an officer or employee absent on account of claimed illness or injury to submit to a physical examination by a physician selected by the department head, or the personnel officer. 
(9)  An officer or employee who is absent from duty after his sick leave allowance has been exhausted will be considered as absent without leave unless he applies for and is granted a leave of absence by his department head. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(A); Ord. of 3-5-91, § 6; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-94, § 3; Ord. of 3-7-02, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-66. - Childbearing and childrearing leaves. 
The following provisions shall apply to leaves for childbearing and childrearing for appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a as follows: 
(1)  Childbearing leave. A pregnant employee shall be allowed to perform the duties of her job as long as she is medically able. A pregnant employee, upon filing appropriate medical evidence, that she is unable to perform the duties of her position due to this pregnancy, shall be permitted to use any accumulated vacation leave, personal illness or injury, excused leave, and accumulated overtime for the period of her incapacity. 
(2)  Childrearing leave. The employee may use any paid leave he/she has accumulated (except personal illness or injury leave) for childrearing leave. The employee shall be granted, upon request, a leave of absence without pay for childrearing for a maximum period of six (6) months exclusive of the period above. This leave may be extended by mutual agreement with the approval of the personnel officer. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(B); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-96, § 7; Ord. of 12-4-00, § 9)  
Sec. 2-5-67. - Serious illness or death in family. 
The following provisions shall apply to leaves for serious illness or death in family for appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a as follows: 
(1)  Officers and employees who have served four (4) months in a department shall have the right to take not more than four (4) working days, with pay, in any calendar year, on account of death or serious illness in the officer's or employee's immediate family upon satisfactory evidence of such. Such absence may be extended to a maximum of ten (10) days, and the excess above four (4) days shall be charged to sick leave, vacation or overtime credits. The immediate family of an employee shall include grandparents, brother, sister, spouse, child, father or mother or foster parent of the employee or his spouse. 
(2)  Absence for serious illness or death outside of the immediate family may be deducted from sick leave credits. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(C); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-68. - Absences covered by workers' compensation. 
The following provisions shall apply to leaves for absences covered by workers' compensation for appointed officers and employees as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a as follows: 
(1)  An officer or employee who is necessarily absent from duty because of occupational injury or disease, as defined by the Workers' Compensation Law, may, pending adjudication of his case, be granted leave with full pay for the period not to exceed six (6) months (exclusive of accumulated sick leave credits), on approval of the department head, after full consideration of all the facts involved and the length of service of the employee. Should this disability persist beyond this period, plus accumulated sick leave credits, such employee may be placed on leave without pay for a further period not to exceed eleven (11) months. 
(2)  The employee shall, on return to active duty, be recredited with the number of days of earned sick leave consumed during his period of absence upon approval of his department head. 
(3)  Sick leave credits shall not be earned under these circumstances for the period that an employee is on such leave without pay. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(D); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-69. - Absence for jury and court attendance. 
On proof of the necessity of jury service or attending court for other than personal matters, leave of absence shall be granted with pay to all appointed officers and employees designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a, upon condition that they surrender to the city the amount received for jury or witness fees. Employees shall request that they be placed on "on-call" jury status, where available. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § (E); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-96, § 8)  
Sec. 2-5-70. - Military leave. 
An appointed officer or employee as designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a who is required to render ordered military duty shall be granted a leave of absence as authorized by law. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(G); Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 2-5-71. - Personal leave. 
The following provisions as to personal leave shall apply to appointed officers and employees designated in Appendices 1, 2b and 3a: 
(1)  Appointed officers and employees may receive up to four (4) days personal leave during the fiscal year. Any personal leave not taken in the fiscal year shall be credited towards the officers' or employees' sick leave. 
(2)  Upon approval of the department head, his designee, or personnel officer, personal leave shall be granted. The minimum unit of such leave shall be one (1) hour, unless the department head determines that it is preferable to use a half day as the minimum unit of leave. The minimum unit of personal leave may differ among employees in a bureau or department, but shall be uniform with respect to similarly situated employees within a bureau or department. 
(3)  Personal leave days shall not be accumulated. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, § 1(Art. II, § 3(G); Ord. of 3-5-91, § 7; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 9-27-04, § 5; Ord. of 10-4-04, § 5)  
Secs. 2-5-72—2-5-75. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-5-82. - Appendix 7, mileage allowance. 
All officers and employees will be reimbursed for mileage at the standard mileage rate used by the Internal Revenue Service, where a private car is authorized for use for the city's business and when the employee has been certified eligible for reimbursement by the insurance risk manager. 
(Ord. of 3-7-83, App. 7; Ord. of 1-7-91, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 4-1-02, § 1)  
Secs. 2-5-83—2-5-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PENSIONS, RETIREMENT AND RELATED BENEFITS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Related laws references— Death benefits for beneficiaries or urban renewal agency officers and employees, Art. A, Div. 12; death benefits for beneficiaries of parking authority officers and employees, Art. A, Div. 13; death benefits for beneficiaries of housing authority officers and employees, Art. A, Div. 14. 
 
Sec. 2-5-86. - Social security for policemen and firemen. 
(a)  The city, pursuant to section 218 of the Federal Social Security Act and Article 3 of the Retirement and Social Security Law, provides old-age and survivors insurance coverage for eligible policemen and firemen effective on December 16, 1957. 
(b)  Such coverage be provided for positions of policemen and firemen covered by the New York State Employees' Retirement System. 
(Res. of 1-20-58) 
Editor's note— See the resolution of March 21, 1955 for general social security coverage.  
Sec. 2-5-87. - Participation is "section 70-a" plan. 
(a)  The city, a participating employer in the New York State Employees' Retirement System, does hereby elect to make contributions to the pension accumulation fund pursuant to section 70-a of the Retirement and Social Security Law, as last amended by Chapter 339 of the Laws of 1960, for the purpose of providing death benefits and pensions-providing-for-increased-take-home-pay. 
(b)  The reductions or discontinuances of retirement system members' contributions, as provided in said section 70-a, shall be made effective for the payroll period commencing on June 24, 1960. 
(Res. of 6-6-60)  
Sec. 2-5-88. - "Section 75-e" benefits. 
(a)  The common council does hereby elect to provide the additional pension benefits of section 75-e, as presently or hereafter amended. 
(b)  This election shall become effective with the payroll period beginning on the second day of May, 1970. 
(Res. of 4-27-70)  
Sec. 2-5-89. - "375-g," "375-i" retirement benefits. 
The common council does hereby elect to provide the additional pension benefits under section 375-e; provide a career retirement plan under section 375-g and provide for an improved career retirement plan under section 375-i of the Retirement and Social Security Law as presently or hereafter amended; effective with the payroll period beginning on August 9, 1976. 
(Res. of 9-7-76)  
Sec. 2-5-90. - Special allowance for unused sick leave. 
(a)  The common council does hereby elect to provide the benefits of Section 41, subdivision-j of the Retirement and Social Security Law as presently or hereafter amended, granting allowance for unused sick leave for eligible employees in an amount not to exceed one hundred sixty-five (165) days. 
(b)  This election shall become effective with the payroll period beginning on the first day of July, 1971. 
(Res. of 8-2-71)  
Sec. 2-5-91. - Participation in Chapter 1006 of Laws of 1966. 
The common council, a participating employer in the New York State Employees' Retirement System, does hereby elect to come under the provisions of Chapter 1006 of the Laws of 1966, as amended effective January 20, 1967. 
(Res. of 1-16-67) 
Editor's note— Ch. 1006 of the Laws of 1966 is found in the Retirement and Social Security Law, §§ 70a, 75a—75c.  
Sec. 2-5-92. - Supplemental police and fire death benefits. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, and in addition to any benefits otherwise provided, the death benefits enumerated below may be payable upon the death of a regular paid member of the police department or fire department of the city if upon application therefor the mayor shall determine, on the basis of the evidence, that such member: 
(1)  Died within one year after, and as the natural and proximate result of injuries sustained at a definite time and place and incurred in the performance of duty as a member of such department, and 
(2)  Did not cause such accident by his own wilful negligence. 
(b)  The death benefit shall be paid by the city upon the allowance of the claim therefor and shall consist of: 
(1)  An amount equal to the salary received by such member either during the year immediately preceding his death, or during the year preceding such injuries, whichever is greater, and 
(2)  One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each child of such member under eighteen (18) on the date of the member's death. 
(c)  The death benefit shall be paid to: 
(1)  the member's widow, or if he shall leave no widow, or if his widow shall die before receiving the total of the amounts provided in section two hereof, then to 
(2)  his child or children under age eighteen (18) in equal amounts. 
(d)  An application for death benefit shall be made: 
(1)  by the member's widow; 
(2)  by any of his children; 
(3)  by any person in behalf of the widow or children; 
(4)  within thirty (30) days after the death of the member; provided, however, that failure to file the application within thirty (30) days may be excused on petition to and order of a justice of the supreme court having jurisdiction, upon a showing either: 
a.  that a sufficient reason exists why such notice was not given; 
b.  that a report or other notice was made or given to the police department or the fire department of which such person was a member of the injuries within the thirty (30) day period; 
c.  that the city has not been prejudiced by the delay in giving the notice. 
(e)  The application for death benefit shall be made: 
(1)  To the commissioner of finance on a form to be prescribed and supplied by him and requiring such information as he shall determine necessary. 
(f)  Such claims or death benefits may be paid out of the general revenues of the city or out of funds otherwise available, or the common council may, by ordinance or resolution, authorize the procuring of policies of insurance in order to provide for the payment of such benefits. The premiums for such policies of insurance shall be borne entirely by the city and shall be paid out of general revenues or out of funds otherwise available. 
(Ord. of 3-1-65, §§ 1—6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, General Municipal Law, § 208-b.  
Sec. 2-5-93. - Supplemental pensions for retired policemen and retired paid firemen and widows of certain firemen. 
(a)  Pursuant to chapter 119 of the laws of 1995, supplemental pension payments to retired policemen and retired paid firemen of the city hereby granted shall be computed by the addition to the regular pension payment to which he was entitled at the time of retirement to an individual pursuant to section 302 or 305 of the Charter, of the sum of the supplemental payments authorized by subsection (c) (previous supplements authorized or computed pursuant to section 207-i of the General Municipal Law) and of subsection (d) (schedule of increases authorized pursuant to section 78 of the Retirement and Social Security Law). 
(b)  The supplemental pension payments referred to in this section shall be payable to retirees who have heretofore been awarded an annual pension pursuant to either section 302 or section 305 of the Charter. 
(c)  The computation for supplemental pension benefits to retirees to whom this section is applicable shall be computed by using as the base the amount of pension that had been awarded to the retiree pursuant to either section 302 or section 305 of the Charter upon the retirement of the paid policemen or fireman, to which shall be added the sum of the supplemental retirement benefits, to be computed as of July 1, 1997, shown on schedule A (authorized pursuant to section 78 of the Retirement and Social Security Law), and of Schedule B (authorized pursuant to Section 207-i of the General Municipal Law,) both schedules being part of this section. 
(d)  The provision for supplemental pension payments provided in this section shall also be applicable to the widow of a member of the paid fire department who was killed in the actual performance of duty who died from the effects of any injury received while in the actual performance of duty, said widow having heretofore been awarded a pension pursuant to subdivision 1 of Section 305 of the Charter so that the supplemental pension payments provided for in this section will be added to the pension originally authorized for such widow. 
(e)  The following shall be Schedule A and may be cited as such:

Sec. 2-5-94. - Supplemental pension payments to widows and orphan minor children of retired policemen and retired paid firemen. 
(a)  Pursuant to chapter 119 of the Laws of 1995 relating to supplemental pension retirement benefits, as amended, supplemental pension payments to widows and orphan minor children of retired policemen and retired paid firemen of the city shall be as computed in this section. 
(b)  The supplemental pension payments referred to in this section shall be payable to widows who have heretofore been awarded an annual pension of three hundred dollars ($300.00) pursuant to either section 302 or 305 of the Charter. 
(c)  The computation for supplemental pension benefits to widows to whom this section is applicable shall be computed by using as the base the amount of pension that had been awarded to the retiree pursuant to either section 302 or section 305 of the Charter, upon the retirement of the paid policeman or fireman, to which shall be added the sum of the supplemental retirement benefits, to be computed as of July 1, 1997, of the additional supplemental payments shown on Schedule A (authorized pursuant to section 78 of the Retirement and Social Security Law) and Schedule B (authorized pursuant to section 207-i of the General Municipal Law) which became effective July 1, 1981, and which remains unchanged, both schedules being annexed to and made a part of this section. The amount to be paid to a widow shall be fifty (50) percent of such total to be paid monthly at one-twelfth of the annual rate for each month of entitlement. If the total of the basic pension and the supplements is less than eighteen hundred dollars ($1,800.00), then the sum of eighteen hundred dollars ($1,800.00) shall be paid to such widow per annum prorated monthly. 
(d)  The following are the previous supplements authorized or computed pursuant to section 207-i of the General Municipal Law:

Sec. 2-5-95. - Supplemental death benefits for other officers and employees. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, and in addition to any benefits otherwise provided, the death benefits enumerated below may be payable upon the death of a paid officer or employee of the city if, upon application therefor, the mayor or president of the common council shall determine, on the basis of the evidence, that such officer or employee: 
(1)  Died within one year after, and as the natural and proximate result of injuries sustained at a definite time and place and incurred in the performance of duty as such paid officer or employee, and 
(2)  Did not cause accident by his own wilful negligence. 
(b)  The death benefit shall be paid by the city upon the allowance of the claim therefor, and shall consist of: 
(1)  An amount equal to the salary received by such paid officer or employee either during the year immediately preceding his death, or during the year preceding such injuries, whichever is greater, and 
(2)  One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each child of such paid officer or employee under eighteen on the date of the paid officer's or employee's death. 
(c)  The death benefit shall be paid to: 
(1)  Such paid officer's or employee's widow, or widower, or if he or she shall leave no widow or widower, or if his widow or her widower shall die before receiving the total of the amounts provided in subsection (b) hereof, then to 
(2)  His or her child or children under age eighteen (18) in equal amounts. 
(d)  Application for death benefit shall be made: 
(1)  By the paid officer's or employee's widow or widower; 
(2)  By any of his children; 
(3)  By any person in behalf of the widow or widower or children. 
(e)  Application for death benefit shall be made: 
(1)  To the commissioner of finance on a form to be prescribed and supplied by him and requiring such information as he shall determine necessary; 
(2)  Within thirty (30) days after the death of such paid officer or employee; provided, however, that failure to file the application within thirty (30) days may be excused on petition to and order of a justice of the supreme court having jurisdiction, upon a showing either: 
a. 
That a sufficient reason exists why such notice was not given; 
b. 
That a report or other notice was made or given to the head of the department in which such paid officer or employee is employed, of the injuries within the thirty day period; 
c. 
That the city has not been prejudiced by the delay in giving the notice. 
(f)  Such claims or death benefits may be paid out of the general revenues of the city or out of the funds otherwise available, or the common council may, by ordinance or resolution, authorize the procuring of a policy or policies of insurance in order to provide for the payment of such benefits. The premiums for such policy or policies of insurance shall be borne entirely by the city and shall be paid out of general revenues or out of funds otherwise available. 
(g)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the regular paid members of the police and fire departments of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, §§ 1—7; Ord. of 9-7-65, § 1) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, Laws, 1965, § 1005.  
Sec. 2-5-96. - Retirement incentive program, 1992. 
(a)  The City of White Plains hereby elects to provide all its eligible employees with a retirement incentive program authorized by Chapter 643, Laws of 1992. 
(b)  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be October 1, 1992. 
(c)  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit shall be ninety (90) days in length. 
(d)  The actuarial present value of the additional retirement benefits payable pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be funded over a five-year period. The amount of the annual payment in each of the five-years shall be determined by the Actuary of the New York State and Local Employees Retirement System, and it shall be paid by The City of White Plains for each employee who receives the retirement benefits payable under this section. 
(L.L. No. 2-1992, §§ 1—4) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 2-1992 did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—4 as § 2-5-96 was at the discretion of the editor.

(b)  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be June 1, 1995. 
(c)  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit, shall be ninety (90) days in length.

(L.L. No. 1-1995, §§ 1—4)

(b)  The commencement date of the retirement incentive program shall be October 3, 1996. 
(c)  The open period during which eligible employees may retire and receive the additional retirement benefit, shall be ninety (90) days in length. 
(d)  The actuarial present value of the additional retirement benefits payable pursuant to the provisions of the local law shall be paid as one (1) lump sum or in five (5) annual installments. The amount of the annual payment shall be determined by the retirement actuary of the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System, and it shall be paid by the city for each employee who received the benefits payable under this local law. 
(L.L. No. 3-1996, §§ 1—4; L.L. No. 5-1996, §§ 1, 2)

Sec. 2-5-99. - Retirement incentive program, 1996, for appointed officials and managerial/confidential positions. 
(a)  The common council of the City of White Plains hereby elects to establish a retirement incentive program for appointed officials and managerial/confidential positions targeted for program participation. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Eligible employee means a person who is an appointed official as set forth in appendix 1 of section 2-5-76 of the White Plains Municipal Code or a managerial/confidential employee as set forth in appendix 2b of section 2-5-77 of the White Plains Municipal Code, who is otherwise eligible for a service retirement as of the effective date of the employee's application for retirement, who has a minimum of ten (10) years of service with the city, whose retirement will result in no greater cost to the city than would result from the employee's retirement under the New York State Early Retirement Incentive Program authorized by Chapter 30, Laws of 1996, and whose position has been targeted for program participation. 
(2)  Targeted position means a position which the mayor has designated as suitable to participate in this retirement incentive program. In making his determination as to which positions are suitable to participate in this retirement incentive program, the mayor shall consider whether the participation of a specific position would: (a) Result in an unacceptable reduction of the level of service required or mandated to protect and care for the residents of the city or to assure public health and safety; (b) unacceptably endanger the health or safety of employees of the city; or (c) result in a loss of significant revenue to the city or result in substantially increased overtime or contractual costs. The mayor shall also determine that the city will attain a compensation savings for the two-year period subsequent to the termination of such eligible employees' employment with the City. 
(3)  Compensation savings means that the total base salary and benefits paid for all new hires, who would not have been hired but for vacancies resulting from the retirement incentive provided herein, shall be less than the total base salary and benefits that would have been paid for the two-year period January 1, 1997 through December 31, 1998 to the eligible employees who terminated their city employment and received the retirement incentive established by this local law. 
(c)  The mayor shall notify the commissioner of finance and the personnel officer of his designation of the targeted positions on or before September 30, 1996. The personnel officer shall notify all eligible employees of the mayor's designations. 
(d)  The first date that the retirement incentive established by this local law shall be made available is October 1, 1996. 
(e)  The period during which an eligible employee may elect to participate in the program and receive the retirement incentive established by this local law shall be the period from October 1, 1996 through October 31, 1996. An eligible employee who wishes to receive the retirement incentive established by this local law must file an application for service retirement with the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System with an effective retirement date no later than December 31, 1996. 
(f)  The benefit provided hereby as an incentive for the participation of an eligible employee shall consist of a payment to said employee based on the following schedule which approximates the pension benefit cost which the city would have been required to pay, calculated to be paid in a payment, to the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System if that employee's position were targeted for, and the employee participated in, the state retirement incentive program authorized by Chapter 30, Laws of 1996: 
Eligible Employees Retirement Plan 	Rate 
75-g, 75-h; 75-i; 	0.15 
70, 71-a, 75-c, 75-e 	0.12 
Article 14, Article 15 	0.09 
 
This benefit shall be calculated by multiplying the appropriate rate for the retirement plan in which the eligible employee is enrolled by the eligible employee's annual salary and multiplying that result by five (5). Payment of this benefit shall be made to the eligible employee after the employee's termination of employment with the city but no later than January 3, 1997. 
(L.L. No. 4-1996, §§ 1—6) 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 4-1996, §§ 1—6, passed Sept. 9, 1996, did not specify manner of codification, but was designated as § 2-5-99 by the editor. See also § 2-5-16.
