The facility owner shall maintain, clean, repair, replace and continue the storm water control measures depicted in Schedule A as necessary to ensure optimum performance of the measures to design specifications. The storm water control measures shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: drainage ditches, swales, dry wells, infiltrators, drop inlets, pipes, culverts, soil absorption devices and retention ponds. 
3.  The facility owner shall be responsible for all expenses related to the maintenance of the storm water control measures and shall establish a means for the collection and distribution of expenses among parties for any commonly owned facilities. 
4.  The facility owner shall provide for the periodic inspection of the storm water control measures, not less than once in every five year period, to determine the condition and integrity of the measures. Such inspection shall be performed by a Professional Engineer licensed by the State of New York. The inspecting engineer shall prepare and submit to the City within 30 days of the inspection, a written report of the findings including recommendations for those actions necessary for the continuation of the storm water control measures. 
5.  The facility owner shall not authorize, undertake or permit alteration, abandonment, modification or discontinuation of the storm water control measures except in accordance with written approval of the City. 
6.  The facility owner shall undertake necessary repairs and replacement of the storm water control measures at the direction of the City or in accordance with the recommendations of the inspecting engineer. 
7.  The facility owner shall provide to the City within 30 days of the date of this agreement, a security for the maintenance and continuation of the storm water control measures in the form of (a Bond, letter of credit or escrow account). 
8.  This agreement shall be recorded in the Office of the County Clerk, County of Westchester together with the deed for the common property and shall be included in the offering plan and/or prospectus approved pursuant to ___________. 
9.  If ever the City determines that the facility owner has failed to construct or maintain the storm water control measures in accordance with the project plan or has failed to undertake corrective action specified by the City or by the inspecting engineer, the City is authorized to undertake such steps as reasonably necessary for the preservation, continuation or maintenance of the storm water control measures and to affix the expenses thereof as a lien against the property. 
10.  This agreement is effective ___________.  
Chapter 3-7 - COMMUNITY CHOICE AGGREGATION (ENERGY) PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 3-7-1. - Legislative findings; intent and purpose; authority. 
(a)  It is the policy of both the City of White Plains and the State of New York to reduce costs and provide cost certainty for the purpose of economic development, to promote deeper penetration of energy efficiency and renewable energy resources such as wind and solar, and wider deployment of distributed energy resources as well as to examine the retail energy markets and increase participation of and benefits for residential and Small Commercial customers in those markets. Among the policies and models that may offer benefits in New York is community choice aggregation, which allows local governments to determine the default supplier of electricity and natural gas on behalf of its residential and Small Commercial customers. 
(b)  The purpose of this Community Choice Aggregation (Energy) Program is to allow participating local governments including the City of White Plains to procure energy supply service for their residential and Small Commercial customers, who will have the opportunity to opt out of the procurement, while maintaining transmission and distribution service from the existing Distribution Utility. This Chapter establishes a program that will allow Sustainable Westchester on behalf of the City of White Plains to put out for bid the total amount of natural gas and/or electricity being purchased by local residential and Small Commercial customers. Bundled Customers will have the opportunity to have more control to lower their overall energy costs, to spur clean energy innovation and investment, to improve customer choice and value, and to protect the environment; thereby, fulfilling the purposes of this Chapter and fulfilling an important public purpose. 
(c)  The City of White Plains is authorized to implement this Community Choice Aggregation (Energy) Program pursuant to Section 10(1)(ii)(a)(12) of the New York Municipal Home Rule Law; and State of New York Public Service Commission Case No. 14-M-0564, Petition of Sustainable Westchester for Expedited Approval for the Implementation of a Pilot Community Choice Aggregation Program within the County of Westchester, Order Granting Petition in Part (issued February 26, 2015) as may be amended, including subsequent orders of the Public Service Commission issued in connection with or related to Case No. 14-M-0564 (collectively, the "Order"). Order shall also mean orders of the Public Service Commission related to State of New York Public Service Commission Case No. 14-M-0224, Proceeding on Motion of the Commission to Enable Community Choice Aggregation Programs (issued December 15, 2014) to the extent that orders related to Case No. 14-M-0224 enable actions by the City of White Plains not otherwise permitted pursuant to orders related to Case 14-M-0564; provided, however, that in the event of any conflict between orders from Case No. 14-M-0564 and orders from Case No 14-M-0224, orders from Case No 14-M-0564 shall govern the Community Choice Aggregation Program. 
(d)  This Chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Community Choice Aggregation (Energy) Program Law of the City of White Plains". 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)  
Sec. 3-7-2. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this Chapter, and unless otherwise expressly stated or unless the context otherwise requires, the terms in this Chapter shall have the meanings employed in the State of New York Public Service Commission's Uniform Business Practices or, if not so defined there, as indicated below: 
(a)  Bundled Customers - Residential and Small Commercial customers of electricity or natural gas ("fuels") who are purchasing the fuels from the Distribution Utility. 
(b)  Small Commercial - Non-residential customers as permitted by the Order. 
(c)  Community Choice Aggregation Program or CCA Program- A municipal energy procurement program, which replaces the incumbent utility as the default Supplier for all Bundled Customers within the City of White Plains. 
(d)  Distribution Utility - Owner or controller of the means of distribution of the natural gas or electricity that is regulated by the Public Service Commission. 
(e)  Public Service Commission - New York State Public Service Commission. 
(f)  Suppliers - Energy service companies (ESCOs) that procure electric power and natural gas for Bundled Customers in connection with this Chapter or, alternatively, generators of electricity and natural gas or other entities who procure and resell electricity or natural gas. 
(g)  Sustainable Westchester- A not-for-profit organization comprised of member municipalities in Westchester County, New York. 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)  
Sec. 3-7-3. - Establishment of a community choice aggregation (energy) program. 
(a)  A Community Choice Aggregation (Energy) Program is hereby established by the Common Council of the City of White Plains, whereby the City of White Plains shall work together with Sustainable Westchester to implement the CCA Program to the full extent permitted by the Order, as set forth more fully herein. The City of White Plains' role under the CCA Program involves the aggregating of the electric and/or natural gas supply of its residents and the entering into a contract with one or more Suppliers for supply and services. Under the CCA Program, the operation and ownership of the utility service shall remain with the Distribution Utility. 
(b)  The City of White Plains' purchase of energy supply through a CCA Program constitutes neither the purchase of a public utility system, nor the furnishing of utility service. The City of White Plains will not take over any part of the electric or gas transmission or distribution system and will not furnish any type of utility service, but will instead allow Sustainable Westchester to negotiate on behalf of the City of White Plains with Suppliers on behalf of participating residential and Small Commercial customers. The gross receipts tax will be paid by companies delivering and supplying energy, including but not limited to, one or more ESCOs. 
(c)  In order to implement the CCA Program, the City of White Plains will adopt one or more resolutions that outline the process of and conditions for participation in the CCA Program, including but not limited to signing a contract for a compliant bid with one or more Suppliers, all as consistent with this Local Law and the Order. 
(d)  The Public Service Commission supervises retail markets and participants in these markets through legislative and regulatory authority and the Uniform Business Practices, which includes rules relating to the eligibility of participating ESCOs, the operation by which ESCOs provide energy services, and the terms on which customers may be enrolled with ESCOs. 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)  
Sec. 3-7-4. - Procedures for eligibility; customer data sharing. 
(a)  As permitted by the Order, Sustainable Westchester, on behalf of the City of White Plains, may request from the Distribution Utility's aggregated customer information by fuel type and service classification on a rolling basis. 
(b)  Sustainable Westchester, on behalf of the City of White Plains, shall issue one or more requests for proposals to Suppliers to provide energy to participants and may then award a contract in accordance with the CCA Program. 
(c)  Sustainable Westchester, on behalf of the City of White Plains, will then request individual customer data from the Distribution Utility in accordance with the CCA Program. 
(d)  Sustainable Westchester, on behalf of the City of White Plains, and the selected Supplier will then notify Bundled Customers of the contract terms and their opportunity to opt out of the CCA Program. 
(e)  In accordance with and for purposes of the Order, the existing Distribution Utility, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will provide to Sustainable Westchester aggregate and customer-specific data (including usage data, capacity tag obligations, account numbers, and service addresses) of all Bundled Customers in the City of White Plains not currently enrolled with an ESCO. 
(f)  Sustainable Westchester and the City of White Plains, will protect customer information as required by law, subject to the Order and the limitations of the New York State Freedom of Information Law. 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)  
Sec. 3-7-5. - Choice of energy supplier; opt-out notice and procedure. 
(a)  Sustainable Westchester, on behalf of the City of White Plains, will notify the existing Distribution Utility's residential and Small Commercial customers, by letter notice, of the City of White Plains' decision to establish the CCA Program, of the contract terms with an ESCO, and of the opportunity to opt out of the CCA Program. 
(b)  The letter notice will be sent to each customer at the address provided by the Distribution Utility and explain the CCA Program and the material provisions of the ESCO contract, identify the methods by which the customer can opt out of the CCA Program, and provide information on how the customer can access additional information about the CCA Program. 
(c)  The opt-out period shall be twenty (20) days from the notice date. 
(d)  CCA Program Bundled Customers, upon enrollment, will receive a welcome letter from the ESCO that will explain the customer's options for canceling the enrollment if they believe they were enrolled incorrectly or otherwise decide to withdraw from the CCA Program in favor of another Supplier. The welcome letter also will explain that residential customers are entitled to the added protection of the mandated three (3) day rescission period as detailed in Section 5(B)(3) of the New York Uniform Business Practices Law. 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)  
Sec. 3-7-6. - Verification and reporting. 
Sustainable Westchester shall be responsible for filing an annual report with the Public Service Commission, which identifies the number of customers enrolled in the CCA Program by municipality and customer class, the number of customers who returned to utility service or service with another Supplier during the reporting period, and the average cost of commodity supply by month for the reporting period. 
(Ord. of 10-5-15, § 1)

Chapter 4-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 4-1-1. - Games of chance legalized. 
(a)  It shall be lawful for any authorized organization, upon obtaining and having in effect a license as provided in The Games of Chance Licensing Law, to conduct games of chance within the territorial limits of the city. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section and the administration of the provisions of The Games of Chance Law, the commissioner of public safety is the chief law enforcement officer of the city, and the city clerk is the clerk of the municipality. 
(Ord. of 7-5-77, §§ 1, 2) 
Editor's note— The ordinance from which this section is derived was approved by the electorate at the November 8, 1977 election as required by law (General Municipal Law, § 188). See Official Proceedings of the Common Council, Vol. 62, No. 32, p. 1017 (December 19, 1977). 
State Law reference— The Games of Chance Licensing Law, General Municipal Law, §§ 185—195-n.  
Sec. 4-1-2. - Bingo legalized. 
It shall be lawful for any authorized organization as defined in section 476 of Article 14-H of the General Municipal Law, and any amendments thereto, upon obtaining the required license, to conduct bingo games within the city, subject to the provisions of this section, article 14-H of the General Municipal Law and any amendments thereto, article 19-B of the Executive Law and any amendments thereto, the rules and regulations of the state bingo control commission and the following restrictions: 
(1)  No person other than a licensee under the provisions of article 14-H of the General Municipal Law, shall conduct such game or shall lease or otherwise make available for conducting bingo a hall or other premises for any consideration whatsoever, direct or indirect. 
(2)  No bingo games shall be held, operated or conducted on or within any leased premises if rental under such lease is to be paid, wholly or partly, on the basis of a percentage of the receipts or net profits derived from the operation of such game. 
(3)  No authorized organization licensed under the provisions of article 4-H of the General Municipal Law shall purchase or receive any supplies or equipment specifically designed or adapted for use in the conduct of bingo games from other than a supplier licensed under the Bingo Control Law or from another authorized organization. 
(4)  The entire net proceeds of any game of bingo and of any rental shall be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct the same. 
(5)  No prize shall exceed the sum or value of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in any single game of bingo. 
(6)  No series of prizes on any one bingo occasion shall aggregate more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(7)  No person except a bona fide member of any such organization shall participate in the management or operation of such game. 
(8)  No person shall receive any remuneration for participating in the management or operation of any game of bingo. 
(9)  The unauthorized conduct of a bingo game and any willful violation of any provision of this section shall constitute and be punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(10)  Limited period bingo shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of this section and the rules and regulations of the commission. 
(Ord. of 5-15-72, § 1) 
State Law reference— The Bingo Licensing Law, General Municipal Law, §§ 475—499.  
Sec. 4-1-3. - Non-criminal applicant fingerprint submission to the division of criminal justice services (DCJS) for certain license applications. 
1.  All applicants to the City of White Plains for a license to be a window cleaner, second hand dealer, pawnbroker, auctioneer, chauffeur, taxicab driver, cabaret operator, hawker, peddler or solicitor shall be fingerprinted. 
2.  The department of public safety shall cause the applicant's fingerprints and appropriate fee to be forwarded to the division of criminal justice services (DCS) in the form and manner as prescribed by DCS for a complete criminal check. 
3.  The commissioner of the department of public safety or his/her designee(s) shall review all information provided by DCS in connection with the applicant's criminal background and investigation. 
4.  If a prospective applicant for any of the aforementioned licenses has been convicted of a crime, any decision regarding such prospective applicant's fitness for a license will be made upon consideration of New York State Correction Law §§ 701-703-b and §§ 751-753. 
(L.L. No. 2-2011, § 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 4-1-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Formerly, §§ 4-1-3 and 4-1-4 specifically permitted the exhibition of motion pictures and the playing of certain sports games after 2:00 p.m. on Sunday. Such sections were repealed by §§ 1, 2, of an ordinance adopted Sept. 2, 2003. Prior to repeal the sections derived from an ordinance adopted Oct. 31, 1949, § 1; and ordinances adopted Aug. 5, 1929, § 1; Dec. 19, 1949, § 1; and July 6, 1970, § 1.  
Sec. 4-1-5. - Solicitors and others on private property. 
(a)  No person shall enter upon any private residential property in the city without the consent of the occupant of the premises having been given for the following purposes: 
(1)  Vending, peddling or soliciting orders for any merchandise, device, book, periodical or printed matter whatsoever; 
(2)  Soliciting alms, or for a subscription or contribution to any church, charitable or public institution whatsoever; 
(3)  Distributing any handbill, pamphlet, tract, notice or advertising matter; 
(4)  Selling or distributing any ticket or chance whatsoever. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply to any person who has been a bona fide resident of the city for a period of at least six (6) consecutive months last past, nor to any person who has maintained a place of business in the city for a period of at least six (6) consecutive months, prior thereto, or his duly authorized representative. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine which shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in amount or imprisonment not exceeding one hundred fifty (150) days or to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  This section is enacted pursuant to the police power of the city and in order to protect the citizens of the city against crime and preserve the private property, peace and comfort of the occupants of private residences in the city. 
(Ord. of 4-20-42, §§ 1—4) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37. 
Cross reference— Charitable solicitations, Ch. 4-5; hawkers, peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 4-9. 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate and license occupations and businesses, General Municipal Law, § 20(13).  
Sec. 4-1-6. - Conversions to cooperative or condominium ownership (General Business Law, § 352-eee). 
The City of White Plains hereby elects that the provisions of section 352-eee, as amended, of the General Business Law, be applicable within The City of White Plains. 
(Res. of 9-2-80)  
Chapter 4-2 - AMBULANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— State regulation of emergency service ambulances, Public Health Law, § 3000 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-2-1. - Definition. 
As used in this chapter the term "emergency ambulance service" means the furnishing of transportation to facilities providing medical treatment services where immediate transportation to such facility of such sick or disabled person is needed or appears to be needed to prevent undue suffering or loss of life of the person needing or appearing to need such transportation with emergency care in transit. 
(Ord. of 12-16-75, § 2)  
Sec. 4-2-2. - Established. 
An emergency ambulance service for the city is hereby established. 
(Ord. of 12-16-74, § 1) 
State Law reference— Power of city to establish ambulance service, General Municipal Law, § 122-b.  
Sec. 4-2-3. - Rules and regulations, fees and charges—Authorized. 
The director of the bureau of emergency planning and civil defense is hereby authorized to prepare and submit for approval of the common council rules and regulations relating to the use of emergency ambulance service provided by the city and fix a schedule of fees or charges to be paid by persons requesting the use of such facilities. 
(Ord. of 12-16-75, § 3)  
Sec. 4-2-4. - Same—Current rules, regulations, etc. 
(a)  All emergency ambulance and transportation requests when reported to the police department will be dispatched by the police department communications office, to Abbey Richmond Ambulance Service, Division of Arco Medical Supply Corporation. However, all ambulance calls, regardless of origin shall be honored within the city limits and confirmed by the ambulance company, with the police communications officer, as soon as possible. 
(b)  All documented emergency ambulance police department calls, will be forwarded to the emergency planning director in report form by data processing print-out sheets monthly. 
(c)  The director of emergency planning will submit the dollar value of ambulance costs monthly to the commissioner of finance in accordance with the terms of the approved contract. 
(d)  The director of emergency planning will prepare a claim voucher for services rendered to the commissioner of finance for payment. 
(e)  The department of public safety shall have the responsibility of inspection of vehicle and determining the availability of the ambulance, as specified in the approved contract. 
(f)  The director of emergency planning will be responsible for providing weather reports as received, to Abbey Richmond, Division of Arco Medical Supply Corporation. 
(g)  A pre-arranged hospital zone is established as follows: 
(1)  Only in the event a patient or patient's family does not request a specific hospital. 
(2)  Transports to St. Agnes Hospital: South on North Broadway into South Broadway to Armory Place Hill including both sides of Bloomingdale Road, South to Mamaroneck Avenue, to the city limits. 
(3)  Transports to White Plains Hospital: West side of mentioned boundaries listed above through the city limits. 
However, Abbey Richmond personnel shall have a legitimate option of choice of hospitals if such factors as traffic and weather conditions are such that compliance to the zone would be detrimental to the patient's well being. 
(h)  Under provision of the contract a billing memo will be supplied no later than ten (10) days by the ambulance company, to the director of emergency planning. 
(i)  An out-of-town rate is established for noncity residents at a call rate of sixty dollars ($60.00) regardless of time. 
(j)  The ambulance company shall maintain communications equipment on the existing emergency planning radio system frequency of 29.61. The radio system is presently installed in police headquarters, emergency planning bureau, and all emergency ambulance calls shall be dispatched to the ambulance company utilizing this system. This radio system also is in operation at the Lexington and Hamilton Avenue fire house, and all the four local hospitals. However, a telephone hot line system will be installed from police headquarters to the ambulance company. This will also serve as a back-up system, and allow adequate delivery in regard to the purchase of radio communications equipment mentioned. 
(k)  The established payment for services rendered is as follows: 
(1)  Billing monthly for a period of three (3) months. 
(2)  Legal action for collection of fees will begin commencing the fourth month. 
(l)  The director of emergency planning accepts full responsibility for collection of any fees from patients for whom service is provided under Section 122-b of the General Municipal Law. 
SCHEDULE OF FEES AND CHARGES 
(1)  Day ambulance rate (weekdays): 
9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ..... $140.00 
(2)  Off-hour and holiday rates: 
Weekdays—6:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. ..... 160.00 
Weekends—6:00 p.m. Friday to 9:00 a.m. Monday ..... 160.00 
Holidays—Full 24 hours ..... 160.00 
Non-city resident rates ..... 160.00 
(3)  Mileage rates (Medicare reimbursement only) ..... 2.50 
(4)  Charges, per patient, when carrying more than one patient in any one given ambulance: 
Stretcher cases—Full charges 
Day ..... 140.00 
Night ..... 160.00 
Ambulatory cases—½ normal charge (after first stretcher case) 
Day ..... 70.00 
Night ..... 80.00 
(5)  Canceled call charge—Call canceled after dispatch of ambulance—½ normal charge: 
Days ..... 70.00 
Nights and weekends ..... 80.00 
(6)  Waiting time charge other than municipal requirements, per hour ..... 45.00 
(7)  Oxygen service charge ..... 25.00 
(8)  Extra man charge ..... 29.00 
(9)  Advanced life support treatment as per same itemized breakdown in items (1) and (2) above: 
Day ..... 240.00 
Night ..... 260.00 
(10)  All medical supplies expended or furnished to authorized users of the ambulance service and damage done by demented beneficiaries of the service will be billed at the prevailing cost. 
(Res. of 12-16-74; Ord. of 6-21-85; Ord. of 6-2-86)  
Chapter 4-3 - AUCTIONEERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General police power of city, § 4. 
State Law reference— Auctions and auctioneers generally, General Business Law, § 21 et seq.; power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-3-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
Auctioneer: Any person who sells or offers goods, wares and chattels at public auction. 
Goods, wares and chattels: These terms shall include, but shall not be limited to, all commodities, compounds, chattels, merchandise, watches, clocks, jewelry, and all other personal property which may be lawfully kept or offered for sale; but shall not include goods damaged at sea or by fire and sold or to be sold for the benefit of the owner's insurers or for the account of whom it may concern or goods sold by virtue of judicial decree. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 1; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-2. - Use of criers, music, etc., to attract persons. 
No auctioneer shall employ a bellman, crier, instrument of music, loud speaker or other means of attracting the attention of passersby. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(4); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(4))  
Sec. 4-3-3. - Flag or sign. 
Any flag or sign used by an auctioneer to attract the attention of passersby shall bear the license number of the auctioneer. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(4); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(4))  
Sec. 4-3-4. - Conducting sales for transient merchants. 
No auctioneer shall conduct any auction sale for a transient merchant or other person who or which has not procured a permit as required by law or ordinance or whose permit has expired or been revoked. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(5); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(5))  
Sec. 4-3-5. - Hours of sale. 
No person shall conduct a public auction sale between 5:30 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., except that an auction conducted for the limited purpose of "going out of business" may be conducted after 9:00 a.m. and continuing until 10:30 p.m. in a nonresidential district in connection with an existing retail use, provided that no auction permit for any sale at such location shall be issued for a period of longer than thirty-five (35) days in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 23; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-6. - Sales on Sundays and legal holidays. 
No person shall conduct a public auction sale on Sundays or legal holidays, except that an auction conducted for the limited purpose of "going out of business" may be conducted after 1:00 p.m. and continuing until 10:30 p.m. in a nonresidential district in connection with an existing retail use, provided that no auction permit for any sale at such location shall be issued for a period of longer than thirty-five (35) days in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 22; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 2)  
Sec. 4-3-7. - Deceptive or fraudulent practices. 
No auctioneer shall do any of the following acts: 
(1)  Make any false representation as to the character, quality, condition, previous history, value or ownership of any property offered for sale. 
(2)  Substitute any other article for the article sold to the bidder. 
(3)  Bid in any property offered for sale by himself and no person shall act as an accomplice or "capper" for the purpose of making mock bids at any auction. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(1)—(3); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(1)—(3))  
Sec. 4-3-8. - Transactions involving minors. 
No auctioneer knowingly shall receive for sale by auction or sell by auction any goods, wares or merchandise from or to any minor. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(7); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(7))  
Sec. 4-3-9. - Records. 
Every auctioneer, upon the receipt or acceptance by him of any goods for the purpose of sale at auction and before offering the same or any part thereof for sale at auction, shall write or cause to be written, in a book to be kept by him for such purpose: 
(1)  The name and address of the person who employed him to sell such goods at auction; 
(2)  The name and address of the person for whose benefit, behalf or account, such goods are to be sold at auction; 
(3)  The name and address of the person from whom such auctioneer received or accepted such goods; 
(4)  The name and address of the person who was the owner, the authorized agent of the owner or the consignor of such goods immediately prior to the receipt or acceptance for the purpose of sale at auction of the same by such auctioneer; 
(5)  The location, with street and number, if any, of such goods immediately prior to the receipt or acceptance of the same by such auctioneer for the purpose of sale at auction; 
(6)  The date of the receipt or acceptance by such auctioneer of such goods for the purpose of sale at auction; 
(7)  The place, with street and number, if any, in which such goods are to be held, kept or stored until sold or offered for sale at auction; 
(8)  The place, with street and number, if any, in which such goods are to be sold or offered for sale at auction; 
(9)  A description of such goods, the quantity thereof and the distinctive marks thereon, if any; and 
(10)  The terms and conditions upon which such auctioneer receives or accepts such goods for sale at auction. 
Such book and the entries therein made, as provided for in this section, shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the city clerk, the commissioner of public safety or their duly authorized agents. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 14; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 14)  
Sec. 4-3-10. - Vehicular parking. 
The commissioner of public safety shall have the authority to require that the auctioneer provide, at the auctioneer's expense, for police personnel to enforce the restrictions as to parking provided by the auctioneer. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 22; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 22)  
Sec. 4-3-11. - Exceptions. 
Nothing herein contained shall apply to judicial sales or sales by or for the account of executors or administrators, by trustees under deed of assignment, by lienors, or by public officers in the manner prescribed by law, or by bona fide religious or charitable organizations conducting auctions on premises regularly occupied or used by said organization for its activities. Sales by or for the account of executors or administrators are those sales comprised of the goods, wares and chattels of an estate of a descendant. Auctioneers shall not include in the inventory of such sales any goods, wares or chattels that are not part of said estate without complying with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 3; Ord. of 3-1-71, § 1; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 3)  
Sec. 4-3-12. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense or by imprisonment for fifteen (15) days or by both such fine and imprisonment, and may result, in addition to the imposition of fines and penalties, in the revocation of the offender's license or permit. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 24; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 23) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-3-13—4-3-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-3-21. - Required. 
No person shall carry on the trade of auctioneer or shall act as an auctioneer without having first secured a license therefor and no sale at public auction of goods, wares and chattels shall be held within the city unless such sale shall be directly conducted by a licensed auctioneer pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 2; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 2)  
Sec. 4-3-22. - Application. 
Every person desiring to procure the license required by this article shall file with the city clerk a written application upon a blank form prepared and furnished by the city. Such application shall contain: 
(1)  The name and business and residence address of the applicant; 
(2)  The applicants' date of birth; 
(3)  His previous employment and where; 
(4)  Whether he has ever been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony and if so what offense, when and in what court; 
(5)  Whether he has either alone or with someone else ever engaged in the business of auctioneer and if so when and where. 
Such application shall be signed and verified before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths in the state. Such application shall be accompanied by a photograph of applicant, in triplicate, in such position as the city clerk may direct, taken within thirty (30) days preceding the filing of the application. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 4; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 4)  
Sec. 4-3-23. - Investigation of applicant. 
When an application is filed pursuant to this article the city clerk shall request the commissioner of public safety to investigate whether the applicant is of good character and repute. Under the supervision of said commissioner fingerprints shall be taken of the applicant. The commissioner of public safety shall furnish to the city clerk, in writing, the information derived from such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether the license should be granted or refused. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 5; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 5)  
Sec. 4-3-24. - Bond. 
An application for the license required by the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a bond in favor of the people of the city, approved as to form and manner of execution by the corporation counsel, in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned that the applicant will faithfully perform his duties as such auctioneer as required by law and ordinances and render such accounts and pay such duties as may be required of him by law. In lieu of such bond, a certified check payable to the city, to be held in a non-interest bearing trust account may be submitted. This certified check will be returned to the auctioneer upon the expiration of his license. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 6; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 6; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-25. - Issuance. 
(a)  Upon filing the application, bond and information as required in this article, the city clerk may, upon approval of such application and the payment to the city of the license fee provided for in this article, issue to the applicant a license to engage in the business of auctioneer. No license shall be refused except for a specific reason and for the protection of the public safety, good order and morals. All licenses shall be numbered in the order in which they are issued and shall state clearly the date of issuance and expiration of the license, the fee paid and the name and business address of the licensee. 
(b)  No applicant to whom a license has been refused shall make further application until a period of at least six (6) months shall have elapsed since the last previous rejection unless applicant can show that the reason for such rejection no longer exists, or unless such application was erroneously refused. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 7; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 7)  
Sec. 4-3-26. - Fee. 
The annual fee for auctioneer's license, shall be the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00), seventy-five dollars ($75.00) of which shall be payable directly to the department of public safety for the cost of a criminal background check and fingerprinting. Auctioneer's license can be renewed for two (2) consecutive annual renewals upon payment of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 8; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 8; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-27. - Expiration and renewal. 
Every license issued pursuant to this article shall expire on the thirty-first day of December next after its issuance. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 9; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 9; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-28. - Transfer or delegation of authority. 
(a)  No license under the provisions of this article shall be transferred or assigned to any person or used by any person other than the licensee to whom it was issued. 
(b)  No person having a license granted under this article shall delegate his power to any clerk, partner or person; the privilege given shall be personal to the person named in the license and shall be exercised by him alone. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 10; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 10)  
Sec. 4-3-29. - Replacement of lost or destroyed license. 
If a license issued pursuant to this article is lost, stolen, or destroyed without fault on the part of the holder, a duplicate in lieu thereof under the original application may be issued by the city clerk upon the filing of an affidavit satisfactorily explaining the facts of such loss or theft and upon the payment of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 11; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 11; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-30. - Destruction, alteration, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, deface or injure a license issued pursuant to this article, or to change the name, numbers or dates thereon. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 11; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 11)  
Sec. 4-3-31. - Display. 
No auctioneer shall refuse to exhibit his license to any police officer upon demand at the place where the auction is being conducted. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 13(6); Ord. of 12-1-80, § 13(6))  
Sec. 4-3-32. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  The city clerk may at any time for such cause as the city clerk, upon investigation, deems sufficient, suspend or revoke any license granted under the provisions of this article. Violations of any of the prohibitions set forth in sections 4-3-2 through 4-3-4, 4-3-7 and 4-3-8 of this Code shall be deemed sufficient cause. 
(b)  Whenever any license shall be so revoked no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made and no license shall be granted to any person whose license has been revoked, in the discretion of the city clerk, within a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation. 
(c)  Notice of the suspension or revocation and the reason or reasons therefor, in writing, shall be served by the city clerk upon the person named in the license application by mailing the same to the business address given in such application and upon filing a copy of such with the commissioner of public safety. Within forty-eight (48) hours after service of the notice of suspension or revocation the licensee may apply to the commissioner of public safety to hear and review the act of the city clerk and the commissioner of public safety shall affirm or disaffirm said suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 12; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 12)  
Secs. 4-3-33—4-3-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 4-3-41. - Required. 
No person shall sell, at public auction, any goods, wares or chattels without a permit issued by the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 15; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 15)  
Sec. 4-3-42. - Application. 
A person required by this article to obtain a permit shall make application to the city clerk. Such application shall be in writing and shall be verified and filed not more than fifteen (15) nor less than five (5) days before the commencement of such sale. It shall set forth: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The name and address of the auctioneer; 
(3)  The street and number of the premises in which it is proposed to conduct such sale; and 
(4)  The place of business of the applicant for the two (2) years next preceding the date fixed for the sale. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, §§ 15, 16; Ord. of 12-1-80, §§ 15, 16)  
Sec. 4-3-43. - Inventory. 
(a)  There shall be attached to the application for the permit required by this article an inventory, in triplicate, showing in detail: 
(1)  The quality, quantity, kind or grade of goods, wares and chattels proposed to be sold; 
(2)  The established current retail prices, if any, of the goods, wares and chattels; 
(3)  The ownership of the items or articles. 
The inventory shall be verified by the applicant if he be an individual, by one of the partners, if a partnership, or by a duly authorized officer, if a corporation. No goods, wares or chattels shall be added to the verified inventory after same has been filed nor shall any goods, wares or chattels be sold which are not included in such verified inventory. 
(b)  The city clerk, or his duly authorized agent, before issuing a permit shall examine and investigate the goods, wares and chattels specified in the inventory to be offered for sale in order to determine whether the inventory correctly sets forth the items to be sold and their estimated value. The city clerk may require such additional information as may be necessary to ascertain the correctness of the items set forth in the inventory. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, §§ 17, 18; Ord. of 12-1-80, §§ 17, 18)  
Sec. 4-3-44. - Fee. 
Upon the application for a permit to conduct a sale at public auction, or renewal thereof, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee in the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a one-day permit, and a fee in the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a permit in excess of one (1) day but not to exceed ten (10) days in duration. If an application is disapproved said payment shall not be returned but shall be retained by the city to cover the cost of investigating the statements contained in the application. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 19; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 19; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-3-45. - Denial. 
The city clerk shall refuse to issue a permit for a sale at public auction in the event any material misrepresentations have been made in the application or inventory provided for in this article. Notice of the refusal and the reason or reasons therefor, in writing, shall be served by the city clerk upon the person named in the application by mailing the same to the business address given in the application and upon filing a copy of such with the commissioner of public safety. Within forty-eight (48) hours after service of the notice of refusal the person who was denied a permit may apply to the commissioner of public safety to hear and review the act of the city clerk and the commissioner of public safety shall affirm or disaffirm the refusal to issue a permit. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 18; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 18)  
Sec. 4-3-46. - Sales on Sunday and legal holidays. 
No permit shall be issued to conduct a sale at public auction on Sundays or legal holidays, except that an auction conducted for the limited purpose of "going out of business" may be conducted after 1:00 p.m. and continuing until 10:30 p.m. in a non-residential district in connection with an existing retail use, provided that no auction permit for any sale at such location shall be issued for a period of longer than thirty-five (35) days in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 20; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 20; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 3)  
Sec. 4-3-47. - Hours of sale. 
No permit shall be issued to conduct a sale at public auction between 5:30 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., except that an auction conducted for the limited purpose of "going out of business" may be conducted after 9:00 a.m. and continuing until 10:30 p.m. in a non-residential district in connection with an existing retail use, provided that no auction permit for any sale at such location shall be issued for a period of longer than thirty-five (35) days in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. of 4-19-51, § 21; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 21; Ord. of 7-5-94, § 4)  
Chapter 4-4 - CABARETS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General police power of city, § 4. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1, amended ch. 4-4, art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. I, §§ 4-4-1—4-4-12, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. of 9-5-23, §§ 3, 12—17, 19—21; Ord. of 5-7-28, § 1; Ord. of 12-7-36, § 2; Ord. of 11-21-66, §§ 2, 3; Ord. of 12-19-66, § 1; Ord. of 2-2-15 § 1; Ord. of 3-2-15(1), § 1. 
 
Sec. 4-4-1. - Purpose and construction. 
This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the state and of the city for the protection of the economic and social welfare, health, peace and morals of the people of the city and all its provisions shall be liberally construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-2 - Definitions. 
Cabaret: Any room, space or area used in connection with a business enterprise, in which musical entertainment, singing, dancing or other form of amusement by performers and/or by patrons ("Entertainment") is allowed. A "cabaret" is only permitted in connection with a "restaurant." However, the following shall not constitute a cabaret: 
A restaurant or bar located in a hotel having more than 50 sleeping rooms; or 
A restaurant or café that provides incidental Entertainment, without dancing, either by: 
• electrical devices such as, but not limited to stereos, radios or media players, but not including music provided by a disc jockey; or 
• not more than four (4) persons playing non-amplified music; or 
• a person with or without a portable low-wattage amplifier associated with a single instrument or microphone. 
Accessory Cabaret: A "cabaret" in which the Entertainment and/or dancing do not, in the aggregate, occupy more than 40% of the Net Floor Area of the principal business of a "restaurant." 
Primary Cabaret: A "cabaret" in which the Entertainment and/or dancing, in the aggregate, occupy more than 40% of the Net Floor Area of the principal business of a "restaurant." 
Net Floor Area: The floor area of a premises open to the public excluding bathroom facilities. 
Restaurant: a "restaurant" is a business enterprise primarily engaged in preparing, cooking, and serving food and beverages on premises; selected from a full menu by patrons seated at a table or counter; served by a waiter or waitress; and consumed on the premises. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-3. - Operation and hours. 
(a)  Operation. It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret to delegate the responsibility of the operation of the cabaret, including security thereat, to any person or entity that is not an employee of said cabaret operator. An owner or employee of the cabaret licensee must be present at the cabaret during all hours of operation and must be in charge of the operation of said cabaret. 
(b)  Hours. It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret to operate a cabaret on any day between the hours of 3:01 a.m. and 11:59 a.m., however the facility may continue to operate as a restaurant after those hours. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-4. - Intoxicating liquors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into or have in his or her possession or partake of any intoxicating liquors in any cabaret. This section shall not apply to cabarets where intoxicating liquors may be lawfully sold under the provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-5. - Nudity. 
No person shall be permitted to appear in any cabaret with the chest, breasts or buttocks fully exposed or any portion of the genitals exposed. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-6. - Sound amplification. 
It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret to operate a cabaret in violation of the following: 
(a)  Sound Level. The sound level of either live or recorded music or other attendant noise as measured from the exterior of the cabaret premises shall not exceed 85 decibels (dB) at any time as measured at a reasonable distance not less than seven (7) nor more than fifteen (15) feet from the premises of the cabaret establishment. A noise level evaluation of the operation of the cabaret use, paid for by the Applicant or owner, shall be conducted by the Department of Building every three (3) months of operation of the cabaret use, with the results to be submitted to the Common Council within two (2) weeks of said evaluation and made available to the public. 
(b)  Sound Amplification Equipment. No Sound Amplification Equipment (speakers, amplifiers, audio systems, radios, televisions, or any other device that can produce or reproduce sound) shall be installed or operated indoors with the intent to amplify the sound outdoors and/or within any temporary structures(s). 
(c)  Sound Amplification Shut-Off. Whenever the building or space fire alarm system is activated all Sound Amplification Equipment within the cabaret shall be shut off. Sound Amplification Equipment shall mean speakers, amplifiers, audio systems, radios, televisions, or any device that can produce or reproduce sound. 
(d)  Reduction of Sound Transmission. In an effort to reduce sound transmission, all doors related to the cabaret use, including those from the street, shall be equipped with automatic self-closers, remain closed during operation of the cabaret use and shall not be permitted to be propped open at any time. Doors may be used for ingress and egress only and must be sealed tightly when closed. In addition, unless technically infeasible, all new cabarets shall incorporate an interior vestibule at the entrance to the room, space or area where the cabaret is proposed. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-7. - Food service. 
It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret to operate a cabaret without food service available from a printed menu. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-8. - Employee roster. 
It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret to fail to maintain a roster, which contains the name, address and telephone number of all employees, excluding kitchen and wait-staff, working at any given time when such cabaret is open. Such roster shall be maintained on the premises of the cabaret for six (6) months and available for inspection by the Department of Public Safety promptly upon request. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-9. - Entry fee. 
It shall be unlawful for an owner, operator, proprietor, manager or person in charge of an accessory cabaret to charge an entry fee payable at or prior to admission. However this shall not prohibit: 
(1)  imposing a fee or fixed charge for entertainment or service that is added to a bill for patrons with reserved table seating; or 
(2)  the selling of tickets in advance or the charging of a fee inside the premises for live musical entertainment, excluding a disc jockey, provided the Department of Public Safety approves a Live Musical Entertainment Permit, the Application for which shall be submitted at least ten (10) days in advance of the scheduled performance. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-10. - Entry powers of police officers and housing/building inspectors. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret or restaurant to refuse admission or entry to the public areas of the cabaret or restaurant during operating hours to any officer charged with enforcing the penal laws of New York State, the New York State Building Code, the White Plains Supplemental Building Code or the City of White Plains Municipal Code. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-11. - Temporary closure. 
If in the opinion of the Commissioner of Public Safety, or the Commissioner's designee, an owner, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret, creates, maintains or permits a condition that endangers or threatens to endanger the safety or health of the public, the Commissioner, or designee, may order the immediate temporary closure of the cabaret. It shall be unlawful for an owner, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any cabaret, to fail to comply with such order. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-12. - Penalty. 
A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand five dollars ($2,500.00) for each offense or by imprisonment for each offense for a period of not exceeding fifteen (15) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 7-6-15, § 1)  
Secs. 4-4-13—4-4-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-4-26. - Required. 
No person shall conduct, manage or operate a cabaret without a license issued by the commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 4)  
Sec. 4-4-27. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to procure a cabaret license shall make application therefor to the commissioner of public safety upon a form as shall be designated and furnished by the commissioner of public safety. 
(b)  Said application shall be signed and duly verified by the applicant before an officer authorized to administer oaths. No such application shall be granted to conduct such cabaret on premises which do not conform to the requirements of this chapter and all laws and regulations of the state and all ordinances and regulations of the city. In addition to the foregoing, the applicant shall supply any and all reasonably relevant information, including, but not limited to financial information and records of the applicants, their officers, directors, and shareholders holding more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, of if a partnership, all partners, concerning its application to operate a cabaret when requested to do so by the commissioner of public safety. 
(c)  All applicants, their officers, directors, and shareholders holding more than ten (10) percent of outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, all partners, shall submit to fingerprinting by the police department of the department of public safety. Fingerprint cards shall be forwarded by the police department to the New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services (DCJS), along with the appropriate processing fees paid by the applicant as established by DCJS for identification processing. The commissioner or designee shall be responsible for the submission and review of the criminal history record information disseminated by DCJS. The commissioner of public safety may use such information provided by DCJS in making a determination concerning the fitness of the applicants under Section 4-4-28 (infra) for licensing but shall also take into account any certificates granted to an applicant under Article 23 of the Correction Law. The information obtained from DCJS shall be kept confidential to the extent permitted. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 5; Ord. of 2-6-06, § 1)  
Sec. 4-4-28. - Issuance and renewal of license. 
(a)  The commissioner of public safety may refuse to issue or renew a license to an applicant upon the occurrence of any one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors and shareholders holding more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners, have not submitted complete and accurate information required by the commissioner of public safety in connection with: 
a.  An application for a license or renewal thereof; 
b.  An application for the approval of a change of ownership; and 
c.  The furnishing of fingerprints as required by subsection 4-4-27(c) hereof. 
(2)  The premises on or in which the licensed business is to be conducted have not been certified as in compliance with the health, fire, building, zoning, water, gas and electricity safety requirements and standards established by the laws of the City of White Plains, the County of Westchester, and the State of New York or any other governmental authority having jurisdiction thereof. 
(3)  With respect to a new license application for the premises on or in which the licensed business is to be conducted, there is no current certificate of occupancy for the premises and/or a special permit to operate a cabaret. 
(4)  The applicant licensee, its officers, principals, directors, shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, partners, agents or employees or in a closely held corporation, shareholders have not complied with the regulations of the commissioner of public safety or have violated any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors and shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners, have been convicted of: 
a.  Any offense which is a felony under the laws of this state or a crime committed in violation of the laws of any other jurisdiction which if committed in this state would be a felony. 
b.  Any offense which is a misdemeanor related to and/or involving the premises on or in which the licensed business is to be conducted. 
(6)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors and shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners, have suffered or permitted the premises on or in which the licensed business is to be conducted, through improper or inadequate maintenance and supervision, to be used for the commission of any of the offenses set forth in subsection (5) of this subdivision. 
(7)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors, and shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners, have not paid, within the time permitted by law, any fine, penalty or judgment duly imposed in connection with or arising from the use, occupation, or operation of the premises on which the licensed business is to be conducted. 
(8)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors, and shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners have suffered or permitted individuals of less than eighteen (18) years of age to commercially promote use of the premises as a cabaret. 
(9)  Any of the applicants, their officers, directors and shareholders owning more than ten (10) percent of the outstanding voting stock, or if a partnership, any of the partners, have been enjoined against operation of the cabaret and/or civil penalties have been assessed in connection with or related to such injunction. 
(b)  Each applicant and licensee shall notify the department of public safety in writing by registered mail, return receipt requested, within three (3) business days of receipt of notice of service of a summons for a violation relating to the operation of the business licensed or to be licensed or to the premises on or in which the business licensed or to be licensed is to be conducted and of a conviction for any offense set forth in subdivision (a)(5) hereof occurring after the filing date of the application for a license or a renewal thereof or occurring during the term of the license. 
(c)  In the manner prescribed in Rule 318 of the Civil Practice Law and Rules, each applicant or licensee shall designate an agent, a substitute agent and a successor agent located within the City of White Plains for receiving service of process and communications from the commissioner of public safety. Proof of such designation shall be filed with the license application at the department of public safety. 
(d)  Upon request of the commissioner of public safety, each applicant and licensee shall produce its security plan, including, but not limited to the adequacy and number of security personnel employed and/or retained on the licensed premises to the commissioner of public safety at the time of the application for a license hereunder and at any other time on request of the commissioner of public safety. Each applicant and licensee shall maintain on the licensed premises a list and pedigree of all security personnel who are currently and who have worked for the preceding twelve-month period on the licensed premises and shall produce such list and photographs to the commissioner of public safety at his or her request. All security personnel employed and/or retained on the licensed premises shall be registered with the Department of State pursuant to Article 7-A, Security Guard Act, of the General Business Law. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, §§ 4a, 6; Ord. of 11-21-66, § 1; Ord. of 2-6-06, § 2)  
Sec. 4-4-29. - Issuance or denial and hearing on denial. 
(a)  The commissioner of public safety, upon presentation of an application for a cabaret license and before acting upon it, shall refer it to the chief of police for a full investigation as to the truth of the statements contained therein, and as to any or all other matters which might tend to aid the commissioner of public safety in determining whether or not the application should be granted. 
(b)  Within a reasonable time after such an application has been referred to him, the chief of police shall furnish a written report to the commissioner of public safety containing the result of his investigation. If the commissioner of public safety is satisfied that the statements contained in the application are true, that the premises described in the application comply with the requirements of this article and that the issuance of the license is not prohibited by section 4-4-28 of this Code he shall issue such license. 
(c)  If the commissioner of public safety is not satisfied that the provisions of section 4-4-28 do not prohibit the issuance of the license, he shall hold a hearing on the application after a minimum of three (3) days' notice to the applicant. At the hearing the applicant shall be given an opportunity to prove by competent evidence that the license should be granted. After the hearing the commissioner of public safety shall grant the license if he is satisfied by a preponderance of the evidence that its issuance is not prohibited by section 4-4-28; if the commissioner finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the issuance of the license is prohibited by section 4-4-28, he shall deny the license. The action of the commissioner of public safety shall be final. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 6; Ord. of 2-6-06, § 3)  
Sec. 4-4-30. - Fee, expiration and transfer. 
The annual fee for a cabaret license shall be two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00); provided that in the event a license be granted after July first of any year the license fee shall be one-half (½) the amount of the annual license fee. The commissioner of public safety shall not issue a cabaret license until the applicant has paid such fee to the city. All such licenses shall expire on December 31 next following their issue. Such license shall not be transferable and shall not authorize the person to whom it is granted to conduct a cabaret at any location other than that specified therein. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 7; Ord. of 12-7-36, § 1; Ord. of 2-2-15 § 2; Ord. of 3-2-15(2), § 2; Ord. of 7-6-15, § 2; Ord. of 5-17-16 , § 9)  
Sec. 4-4-31. - Suspension and revocation of license. 
(a)  The commissioner of public safety may suspend or revoke a license for conduct of the licensee, its officers, principals, directors, partners, agents or employees or in a closely held corporation, shareholders that would constitute grounds for denying the issuance or renewal of a license pursuant to section 4-4-28. 
(b)  At least three (3) days before suspending or revoking any license, the commissioner of public safety shall cause to be mailed to the holder of the license at the address provided or the designated agent pursuant to subsection 4-4-28(c) hereof, a notice, stating a time and place of a hearing concerning the suspension or revocation at which the licensee shall be entitled to be heard and introduce the testimony of witnesses. The action of the commissioner of public safety relative to such suspension or revocation shall be final. 
(c)  Upon application to the commissioner of public safety and prior to the reinstatement or reissuance of a suspended or revoked license, the licensee, with the commissioner of public safety's approval, shall, upon payment of the fee as specified in section 4-4-30, be permitted to operate for six (6) months on a probationary license. At the end of such six-month period, the license shall be reinstated or reissued unless the commissioner of public safety finds that the licensee, its officers, principals, directors, agents or employees or, in a closely held corporation, stockholders, have engaged in conduct that would constitute grounds for denying the issuance or renewal of a license pursuant to section 4-4-28. Upon a finding of such conduct, the probationary license shall be revoked and shall not be reissued for a period of one year. 
(Ord. of 9-5-23, § 8; Ord. of 2-6-06, § 4)  
Sec. 4-4-32. - Summary suspension. 
(a)  A license may be summarily suspended if the commissioner of public safety determines there is an imminent threat to the health, safety or welfare of the public at the licensed premises or on any parking site or similar facility used by customers of the licensed business or used as part of the licensed business operation. The commissioner of public safety may consider an imminent threat to the health, safety or welfare of the public which exists within one hundred (100) feet of the licensed business premises or within one hundred (100) feet of any parking site or similar facility used by the customers of the licensed business or used as part of the licensed business operation. 
(b)  The commissioner of public safety's determination that there is an imminent threat to the public health, safety or welfare shall be based on one or more of the following: 
(1)  There is an urgent need to take immediate action to protect the public from an imminent threat of injury or harm; 
(2)  There has been a violation of a license condition or other requirement of this Code that creates an imminent danger to the public health, safety or welfare; or 
(3)  There has been a violation of municipal, state or federal law, in connection with the operation of the licensed business, that created an imminent danger to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(c)  The summary suspension shall remain in effect for no more than thirty (30) days. 
(d)  Written notice of summary suspension shall be delivered to the licensee at the address provided or to the designated agent pursuant to subsection 4-4-28(c) hereof. Notice given to the licensee shall include the following information: 
(1)  The length of time the summary suspension shall remain in effect; 
(2)  The grounds and reasons upon which the summary suspension is based; and 
(3)  That the licensee aggrieved by the summary suspension may immediately request relief from the summary suspension by requesting that the commissioner of public safety schedule a hearing and the method for requesting such a hearing. 
(e)  If the licensee wishes to be relieved from the summary suspension, the licensee must request a hearing by following the procedures set forth in the notice of summary suspension. 
(f)  The commissioner of public safety or designee must respond to the licensee's request for a hearing by scheduling a hearing to affirm, modify or overrule the summary suspension within five (5) business days of the licensee's request, unless the licensee requests an extension of the time for the hearing. Said hearing shall be before a hearing officer designated by the commissioner of public safety. 
(g)  At the hearing before the hearing officer, the licensee shall be given the opportunity to present evidence that either rebuts the ground(s) for which the summary suspension was issued or demonstrates that the reason or reasons leading to the summary suspension have been mitigated or corrected. 
(h)  The hearing will be conducted informally and technical rules of evidence shall not apply. Any and all other evidence which the hearing officer deems reliable, relevant and not unduly repetitious may be considered. 
(i)  Following the conclusion of the hearing, and after a review of the recommendations of the hearing officer, the commissioner of public safety shall issue a decision which affirms, modifies or overrules the summary suspension, as specified in subsection (j). In connection with the modification of the summary suspension, the hearing officer designated by the commissioner of public safety may recommend the imposition of additional conditions upon the license if those conditions were reviewed at the hearing and the conditions are aimed at protecting the health, safety and welfare of the public or preventing the conduct or condition that lead to the summary suspension. 
(j)  The decision of the commissioner of public safety shall be communicated to the licensee within three (3) business days after completing the review of the hearing officer's recommendation by sending the decision to the licensee at the address provided or to the designated agent pursuant to subsection 4-4-28(c) and to the address at which the cabaret business is conducted, unless such premises have been closed. 
(Ord. of 2-6-06, § 5)  
Sec. 4-4-33. - Rules and regulations. 
The commissioner of public safety is authorized to adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as he or she may deem necessary for the proper control, operation, and supervision of cabarets. Each licensee shall receive a copy of such rules and regulations on issuance of a license. 
(Ord. of 2-6-06, § 6)  
Chapter 4-5 - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Solicitors on private property, § 4-1-5; hawkers, peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 4-9. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-5-1. - Labeling of collection boxes and containers. 
Persons holding licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall label all collection boxes or containers used in the public solicitation of funds either by appeal in person or by the placing of receptacles for the receipt of such public contributions in stores, factories, shops, offices, theatres, hotels, restaurants, railway stations or other public places, with the name of the organization for which the license has been issued and in such conspicuous manner as the commissioner of public safety may direct. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 4)  
Sec. 4-5-2. - Regulations authorized. 
The commissioner of public safety may establish such regulations as he deems necessary in carrying out the purposes and objects of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 3)  
Sec. 4-5-3. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates this chapter or who neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding one hundred fifty (150) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 5) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-5-4—4-5-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-5-16. - Required. 
No person shall solicit money, donations or financial assistance of any kind upon the streets or in public places in the city without a license issued by the commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 1)  
Sec. 4-5-17. - Application. 
Applications for the license required by the provisions of this article to publicly solicit funds for any cause whatever shall be addressed to the commissioner of public safety and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and purpose of the cause for which permission is sought. 
(2)  Names and addresses of the officers and directors of the organization. 
(3)  Time for which permission is sought and localities and places for solicitation. 
(4)  Whether or not any commissions, fees, wages or emoluments are to be expended in connection with such solicitation. 
(5)  Such other information as the commissioner of public safety shall require. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 2)  
Sec. 4-5-18. - Statement as to monies collected. 
It shall be the duty of the commissioner of public safety before granting any license to solicit in public to compel the applicant to file with him a sworn statement of all moneys collected in the calendar year or the fiscal year of such organization, society, association or corporation previous to the application, the expenditures connected therewith, together with the names and addresses of all persons receiving wages, commissions or emoluments and the amounts so expended. 
(Ord. of 4-26-26, § 3)  
Chapter 4-6 - COIN-OPERATED DRY CLEANING MACHINES AND ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Fire prevention code provisions dealing with coin-operated dry cleaning machines, § 9-6-8.01 et seq. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate business, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-6-1. - Legislative determination. 
As a legislative determination, it is deemed necessary to the safety, health and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city that certain coin-operated dry cleaning machines and establishments be regulated and restricted in order to prevent injury and damage to persons and property in the city, and to eliminate conditions dangerous to the safety, health and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 1)  
Sec. 4-6-2. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated, when used in this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meaning herein respectively ascribed to them: 
(1)  Commissioner: The commissioner of public safety or his duly authorized representative. 
(2)  Premises: Any place, whether self-service or otherwise, maintained for use of and by the general public for the purpose of dry cleaning of clothing, apparel or other fabrics or household articles by or in automatic or coin-operated machines, excepting, however, such places in private homes. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 2)  
Sec. 4-6-3. - Scope. 
This chapter shall be applicable to all coin-operated dry-cleaning premises, whenever established. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 14)  
Sec. 4-6-4. - Prohibited in multiple residences. 
Automatic or coin-operated dry-cleaning devices shall not be installed or used in any multiple residence. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 3)  
Sec. 4-6-5. - Attendant; supervision. 
All coin-operated dry cleaning establishments shall have an attendant on the licensed premises at all times when the premises are open for business or public use, said attendant shall not be less than twenty-one (21) years of age. No coin-operated dry cleaning machine shall be used by the general public unless under the continuous, direct supervision of an employee or owner of the coin-operated dry cleaning establishment who has previously been examined and certified in writing by the fire chief as competent to handle such machines. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 8)  
Sec. 4-6-6. - Departmental approvals. 
All coin-operated dry cleaning machines and locations must be approved by the city departments having jurisdiction, prior to the installation of machinery. A floor plan showing the business premises and the location, type and manner of installation of all equipment shall be submitted with each license application. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 9)  
Sec. 4-6-7. - Operating restrictions. 
(a)  No coin-operated dry cleaning licensee shall permit or allow such machines to be used by any person who is less than sixteen (16) years of age. A suitable sign indicating such age restriction must be prominently posted and maintained on the premises. 
(b)  All coin-operated dry cleaning machines shall be fitted with a device which will prevent the opening of the door of any such machine while such machine is in operation and until all solvent vapors have been removed from any textile, fabric, garment or other article, and from the drum in which the same shall be placed. 
(c)  In the event that Perchlorethylene or any chlorinated hydro-carbon is a component part of any solvent used in a coin-operated dry cleaning machine, then such machine shall not be used: 
(1)  if the odor of Perchlorethylene or any chlorinated hydro-carbon is masked or altered in any fashion; or 
(2)  if the concentrations of solvent vapor of such Perchlorethylene or chlorinated hydro-carbon is greater than forty (40) parts of such vapor to one million (1,000,000) parts of air at any time and anywhere in such machines or appurtenant equipment. 
(d)  In any coin-operated dry cleaning establishment, solvent storage tanks, power boxes and other sources of danger shall be so situated as to be inaccessible to the general public and patrons of such establishment. 
(e)  Spotting operations utilizing flammable liquids shall not be permitted in this type of occupancy. 
(f)  Only the front or customer side of dry cleaning machines shall be exposed in the customer area. The working or maintenance portion of the equipment shall be separated from the front of such machines by a solid partition. Access doors to the enclosure back of the machines shall be kept closed and locked. The enclosure for the dry cleaning machines shall not be a part of or interconnected with those areas that contain heating devices requiring air for combustion, such as dryers, water heaters and boilers. 
(g)  An exhaust system shall be provided for the removal of toxic vapors. This exhaust system consists of the individual exhaust on each dry cleaning machine, scavenger ducts strategically located, exhaust fans for the enclosure behind such machines, and the front grill of loading door air intakes on each machine.
