(h)  The central exhaust ventilating system for dry cleaning machines as described above shall be operated continuously while the premises are open to the public. The vapor removal system shall be interlocked with the dry cleaning machines so that the latter cannot be operated without actuating the exhaust system. The manifold exhaust system shall exhaust to the outside, not terminate within twenty-five (25) feet of any building opening, not expose the passing public, and be located as remotely as possible from appliance air intakes. In addition to the individual exhaust for the vapor from each such machine a scavenger duct shall be provided for each two machines to pick up vapors surrounding the equipment near the floor. The suction of these scavenger pipes should be located two (2) to four (4) inches above the floor. A general ventilation fan shall also be installed within the rear enclosure of such machine to be used in case of serious solvent spill. Each such machine shall be designed so that when the machine is not in operation air is drawn through the front door or grill of the machine at a face velocity of at least one hundred (100) feet per minute. 
(i)  Provisions shall be made for makeup air to compensate for that which is exhausted to the outside. 
(j)  Such dry cleaning machines shall be provided with some satisfactory means to limit vapor accumulation and to salvage the solvent resulting from a spill due to an accident or failure of equipment, such as by diking the entire system with a four (4) inch curb on the floor which will contain the solvent and drain it to an underground tank where it can be recovered. When an underground tank is not feasible, the curbed area can be provided with a sump pump that will pump the solvent to an above ground tank. 
(k)  All coin-operated dry cleaning establishments shall have two (2) exits which shall be at least twenty-five (25) feet apart from each other and shall lead directly to the outside. 
(l)  Filter residue and other residues containing solvent shall be disposed of so as not to create a health hazard or nuisance. A locked covered metal container shall be used for temporary storage outside the building. 
(m)  All direct equipment exhausts or vents shall be provided with mesh lint arrestors which shall be kept clean unless lint traps are provided on the dry cleaning unit. 
(n)  Each self-service dry cleaning establishment shall be provided with a portable fire extinguisher of the carbon dioxide or dry chemical type. 
(o)  Each day, dry cleaning machines shall be serviced, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Adding "charged" solvent to restore the main supply. 
(2)  Cleaning the button trap and the lint bag, trap or screen. 
(3)  Cleaning the tank sump and removing the sludge. 
(4)  Adding filter aids to dispersers. 
(5)  Resetting the cycle counter, if one is provided. 
(6)  Emptying the water from the separator. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 10)  
Sec. 4-6-8. - Instruction to public. 
(a)  All coin-operated dry cleaning establishments shall prominently display lighted indoor signs warning the general public of the danger of excessive solvent vapor inhalation and skin irritation from unevaporated dry cleaning solvent. 
(b)  A step-by-step instruction list shall be posted in a conspicuous location near each dry cleaning machine for customer use. There shall be posted and conspicuously displayed and maintained at all times on the premises a legible sign, on a form to be provided by the commissioner, stating the name, address and telephone number of the owner or managing agent, and which telephone number shall be listed at police headquarters for emergency assistance. 
(c)  All machines shall be checked daily and kept in good repair by the licensee. All maintenance personnel shall be familiar with all necessary machinery repairs and instructed as to the solvent hazards. 
(d)  Only the solvent specified by the equipment manufacturer shall be used. 
(e)  Coin-operated dry cleaning plants shall utilize only solvents classified as nonflammable or as nonflammable at ordinary temperatures and uses. 
(f)  There shall be posted and conspicuously displayed and maintained at all times on the premises, the license issued by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 11)  
Sec. 4-6-9. - Hours of operation. 
No coin-operated dry cleaning establishment shall be open for business between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 12)  
Sec. 4-6-10. - Penalty. 
Any person maintaining or conducting or carrying on or operating a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment, who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation, or to imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. Each day or fraction of a day on which each such violation shall continue shall be construed as a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 13) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-6-11—4-6-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-6-21. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment in any premises in the city without a license therefor. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 3)  
Sec. 4-6-22. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  The application for a license or for any renewal thereof to conduct a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment shall be in writing upon a form to be furnished by the commissioner and shall state the specific location of such establishment and the number and type of all machines to be maintained therein. Before issuing any such license, the commissioner shall cause all necessary investigations to be made of the premises described in such application for the purpose of determining whether the provisions of all applicable state, county, health and local laws, ordinances and regulations are fully complied with. 
(b)  If the commissioner shall be satisfied that such premises conform to the provisions of this chapter and other laws relating thereto, he shall issue or cause to be issued a license authorizing such applicant to establish, maintain, conduct or operate a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment at the place, and with the number of machines, as specified and designated in such application, for and during the period of such license. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 4)  
Sec. 4-6-23. - Fee; bond. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment license, each applicant therefor shall pay an annual license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each machine installed therein for the license period May 1 to April 30, and furnish a continuing bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Such bond shall be executed by a duly authorized surety company, and be approved as to form by the corporation counsel, shall be payable to the city and shall be conditioned upon the licensee's compliance with the provisions of this chapter and upon the further condition that the licensee will pay to said city any fine, penalty, or other obligation within thirty (30) days of its final imposition. 
(b)  For licenses issued between November 1 and April 30 only one-half of the annual license fee shall be payable. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 5)  
Sec. 4-6-24. - Term and transfer. 
Each license issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on the last day of April following the date of its issuance unless sooner suspended or revoked by the commissioner. Such license shall not be transferable from person to person or from the location for which it is originally issued. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 6)  
Sec. 4-6-25. - Revocation. 
The commissioner may, at any time, for violation of this chapter or of any applicable law, regulation or ordinance, or such other cause as the commissioner, upon investigation and after a hearing, deems sufficient, suspend or revoke any license granted under the provisions of this chapter. Notice in writing of the proposed suspension or revocation and the reason or reasons therefor, and of the time and place of a hearing to be held thereon by the commissioner shall be served upon the licensee either personally or by certified or registered mail to the business address given in the application at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. Whenever any license shall be so revoked, no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. No license shall be granted to any person whose license has been revoked within a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation, except in the discretion of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 7)  
Chapter 4-7 - COIN-OPERATED LAUNDRIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Building code, Ch. 9-5; provisions of fire prevention code dealing with coin-operated laundries, § 9-6-8.09; plumbing code, Ch. 9-7. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-7-1. - Legislative determination. 
As a legislative determination, it is deemed necessary to the safety, health and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city that certain coin-operated laundry establishments within the city be regulated and restricted, as herein set forth, in order to prevent injury and damage to persons and property in the city, and to eliminate conditions dangerous to the safety, health and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 1)  
Sec. 4-7-2. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated, when used in this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meaning herein respectively ascribed to them: 
Commissioner: The commissioner of public safety or his duly authorized representative. 
Premises: Any place, whether self-service or otherwise, maintained for use of and by the general public for the purpose of washing and drying of clothing, apparel or other fabrics or household articles by or in automatic or coin-operated machines, excepting, however, such places in private homes and apartment houses used solely by residents thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 2)  
Sec. 4-7-3. - Approval of location of machine. 
All coin-operated washing and drying machines and locations must be approved by the city departments having jurisdiction, prior to the installation of machinery. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 8)  
Sec. 4-7-4. - Hours of operation. 
No coin-operated laundry establishment shall be open for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 9)  
Sec. 4-7-5. - Health and safety precautions. 
The following provisions shall apply to all coin-operated laundry establishments: 
(a)  Filter residue shall be disposed of so as not to create a health hazard or nuisance. A locked, covered metal container shall be used for temporary storage outside the building. 
(b)  All equipment exhausts or vents for drying machines shall be provided with mesh lint arrestors which shall be kept clean. Lint traps shall be provided on all drying units. 
(c)  Each self-service or coin-operated laundry establishment shall be provided with a portable fire extinguisher of the carbon dioxide or dry chemical type. 
(d)  All machines shall be checked daily and kept in good repair. 
(e)  Drying machines shall be serviced each day, including, but not limited to cleaning the lint bag, trap or screen. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 10)  
Sec. 4-7-6. - Posting of certain information. 
A step-by-step instruction list shall be posted in a conspicuous location near each washing and drying machine for customer use located in a coin-operated laundry establishment. There shall be posted and conspicuously displayed and maintained, at all times, on the premises a legible sign on a form, to be provided by the commissioner, stating the name, address and telephone number of the owner or managing agent, which telephone number shall be listed at police headquarters for emergency assistance. There shall be posted and conspicuously displayed and maintained, at all times, on the premises, the license issued by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 11)  
Sec. 4-7-7. - Penalty. 
Any person maintaining or conducting or carrying on or operating a coin-operated laundry establishment, who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation, or to imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. Each day or fraction of a day on which each such violation shall continue shall be construed as a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 12) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-7-8—4-7-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-7-16. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate a coin-operated laundry establishment in any premises in the city without a license issued by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 3)  
Sec. 4-7-17. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  The application for a license or for any renewal thereof to conduct a coin-operated laundry establishment shall be in writing upon a form to be furnished by the commissioner and shall state the specific location of such establishment and the number and type of all machines to be maintained therein. A floor plan showing the business premises and the location, type and manner of installation of all equipment shall be submitted with each license application. Before issuing any such license, the commissioner shall cause all necessary investigations to be made of the premises described in such application for the purpose of determining whether the provisions of all applicable state, county, health and local laws, ordinances and regulations are fully complied with. 
(b)  If the commissioner shall be satisfied that such premises conform to the provisions of this chapter and other laws relating thereto, he shall issue or cause to be issued a license authorizing such applicant to establish, maintain, conduct or operate a coin-operated laundry establishment at the place, and with the number of machines, as specified and designated in such application, for and during the period of such license. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, §§ 4, 8)  
Sec. 4-7-18. - Fee. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a coin-operated laundry establishment license, each applicant shall pay an annual license fee as indicated in the following schedule: 
Number of Machines 
  In Premises     License Fee 
 1—30 ..... $ 150.00  
31 and over ..... 250.00  
(b)  For licenses issued between the first day of November and the thirtieth day of April, inclusive, only one-half of the annual license fee shall be payable. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 5; Ord. of 5-17-16 , § 7)  
Sec. 4-7-19. - Bond. 
Prior to the issuance of a coin-operated laundry establishment license the applicant shall furnish a continuing bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Such bond shall be executed by a duly authorized surety company, and be approved as to form by the corporation counsel, shall be payable to the city and shall be conditioned upon the licensee's compliance with the provisions of this chapter and upon the further condition that the licensee will pay to said city any fine, penalty, or other obligation within thirty (30) days of its final imposition. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 5(a))  
Sec. 4-7-20. - Expiration and transfer. 
Each license for a coin-operated laundry establishment shall expire on the thirtieth day of April following the date of its issuance unless sooner suspended or revoked by the commissioner. Such a license shall not be transferable from person to person or from the location for which it is originally issued. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 6)  
Sec. 4-7-21. - Revocation. 
The commissioner may, at any time, for violation of this chapter or of any applicable law, regulation or ordinance, or such other cause as the commissioner, upon investigation and after a hearing, deems sufficient, suspend or revoke any license granted under the provisions of this chapter. Notice in writing of the proposed suspension or revocation and the reason or reasons therefor, and of the time and place of a hearing to be held thereon by the commissioner shall be served upon the licensee either personally or by certified or registered mail to the business address given in the application at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. Whenever any license shall be so revoked, no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. No license shall be granted to any person whose license has been revoked within a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation, except in the discretion of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 8-2-65, § 7)  
Chapter 4-8 - GASOLINE STATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Permit to store flammable liquids, § 9-6-15.103; dispensing gas, § 9-6-15.503; garage or repair shops, § 9-6-17.04. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
Sec. 4-8-1. - Posting of price. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at retail any gasoline or diesel fuel unless such seller shall post and keep continually posted on the individual pump or other dispensing device, a sign twelve (12) inches in height and twelve (12) inches in width, stating clearly and legibly thereon in letters sufficiently large to be read by a person having normal vision from the public street closest to the place of business, the total price of such gasoline or diesel fuel, including all taxes. 
(b)  Each pump or dispensing unit shall have a similar sign equally legible setting forth the trade name, brand and grade or classification of such gasoline or diesel fuel permanently affixed thereto. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon the first conviction therefor be subject to a fine which shall not exceed more than fifty dollars ($50.00) and on any subsequent conviction therefor shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in amount or imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days or to both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. of 11-4-74, §§ 1—3) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Chapter 4-9 - HAWKERS, PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Solicitors and others on private property, § 4-1-5; charitable solicitations, Ch. 4-5; transient retail businesses, Ch. 4-16. 
State Law reference— Peddlers generally, General Business Law, §§ 32—36; power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-9-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Established place of business: A building, store or vacant property in which or where the person transacts business and deals in goods, wares and merchandise he hawks, peddles or for which he solicits during regular business hours. 
(2)  Hawker or peddler: Any person, either principal or agent, who, from any boat or car on a railroad track or in any public street or public place or by going from house to house or place of business to place of business on foot or on or from animal or vehicle, sells or barters, offers for sale or barters or carries or exposes for sale or barter any goods, wares or merchandise, except milk or newspapers. 
(3)  Solicitor: Any person who goes from place to place or house to house or who stands in any street or public place requesting, either directly or indirectly, money, credit, funds, contributions, personal property or anything of value; taking or offering to take orders for goods, wares and merchandise, except milk or newspapers, or for services to be performed in the future, or for selling, making, manufacturing or repairing any articles or thing whatsoever for future delivery. 
(4)  Veteran: Every honorably-discharged soldier, sailor or marine of the military or naval service of the United States, and a veteran of either the Civil War, Spanish-American War or any other war or who shall have served in the armed forces of the United States overseas, who is a resident of the county and the widow of any such veteran, if she be a resident of the county. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 1; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 11-5-12, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-2. - Vehicles generally. 
Every vehicle used by a hawker, peddler or solicitor in or about his business shall have the name of the licensee and his address plainly, distinctly and legibly painted in letters and figures at least two (2) inches in length in a conspicuous place on the outside of each side of every such vehicle. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 8)  
Sec. 4-9-3. - Sanitation. 
A peddler, hawker or solicitor shall keep the vehicles and receptacles used by him in a clean and sanitary condition and the food stuffs and edibles offered for sale well covered and protected from dirt, dust and insects. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(c))  
Sec. 4-9-4. - Noise. 
A peddler, hawker or solicitor shall not blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other noisy device to attract public attention to his wares, or shout or cry out his wares. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(d))  
Sec. 4-9-5. - Fraud or sale of diseased merchandise. 
No hawker, peddler or solicitor shall falsely or fraudulently misrepresent the quantity, character or quality of any article offered for sale, or offer for sale any unwholesome, tainted or diseased provisions or merchandise. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(a))  
Sec. 4-9-6. - Receipts for orders. 
All orders taken by licensed solicitors, who demand, accept or receive payment or deposit money in advance of final delivery, shall be in writing, in duplicate, stating the terms thereof and the amount paid in advance, and one copy shall be given to the purchaser at the time the deposit of money is paid to the solicitor. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 11)  
Sec. 4-9-7. - Sales near schools. 
No peddler, hawker or solicitor shall sell any confectionery or ice cream within two hundred and fifty (250) feet of any school between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on school days. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10)  
Sec. 4-9-8. - Standing of vehicle. 
No peddler, hawker or solicitor shall stand or permit the vehicle used by him to stand in one place in any public place or street for more than ten (10) minutes, or in front of any premises for any time if the owner of or lessee of the ground floor thereof objects. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(e))  
Sec. 4-9-9. - Parking on crosswalk. 
No peddler, hawker or solicitor shall permit any vehicle used by him to stop or remain on any crosswalk. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(g)) 
State Law reference— Parking on crosswalk, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1202.  
Sec. 4-9-10. - Obstruction of streets and public places. 
A peddler, hawker or solicitor shall not create or maintain any booth or stand or place any barrels, boxes, crates or other obstructions upon any street or public place for the purpose of selling or exposing for sale any goods, wares or merchandise. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(h))  
Sec. 4-9-11. - Exemptions. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be held to apply to: 
(1)  Any sales conducted pursuant to statute or by order of any court, to any person selling personal property at wholesale or dealers in such articles; 
(2)  Persons having an established place of business within the city or their employees for soliciting orders from customers and delivering the same; or 
(3)  Farmers or truck gardeners who themselves or through their employees vend, sell or dispose of products of their own farms and gardens. 
This chapter shall also not apply so as unlawfully to interfere with interstate commerce. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 2) 
State Law reference— Exemption for veterans and their widows, General Business Law, § 32.  
Sec. 4-9-12. - Penalty. 
Any person, who himself or by his clerk, agent or employee, shall act as a hawker, peddler or solicitor as herein defined, without a license, or shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or who, having had his license revoked, shall continue to act as a hawker, peddler or solicitor, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) each day on which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 13; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-9-13—4-9-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-9-26. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a hawker, peddler or solicitor in the city without a license issued by the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 3; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-26a. - Do-not-knock registry. 
(1)  Any owner or occupant of property located in the City who wishes to prohibit hawkers, peddlers or solicitors on the premises shall complete a form available in the City Clerk's office. The completion of the form will allow the owner/occupant's premises to be included on a list of properties that do not permit solicitation (hereinafter referred to as the "do-not-knock registry" or "registry"). 
(2)  In order to be removed from the registry, the owner and/or occupant must complete a form indicating that he/she does not want the property to be included on the registry. 
(3)  Any owner or occupant who has requested enlistment on the do-not-knock registry shall be able to purchase from the City Clerk's office, for a nominal fee, a sticker for display indicating enlistment on the do-not-knock registry. 
(4)  All hawkers, peddlers and solicitors shall obtain the current do-not-knock registry at the time of issuance of a license or at the time of registration pursuant to the provisions of Article II of this Chapter. 
(5)  The City Clerk shall update the do-not-knock registry on January 1, April 1, July 1 and October 1 or each year, which updated registry shall constitute the current do-not-knock registry. Copies of the current do-not-knock registry shall be available at the office of the City Clerk. 
(Ord. of 11-5-12, § 2)  
Sec. 4-9-26b. - Unwanted hawking, peddling and solicitation prohibited. 
(1)  Hawkers, peddlers and solicitors shall not engage as such at any premises identified on the current do-not-knock registry. 
(2)  Activities related to a service requested by the owner or occupant of the property and undertaken in the ordinary course of business, including but not limited to deliveries of utility notices, telephone directory deliveries, regular newspaper deliveries, work order notices and service inquiries, are presumed to be requested or invited for the purpose of this section. 
(3)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the distribution of leaflets, pamphlets or other literature such as commercial, political or religious material distributed in a lawful manner. 
(Ord. of 11-5-12, § 2)  
Sec. 4-9-27. - Application and investigation. 
(a)  Any person desiring to procure a license required by this article shall file with the city clerk a written application upon a blank form prepared by the city clerk and furnished by the city, and shall file at the same time satisfactory proof of good character. Such application shall include the following: 
(1)  The license plate and registration numbers and kind of vehicle to be used by the applicant in carrying on the business for which the license is desired; 
(2)  The kind of goods, wares and merchandise he desires to sell or the kind of services he desires to perform, and the method of distribution; 
(3)  The name, address and age of applicant; the name and address of any person represented; 
(4)  If the applicant is a veteran or the widow of a veteran, the name and address as appears on the application for his county peddler's license, date of issuance of county license and the license number; 
(5)  The applicant's photograph, in triplicate, in such position as the city clerk may direct, taken within thirty (30) days preceding the filing of the application; and 
(6)  Such other information as may be required by the city clerk from said person, veteran or the widow of a veteran. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by a certificate from the sealer of weights and measures certifying that all weighing and measuring devices to be used by the applicant have been examined and approved. 
(c)  The city clerk shall thereupon request the commissioner of public safety to investigate the applicant. As part of the investigation the applicant shall submit to having the fingerprints taken at police headquarters. Such fingerprints shall be kept on file at police headquarters as a permanent record. The commissioner of public safety shall furnish to the city clerk in writing the information derived from his investigation accompanied by a recommendation as to whether the license should be granted or refused. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 4; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-28. - Persons ineligible to apply for license. 
No applicant to whom a license has been refused or who has had a license revoked shall make further application until at least six (6) months has elapsed since the last previous rejection or revocation unless he can show that the reason for such rejection no longer exists. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-29. - Issuance and denial of certificate of registration. 
Upon filing of the complete application by the applicant and providing all of the information requested, certificate and recommendation as provided in Section 4-9-27(c), the city clerk shall, upon approval of such application, within ten (10) business days issue to the applicant a license as provided in section 4-9-26, signed by the city clerk. Except as hereinafter provided, no license shall be refused except for a specific reason and for the protection of the public safety, health, morals or general welfare as stated below: 
a)  Applicant is under the age of eighteen (18); 
b)  The location and time of the activities described in the application would endanger the safety and welfare of the applicant and its customers; 
c)  Investigation reveals that applicant falsified information on the application; 
d)  Applicant has been criminally convicted of a felony, misdemeanor, or violation involving a sex offense, sale or distribution of controlled substances, or any violent acts against persons or property which would endanger the safety and welfare of specific individuals, the general public, and public or private property; 
e)  Applicant has been incarcerated in federal or state prison for crimes which would endanger the safety and welfare of specific individuals, the general public, and public or private property; 
f)  A civil judgment has been entered against applicant indicating that applicant engaged in fraud, deceit or misrepresentation within the last five (5) years. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-19, § 1 )  
Sec. 4-9-30. - Fee. 
The initial fee for a license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
a)  seventy-five dollars ($75.00) of which shall be payable directly to the department of public safety for the cost of a criminal background check and fingerprinting. 
b)  one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) of which shall cover the cost of processing the application by the city clerk and issuing the license. 
The license can be renewed for two consecutive annual renewals at a fee of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00), if there have been no legitimate complaints made against the applicant verified by the commissioner of public safety and applicant has not engaged in any activity in violation of this chapter or any other law which would warrant for a discontinuance and/or denial of the applicant's license. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 6; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1, Ord. of 6-6-83, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-19, § 1 )  
Sec. 4-9-31. - Expiration. 
Licenses shall be issued for a twelve-month period commencing the first day of the month in which such permit is issued and expiring on the last day twelve (12) months subsequent. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-32. - Assignment or allowing another to use license. 
A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall not be assignable and it shall be unlawful for its holder to allow another to use such license. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article which was not issued to him. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-33. - Display. 
A hawker, peddler or solicitor, while engaged as such, shall carry the license issued to him pursuant to this article with him and shall exhibit the same upon demand. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-34. - Number of vehicles license covers. 
A license issued pursuant to this article shall include the right to use only one vehicle in carrying on the business for which the person is licensed. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-35. - License generally. 
The city clerk shall issue an official license with photograph to each hawker, peddler and solicitor. Such license shall not be transferred or assigned. On the expiration of the license the licensee shall surrender such license to the city clerk. It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy or deface such license in any manner, or change the number or date thereon. It shall also be unlawful for any person to have in his possession such license unless he be the licensed hawker, peddler or solicitor in whose name the license is issued. The carrying of the license is hereby made a condition of every license and failure by the licensee to carry the license while in the exercise thereof, shall be cause for revocation of such license. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 7; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95)  
Sec. 4-9-36. - Replacement of lost or destroyed license. 
Whenever a license is lost or destroyed, a duplicate in lieu thereof under the original application may be issued by the city clerk upon the filing with the clerk by the licensee of an affidavit setting forth the circumstances of the loss and what, if any, search has been made for it and upon payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 5; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-37. - Displaying license badge after expiration or revocation. 
A hawker, peddler or solicitor shall not display the license provided by the city after the expiration or revocation thereof. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 10(b); Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Sec. 4-9-38. - Revocation. 
The commissioner of public safety may, at any time, suspend or revoke any license for any reason warranting a denial of a license or for a violation of this chapter. When a license shall be revoked no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. The commissioner of public safety shall notify the city clerk of the revocation of any license and the reason or reasons therefore and notice of such revocation and the reason or reasons therefore in writing shall be served by the city clerk upon the person named in the application, or by mailing the same to the address given in the application. A copy of such notice shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 9; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-19, § 1 )  
Sec. 4-9-39. - Records. 
The city clerk shall keep a record of all applications and of all licenses granted under the provisions of this article, giving the number and date of each license, the name and residence of the persons licensed, the amount of the license fee paid and also the date of revocation of all licenses revoked. 
(Ord. of 10-5-31, § 12; Ord. of 1-3-95, § 1)  
Chapter 4-10 - HOUSING AND RENT CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Fair housing, Ch. 4-19. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-10-1. - Scope of Emergency Housing Rent Control Law. 
The common council of The City of White Plains hereby elects that the provisions of paragraph (k) of subdivision 2 of section 2 of the Emergency Housing Rent Control Law shall not apply in the city. 
(Res. of 5-13-57) 
State Law reference— Emergency Housing Rent Control Law, Unconsol. L., §§ 8581—8597 (McKinney); paragraph (k) of subdivision 2 of section 2 is § 8582, 2(k); power of city to pass resolution to this effect, Unconsol. L., § 8592, 4 (McKinney).  
Secs. 4-10-2—4-10-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION OF EMERGENCY TENANT PROTECTION ACT OF 1974 
 
Sec. 4-10-16. - Definition. 
As used in this article the term "Act" shall mean the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, as amended, (Laws 1974, Chapter 576, as amended). 
State Law reference— Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, Unconsol. L., §§ 8621—8634 (McKinney).  
Sec. 4-10-17. - Legislative determination. 
The common council, on July 29, 1974, declared an emergency pursuant to the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, providing for regulation of rents of all housing accommodations subject to regulation under the "act". Section 8 of the "act" requires that the city pay the costs incurred by the state division of housing and community renewal in administering the rent regulations under the "act", by making deposits in a revolving fund. 
Section 8-b of the "act", authorizes the city to impose on the owners of every building containing housing accommodations, subject to regulation under the "act", an annual charge for each such accommodation, in such amount as the city determines to be necessary for the expenses thereby incurred in the administration of such regulation. The procedures for enforcing the charges establishing rates, penalties and liens therefor are established in this article pursuant to the power delegated to the city in subdivision 5, § 10 of the Statute for Local Governments, and other applicable laws. 
(Ord. of 9-8-81, § 1) 
State Law reference— Power of city to declare emergency pursuant to act, Unconsol. L., § 8623 (McKinney); section 8-b is § 8628b (McKinney).  
Sec. 4-10-18. - Administrative charges. 
The owner of every building containing housing accommodations, subject to regulation pursuant to the act, shall pay to the city an annual charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each such housing accommodation in a building owned by said owner for the fiscal period commencing January 1 and ending the following December 31. 
(Ord. of 9-8-81, § 2; Ord. of 9-7-82, § 1; Ord. of 8-1-83, § 1; Ord. of 1-4-88, § 1; Ord. of 2-3-03)  
Sec. 4-10-19. - Billing and collection procedures. 
(a)  The commissioner of planning shall prepare a tentative list of owners of buildings to be charged the annual charge, identifying the address and tax lot reference of the premises and the address of the owner thereof, taken from the assessor's records and other available information as to the names and addresses of the owners. The list shall state as to each building the number of units of housing accommodations at the premises subject to regulation under the "act." This list shall be posted in a public place at the office of the Commissioner of Planning for a period of two (2) weeks from January 1 in each year. 
(b)  Notice of such posting shall be published in the official newspaper at least twice between January 1 and January 15. During the period between January 1 and January 31, during the regular business hours, objections shall be heard by the commissioner of planning or his designated representative, as to any claim or discrepancy in the amount of units for which the annual charge is to be made. 
(c)  The commissioner of planning shall make a record of any such objections and determine the merits of such objections and amend the tentative list consistent with the determination of objections, establishing thereby the final list of annual charges. 
(d)  After January 1, but prior to January 31, the commissioner of planning shall file with the commissioner of finance a certified copy of the list of annual charges. 
(e)  The commissioner of finance shall then render bills on account of the annual charge to the owners in the amounts designated on the list, and mail the bills to the owners at the addresses designated thereon in the same manner as is provided for the billing of the second half city taxes. The annual charges shall become a lien, be due and payable, interest charged, penalties accrued, and collections enforced in the same manner as is provided by the Charter for taxes levied pursuant to section 84 of the Charter. 
(f)  The commissioner of finance shall, upon receipt of the adjusted bill to the city at the close of the state fiscal year as provided for in section 8-a of the "act," render a bill for the adjusted annual charge to the person billed for the initial annual charge. When a refund is otherwise payable upon the annual charge for a building, but the annual charge has not been paid, then the commissioner of finance shall render a corrected bill setting forth the balance owing, inclusive of penalties and interest. 
(Ord. of 9-8-81, § 3; Ord. of 1-4-88, §§ 2, 3) 
State Law reference— Power of local government to fix, levy, impose, collect and administer fees and liens on local property in connection therewith, Statute of Local Governments, § 10(5).  
Chapter 4-11 - PAWNBROKERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers generally, General Business Law, §§ 40—55; power of city to license and regulate businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
Sec. 4-11-1. - License. 
Every pawnbroker shall pay a yearly license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each established business in the city. The initial license fee for a pawnbroker license shall be two hundred and seventy-five dollars ($275.00) which shall include a fingerprinting fee. All licenses shall be issued as of May 1, and shall continue in force until April 30 next succeeding the issuance thereof, unless sooner revoked by the city's commissioner of public safety, or other local licensing authority. 
(Ord. of 5-15-61, § 1; Ord. of 9-6-11, § 1) 
State Law reference— Licensing of pawnbrokers by city, General Business Law, §§ 40, 41.  
Chapter 4-12 - RESIDENTIAL ZONE; COMMERCIAL VEHICLE PARKING RESTRICTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Garaging auto trucks or light delivery cars in residential zones, § 9-2-5J; building code, Ch. 9-5. 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-12-1. - Legislative finding. 
(a)  Despite the prohibition in the existing zoning ordinance prohibiting and restricting the parking of commercial vehicles in residentially zoned areas, there has been a tendency to violate the ordinance arising out of hardship by many citizens who employ auto trucks or light delivery cars to go to and from their employment, or place of business, and their residences. The standing of such commercial vehicles in residential zones tends to deteriorate the quality of living in such zones by the ugliness of most commercial vehicles; by the creation of hazards by reason of the types of material carried in such commercial vehicles; by the increase in hazards to neighbors by reason of the increased traffic of heavy vehicles in the neighborhood as compared to the lighter weight passenger vehicles normally considered to use the roads and driveways of such residential neighborhoods; by generation of violations of the building code and aspects of the zoning ordinance by reason of the placement of commercial vehicles in garages not designed for the housing of such vehicles and which were intended by the zoning ordinance to house only private vehicles; by generating disobedience to the provisions for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the community at large of the protections intended by the zoning ordinance and building code for the community. 
(b)  Concurrently with the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the common council liberalized, but carefully controlled, the conditions under which such commercial type vehicles may be garaged in a residentially zoned area in a private garage and found it necessary to require that the vehicle intended to be used in such private garage in a residential zone, shall be carefully regulated by means of an annual inspection of the vehicle to determine that the vehicle is of the appropriate size and is equipped as to the essential safety devices necessary to protect the community when such vehicles are permitted in such zones. The amount of the license fee adopted in this chapter is intended to offset the expected costs of annual registration and inspection and identification of the vehicles so licensed. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 1)  
Sec. 4-12-2. - Use of authorized garage required. 
No person shall park or otherwise allow an auto truck or light delivery car to stand on private property in a residential zone otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers, unless it is garaged, parked or allowed to stand in a private garage duly authorized for such use pursuant to the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 2) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 4-12-3. - Compliance with other laws. 
A vehicle licensed pursuant to this chapter shall not be used for any purpose prohibited by any law, code, rule or regulation pertaining to the premises. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 5)  
Sec. 4-12-4. - Penalty. 
Any violation of this chapter may be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day or fraction of a day on which any such violation occurs, may be separately charged as a separate and distinct violation for the purpose of punishment. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 7) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-12-5—4-12-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-12-16. - Required. 
No person shall park or otherwise allow an auto truck or light delivery car to stand on private property in a residential zone otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers, unless it has affixed to it and displayed on its hood, a current license issued by the commissioner of building for such use. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 2)  
Sec. 4-12-17. - Application and fee. 
(a)  The application for a license or for any renewal thereof under this article shall be in writing upon a form to be furnished by the commissioner of building which shall require: 
(1)  A statement of the specific location of the private garage to be used; 
(2)  A copy of the current state department of motor vehicles owner registration form for the vehicle; 
(3)  A certification by the owner of the vehicle that the vehicle is not to be used for the purpose of conducting any business or any occupation prohibited by the zoning ordinance at the premises, signed by both the owner of the vehicle and the owner of the premises; and 
(4)  Such other information reasonably required by the commissioner of building to carry out the purpose of this chapter. 
(b)  A nonrefundable fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid for the initial application for the license for garaging of a particular vehicle and fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be paid for the annual renewal of such license. The fee shall accompany the initial application and the application for renewal. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 3(a), (b))  
Sec. 4-12-18. - Issuance. 
(a)  The commissioner of building, upon receipt of an application for the license required by this article, shall order an inspection of the premises to determine whether the premises may be lawfully used under all applicable codes, rules and regulations pertaining to the use of the premises and particularly for the parking or standing of such auto truck or light delivery cars at the premises. If the commissioner of building determines that the vehicle may be lawfully parked or allowed to stand at the premises, he shall issue a license authorizing the vehicle to be garaged at the designated private garage for the calendar year, or part thereof, for which the vehicular license is to be issued and shall require that the license be affixed to the exterior of the vehicle upon its hood. 
(b)  The license so issued shall state as a minimum the following information: 
(1)  The plate number and maximum gross weight of the vehicle as appears on the certificate of registration as issued by the state department of motor vehicles then in effect for the vehicle; 
(2)  The name of the owner of the vehicle; 
(3)  The name of the owner of the premises at which the vehicle is to be allowed to be parked in a private garage; 
(4)  The date of issuance and the date of expiration of the license issued by the commissioner of building. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 3(c), (d))  
Sec. 4-12-19. - Expiration. 
Each license issued pursuant to this article, including any renewal thereof, shall expire on the last day of December of the year of its issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked by the commissioner of building. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 4)  
Sec. 4-12-20. - Transfer. 
A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall not be transferable or assignable and shall only be valid for use at the premises designated thereon. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 5)  
Sec. 4-12-21. - Cancellation. 
If, at any time during the period for which a license has been issued pursuant to this article, the commissioner of building shall receive information that the vehicle so licensed is being used contrary to any law, code, rule or regulation issued thereunder, pertaining to use of premises in the city, the commissioner of building shall serve a notice of intention to cancel the license, in writing, served by certified mail addressed to the owner of the premises and to the owner of the vehicle. Such notice shall specify the day, time and place of the hearing to be conducted by the commissioner of building, or his designee, upon at least ten (10) days' notice prior to the hearing. Upon a determination of the commissioner after such hearing that a violation has occurred, or if there is a default in appearing for such hearing, or upon a waiver of such hearing, the commissioner is authorized to cancel or revoke such license. 
(Ord. of 5-2-77, § 6)  
Chapter 4-13 - SECONDHAND DEALERS, RUMMAGE SALES, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
State Law reference— Sale of secondhand watches, General Business Law, § 392; power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-13-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Rummage sale: A sale of goods or odds and ends, accumulated or collected for a sale for charity. 
(2)  Secondhand dealer: Any person engaging in the business of the purchase from the public at large of any and all secondhand goods or articles of personal property and the re-sale thereof, and holds himself out as engaging in such business, either through advertising or other means. 
(3)  Secondhand goods or secondhand articles: Any material or article of personal property of which prior use has been made. 
(4)  Thrift shop: A shop where used and new merchandise is donated and offered for sale for welfare and charitable purposes. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 1; Ord. of 6-17-63, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-2. - Reports to commissioner of public safety. 
Every dealer in secondhand articles shall deliver to the commissioner of public safety or his representative within four (4) hours after demand the records or portions thereof specified by the commissioner, or copies or extracts thereof required to be kept in section 4-13-4 of this Code of all goods, articles or things purchased, received or sold in the course of business of the dealer. The contents of such records, copies or extracts thereof shall not be communicated to any person for the purpose of publication but shall be used by the commissioner of public safety and others in authority to protect the public interest and detect crime. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 14)  
Sec. 4-13-3. - Purchase from minor or intoxicated persons. 
No dealer in secondhand articles shall purchase any secondhand goods, articles or things whatsoever from any minor or a person who is actually or apparently intoxicated, knowing or having reason to believe the person to be such. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(3))  
Sec. 4-13-4. - Record of purchases and sales. 
Every dealer in secondhand articles shall keep a substantially bound book in which shall be legibly written in ink and in English at the time of every purchase or sale a description of every secondhand article so purchased or sold, the number or numbers and any monograms, inscriptions or other marks of identification that may appear on the article, the name, residence, general description and signature of the person from whom such purchase was made and the name and residence of the person to whom sold. Such book shall at all reasonable times be open for inspection, or for copying or photostating, by the commissioner of public safety or his duty [duly] authorized agents. No entry in such book shall be erased, obliterated, altered or defaced and such book shall be kept and maintained for a period of two (2) years from the date of the latest purchase or sale entry made therein. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 13)  
Sec. 4-13-5. - Misleading signs. 
No dealer in secondhand articles shall display any sign which is calculated to mislead others. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(4))  
Sec. 4-13-6. - Acting or being licensed as pawnbroker, junk peddlers, etc., prohibited. 
No dealer in secondhand articles, while licensed as such, shall be licensed as a pawnbroker, a junk peddler or junk merchant or a used car dealer, nor shall any sign or other device or subterfuge be displayed, used or employed by any dealer in secondhand articles in or about the premises where such business is conducted which in any wise resembles the emblem or sign commonly used by pawnbrokers or which is intended to give the appearance that the business conducted on such premises is connected with the business of a pawnbroker. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(4))  
Sec. 4-13-7. - Tagging items. 
Every dealer in secondhand articles shall at the time of making any purchase and until resale attach and keep affixed a properly numbered tag to, or otherwise keep legibly numbered, each secondhand article bought and shall also make entry of such number in the book provided for in section 4-13-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(6))  
Sec. 4-13-8. - Inspection of premises and records. 
A secondhand dealer shall allow his place of business and all secondhand articles and records therein to be at all reasonable times examined by the commissioner of public safety or his duly authorized agents. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(5))  
Sec. 4-13-9. - Buying goods from other than owners. 
No secondhand dealer shall buy any secondhand articles of any kind which are distinctly and plainly marked as being the property of any person other than the person offering to sell the same, unless the person offering to sell the same shall show satisfactory evidence in writing that he is the legal and lawful owner of such property. Such written evidence shall be posted in the book provided for in section 4-13-4 of this Code and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The source of the property; 
(2)  Date of purchase; purchase price; and 
(3)  The length of time the property was in the possession of the seller. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(9))  
Sec. 4-13-10. - Signs generally. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall post in a conspicuous place in his place of business a sign indicating that he deals in secondhand goods. 
(b)  A secondhand dealer shall not display on the premises any sign with reference to rummage sales. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(10), (11); Ord. of 6-17-63, § 2)  
Sec. 4-13-11. - Reporting suspicious characters. 
In case any suspicious or known dishonest person shall offer for sale to any secondhand dealer, his employee, agent or servant, any article of value and he has reason to believe from any circumstances that the same has been stolen or acquired by dishonest means, it shall be his duty to report the same immediately to the commissioner of public safety or his representatives. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 16)  
Sec. 4-13-12. - Lost or stolen property. 
The commissioner of public safety shall furnish to every dealer in secondhand articles a list of all articles reported to the police department as lost or stolen. If the commissioner of public safety shall notify a secondhand dealer that any goods, articles or things have been lost or stolen and if any goods, articles or things described in the notice shall be or shall come into the possession of any such person, he shall immediately give to the commissioner of public safety information in writing that certain goods, articles or things listed by the police are in his possession and shall not dispose of the same except upon written authority so to do from the commissioner of public safety. Every dealer in secondhand articles who shall have or receive any goods, articles or things lost or stolen, or alleged or supposed to have been lost or stolen, shall exhibit the same on demand to the commissioner of public safety or his duly authorized agents. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 17)  
Sec. 4-13-13. - Special provisions for thrift shops and rummage sales. 
(a)  No person whether as principal, agent or employee shall establish, engage in, or carry on a thrift shop without the written consent of the commissioner of public safety. 
(b)  No person whether as principal, agent or employee shall establish, engage in, or carry on a rummage sale without the written consent of the commissioner of public safety. Such consent shall be granted only to a person who is a resident of the city or who maintains an office for the conduct of business in the city. 
(c)  A rummage sale conducted pursuant to the written permission of the commissioner of public safety shall not exceed a period of seven (7) days and the applicant may not conduct more than two (2) rummage sales within a one year period commencing with the date of issuance of the first permit by the commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, §§ 18, 19; Ord. of 6-17-63, § 4)  
Sec. 4-13-14. - Posting of chapter. 
Every person holding a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall post in a conspicuous place in his place of business a copy of this chapter, to be furnished by the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(7))  
Sec. 4-13-15. - Exemption. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to apply to retail stores selling articles taken as part-payment on new merchandise or to the sale of books, magazines, pianos, cooking ranges, refrigerators, washing machines, automobiles or automobile accessories, including tires, or to exchanges, returns or credits of merchandise when the articles exchanged, returned or credited are accepted in full or part-payment, nor to church or other religious or charitable association rummage or similar sales. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-16. - Violations. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a fine that shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in amount or by imprisonment not exceeding one hundred fifty (150) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. Each day on which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 20; Ord. of 6-13-63, § 3) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-13-17—4-13-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE FOR SECONDHAND DEALERS 
 
Sec. 4-13-26. - Required. 
No person, either as principal, agent or employee shall establish, engage in or carry on the business of dealing in secondhand articles, either separately or in connection with some other business, without a license issued by the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 2)  
Sec. 4-13-27. - Application. 
(a)  Every person desiring to procure a secondhand dealer's license, as herein provided, shall file with the city clerk a written application upon a blank form prepared and furnished by the city. Such application shall contain the name and residence or the names and residences of the applicant, if an individual, partnership or firm, or the names and residences of the principal officers and stockholders owning more than twenty (20) per cent thereof, if the applicant is an association or corporation. Such applicant shall also describe in detail the character of the business in which he, they or it desire to engage. 
(b)  The application shall also state the following: 
(1)  The length of time such applicant or applicants, if an individual, firm or partnership, or the officer, manager or person in charge if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association, has or have resided in the city, his or their place of previous employment, whether he or they or any of them have been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, and if so, what offense, when and in what court. 
(2)  The premises where such business is to be located or carried on, giving street and number. 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any officer or manager thereof has, either alone or with someone else, previously been a dealer in secondhand articles. 
(c)  Such application shall be signed and sworn to before a notary public or other official authorized to administer oaths in the city. Such application shall be accompanied by a photograph of applicant, if an individual, in triplicate, in such position as the commissioner of public safety may direct, taken within thirty (30) days preceding the filing of the application; similar photographs shall be required of each partner of a co-partnership, each officer and managing agent of a corporation and of each member of any other legal entity. Photographs shall be of a size which may be easily attached to the license, one of which shall be attached to the license when issued and the others filed with the application. Such application shall be accompanied by fingerprints of the above described persons whose photographs are required. A copy of the fingerprints and of the photographs so taken shall be kept on file at police headquarters as a permanent record. 
(d)  Any changes in any facts or information required on said application occurring after filing thereof shall be reported by the licensee in writing to the commissioner of public safety within ten (10) days. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 3)  
Sec. 4-13-28. - Bond. 
An application for a secondhand dealer's license shall be accompanied by a bond in favor of the people of the city, approved as to form and correctness by the corporation counsel, in the penal sum of seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00), conditioned for the due observance during the term of the license of any and all ordinances which are now in force or may hereafter be adopted by the common council respecting the business of dealing in secondhand articles. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 4; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-29. - Investigation. 
When an application for a secondhand dealer's license is filed, the city clerk shall request an investigation to be made by the commissioner of public safety to ascertain whether the applicant and the persons required to be fingerprinted and photographed are of good character and repute, and to further ascertain whether proper precautions against danger from fire, both within and without the premises named in the application, have been taken. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 5)  
Sec. 4-13-30. - Issuance generally. 
Upon the filing of the application, bond and satisfactory investigation report by the commissioner of public safety, the city clerk may, upon approval of such application and the payment to the city of the proper license fee hereinafter provided, issue to the applicant a license to engage in business as a secondhand dealer. All licenses shall be numbered in the order in which they are issued and shall state clearly the location of the place of business in which the person receiving such license shall be authorized to establish, engage in or carry on the business, the kind of business, the dates of issuance and expiration of the license and the name and address of the licensee. No applicant to whom a license has been refused shall make further application until a period of at least six (6) months shall have elapsed since the last previous rejection unless he can show that the reason for such rejection no longer exists. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 6)  
Sec. 4-13-31. - Fee. 
Every dealer in secondhand articles shall pay a license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), seventy-five ($75.00) of which shall be payable directly to the department of public safety for the cost of a criminal background check and fingerprinting. Such license may be renewed yearly for a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Every license may be renewed for two (2) consecutive annual renewals as of the first day of January upon payment of the required fee and filing a renewal application, under oath, on a form furnished by the city clerk certifying that no changes have occurred with respect to any of the facts or information required or supplied on the original application or, if there have been any changes, the applicant shall furnish the facts and information relating to all such changes and shall comply with the requirements of section 4-13-27 of this Code with respect thereto. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 7; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-32. - Persons ineligible for license. 
No secondhand dealer's license shall be granted to any person who shall have been convicted within three (3) years of the date of application of a violation of this chapter, or a felony, petty larceny or knowingly receiving stolen goods. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(8))  
Sec. 4-13-33. - Expiration and renewal. 
Every secondhand dealer's license shall expire on the thirty-first day of December next after its issuance. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 8; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-34. - Transfer. 
No license under the provisions of this chapter shall be transferred or assigned to any person or used by any person other than the person to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 9)  
Sec. 4-13-35. - Alteration, injury, etc., prohibited. 
No person shall deface or injure any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or change the name, numbers or dates on such license. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 10)  
Sec. 4-13-36. - Replacement of lost or destroyed license. 
If a secondhand dealer's license is lost, stolen or destroyed without fault on the part of its holder, a duplicate may be issued by the city clerk upon the filing of an affidavit satisfactorily explaining the facts of such loss or theft and upon the payment of one dollar ($1.00) for such duplicate license. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 10)  
Sec. 4-13-37. - Changing place of business. 
In case any person holding a secondhand dealer's license moves his place of business from the place designated on the license, he shall immediately thereupon give notice to the city clerk and have the same endorsed on the license. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 12)  
Sec. 4-13-38. - Use of location specified in license required. 
No person holding a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall carry on business at any place other than the one designated in his license. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(1))  
Sec. 4-13-39. - Revocation or suspension. 
Any license granted under the provisions of this chapter may be suspended or revoked, for cause, after a hearing for that purpose. The hearing upon such charges shall be held by the city clerk, or other person designated by the city clerk in writing. In the case of a hearing officer so designated, he shall make a record of such hearing which shall, with his recommendation, be returned to the city clerk for review and decision. Any such hearing shall be held after reasonable written notice by the city clerk to the licensee of the charges, and the licensee shall have the right to counsel and to present evidence. Violation by the licensee or his agent or employee of any of the provisions set forth in sections 4-13-2 through 4-13-10, 4-13-12, 4-13-14, 4-13-33 or 4-13-34 of this chapter shall be deemed sufficient cause for such suspension or revocation but shall not be limited thereto. Notice of the suspension or revocation and the grounds therefor, in writing, shall be sent by the city clerk to the licensee by mailing same to the business address of the premises or to the last-known place of residence of the licensee. Whenever any license shall be so revoked, no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. No license shall be granted to any person whose license has been revoked for a period of three (3) years from the date of such revocation. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 11; Ord. of 9-4-84, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13-40. - Carrying on business after license revoked or expired prohibited. 
No dealer in secondhand articles shall continue to carry on business after his license is revoked or expired. 
(Ord. of 5-4-53, § 15(2))  
Chapter 4-14 - SHOWS, CIRCUSES, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate occupations and businesses, General City Law, § 20(13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 4-14-1—4-14-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMANENT SHOWS, CIRCUSES, ETC. 
 
Sec. 4-14-16. - Investigations. 
It shall be the duty of the commissioner of public safety to investigate the character of the exhibitions given in any place of public amusement in the city in accordance with the provisions of this article to ascertain whether any of the provisions of this article are being violated and as to whether there is any offense against morality, decency or public welfare committed in said exhibitions. The members of the police force of the city shall investigate the character of such exhibitions and report to the commissioner of public safety any offense against morality, decency or public welfare committed in such exhibitions. 
(Ord. of 3-24-19, § V)  
Sec. 4-14-17. - Exemption. 
This article shall not apply to any building, hall, room or rooms, in which only private theatricals and exhibitions for charitable and religious performances are given, or to the manager of exhibitions given by amateurs for the benefit of any church, mission, parish, or Sunday School, or for any other charitable or religious performance. 
(Ord. of 3-24-19, § VII)  
Sec. 4-14-18. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates or refuses or neglects to comply with any provisions of this article, shall, upon convictions thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. And any such person shall also, for each offense, be subject to the payment of a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) to be recovered in a civil action. 
(Ord. of 3-24-19, § IX) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-14-19—4-14-40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Former §§ 4-14-26—4-14-29 were substantive sections set out herein as a Div. 2, Licenses, derived from ordinances adopted Mar. 24, 1919, §§ I—IV, VI; Jan. 17, 1921, § 1; Jan. 20, 1958, § 1; and June 9, 1983, § 1. Such provisions were repealed by an ordinance adopted Sept. 2, 2003, § 3.  
ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT SHOWS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-14-41. - Investigations. 
It shall be the duty of the commissioner of public safety to investigate the character of any of the exhibitions or shows licensed in this article to ascertain whether any of the provisions of this article are being violated and as to whether there is any offense against morality, decency or public welfare committed in any such exhibitions. The members of the police force of the city shall investigate the character of such exhibitions and report to the commissioner of public safety any offense against morality, decency or public welfare committed in any such exhibitions. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 4)  
Sec. 4-14-42. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates or refuses or neglects to comply with any provisions of this article, shall, upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisonment not exceeding fifteen (15) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 7) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 4-14-43—4-14-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 4-14-51. - Required. 
No person shall exhibit any menagerie, feats of horsemanship, circuses, carnivals, caravans of animals, animal shows, tent shows or transient shows or exhibitions of such nature, within the city without a license for such performance from the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 1)  
Sec. 4-14-52. - Issuance; fee; term; renewal. 
The city clerk is hereby authorized and empowered to grant and issue, the license required by this division upon receipt for such license the sum of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00). Such license shall be for a period of one (1) day only. The city clerk is hereby authorized and empowered to renew said license from day to day, upon receiving thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per day for each day after the first day. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 2; Ord. of 2-4-08, § 1)  
Sec. 4-14-53. - Revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued pursuant to this division by the preceding sections may be revoked by the commissioner of public safety, upon proof of any violation of the provisions of this article. The proof shall be taken before such commissioner of public safety upon notice of not less than two (2) hours, to show cause why such license should not be revoked. He shall hear the proofs and allegations in the case and determine the same summarily. The decision of the commission of public safety shall be final. 
(b)  Any person whose license is revoked shall not thereafter be entitled to a license under this division. On any examination pursuant to a notice to show cause, as aforesaid, the licensee may be a witness in his own behalf. 
(c)  If after such hearing the commissioner of public safety determines that the exhibition it is for has committed any offense against morality, decency or public welfare, the license for such exhibition shall be revoked. Such revocation shall take effect immediately upon the commissioner of public safety filing with the city clerk written notice of his finding. Upon the revocation of said license, the city clerk shall not issue a new license for said exhibition. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, §§ 3, 5)  
Chapter 4-15 - TAXICABS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Cross reference— Traffic and street use, Tit. 8; horse-drawn carriages, Ch. 4-22. 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate taxicabs, General Municipal Law, § 181. 
Editor's note— Ord. of April 4, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 4-15, §§ 4-15-1—4-15-73, and enacted a new Ch. 4-15 as set out herein. The former Ch. 4-15 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from ; Ord. of 5-19-59, § 1(9b.); Ord. of 5-19-69, §§ 1(2, a, 1), 1(2, a, 2), 1(2, a, 3(a)—(e), 1(2, b, 1, (a)—(j), 1(2, b, 1, (h), 2, b, 2, 1(2, b, 3—6), 1(3b), 1(3, a), 1(3, c, 1, 2(a)—(j), 1(4)—(7), 1(8a—8d), 1(9a.); Ord. of 4-16-69; Ord. of 5-19-69, § 1(1); Ord. of 11-5-73, § 1; Ord. of 6-16-75, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 4-6-79, §§ 3—5; Ord. of 4-16-79, §§ 1, 6, 8, 9—12; Ord. of 5-16-83, § 1, 2); Ord. of 1-5-87, §§ 1—7); Ord. of 9-8-87, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 2-8-88, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-88, §§ 1—12; Ord. of 2-5-91, § 1; Ord. of 5-7-91, § 1; Ord. of 11-2-92, §§ 1—8; Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1; Ord. of 12-6-93, § 1; Ord. of 6-3-96, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-00); Ord of 5-1-00, § 1; Ord. of 10-2-00, § 1; Ord. of 4-7-03, § 1; Ord. of 5-28-03, §§ 1—6; Ord. of 7-1-04, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-05, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-06, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-06, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 12-3-07, § 1; Ord. of 5-5-08, § 1; Ord. of 5-22-08, § 1; Ord. of 3-2-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-28-09, § 1; Ord. of 3-1-10, §§ 1—5; Ord. of 4-7-11, § 1; Ord. of 12-5-11, § 1; Ord. of 2-6-12, § 1; Ord. of 2-3-14, § 1; Ord. of 3-2-15, § 1, eff. 1-1-15). 
 
Sec. 4-15-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Accessible taxicab: An accessible taxicab is a vehicle that complies with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 and all regulations promulgated thereunder, and meets the minimum requirements of an accessible vehicle as specified by the Department of Public Safety. 
(2)  Base station: A central facility which manages, organizes, and/or dispatches taxicabs. Base stations must be located within the City of White Plains in compliance with the Zoning Ordinance of the city. 
(3)  Driver's license: The permission granted by the State of New York to a person to operate a vehicle. 
(4)  Fleet: Five (5) or more taxicabs, owned and licensed by the same individual, or owned and licensed by individuals but operated in conjunction with the same corporate identity. 
(5)  Hailing: A request, either through a verbal action such as calling out, or whistling, and/or a visible physical action such as raising one's hand or arm, by a person who is currently ready to travel. Hailing shall be permitted only in the Hail Zone. 
(6)  Hail zone: The business and parking district that encompasses the following area: Ferris Avenue south of Water Street to Martine Avenue; Martine Avenue east to South Lexington Avenue; South Lexington Avenue south to West Post Road; West Post Road southwest to Soundview Avenue; West Post Road northeast to Maple Avenue; Maple Avenue east to Mamaroneck Avenue; Mamaroneck Avenue southeast to Bloomingdale Road; Bloomingdale Road north to Westchester Avenue; Westchester Avenue east to South Kensico Avenue; South Kensico Avenue north to Lake Street; Lake Street west to North Broadway; North Broadway north to Barker Avenue; Barker Avenue west to Water Street; and Water Street west to Ferris Avenue. 
(7)  Rate card: a rate card is the official listing of rates issued by the Department of Public Safety, The rate card shall be displayed at all times, in the interior of the taxicab where it can be readily seen by the passengers.
