Cross reference— Games of chance legalized, § 4-1-1; bingo legalized, § 4-1-2; motion pictures on Sunday, § 4-1-3; public sports on Sunday, § 4-1-4; rules and regulations to be followed when in parks and playgrounds, Ch. 6-2; skateboarding or playing ball on streets, § 7-2-3; parades, Ch. 8-4; fire bombs, § 9-6-15.112. 
 
Chapter 5-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 5-1-1. - Memorial Day. 
(a)  The legal holiday known as Memorial Day being by general consent set apart for rest, repose and patriotic observances and uses, and the observance thereof being for the general welfare and health of the community, the going of certain acts hereinafter specified, which are deemed serious interruptions and desecrations of the repose and patriotic liberty and sentiment of the community, are prohibited. 
(b)  All labor, manufactures and trades on such holiday are prohibited, excepting the works of necessity and charity, which includes whatever is needful during the holiday for the good order, health or comfort of the community, and which is performed in orderly manner so as not to interfere with the repose or patriotic liberty and sentiment of the community. Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit public or private sports, exercises, games, recreation, concerts, dances, shows, entertainments or performances, nor any necessary labor involved in such activities. 
(c)  All manner of public selling or offering for sale of any property upon such holiday is prohibited during the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m., except as follows: 
(1)  Articles of food may be sold, served, supplied and delivered at any time of the day; 
(2)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold for on-premises or off-premises consumption, at such times of the day as prescribed by law, or by rule duly adopted for the locality pursuant to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law; 
(3)  Flowers, souvenirs, newspapers, gasoline, oil, tires, drugs, medicine and surgical instruments may be sold and may be delivered at any time of the day. 
(d)  A violation of the prohibition herein specified is an offense, punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding five (5) days, or by both, but for a second or other offense, where the party shall have been previously convicted, it shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not less than five (5) or more than fifteen (15) days, or both. 
(Ord. of 5-21-62, § 1; Ord. of 10-21-74; Ord. of 3-18-81, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-24-94, § 1; Ord. of 4-1-96, § 1) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37. 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate commercial and business activities on Memorial Day and Independence Day, General Municipal Law, § 86.  
Sec. 5-1-2. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages, or possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages on public property. 
(a)  The consumption of any alcoholic beverage, or the possession of any opened container containing any alcoholic beverage under circumstances evincing intent to consume, on any public property within the city including the public areas of property of the White Plains Housing Authority is prohibited, except that the provisions of this section shall not apply to persons permitted to use or possess alcoholic beverages by virtue of Section 1227 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, nor to persons invited to attend or participate in events permitted or sponsored by the city through the department of parks and recreation or the common council. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a violation and on the first conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) in amount, or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days or to both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 12-15-80, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-83, § 1) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 5-1-3. - Placement of iceboxes, containers, etc., accessible to children. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly leave or suffer to remain in any place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any substantially air-tight container of any kind, of a size large enough to contain any child, unless such icebox, refrigerator or other container can be readily opened from the interior by any child, or unless it has been kept securely closed and locked to prevent entry, or unless the latching or locking mechanism on the door, doors, lid or cover on the same has or have been removed or unless all such doors, lids or covers on the same have been removed. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of subsection (a) shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment not in excess of thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. of 10-5-53, §§ 1, 2) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37. 
State Law reference— Abandonment of containers attractive to children, Penal Law, § 270.10.  
Sec. 5-1-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 5-1-4, prohibiting loitering in municipal public parking areas, derived from § 1 of an ordinance adopted Oct. 17, 1960, was repealed by § 1 of an ordinance adopted July 7, 1986. Loitering is covered in § 240.35 of the Penal Law. A loitering ordinance similar to that formerly contained in § 5-1-4 was struck down by the New York Court of Appeals in People v. Burck in 1973.  
Sec. 5-1-5. - [Use of public areas for manufacturing, producing, etc., materials, etc.—Prohibited.] 
No person shall use or occupy any portion of any public area in the city of White Plains including but not limited to streets, sidewalks or public parking lots for manufacturing, fabricating, producing, processing or preparing any material or substance, including but not limited to dry cleaning, laundering or preparing or cooking any food products. 
(L.L. No. 2-1963, § 1) 
State Law reference— Power of city to adopt local law governing the use of its highways, roads, streets, avenues and property, Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10,1.(ii)a.(6).  
Sec. 5-1-6. - [Same—Exceptions.] 
The provisions of this local law [sections 5-1-5 through 5-1-7] shall not apply to the following: 
a.  Preparation of concrete by "mix in transit" trucks, provided such trucks are actually traveling over public streets or are parked at the actual location where the concrete is to be used. 
b.  Public areas under the charge of the commissioner of recreation and parks. 
c.  Activities in public areas being conducted for municipal purposes by officers, agents, servants or employees of the city. 
d.  Activities in public areas as may be authorized by the commissioner of public safety in connection with a duly designated public celebration or festival. 
e.  Governmental activities in public areas over which other governmental agencies have jurisdiction. 
(L.L. No. 2-1963, § 2; L.L. No. 1-1975, § 1)  
Sec. 5-1-7. - [Same—Violations and penalties.] 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this local law shall be guilty of an offense and on conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in amount, or imprisonment not exceeding one hundred fifty (150) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(L.L. No. 2-1963, § 3) 
State Law reference— Penalty for violation of local laws, General Municipal Law, § 10, 4.(b).  
Sec. 5-1-8. - Public urination and public defecation. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate in any public park, street, sidewalk, alley, highway, public meeting, assembly, or other public place, or in the immediate neighborhood thereof and in view from the same places; provided, that this section shall not be applicable to the act of urinating or defecating in a proper receptacle in a restroom or bathroom in any enclosed structure or portable, self-contained sanitation facility. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a violation and shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or by imprisonment for not more than fifteen (15) days or both. 
(Ord. of 3-1-10, § 1)  
Chapter 5-2 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Noisy animals, § 3-4-3(d); pets in parks, § 6-2-11; horse-drawn carriages, Ch. 4-22; fastening animals to trees, § 7-5-6; disposal of dead animals, § 7-6-7; keeping of animals and pets in dwelling units, § 9-8-200.7. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-2-1. - Fowl running at large. 
(a)  No live chickens, geese, ducks or other fowl shall be kept in the city unless they are securely enclosed in such a manner as to prevent them from straying from the premises of the person owning them. 
(b)  Any person who shall permit chickens, geese, ducks, or other fowl owned by him to stray from his premises shall be subject to a fine of not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. of 7-5-21, §§ 1, 2) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 5-2-2. - Livestock running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any livestock which is under his ownership, care, custody or control to run at large 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of subsection (a) shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. of 5-13-18, § 3) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 5-2-3—5-2-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING, IDENTIFICATION AND CONTROL OF DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of Nov. 1, 2010, § 1, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 5-2-16—5-2-21, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to dogs. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate dogs, Agriculture and Markets Law, § 124. 
 
Sec. 5-2-16. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide for the licensing and identification of dogs, the control and protection of the dog population and the protection of persons, property, domestic animals and deer from dog attack and damage. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-17. - Application. 
Any dog harbored within the City of White Plains which is owned by a resident of New York City or is licensed by the City of New York, or which is owned by a non-resident of New York State and licensed by a jurisdiction outside the State of New York, shall for a period of thirty (30) days be exempt from the licensing and identification provisions of this article herein. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-18. - Licensing of dogs; rabies vaccination requirement. 
(a)  All dogs within the City of White Plains four (4) months of age or older, unless otherwise exempted shall be licensed. The owner of each dog required to be licensed shall obtain, complete and return to the office of the city clerk a dog license application prescribed by the city together with the license application fee, any applicable license surcharges, and any such additional fees as may be established by the city. Each license issued shall be valid for a period of one (1), two (2) or three (3) year(s) and shall not be transferable. Upon the transfer of ownership of any dog, the new owner shall immediately apply for a new licenses for the dog. A license cannot be transferred to another dog. 
(b)  Each license application shall be accompanied by proof in the form of a statement certified by a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog has been vaccinated against rabies. No license shall be issued or renewed for a period expiring after the expiration date of the current rabies certificate for the dog being licensed. In lieu of a vaccination certificate, the applicant shall be required to present a statement certified by a licensed veterinarian stating that the administration of such vaccination would endanger the dog's life, in which case vaccination shall not be required. Where an applicant for a license submits said certified statement, a license shall be issued or renewed for a period of one (1) year from the date of said statement. 
(c)  Any owner failing to renew a dog license within sixty (60) days after the expiration thereof may be issued a summons by an authorized individual in the office of city clerk, an authorized animal control officer, a police officer or any authorized agent of the department of public safety. 
(d)  The city does not allow the licensing of dogs by a shelter. The shelter must send the adoptive dog owners to the licensing authority of the municipality in which the dog will be harbored for licensing within ten (10) days of adoption. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-19. - License fees. 
(a)  The City of White Plains hereby establishes that the license fee for each year or portion thereof for each dog license issued by the city clerk pursuant to this article shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for a spayed or neutered dog and eighteen dollars ($18.00) for an unspayed or an unneutered dog. Any dog owner may license his or her spayed or neutered or unspayed or unneutered dog for multiple years at a cost of seventeen ($17.00) for a two-year license for a spayed or neutered dog and twenty-seven dollars ($27.00) for an unspayed or an unneutered dog; however, no multiple year license can be issued if the expiration date were to exceed the expiration date of the rabies vaccination. 
(b)  Exempted from payment of the license fee are applications submitted for a dog license for any guide, hearing, service, war, working search, detection, police work and therapy dogs, as such dogs are defined by Section 108 of the New York State Agriculture and Markets Law. 
(c)  Incorporated within the license fees established by subsection (a) above of this section herein, is a surcharge of one dollar ($1.00) if the dog to be licensed is altered, or a fee of three dollars ($3.00) if the dog sought to be licensed is unaltered. 
(d)  A purebred kennel license may be issued by the city clerk for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a kennel housing between one (1) and ten (10) purebred dogs, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a kennel housing between eleven (11) and twenty-five (25) purebred dogs, and a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a kennel housing more than twenty-five (25) dogs. In addition to the license fee, a surcharge of three dollars ($3.00) shall also be imposed at the time the dog application is filed. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-20. - Identification of dogs. 
(a)  Each dog licensed pursuant to this article shall be assigned, at the time the dog is first licensed, a City of White Plains identification number. Such identification number shall be carried by the dog on an identification tag which shall be affixed to a collar on the dog at all times. 
(b)  A dog participating in a dog show shall be exempt from the identification requirement during such participation. 
(c)  The official identification number shall constitute the official identification of the dog to which it is assigned, regardless of changes of ownership, and the number shall not be reassigned to any other dog during the lifetime of the dog to which it is assigned. 
(d)  At the time a dog is first licensed, one (1) identification tag shall be furnished to the owner at no additional charge. Any replacement tag shall be obtained by the owner at the owner's expense, for the sum of three dollars ($3.00) to the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-21. - Change of ownership, lost or stolen dogs. 
(a)  Upon the transfer of ownership of any dog, the new owner shall immediately make application for a license for such dog. The original issued identification tag shall remain the same for the duration of the dog license. 
(b)  In the event of a change in ownership of any dog which has been assigned an official identification number, or in the event of a change in address of the owner of record of any such dog, the owner of record shall, within ten (10) days of such change, notify the city clerk. 
(c)  If any dog assigned an official identification number is lost or stolen, the owner of record shall, within ten (10) days of the discovery of such loss or theft, notify the city clerk. 
(d)  In the case of a dog's death, the owner of record shall so notify the city clerk either prior to renewal of license or upon the time of such renewal. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-22. - Seizure of dogs; redemption periods; impoundment fees. 
The owner of any dog impounded by the City of White Plains shall be entitled to redeem that dog within five (5) business days, excluding the day the dog is impounded, from the day the dog is impounded, provided that the owner produces proof the dog is licensed, vaccinated and identified and pays a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person for each twenty-four (24) hours or part thereof; a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the second impoundment within one (1) year of the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person and an additional fee of three dollars ($3.00) for each additional twenty-four-hour period; a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for a third and each subsequent impoundment within one (1) year of the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person and an additional fee of three dollars ($3.00) for each additional twenty-four-hour period. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Sec. 5-2-23. - Running at large. 
(a)  No person owning, harboring or having the custody and control of a dog shall permit such dog to be at large in the city elsewhere than on the premises of the owner, except it be on the premises of another person with the knowledge and assent of such other person. 
(b)  The owner, harborer or person having custody and control of a dog, in the city which is not on the premises of the owner or upon the premises of another person with the knowledge and assent of such person, shall control and restrain such dog by a chain or leash not exceeding eight (8) feet in length. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2) 
State Law reference— Impoundment of dogs found at large, Agriculture and Markets Law, § 118.  
Sec. 5-2-24. - Removal of feces from public places. 
A person who owns, harbors or has custody and control of a dog shall remove any feces left by his dog on any sidewalk, gutter, street or other public area. This section shall not apply to a blind person while such person is actually using a "guide dog" as defined by Section 108 of the Agriculture and Markets Law and licensed by the city as such. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4.  
Sec. 5-2-25. - Penalty. 
(a)  A violation of section 5-2-23 or section 5-2-24 of this article shall be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(b)  A violation of section 5-2-18 of this article shall be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), except where the person was found to have violated this section or former article seven of the Agriculture and Markets Law within the preceding five (5) years, the fine may not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00), and (ii) where the person was found to have committed two (2) or more violations within the preceding five (5) years, the civil penalty may not be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37. 
State Law reference— Violation of dog ordinances, Agriculture and Markets Law, § 124.  
Sec. 5-2-26. - Severability clause. 
The provisions of this article are declared to be severable, and if any section, subsection, sentence, clause or part thereof is, for any reason, held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of any remaining sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or part of this article. 
(Ord. of 11-1-10, § 2)  
Chapter 5-3 - HANDBILLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
 
Sec. 5-3-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as is indicated below: 
Handbill shall mean any written or printed poster, pamphlet, sheet of paper, booklet, leaflet, sticker, circular or advertisement, other than newspapers or magazines, whether original or a reproduction thereof. 
Public place shall mean any and all streets, avenues, highways, lanes, alleys or other public places, and all public parks, parking areas, squares, spaces, plazas, grounds and buildings. 
(Ord. of 11-5-53, § 1; Ord. of 8-2-82, § 1(1); Ord. of 3-7-88, § 1)  
Sec. 5-3-2. - Distribution, etc., in public places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to post, deposit, place, throw, scatter, cast or cause to be posted, deposited, placed, thrown, scattered or cast any handbill in any public place in the city. In addition, it shall be unlawful for any person to place, attach or otherwise affix any handbill to any bridge, statue, monument, curb, sidewalk, tree, lamppost, utility pole, telephone booth, police call box, fire call box, traffic-control signal, traffic sign, fence, fire hydrant or any property owned by the city. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of paragraph (a) above, it shall be lawful to distribute handbills. 
(Ord. of 11-5-53, §§ 2, 3; Ord. of 8-2-82, § 1(2), (3); Ord. of 3-7-88, § 2)  
Sec. 5-3-3. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a term of imprisonment not to exceed ten (10) days, a fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), or both. 
(Ord. of 11-5-53, § 4; Ord. of 8-2-82, § 1(4)) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violation of ordinances, § 37.  
Chapter 5-4 - SHOPPING CARTS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-4-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Public place: A street, sidewalk, avenue, road, alley, lane, highway, broadway, concourse, driveway, culvert, crosswalk, every class of road, square, place and municipal parking lot. 
(2)  Shopping cart: A handdrawn or propelled vehicle or wheeled container made of wire, metal, wood or other material, such as is generally provided by merchants for carting or carrying merchandise or food stuffs to automobiles or other places, hereinafter referred to as cart. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 1; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(1))  
Sec. 5-4-2. - Removal from premises of owner. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a shopping cart or suffer or permit such removal of a shopping cart from the property of any food dispensing or other establishment or business, except to convey the same to an adjoining private parking lot or a sidewalk area immediately in front of or contiguous to such food dispensing or other establishment or business, and except that the owners of such food dispensing or other establishments or businesses may move carts, in bulk, from one store to another store or to another location. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 2; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(2))  
Sec. 5-4-3. - Tagging. 
Every person who, in connection with the conduct of a food dispensing or other establishment or business, owns or makes any cart available to the public, shall make or cause the same to be marked and identified conspicuously with the name and address of the owner. Such identification shall be in the form of a metal tag securely fastened to the cart or a cutting or stamping on the frame of the cart. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 4; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(4))  
Sec. 5-4-4. - Leaving on public property prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or suffer or permit to be left upon any public place any shopping cart which is owned by him or which is in his possession, custody or control. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 3; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(3))  
Sec. 5-4-5. - Exemption. 
This chapter shall not apply to any cart or personal property which may come into the possession or custody of any department of the city pursuant to any other ordinance, law or regulation. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 10; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(10))  
Sec. 5-4-6. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding five (5) days, or both fine and imprisonment for the first offense; and by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding fifteen (15) days, or both such fine and imprisonment for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 11; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(11); Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 11; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 11) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 5-4-7—5-4-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REMOVAL FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 5-4-16. - Removal by commissioner of public works required. 
The commissioner of public works of the city shall remove, or cause to be removed, from time to time, any shopping cart found upon any public place, and shall take the same to city property where it shall be held until redeemed, sold or otherwise disposed of as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 5; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(5))  
Sec. 5-4-17. - Notice to owner and redemption by owner. 
Whenever the city shall remove any shopping cart bearing identification of ownership, the commissioner of public works shall mail a notice to the owner at the address shown on the identification tag, cut or stamp. Such notice shall advise that such cart may be redeemed upon payment to the department of finance of the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each cart so redeemed and shall set forth the place for the redemption of such cart where possession of the same may be procured. Payment for redemption shall be made to the department of finance and a receipt shall be given therefor, which receipt shall entitle such owner to redeem, at the place of storage thereof, one or more carts, as provided for in said receipt, upon surrender of the same at the place of storage of such cart or carts. No cart shall be delivered to a person seeking to redeem the same unless proof is submitted establishing, to the satisfaction of the city, such person's ownership or right to possession. Any delivery to a person deemed entitled thereto by the city, from the proof submitted, shall be an absolute defense of the city against any other person claiming to be entitled thereto. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 6; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(6); Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 12)  
Sec. 5-4-18. - Auction of unredeemed carts. 
After the mailing of the notice provided for in section 5-4-17 of this Code or after removal of a shopping cart bearing no identification of ownership, the city shall, from time to time, sell such carts at public auction. Notice of such public auction shall be given by publication in the official newspaper of the city by publication at least once, the first date of publication to be not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of public auction and shall set forth the time and place of holding such public auction and shall also advise that said carts will be sold at public auction. Any cart or carts may be redeemed by the owner thereof at least two (2) days prior to such public auction upon payment to the city of the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each cart. No cart shall be delivered to a person seeking to redeem the same unless proof is submitted establishing, to the satisfaction of the city, such person's ownership or right to possession. Any delivery to a person deemed entitled thereto by the city, from the proof submitted, shall be an absolute defense of the city against any other person claiming to be entitled thereto. Such sale at public auction shall be conducted by the commissioner of public works, or such other person as he shall designate. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 7; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(7); Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 13)  
Sec. 5-4-19. - Carts not sold at auction. 
If a shopping cart is not sold at public auction, the city may similarly offer the same again for sale at public auction or may dismantle or destroy or otherwise dispose of such cart. Any disposition of such cart made pursuant to this chapter shall be without any liability on behalf of the city or to any person lawfully entitled thereto or having any interest therein. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 8; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(8))  
Sec. 5-4-20. - Use of funds. 
Upon a redemption or sale of a shopping cart the proceeds shall be deposited in the general funds of the city. 
(Ord. of 2-19-63, § 9; Ord. of 5-2-83, § 1(9))  
Chapter 5-5 - WEEDS AND OTHER NOXIOUS MATERIALS 
 
Sec. 5-5-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The words "commissioner of building" as used in this chapter shall mean the commissioner of building of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
(b)  The words "commissioner of finance" as used in this chapter shall mean the commissioner of finance of the city, or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1)  
Sec. 5-5-2. - Cutting and removal of grass, weeds and other rank, poisonous or harmful vegetation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant, or any agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee or occupant, having control of any occupied or unoccupied building lot or plot of land or any part thereof in any developed section of the city to permit or maintain on any such lot or plot of land or on or along the sidewalk, street or alley adjacent to the same between the property line and the curb or middle of the alley, or for ten (10) feet outside the property line, if there be no curb, any growth of weeds, grass or other rank vegetation to a height greater than twelve (12) inches, on the average, or any accumulation of dead weeds, grass or brush. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any such person to cause, suffer or allow poison ivy, ragweed or other poisonous plants or plants detrimental to health, to grow on any such lot or plot of land in such manner that any part of such ivy, ragweed, or other poisonous weed shall extend upon, overhang, or border any public place, or allow weeds, pollen or other poisonous particles or emanations therefrom to be carried through the air into any public place. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1(2))  
Sec. 5-5-3. - Duty of owner, lessee or occupant. 
It shall be the duty of any owner, lessee or occupant of any such lot or plot of land in the city to cut and remove or cause to be cut and removed all such weeds, grass or other rank, poisonous or harmful vegetation as often as may be necessary to comply with the provisions of section 5-5-2 of this Code; provided, that cutting and removing such weeds, grass and vegetation at least once in every three (3) weeks between May 15 and September 15 shall be deemed to be a compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1(3))  
Sec. 5-5-4. - Throwing or casting of rubbish, junk or flammable materials upon vacant land. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, lessee, agent, tenant, or otherwise, to throw, cast, or deposit, or cause or permit to run, drop or remain or to be thrown, cast or deposited, in or upon any vacant lot of land or vacant place, upon the surface of any lot of land, enclosed or otherwise, within the city, except at such place or places designated or provided by the board of health of the county or the department of public works, any waste, leaves, brush, hay, weeds, straw, litter, waste paper, boxes, abandoned vehicles, debris, junk, shavings or any filthy, combustible or flammable materials, rubbish, garbage, or dirt whereby a fire hazard, danger or risk is or may be endangered or injuriously effected or whereby the premises of another, or the enjoyment of the premises of another, are or may be injured, damaged, interfered with, or prejudiced. Nothing in this section shall be construed as to prohibit the depositing of manure upon any private property for the purpose of cultivating same. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1(4))  
Sec. 5-5-5. - Notice of removal; removal. 
(a)  If the provisions of sections 5-5-2 through 5-5-4 of this Code are not complied with, the commissioner of building shall serve written notice upon the owner, lessee or occupant or any person having the care or control of any such lot or land to comply with the provisions of this chapter. If the person upon whom the notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to cut or remove, or to cause to be cut and removed, such weeds, grass or other vegetation, or shall fail to cause such substances or matter described in such notice to be removed within ten (10) days thereafter, the commissioner of building shall cause such work to be done as is necessary to comply with the provisions of such notice. 
(b)  The commissioner of building shall charge the actual cost of such work, plus five (5) per centum for inspection and other additional costs in connection therewith, and on or before November 1 in each year shall mail or otherwise deliver a bill or statement thereof to the owner of such lot or land so far as such owner and the address of such owner are known. If payment of such bill or statement shall not be made on or before December 1 of such year the commissioner of building shall make a list of all unpaid accounts as hereinafter set forth. 
(c)  During the month of December in each year the commissioner of building shall make a list of all such charges and file the same in his office and give public notice of such filing by publication in the official newspaper, two (2) insertions, that said list has been made and filed and that for ten (10) days from the date of the first publication of said notice said list may be examined by any person interested therein and that upon a day and hour stated in such notice, and at least ten (10) days after the first publication thereof, he will attend at his office to hear any objections to said list and pass upon all objections, and, if need be, alter and correct said list. 
(d)  After said hearing and making of the necessary corrections, if any, he shall attach thereto his certificate that such hearing has been had and that said list is now complete and file the same with the commissioner of finance, whereupon the commissioner of finance shall mail to each owner of real property included in such list whose name and address he is able to ascertain a statement of the amount of charges against his property. Upon the filing of the said list with the commissioner of finance the several sums mentioned in said list shall be deemed to be assessed against the several persons named therein and the commissioner of finance shall, when extending the next general tax upon the city assessment roll, place unpaid amounts thereon as against the property of the person named in said list and such amount shall be collected at the same time, in the same manner and by the same proceedings as other taxes on said roll. The failure to mail any notice or statement referred to in this section or failure of the addressee to receive the same shall not in any manner affect the validity of the assessment or the penalties imposed by law with respect thereto. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1(5)) 
State Law reference— Power of city to fix, levy, impose, collect and administer rents, charges, rates and fees, penalties and rates of interest thereon, liens on local property in connection therewith and charges thereon, Statute of Local Governments, § 10, 6.  
Sec. 5-5-6. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, or who shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided, or who shall resist or obstruct the commissioner of building or his employees or any employee of the city in carrying into effect the provisions of any notice served hereunder, shall be guilty of a violation and upon conviction thereof, subject to the following fines: 
(1)  For a first conviction, a fine not to exceed twenty five hundred dollars ($2,500). 
(2)  For a second or subsequent offense, a fine not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000), or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both. 
In case of continuing violation, every day's continuance thereof, shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. of 12-2-74, § 1(6); Ord. of 5-30-19, § 2, eff. 7-1-19 ) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Chapter 5-6 - GRAFFITI 
 
Sec. 5-6-1. - Legislative intent. 
It has become apparent that the use of pens, writing and artistic devices, spray can and marking devices used in connection with the writing of graffiti on walls and other places of buildings and property has reached such significant levels and proportions that immediate local attention should be given this matter by this municipality. The defacing of such property and the use of foul language in many of the writings is harmful to the general public and violative of the good and welfare of the citizens, residents and people of the city. It is the further intent of the common council that any person guilty of writing graffiti on buildings and property shall be punished so that the punishment shall fit the offense. 
(Ord. of 5-6-85, § 1; Ord. of 11-4-91, § 1)  
Sec. 5-6-2. - Writing on property without permission of owner prohibited. 
No person shall write, paint or draw any inscription, figure or mark of any type on any building, public or private, or any other property, real or personal, owned, operated or maintained by any public benefit corporation, the city, or by any person, firm or corporation or any agency or instrumentality thereof, without the express written permission of the owner of the property or his agent. 
(Ord. of 5-6-85, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-91, § 1)  
Sec. 5-6-3. - Penalties for offenses. 
Any person who violates section 5-6-2 of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense, and of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a second or subsequent offense, or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 5-6-85, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-91, § 1)  
Sec. 5-6-4. - Reward. 
Under the authority of section 91 of the General Municipal Law of the State of New York, any person who shall provide information which leads to the detection, arrest and conviction of any other person of a violation of this chapter shall be entitled to a reward equal to one-half of any fine imposed by the court, but in no event greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. of 5-6-85, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-91, § 1)  
Sec. 5-6-5. - Responsibility of owner. 
It is the responsibility of the owner or his agent of the building or structure which has been defaced without the owner's, or his agent's, prior written permission by a writing, painting or drawing of any inscription, figure or mark, to completely remove said graffiti from the building or structure within ten (10) business days of receipt of written notice of the defacement by the commissioner of public safety, or his designee, said notice served personally or as otherwise permitted by law. 
(Ord. of 11-7-91, § 1; Ord. of 7-9-07, § 1)  
Sec. 5-6-6. - Penalty for owner. 
Failure of the owner of the building or structure to remove the graffiti within the time allowed after written notice may subject the owner to a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first offense. Each ten (10) business day period thereafter where the owner fails to take action shall be deemed a separate offense and shall subject the owner to additional fines not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. of 11-7-91, § 1; Ord. of 7-9-07, § 1)  
Chapter 5-7 - Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, adopted Aug. 5, 2019, repealed the former Ch. 5-7, §§ 5-7-1—5-7-9, and enacted a new Ch. 5-7 as set out herein. The former Ch. 5-7 pertained to Energize NY Benefit Financing Program and derived from L.L. No. 1-2013 , § 1, 2-4-2013; L.L. No. 1-2018 , § 1, 3-5-18. 
 
Sec. 5-7-1. - Legislative findings, intent and purpose, and authority. 
5-7-1-1. It is the policy of both the City of White Plains and the State of New York (the "State") to achieve energy efficiency and renewable energy improvements, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, mitigate the effect of global climate change, and advance a clean energy economy. The City of White Plains finds that it can fulfill this policy by providing property assessed clean energy financing to Qualified Property Owners (as defined below) for the installation of renewable energy systems and energy efficiency measures. This Chapter establishes a program that will allow the Energy Improvement Corporation (as defined below, "EIC"), a local development corporation, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains pursuant to the municipal agreement (the "Municipal Agreement") to be entered into between the City of White Plains and EIC, to make funds available to Qualified Property Owners that will be repaid through charges on the real properties benefited by such funds, thereby fulfilling the purposes of this Chapter and accomplishing an important public purpose. This Chapter provides a method of implementing the public policies expressed by, and exercising the authority provided by, Article 5-L of the General Municipal Law (as defined below, the "Enabling Act"). 
5-7-1-2. The City of White Plains is authorized to execute, deliver and perform the Municipal Agreement and otherwise to implement this Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program pursuant to the Constitution and laws of New York, including particularly Article IX of the Constitution, Section 10 of the Municipal Home Rule Law, the Enabling Act and this Chapter. 
5-7-1-3. This Chapter, which is adopted pursuant to Section 10 of the Municipal Home Rule Law and the Enabling Act shall be known and may be cited as the "Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program". 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-2. - Definitions. 
Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings assigned in the Enabling Act. For purposes of this Chapter, and unless otherwise expressly stated or unless the context requires, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
5-7-2-1. Annual Installment Amount - shall have the meaning assigned in Section 5-7-8-2 of this Chapter. 
5-7-2-2. Annual Installment Lien - shall have the meaning assigned in Section 5-7-8-2 of this Chapter. 
5-7-2-3. Authority - the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority. 
5-7-2-4. Benefit Assessment Lien - shall have the meaning assigned in Section 5-7-3-1 of this Chapter. 
5-7-2-5. Benefited Property - Qualified Property for which the Qualified Property Owner has entered into a Finance Agreement for a Qualified Project. 
5-7-2-6. Benefited Property Owner - the owner of record of a Benefited Property. 
5-7-2-7. EIC - the Energy Improvement Corporation, a local development corporation, duly organized under Section 1411 of the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law of the State, authorized hereby on behalf of the City of White Plains to implement the Program by providing funds to Qualified Property Owners and providing for repayment of such funds from money collected by or on behalf of the City of White Plains as a charge to be levied on the real property. 
5-7-2-8. Eligible Costs - costs incurred by the Benefited Property Owner in connection with a Qualified Project and the related Finance Agreement, including application fees, EIC's Program administration fee, closing costs and fees, title and appraisal fees, professionals' fees, permits, fees for design and drawings and any other related fees, expenses and costs, in each case as approved by EIC and the Financing Party under the Finance Agreement 
5-7-2-9. Enabling Act - Article 5-L of the General Municipal Law of the State, or a successor law, as in effect from time to time. 
5-7-2-10. Finance Agreement - the finance agreement described in Section 5-7-6-1 of this Chapter. 
5-7-2-11. Financing Charges - all charges, fees and expenses related to the loan under the Finance Agreement including accrued interest, capitalized interest, prepayment premiums, and penalties as a result of a default or late payment and costs and reasonable attorneys' fees incurred by the Financing Party as a result of a foreclosure or other legal proceeding brought against the Benefited Property to enforce any delinquent Annual Installment Liens. 
5-7-2-12. Financing Parties - Third party capital providers approved by EIC to provide financing to Qualified Property Owners or other financial support to the Program which have entered into separate agreements with EIC to administer the Program in the City of White Plains. 
5-7-2-13. City of White Plains - the City of White Plains, a municipality of the State constituting a tax district as defined in Section 1102 of RPTL of the State. 
5-7-2-14. Municipal Lien - a lien on Qualified Property which secures the obligation to pay real property taxes, municipal charges, or governmentally imposed assessments in respect of services or benefits to a Qualified Property. 
5-7-2-15. Non-Municipal Lien - a lien on Qualified Property which secures any obligation other than the obligation to pay real property taxes, municipal charges, or governmentally-imposed assessments in respect of services or benefits to a Qualified Property Owner or Qualified Property. 
5-7-2-16. Program - the Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program authorized by this Chapter. 
5-7-2-17. Qualified Project - the acquisition, construction, reconstruction or equipping of Energy Efficiency Improvements or Renewable Energy Systems or other projects authorized under the Enabling Act on a Qualified Property, together with a related Energy Audit, Renewable Energy System Feasibility Study and/or other requirements under or pursuant to the Enabling Act, with funds provided in whole or in part by Financing Parties under the Program to achieve the purposes of the Enabling Act. 
5-7-2-18. Qualified Property - Any real property other than a residential building containing less than three dwelling units, which is within the boundaries of the City of White Plains that has been determined to be eligible to participate in the Program under the procedures for eligibility set forth under this Chapter and the Enabling Act and has become the site of a Qualified Project. 
5-7-2-19. Qualified Property Owner - the owner of record of Qualified Property which has been determined by EIC to meet the requirements for participation in the Program as an owner, and any transferee owner of such Qualified Property. 
5-7-2-20. RPTL - the Real Property Tax Law of the State, as amended from time to time. 
5-7-2-21. Secured Amount - as of any date, the aggregate amount of principal loaned to the Qualified Property Owner for a Qualified Project, together with Eligible Costs and Financing Charges, as provided herein or in the Finance Agreement, as reduced pursuant to Section 5-7-8-3 of this Chapter. 
5-7-2-22. State - the State of New York. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-3. - Establishment of an Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program. 
5-7-3-1. An Energize NY Open C-PACE Financing Program is hereby established by the City of White Plains, whereby EIC acting on its behalf pursuant to the Municipal Agreement, may arrange for the provision of funds by Financing Parties to Qualified Property Owners in accordance with the Enabling Act and the procedures set forth under this Chapter, to finance the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, and installation of Qualified Projects and Eligible Costs and Financing Charges approved by EIC and by the Financing Party under the Finance Agreement. EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, and with the consent of the Benefited Property Owner, will record a Benefit Assessment Lien on the Benefited Property in the Secured Amount (the "Benefit Assessment Lien") on the land records for the City of White Plains. Such recording shall be exempt from any charge, mortgage recording tax or other fee in the same manner as if recorded by the City of White Plains. 
5-7-3-2. Before a Qualified Property Owner and a Financing Party enter into a Finance Agreement which results in a loan to finance a Qualified Project, repayment of which is secured by a Benefit Assessment Lien, a written consent from each existing mortgage holder of the Qualified Property shall be obtained, permitting the Benefit Assessment Lien and each Annual Installment Lien to take priority over all existing mortgages. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-4. - Procedures for eligibility. 
5-7-4-1. Any property owner in the City of White Plains may submit an application to EIC on such forms as have been prepared by EIC and made available to property owners on the website of EIC and at the City of White Plains' offices. 
5-7-4-2. Every application submitted by a property owner shall be reviewed by EIC, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains, which shall make a positive or negative determination on such application based upon the criteria enumerated in the Enabling Act and this Chapter. EIC may also request further information from the property owner where necessary to aid in its determination. 
5-7-4-3. If a positive determination on an application is made by EIC, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains, the property owner shall be deemed a Qualified Property Owner and shall be eligible to participate in the Program in accordance with Section 5-7-6 of this Chapter. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-5. - Application criteria. 
Upon the submission of an application, EIC, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains, shall make a positive or negative determination on such application based upon the following criteria for the making of a financing: 
5-7-5-1. The property owner may not be in bankruptcy and the property may not constitute property subject to any pending bankruptcy proceeding; 
5-7-5-2. The amount financed under the Program shall be repaid over a term not to exceed the weighted average of the useful life of Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvements to be installed on the property as determined by EIC; 
5-7-5-3. Sufficient funds are available from Financing Parties to provide financing to the property owner; 
5-7-5-4. The property owner is current in payments on any existing mortgage on the Qualified Property; 
5-7-5-5. The property owner is current in payments on any real property taxes on the Qualified Property; and 
5-7-5-6. Such additional criteria, not inconsistent with the criteria set forth above, as the State, the City of White Plains, or EIC acting on its behalf, or other Financing Parties may set from time to time. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-6. - Energize NY finance agreement. 
5-7-6-1. A Qualified Property Owner may participate in the Program through the execution of a finance agreement made by and between the Qualified Property Owner and a Financing Party, to which EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, shall be a third-party beneficiary (the "Finance Agreement"). Upon execution and delivery of the Finance Agreement, the property that is the subject of the Finance Agreement shall be deemed a "Benefited Property". 
5-7-6-2. Upon execution and delivery of the Finance Agreement, the Benefited Property Owner shall be eligible to receive funds from the Financing Party for the acquisition, construction, and installation of a Qualified Project, together with Eligible Costs and Financing Charges approved by EIC and by the Financing Party, provided the requirements of the Enabling Act, the Municipal Agreement and this Chapter have been met. 
5-7-6-3. The Finance Agreement shall include the terms and conditions of repayment of the Secured Amount and the Annual Installment Amounts. 
5-7-6-4. EIC may charge fees to offset the costs of administering the Program and such fees, if not paid by the Financing Party, shall be added to the Secured Amount 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-7. - Terms and conditions of repayment. 
The Finance Agreement shall set forth the terms and conditions of repayment in accordance with the following: 
5-7-7-1. The principal amount of the funds loaned to the Benefited Property Owner for the Qualified Project, together with Eligible Costs and Financing Charges approved by EIC and by the Financing Party, shall be specially assessed against the Benefited Property and will be evidenced by a Benefit Assessment Lien recorded against the Benefited Property on the land records on which liens are recorded for properties within the City of White Plains. The special benefit assessment shall constitute a "charge" within the meaning of the Enabling Act and shall be collected in annual installments in the amounts certified by the Financing Party in a schedule provided at closing and made part of the Benefit Assessment Lien. Said amount shall be annually levied, billed and collected by EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, and shall be paid to the Financing Party as provided in the Finance Agreement. 
5-7-7-2. The term of such repayment shall be determined at the time the Finance Agreement is executed by the Benefited Property Owner and the Financing Party, not to exceed the weighted average of the useful life of the systems and improvements as determined by EIC, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains. 
5-7-7-3. The rate of interest for the Secured Amount shall be fixed by the Financing Party in conjunction with EIC, acting on behalf of the City of White Plains, as provided in the Finance Agreement 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-8. - Levy of annual installment amount and creation of annual installment lien. 
5-7-8-1. Upon the making of the loan pursuant to the Finance Agreement, the Secured Amount shall become a special Benefit Assessment Lien on the Benefited Property in favor of the City of White Plains. The amount of the Benefit Assessment Lien shall be the Secured Amount. Evidence of the Benefit Assessment Lien shall be recorded by EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, in the land records for properties in the City of White Plains. Such recording shall be exempt from any charge, mortgage recording tax or other fee in the same manner as if recorded by the City of White Plains. The Benefit Assessment Lien shall not be foreclosed upon by or otherwise enforced by the City of White Plains. 
5-7-8-2. The Finance Agreement shall provide for the repayment of the Secured Amount in installments made at least annually, as provided in a schedule attached to the Benefit Assessment Lien (the "Annual Installment Amount"). The Annual Installment Amount shall be levied by EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, on the Benefited Property in the same manner as levies for City of White Plains charges, shall become a lien on the Benefited Property as of the first day of January of the fiscal year for which levied (the "Annual Installment Lien") and shall remain a lien until paid. The creation or any recording of the Annual Installment Lien shall be exempt from any charge, mortgage recording tax or other fee in the same manner as if recorded by the City of White Plains. Payment to the Financing Party shall be considered payment for this purpose. Such payment shall partly or wholly discharge the Annual Installment Lien. Delinquent Annual Installment Amounts may accrue Financing Charges as may be provided in the Finance Agreement. Any additional Financing Charges imposed by the Financing Party pursuant to the Finance Agreement shall increase the Annual Installment Amount and the Annual Installment Lien for the year in which such overdue payments were first due. 
5-7-8-3. The Benefit Assessment Lien shall be reduced annually by the amount of each Annual Installment Lien when each Annual Installment Lien becomes a lien. Each Annual Installment Lien shall be subordinate to all Municipal Liens, whether created by Section 902 of the RPTL or by any other State or local law. No portion of a Secured Amount shall be recovered by the City of White Plains, EIC, or an assignee upon foreclosure, sale or other disposition of the Benefited Property unless and until all City of White Plains Liens are fully discharged. Each Annual Installment Lien, however, shall have priority over all Non-Municipal Liens, irrespective of when created, except as otherwise required by law. 
5-7-8-4. Neither the Benefit Assessment Lien nor any Annual Installment Lien shall be extinguished or accelerated in the event of a default or bankruptcy of the Benefited Property Owner. Each Annual Installment Amount shall be considered a charge upon the Benefited Property and shall be collected by EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, at the same time and in the same manner as real property taxes or municipal charges. Each Annual Installment Lien shall remain a lien until paid. Amounts collected in respect of an Annual Installment Lien shall be remitted to EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, or the Financing Party, as may be provided in the Finance Agreement. 
5-7-8-5. EIC shall act as the City of White Plains' agent in collection of the Annual Installment Amounts. If any Benefited Property Owner fails to pay an Annual Installment Amount, the Financing Party may redeem the Benefited Property by paying the amount of all unpaid Municipal Liens thereon, and thereafter shall have the right to collect any amounts in respect of an Annual Installment Lien by foreclosure or any other remedy available at law. Any foreclosure shall not affect any subsequent Annual Installment Liens. 
5-7-8-6. EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, may sell or assign for consideration any and all Benefit Assessment Liens and Annual Installment Liens to Financing Parties that provide financing to Qualified Properties pursuant to Finance Agreements. The Financing Parties may sell or assign for consideration any and all Benefit Assessment Liens and Annual Installment Liens received from EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, subject to certain conditions provided in the administration agreement between EIC and the Financing Party. The assignee or assignees of such Benefit Assessment Liens and Annual Installment Liens shall have and possess the same powers and rights at law or in equity as the City of White Plains would have had if the Benefit Assessment Lien and the Annual Installment Liens had not been assigned with regard to the precedence and priority of such lien, the accrual of interest and the fees and expenses of collection. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-9. - Verification and report. 
EIC, on behalf of the City of White Plains, shall verify and report on the installation and performance of Renewable Energy Systems and Energy Efficiency Improvements financed by the Program in such form and manner as the Authority may establish. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
Sec. 5-7-10. - Separability. 
If any clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part of this Chapter shall be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder thereof, but shall be confined in its operation to the clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered. 
( L.L. No. 3-2019, § 1, 8-5-19 )  
TITLE VI. - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
