Chapter 6-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 6-1-1. - Recreation advisory committee. 
(a)  A recreation advisory committee is hereby established for the purpose of advising and cooperating with the common council in relation to the establishment, maintenance and operation of playgrounds and recreation centers in this city. 
(b)  Such committee shall consist of eleven (11) residents of the city who shall serve for two-year terms; ten (10) of the members, including the chairman, shall be appointed by the common council. The eleventh member shall be a representative of the city school district and shall be designated by the board of education. One (1) of the members appointed by the common council shall be a member thereof. 
(Res. of 10-15-74; Res. of 9-5-78)  
Sec. 6-1-2. - Jacob Purdy Park and House and White Plains Monument Committee. 
(a)  The land temporarily known as the Kirby-Ridge Park being the property shown on the tax assessment map of The City of White Plains known as lots 1A, 1C, 2H, 2I, 8, 9, and 10, block 22, ward 4, be designated as the Jacob Purdy Park. 
(b)  The commissioner of recreation and parks shall be ex officio a member of The Battle of White Plains Monument Committee, Inc. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized on behalf of the city to enter into an agreement with The Battle of White Plains Monument Committee, Inc., in relation to the Purdy House which agreement shall read substantially as follows: 
AGREEMENT made as of the ________ day of _______, 1973, between THE CITY OF WHITE PLAINS, a municipal corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of New York, having its principal office at the Municipal Building, 255 Main Street, White Plains, New York (the "city"); and 
THE BATTLE OF WHITE PLAINS MONUMENT COMMITTEE, INC., a not-for-profit corporation, organized and existing under the laws of the State of New York, having its principal office at Buckout Road, White Plains, New York (the "committee"); 
WITNESSETH: 
WHEREAS, on August 8, 1973, in order to preserve the Purdy House as an historic structure the committee conveyed to the city all their right, title and interest in and to the said structure; and 
WHEREAS, the city agreed that it would restore and perpetually maintain the Purdy House for historical purposes; 
NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual promises contained herein it is covenanted and agreed by the parties hereto as follows: 
1.  As long as the committee remains a chartered non-profit corporation it shall have exclusive control of all activities conducted therein, the maintenance thereof, the furnishings placed within the Purdy House and the custodial care of the Purdy House. 
2.  The committee further agrees that should its charter be revoked, terminated or suspended, or should the committee determine that it be unable to continue the maintenance and operation of said house for historical purposes, this agreement will be deemed to have terminated. 
IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have executed this agreement as of the date first above written. 
THE CITY OF 
WHITE PLAINS 
BY _______ 
THE BATTLE OF 
WHITE PLAINS 
MONUMENT 
COMMITTEE,INC. 
BY 
(Acknowledgments to be added) 
(Ord. of 9-4-73, § 3)  
Chapter 6-2 - PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS 
 
Sec. 6-2-1. - Definitions. 
The term "city school district" as used in this chapter shall be deemed to mean the city school district of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 1)  
Sec. 6-2-2. - Intoxicants and alcoholic beverages. 
No person shall bring into, sell, give away, display or drink, or cause, permit or procure to be sold, given away, displayed or drunk, any alcoholic or spirituous liquors or beverages in any park, playground, sports field of the city or city school district or any other property of the city school district, except only as may be permitted by the commissioner of recreation and parks of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 2)  
Sec. 6-2-3. - Loitering at night. 
No person shall loiter or remain within any park, playground or sports field of the city between 11:00 p.m. and one (1) hour before sunrise without permission, except that the commissioner of recreation and parks shall have the authority to designate those parks, playgrounds and sports fields which shall be closed one (1) hour after sunset. No person shall loiter or remain on any city school district property between one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise except for the running tracks at White Plains High School, White Plains Middle School and White Plains Intermediate School where they are permitted until 11:00 p.m.; provided that persons may remain within any of the aforementioned properties at any time when in attendance at an activity being staged, supervised or sanctioned by the department of recreation and parks or the city school district. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 3)  
Sec. 6-2-4. - Camping and overnight sleeping. 
No person shall tent or camp or erect or maintain a tent, shelter or camp in any city or city school district park, playground, or sports fields unless said camp or overnight sleeping be part of a special program sponsored, sanctioned or supervised by the department of recreation and parks or the city school district. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 4)  
Sec. 6-2-5. - Fires. 
No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire in a city or city school district park, playground, or sports field except that charcoal cooking fires shall be permitted in reserved picnic areas specified by the department of recreation and parks or the city school district. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person over eighteen (18) years of age from the time it is kindled until it is completely extinguished. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 5)  
Sec. 6-2-6. - Operation of vehicles in paths, grass and surfaced areas. 
No motorized vehicle of any kind except a city school district vehicle, emergency vehicle or city vehicle shall be allowed or permitted on any park, sidewalk, walkway, or trail maintained for pedestrians or on any grass area of any park or property of the city or city school district; nor shall said vehicle be permitted on running tracks, tennis courts, or other off-limit areas owned by the city or city school district. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 6)  
Sec. 6-2-7. - Bicycling. 
Bicycling in parks, playgrounds and sports fields shall be permitted, except where prohibited by the commissioner of recreation and parks. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 6-a)  
Sec. 6-2-8. - Preservation of trees, shrubs, and grass. 
No person shall destroy, cut, pick, deface, mutilate, injure, disturb, or remove any plant, flower bed, shrub, tree, plant growth or any branch, stem, fruit or leaf thereof located in any park; or pile or maintain any material or debris of any kind against or upon the same; or attach any rope, cable or other contrivance thereto; or set fire or assist another to set fire to any timber, tree, shrubs, plants, flowers, grass, or plant growth, or suffer any fire upon other lands to extend to any park, playground, sports field or turf area owned by the city or city school district. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 7)  
Sec. 6-2-9. - Littering prohibited. 
No person shall throw, dump, deposit or place or cause to be thrown, dumped, deposited or placed upon any park, playground, sports field or similar area owned by the city or city school district any refuse, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter or any nauseous or offensive matter. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 8)  
Sec. 6-2-10. - Dogs and other pets prohibited. 
The presence of dogs and other pets within any park, playground, sports field of the city or any other property of the city school district is hereby prohibited except when in attendance at an activity being staged, supervised or sanctioned by the department of recreation and parks or the city school district. Dogs and other pets on leashes are restricted to walkways of the aforementioned properties only for the purpose of traversing said properties. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 9)  
Sec. 6-2-11. - Prohibited uses of parks, playgrounds and sports fields. 
No person shall use in any manner whatsoever any park, playground or sports fields, turf or hard-surface area owned by the city or city school district, or any building thereon for any illegal, immoral or bawdy purpose, or for any purpose in violation of any federal, state or municipal law, ordinance, rule, or regulation, now in effect or hereafter adopted. There shall be no golfing, or archery, except with the written permission of the commissioner of recreation and parks or the superintendent of schools. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 10; Ord. of 5-4-92, § 1)  
Sec. 6-2-12. - Sport field permits. 
Organized groups using city parks or school district facilities shall have valid permits to use the facilities. An organized group shall mean any team use of city or school facilities by a municipality, corporation, organization, club or sports team playing or practicing for and in competition with others in or out of uniform. The casual use of city and school facilities by White Plains residents will be permitted providing these sport fields have not had valid permits issued for their use to others. 
Only valid permit holders may use voice amplification equipment or other electronic equipment when authorized on the permit by the commissioner of recreation and parks or the superintendent of schools. 
All sport field permits are subject to being revoked due to weather conditions as determined by city or school district representatives. 
Sale or distribution of any food items or merchandise without the written permission of the commissioner of recreation and parks or the superintendent of schools is prohibited. 
Valid permit holders must remove from the premises any refuse or waste emanating from the players or spectators. Such refuse and rubbish shall be deposited in receptacles so provided. Where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the premises by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. Failure to remove any refuse or waste by the permit holder will be grounds for the denial of a permit for future activities. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 10-a; Ord. of 5-4-92, § 2)  
Sec. 6-2-13. - Parking. 
The parking of any motor vehicle on city park, ballfield, playground or city school district property is prohibited, except at such places designated as parking areas, and at such times the parking of said vehicles is permitted, to wit, when said site is open for regular operation or when the occupant of said vehicle will attend a gathering, function or special event being staged therein by the city or city school district. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 11)  
Sec. 6-2-14. - Police access during school hours. 
(a)  Members of the city police department shall not enforce this chapter in respect to city school district property during the hours that students are in attendance at regularly scheduled classes without the expressed request of the school principal or his or her designee. 
(b)  This section authorizes the White Plains Police Department to be the complainant in the enforcement of all matters contained in this chapter, within their ability to do so, on school district property during the hours that students are not in attendance at regularly scheduled classes or at the expressed request of the school principal or his or her designee. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 13; Ord. of 5-4-92, § 2)  
Sec. 6-2-15. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a violation and on the first conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) in amount, or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. 
(Ord. of 5-19-80, § 12)  
Chapter 6-3 - RECREATIONAL PROGRAM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Power of commissioner of parks and recreation to make rules and regulations governing parks, § 238-b. 
 
Sec. 6-3-1. - Generally. 
(a)  The White Plains Department of Recreation and Parks provides an extensive publicly financed program of recreational activities that are planned, organized and operated to serve all city residents. The department also operates city parks and other assigned city-owned properties. 
(b)  Insofar as possible, it is the intent of the city government to provide programs and facilities without cost to residents. However, there are programs and services desired by many city residents that generate leadership, maintenance and operating costs beyond the general funding capability of the city. Under these circumstances and in situations where proper control of participation relates closely to equitable facility use and program continuity, the additional funds required must be secured from the actual participants through a system of charges and fees. 
(c)  To permit these expanded programs and services and guarantee their availability to residents on a first priority basis, the commissioner of the department of recreation and parks, subject to the supervision and control of the common council, shall establish and maintain a system to properly control program and facility operations. He shall also, subject to the supervision and control of the common council, establish and maintain a uniform system of charges and fees for special programs and facility use. These charges and fees shall be set at the lowest possible levels consistent with proper operating standards. Fees and charges established in accordance with this policy shall either be waived or reduced for senior adults. 
(d)  Under this policy, the commissioner of the department of recreation and parks may, in response to changing needs, initiate programs that are not funded in the current budget by extending the charges and fees system. Programs so initiated shall be carefully evaluated and, where justified, presented to the common council for possible funding during the next fiscal year. Annually, all programs and services involving charges and fees shall be evaluated and considered in a similar manner since it is the intent of this policy to evolve a system of charges and fees that will stimulate resident use and enjoyment of their parks and recreation programs. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79; Ord. of 6-2-03, § 1)  
Sec. 6-3-2. - Permits generally. 
(a)  By providing proof of residency, permits in the form of a plastic laminated, wallet-size card featuring a recent photo of the individual and carrying other essential information will be issued and used to control program and facility operations. Upon presentation, the holder will be entitled to special rates for program participation and facility use. The I.D. card may also, upon payment of an applicable fee, be validated to entitle the holder to seasonal program and facility use without further payments. 
(b)  Permits will be issued pursuant to the fees as fixed by the common council in the budget ordinance of the City of White Plains pursuant to the fee schedule filed with the city clerk by the commissioner of recreation and parks and deemed part of the budget. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79; Res. of 5-25-94)  
Sec. 6-3-3. - Charges and fees. 
The charges and fees for the programs organized and operated by the department of recreation and parks shall be fixed by the common council in the budget ordinance of the City of White Plains pursuant to the fee schedule filed with the city clerk by the commissioner of recreation and parks and deemed part of the budget. Advance deposit may be required at the discretion of the commissioner. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79; Res. of 5-25-94)  
Chapter 6-4 - PROHIBITING SMOKING AND VAPING IN SPECIFIED CITY-OWNED OUTDOOR AREAS IN THE CITY OF WHITE PLAINS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted Aug. 6, 2018, amended the title of Ch. 6-4 to read as herein set out. The former Ch. 6-4 pertained to prohibition of smoking in outdoor areas owned by the City of White Plains. 
 
Sec. 6-4-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
(1)  Park means city-owned parks, playgrounds, playing fields, trails, and recreation areas. Parking lots are not included within the definition herein. 
(2)  Playground means a city-owned outdoor recreation area that is designed and intended for use by children. For the purposes of this chapter, a city-owned playground that is fenced or otherwise physically demarcated shall be deemed to include all of the area inside such fence or demarcation; a city-owned playground that is not fenced or otherwise demarcated shall be deemed to include all open space that is associated with or adjacent to it. 
(3)  Playing field means that portion of an outdoor recreation area owned by the City of White Plains that is set up and marked in some way for the playing of one (1) or more specific games (such as baseball, football or soccer) and open to the general public. For the purposes of this chapter, a playing field owned by the city that is fenced or the outside perimeter of which is otherwise physically demarcated shall be deemed to include all of the area inside such fence or demarcation, together with any bleachers or other, designated viewing area; a playing field that is not fenced or otherwise demarcated (as to its outside perimeter) shall be deemed to include all of the area customarily required for playing the game for which it is being used, together with any bleachers or other designated viewing area. 
(4)  Recreational area means any outdoor area that is owned by the city and open to the general public for recreational purposes, regardless of any fee or age requirement. The term "recreational area" includes but is not limited to city-owned playing fields, playgrounds, parks, plazas, picnic areas, walking paths, gardens, hiking trails, and bike paths. 
(5)  Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated cigar, cigarette, or pipe, or any other lighted or heated tobacco intended for inhalation, in any manner or in any form. 
(6)  Vaping means the use of an electronic cigarette or e-cigarette. 
(7)  Electronic cigarette or e-cigarette means an electronic device that delivers vapor which is inhaled by an individual user and shall include any refill cartridge and any other component of such device. 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-18, § 2 )  
Sec. 6-4-2. - Prohibition of smoking and vaping in outdoor areas owned by the City of White Plains. 
(1)  Smoking and vaping is prohibited in all of the following public places owned by the City of White Plains: 
(a)  Parks; 
(b)  Playgrounds; 
(c)  Playing fields; 
(d)  Plazas, including, but not limited to the area near the White Plains Library, and the fountain area at the corner of Main and Mamaroneck Avenue; 
(e)  The Greenway and other trails; and 
(f)  Recreational areas. 
(2)  The sidewalks immediately adjoining but not traversing parks, playgrounds, playing fields, plazas, trails, and recreation centers are excluded from the smoking and vaping prohibition contained herein. 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-18, § 3 )  
Sec. 6-4-3. - Other requirements and prohibitions. 
No ashtray, or other smoking and vaping waste receptacle shall be placed in any area in which smoking is prohibited by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-18, § 4 )  
Sec. 6-4-4. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(1)  The remedies provided by this chapter are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity. 
(2)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense punishable by the following penalties: 
1st offense: $50.00 
2nd offense: $75.00 
3rd or subsequent offense: $100.00 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-18, § 5 )  
Sec. 6-4-5. - Statutory construction and severability. 
The provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable, and if any section of this chapter is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions of this chapter that can be given effect without the invalidated provision. 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1)  
Sec. 6-4-6. - Effective date. 
The effective date of this chapter shall be thirty (30) days from the date of its enactment. 
(Ord. of 6-6-11, § 1)

Chapter 7-2 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES GENERALLY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; what are deemed public streets, § 120. 
Cross reference— Removal of dog feces from public places, § 5-2-17. 
 
Sec. 7-2-1. - Snow removal by owners of abutting property. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any lot or premises abutting or adjoining any public street, alley, park or place within the city to clean and keep free from snow, ice, dirt and debris or other foreign matter, the sidewalk in front of or adjoining said lot or premises. Should the snow cease to fall or the foreign matter be deposited in the daytime, such removal shall be completed within two (2) hours after such fall or deposit, if the abutting or adjoining lot or premises is a place of business, or is within a "B," "BR," "CB," "UR," "OR," "CO" or "LI" District of the zoning ordinance, and within ten (10) hours if the abutting or adjoining lot or premises is within any other district of the zoning ordinance. Should the snow cease to fall or the foreign matter be deposited in the nighttime, such removal shall be done before 10:00 the next morning if the abutting or adjoining lot or premises is a place of business, or is within a "B," "BR," "CB," "UR," "OR," "CO" or "LI" District of the zoning ordinance, or before 12:00 noon if the abutting or adjoining lot or premises is within any other district of the zoning ordinance. In the event the snow and ice on the sidewalk shall be frozen so hard that it cannot be removed without injury to the sidewalk, the owner or occupant of said lot or premises shall cause the sidewalk to be strewn with ashes, sand or some other approved abrasive material and shall as soon thereafter as the weather shall permit, thoroughly clean such sidewalk. 
(b)  The owner or occupant of any hereinabove described lot or premises may place in the gutter only the fallen snow that has been removed from the sidewalk area. 
(c)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall, on conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than thirty-five dollars ($35.00) or more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. of 12-19-66, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 10-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 5-3-10, § 1) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37; lien for cleaning snow and ice from walks, § 160. 
Cross reference— Amount in annual budget for snow removal by city, § 2-4-16; zoning, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-2-2. - Driving vehicles on closed streets. 
(a)  All persons are hereby forbidden from driving or operating any vehicle upon or through that portion of any street, avenue, highway or public place of the city which has been closed by order of the commissioner of public works. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed as forbidding a street railway from operating upon its tracks in such closed street, avenue, highway or public place where other provisions have not been made, nor shall anything herein contained forbid egress or ingress to any property bounded upon such street providing no egress and ingress may not be had in any other manner. 
(c)  Violations of any provisions of this section shall be a misdemeanor and shall be punished upon conviction by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not exceeding twenty-five (25) days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 8-16-17, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 5-3-93) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 7-2-3. - Skateboarding, playing ball, etc., on street. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section the term "street" shall include the entire right-of-way as shown on the official map of the city. 
(b)  No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any sleigh, sliding device, coaster, toy vehicle, skateboard or similar device shall go in any municipal parking facility or upon any street, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(c)  No person shall play ball or any game or sport with a ball, football, or any other object, or throw, cast or propel any missile or any other object, in, over, across, along or upon any street in the city. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and, on the first conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00) in amount or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. 
(Ord. of 2-20-67, §§ 1—4; Ord. of 3-2-92, § 1) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4; penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37. 
Cross reference— Official plan, § 9-3-1.  
Chapter 7-3 - STREET, SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY REPAIR, EXCAVATION, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Waiver of fee for certain public agencies authorized, § 2-1-3; prohibition of illicit discharges, activities and connections to the City of White Plains' municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4), Ch. 7-7; notice of excavations for water lines, § 7-8-7. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 7-3-1. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms as used in this chapter shall mean as indicated below: 
(a)  Commissioner shall mean the commissioner of public works, or his duly authorized representative. 
(b)  Permit shall refer to the written permission issued with the approval and signature of the commissioner of public works and specifically authorizing a person to perform certain work or in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Permittee shall mean the person obtaining a permit, or his duly authorized representative. 
(d)  The words directed, required, permitted, ordered, designated, selected, prescribed, determined, certified, specified, or words of like import used in this article shall mean, respectively, the direction, requirement, permission, order, designation, selection, prescription, determination, certification or specification of the commissioner of public works. 
(e)  The words approved, authorized, acceptable, satisfactory, equal, necessary, adequate, suitable, competent, or words of like import shall mean respectively, approved by, authorized by, acceptable to, satisfactory to, equal to, or necessary, adequate, suitable or competent in the opinion of the commissioner of public works. 
(f)  Sanitary sewer shall refer to the lateral or street sewer or manhole built thereon in public street, highway, sidewalk area, easement or other public area, and under the control of the city. 
(g)  Sewer service line shall mean the pipe or conduit laid between its connection point on a sanitary sewer and a building for the purpose of conducting domestic sewage and noninjurious water liquids from the said building into the said sanitary sewer. 
(h)  Stormwater drain shall refer to the lateral or main stormwater drain in public street, highway, sidewalk area, easement or other public area, and under the control of the city. 
(i)  Drainage service line shall refer to the pipe or conduit laid between its connection point on a stormwater drain and a building or property for the purpose of conducting waste other than domestic sewage and other than injurious water liquids from the said building or property into the said stormwater drain. 
(j)  Invert shall mean the lowest point in the internal cross-section of a sanitary sewer, storm-water drain, house sewer or drain. 
(k)  Sidewalk drain and curb drain shall refer to the pipe or other conduit laid under or across the sidewalk area between the curb or curb line and the property line for the purpose of conducting roof and surface water from buildings and ground into the gutter. 
(l)  A public service corporation is a gas corporation, electric corporation, gas and electric corporation, steam corporation, and telephone or telegraph corporation operating an agency or agencies for public service, subject to the jurisdiction, supervision and regulations prescribed by or pursuant to the Public Service Law. 
(m)  The phrase, R-0, R-1, and R-2 and R-3 districts when used in this article shall mean and include any residence-one- and two-family or residence-one-family use zone in which the minimum size of lot per family as prescribed by the zoning ordinance is not less than five thousand (5,000) square feet for a one-family dwelling. 
(n)  Plate shall mean a temporary cover approved by the commissioner to provide a traffic surface over an unclosed street opening. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 1; Ord. of 11-3-69, § 1; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 1; Ord. of 11-14-96, § 1) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-2. - Notice to gas company and commissioner prior to doing work; inspections; work on holidays. 
(a)  Except for emergencies governed by section 322-a. of the General Business Law or section 7-3-46 of this Code, a permittee shall not begin or carry on any part of work provided to be done under any permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter until the written notices required to be delivered to the person or corporation engaged in the distribution of gas in the territory involved have been duly given, at least seventy-two (72) hours in advance, to such company and a copy thereof has been filed with the office of the commissioner and the commissioner's approval to commence work under said permit has been endorsed upon said permit. The copy of such notice delivered to the commissioner shall have endorsed thereon a signed statement by the applicant or permittee attesting to the delivery of such notice to such person or corporation engaged in the distribution of gas. At the time of application for a permit, the commissioner shall notify the applicant of the name and address of such person or corporation engaged in the distribution of gas in such territory. 
(b)  The commissioner shall not be required to inspect any work done under the provisions of the chapter unless the permittee shall have given said commissioner not less than twenty-four (24) hours' notice that said work is ready for inspection. 
(c)  No work provided to be done under the said permit shall be performed on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays except with the prior approval of the commissioner or in the event of an emergency as described herein. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 2; Ord. of 8-4-54, § 2; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 1; Ord. of 11-3-69, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-3. - Restrictions as to time of doing work. 
(a)  No street openings, street obstructions or maintenance operations will be allowed in streets located in or contiguous to any B District or C District, exclusive of C-O Campus Office District, as set forth in the zoning ordinance, nor in streets designated as county roads, on any day during the period beginning on the second Monday preceding Thanksgiving Day and ending on the first day of January, on any day during the week immediately preceding Easter Sunday, nor, in the discretion of the commissioner, on days occurring during periods of unusually heavy traffic, except in cases of emergency specifically certified by the commissioner. 
(b)  Any such emergency work, if and when authorized as provided above, shall be restricted to Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless otherwise authorized by the commissioner and no material or equipment shall be allowed to obstruct the normal flow of traffic between said hours. 
(c)  In all such cases work is to be completed and any obstruction removed, and trenches or other areas must be temporarily resurfaced at close of work or not later than the final day of effective period of permit except as otherwise authorized in advance by the commissioner. 
(d)  In the event that openings have not been backfilled and satisfactorily resurfaced, or obstructions removed, on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays or during periods of unusually heavy traffic volume or at the expiration of effective period of permit as provided above, the city reserves the right to backfill and resurface such openings or to remove such obstructions, by contract or otherwise, at permittee's own expense. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 2-a; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 1) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-4. - Expenses incurred by city. 
(a)  Any expenses that may be incurred by the city in connection with any inspection and/or other expenses incurred by the city in connection with the work to be done under the provisions of the permit and/or in the enforcement of this chapter or by reason of the failure or default on the part of the permittee, as determined and certified by the commissioner, shall be paid by the permittee within ten (10) days after the commissioner shall have sent the permittee a statement of such expenses. 
(b)  If not paid by the permittee within the above specified period, the said expenses shall be deducted from the deposit as herein otherwise provided for. 
(c)  The commissioner may, at his discretion, assign a representative to inspect, on behalf of the city, the work to be done under the provisions of any permit granted to a permittee, in which case such permittee shall pay, in addition to the fees provided in section 7-3-43 of this Code, to the city by check payable to the city, a weekly amount to be determined and established by the commissioner for each week or fraction thereof that such work shall be in progress, as payment for such inspection. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 3; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 1; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-5. - Materials. 
(a)  All materials used or incorporated in any work done under the provisions of this chapter shall conform to such specifications as may be promulgated by the commissioner. 
(b)  In general, the current standard specifications of the department of public works shall be followed, subject to the prior approval of the commissioner before these materials are incorporated in the work. 
(c)  Materials shall, at the discretion of the commissioner, be submitted to such tests as may in his opinion be necessary to determine their quality and acceptability. Such tests may be made in any laboratory designated by the commissioner and the city shall be reimbursed by the permittee for any expense incurred by said city on account of such tests. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 4)  
Sec. 7-3-6. - Performance of work to be at permittee's expense; compliance with other laws. 
All work related to any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be performed by the permittee at said permittee's own expense and strictly in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and ordinances of the city, the applicable rules and regulations of the department of public works and such specifications as may be promulgated by the commissioner, and to the satisfaction of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 5)  
Sec. 7-3-7. - Permit to be exhibited. 
The permit shall be exhibited on the job site to the commissioner or to any authorized representative of the city upon request. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 6; Ord. of 10-16-72)  
Sec. 7-3-8. - Transfer of permit. 
A permit shall not be assigned or transferred except upon the prior written consent of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 8)  
Sec. 7-3-9. - Revocation of permits. 
The commissioner shall have the right to revoke or cancel a permit at any time should the permittee fail to comply with any of the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions thereof. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 7)  
Sec. 7-3-10. - Cleaning up and top soil restoration. 
(a)  A permittee shall clean up and remove promptly from the site of the work, upon completion thereof, all surplus excavated material and debris, and shall leave the site of the work in a neat and orderly condition. 
(b)  Where top soil, seeded areas or sod are disturbed in the course of the work, the permittee shall restore the ground surfaces to a condition as good as they were previously. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, § 9)  
Sec. 7-3-11. - Payment of fees by public service corporation. 
(a)  A public service corporation may, in lieu of payment of fees required by sections 7-3-21 through 7-3-56 or 7-3-86 through 7-3-94 of this Code, file and keep on file with the commissioner of public works an agreement, approved as to form by the corporation counsel, to pay such fees monthly to the city, upon being billed by the commissioner of public works for the amount of fees due on permits taken out by such public service corporation during the preceding month. Such bills shall be paid within thirty (30) days after same shall have been rendered by the commissioner. 
(b)  A public service corporation shall not be required to pay the fees otherwise prescribed in this article where the said corporation is required to relocate its facilities at its own cost and expense in connection with, and within the limits of, a street improvement project or other public works project carried on by the city, county or the state when said relocation is made necessary by said project. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. I, §§ 10, 11; Ord. of 8-5-68, § 1; Ord. of 11-3-69, § 3)  
Sec. 7-3-12. - Penalty. 
Any person doing or permitting to be done or causing to be done any act or thing contrary to the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be guilty of a violation and, on the first conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in amount, or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or both such fine and/or imprisonment, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be guilty of a violation and shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) in amount or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or both fine and imprisonment for each such violation. Every violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a separate and distinct offense and, in case of continuing violation, every day's continuance thereof, shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VIII; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 8; Ord. of 5-30-19, § 2, eff. 7-1-19 ) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 7-3-13. - Stop work orders. 
(a)  The city may issue a stop work order for violations of this Chapter. Persons receiving a stop work order shall be required to halt all land development or redevelopment activities, except those activities that address the violations leading to the stop work order. The stop work order shall be in effect until the city confirms that the land development or redevelopment activity is in compliance and the violation has been satisfactorily addressed. Failure to address a stop work order in a timely manner may result in civil, criminal, or monetary penalties in accordance with the enforcement measures authorized in this chapter. 
(b)  Any work done without a required permit shall be subject to a five hundred dollar ($500.00) additional fee in addition to all applicable permit fees. 
(Ord. of 5-30-13, § 1, eff. 7-1-13)  
Secs. 7-3-14—7-3-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK, CURB AND DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION, REMOVAL, REPLACEMENT OR REPAIR 
 
Sec. 7-3-21. - Permit required. 
No person shall construct, remove, replace or repair a sidewalk, curb or driveway within the limits of any public street, highway or other public property, without first obtaining therefor from the commissioner a written permit. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-22. - Expiration and extension of permit. 
The permit required by the provisions of this article shall be valid for a period, not to exceed thirty (30) consecutive calendar days, to be determined and specified therein by the commissioner. Such period may be extended, if so requested in writing by the permittee prior to expiration thereof, for such additional period as the commissioner, at the latter's discretion, may authorize. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-23. - Application for permit. 
Any person desiring the permit required by the provisions of this article for such work shall make application to the commissioner upon forms provided for that purpose. The application shall contain: 
(1)  The names and addresses of the applicant and of the owner of the property in front of which or for whom the work is to be performed; 
(2)  The location of such property, the ward, block and lot designation thereof; 
(3)  The extent and nature of the work to be done; 
(4)  The date or dates when the work is to be done; 
(5)  Such necessary sketches and additional information as the commissioner may require; and 
(6)  A signed statement by the applicant that the applicant agrees to perform the work for which the permit is granted strictly in accordance with the conditions of the permit, the provisions of the charter and the ordinances of the city and the applicable rules and regulations of the department of public works, and that the city is to be saved harmless from any loss, injury or damage arising out of the granting of the permit or from any negligence or fault of said applicant, his servants or agents, in connection with any of the work done under or in connection with the permit. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-24. - Fees. 
No permit for the construction, removal, replacement or repair of a sidewalk, curb or driveway shall be issued by the commissioner until the applicant pays to the commissioner, in cash or by check payable to the city, a fee of one hundred and seventy-five dollars ($175.00) or ten (10) per cent of amount of deposit, whichever is greater, when such work, or any part thereof, is to be performed in streets located in or contiguous to any district other than the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 districts, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city; no fee shall be required for the construction, removal, replacement or repair of such portion of a driveway or curb located within the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 zoning districts, the limits of a county road under the jurisdiction of the county commissioner of public works, or within the limits of a state highway under the jurisdiction of the state superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, § 2-a; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 2; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 2; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 1; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 1) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-25. - Deposits. 
(a)  No permit for the construction, removal, replacement or repair of a sidewalk, curb or driveway shall be issued by the commissioner until the applicant has paid to the commissioner, in cash or by check payable to the city, a deposit in an amount to be determined in accordance with the following unit prices for work to be done as determined by the commissioner: 
SIDEWALK to be constructed, removed, replaced or repaired, for each square foot ..... $25.00 
DRIVEWAY to be constructed, removed, replaced or repaired, for each lineal foot ..... 30.00 
CURB to be constructed, removed, replaced or repaired, for each lineal foot ..... 75.00 
DEPRESSED CURB — lowering, raising or cutting curb, or setting depressed curb for driveway entrance, for each lineal foot ..... 75.00 
TREES to be replaced (other than in R-0, R-1, R-2 and R-3 districts), for each tree ..... 750.00 
MINIMUM AMOUNT OF DEPOSIT ..... 250.00 
(b)  The amount of deposit, and minimum amount thereof, noted above, shall be doubled when such work, or any part thereof, is to be performed in front of property in a district other than the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5, and R2-4 districts, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city, except that no deposit shall be required for the construction, removal, replacement or repair of such portion of a driveway or curb located within the limits of a county road under the jurisdiction of the county commissioner of public works or within the limits of a state highway under the jurisdiction of the state superintendent of public works. 
(c)  The deposit shall be retained by the city until the final completion of the work to be done pursuant to the terms of the permit, as security for the faithful performance by the applicant of all the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on the applicant's part to be done or performed. Upon the failure or default by the permittee of any of the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on its part to be done and performed, said deposit may be used by the city for any expense incurred by the city by reason of such failure or default on the part of the permittee. 
(d)  Any balance left after the expense of such failure or default, as determined and certified by the commissioner, has been paid and deducted from the amount of the deposit shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 3; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 3; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 3; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 2; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 2) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-26. - Work to conform with city specifications. 
(a)  Sidewalks, curbs and driveways shall be constructed, removed, replaced or repaired in accordance with such grades and specifications as may be determined or promulgated by the commissioner and the permittee shall perform the work so as to meet the grade and alignment of the adjoining sidewalk, curb and driveway and/or such established line and grade as may be determined by the commissioner and in accordance with the latter's directions. 
(b)  In general, the current standard specifications of the department of public works shall be followed, subject to the prior approval of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 4)  
Sec. 7-3-27. - Depressed curb for driveway entrance. 
(a)  Upon prior written approval of the commissioner and subject to the provisions of this chapter, existing curbs may be cut or lowered, as provided herein, for the purpose of providing driveway entrances or exits. 
(b)  Bluestone and granite curbs shall not be cut, but shall be lowered in an acceptable manner. Concrete curbs may be cut if so authorized by the commissioner and provided such cutting can be done in a workmanlike and satisfactory manner. 
(c)  The cutting or lowering of existing curbs, or the construction of new depressed curbs, for the purpose of providing driveway entrances or exits shall not be allowed unless the permittee shall provide and install in each such case, an adequate driveway ramp or apron between the said curb and the abutting property line and extending over the entire width of the existing or proposed driveway. 
(d)  The driveway ramp or apron shall be surfaced with reinforced concrete seven (7) inches in thickness, or macadam at least four (4) inches in thickness, or not less than two (2) inches of bituminous surfacing material over four (4) inches of crushed stone, of satisfactory workmanship and construction. 
(e)  The portion of a curb so depressed shall not exceed in length such limits as shall be established by the commissioner, in the latter's discretion. 
(f)  The portion of driveway ramp or apron common with the sidewalk and forming a part thereof shall, unless otherwise authorized, consist of reinforced concrete seven (7) inches in thickness. 
(g)  When a depressed curb or portion thereof is no longer used or needed for driveway entrance purposes, the owner of property fronting thereon shall, upon the written order of the commissioner and within thirty (30) days following such written order, raise and restore such depressed curb or such portion thereof to its full height to conform with adjoining curbs or to such grade as shall be established by the commissioner. 
(h)  Failure of said owner to comply with such written order of the commissioner within the time specified hereinabove shall constitute a violation of this chapter and the owner shall thereupon be subject to the penalty provided for violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 5; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 3)  
Sec. 7-3-28. - Trees removed for driveway purposes. 
Whenever it becomes necessary to remove a tree on city property in order to construct, replace or repair a sidewalk or driveway, the permittee shall furnish and plant a new tree for each tree removed, of a species and size acceptable and in an approved location, in front of or adjoining the permittee's property. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 5-a; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 4; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1) 
Cross reference— Zoning ordinance, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-29. - Pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
Pedestrian and vehicular traffic is to be adequately protected by the permittee by means of suitable protective barricades and lighted red lanterns around the work and the work is to be so arranged as to cause a minimum of inconvenience and hazard to such pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. II, § 6)  
Secs. 7-3-30—7-3-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STREET, SIDEWALK, ETC., OPENINGS AND EXCAVATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7-3-41. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall open or cause to be opened, by cutting or excavating, the surface or soil of any street, highway, sidewalk area or public ground for any purpose whatsoever without first obtaining therefor from the commissioner a written permit for street opening except, however, that the construction, removal, replacement, or repair of a sidewalk, curb or driveway shall be done under a permit for sidewalk, curb or driveway, as set forth in sections 7-3-21 through 7-3-29 of this Code, in lieu of a permit for street opening. 
(b)  No person shall make or cause to be made any connection into a sanitary sewer, storm-water drain or water main in an easement or right-of-way across private property, said sanitary sewer, storm-water drain or water main forming a part of the sewer, drainage or water distribution system, respectively, of the city, without first obtaining from the commissioner a written permit for street opening. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-42. - Application for permit. 
Any person desiring a permit for street opening shall make application therefor to the commissioner for each such opening upon forms to be provided for that purpose. The application shall contain: 
(1)  The names and addresses of the applicant and of the owner of the property in front of which or for whom the work is to be performed; 
(2)  The location of such property, the ward, block and lot designation thereof; 
(3)  The size and purpose of the opening to be made and the maximum size of such opening; 
(4)  The dates when the work is to be performed; 
(5)  The type of pavement or surface to be disturbed; 
(6)  Such necessary sketches and additional information as the commissioner may require; and 
(7)  A signed statement by the applicant that the said applicant agrees to perform the work for which the permit is granted strictly in accordance with the conditions of the permit, the provisions of the charter and of the ordinances of the city and the applicable rules and regulations of the department of public works. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-43. - Deposit and fees—Generally. 
No permit for street opening shall be issued by the commissioner until the applicant therefor shall have first paid to the commissioner, in cash or by check payable to the city: 
(a)  A deposit to be determined as provided herein and to be furnished by the applicant only, unless otherwise authorized personally by the commissioner; and 
(b)  A fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) or ten (10) per cent of amount of deposit, whichever shall be greater, or in the case of a public service corporation, which shall file a bond in lieu of a deposit, in accordance with section 7-3-46 of this Code, said fee shall be eight dollars ($8.00) per lineal foot of street opening or three hundred dollars ($300.00) whichever is greater; no fee shall be charged a public service corporation for the installation or relocation of poles. Said fee is to cover the cost of issuing and recording the permit and the supervision and inspection of the work done in connection therewith. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 4; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 3; Ord. of 7-5-55, § 1; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 5; Ord. of 11-3-69, § 5; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 3; Ord. of 2-5-73, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 3; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 3; Ord. of > 5-17-16 , § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-44. - Same—Calculation generally, disposition, etc., of deposit. 
(a)  The amount of deposit for street openings shall be computed in accordance with the following unit prices for pavements or other areas to be disturbed or work to be done, as determined by the commissioner, except that no deposit shall be required in the case of an opening made in an area other than a sidewalk, located within the limits of a county road under the jurisdiction of the county commissioner of public works, or within the limits of a state highway under the jurisdiction of the state commissioner of transportation, nor shall a deposit be required for connecting to a storm-water drain or other structure under the jurisdiction of said county commissioner of public works or state commissioner of transportation: 
CONCRETE OR REINFORCED CONCRETE pavement to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... $150.00 
PLANT-MIXED OR HOT-MIXED BITUMINOUS surfaced pavement to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... 125.00 
ASPHALTIC MACADAM pavement to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... 125.00 
BRICK PAVEMENT to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... 125.00 
ALL OTHER TYPES OF PAVEMENT to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... 100.00 
UNPAVED surfaces, of any type, to be disturbed, for each square yard ..... 30.00 
SIDEWALKS, bituminous to be disturbed, for each square foot ..... 20.00 
SIDEWALKS, other types, to be disturbed, other than for the installation of underground storage tanks, for each square foot ..... 25.00 
GUTTERS (brick) to be disturbed, for each square foot ..... 30.00 
GUTTERS (other types) to be disturbed, for each square foot ..... 25.00 
CURBING (bituminous) to be disturbed, for each lineal foot ..... 40.00 
CURBING GRANITE (saw-cut) to be disturbed, for each lineal foot ..... 60.00 
CURBING (other types) to be disturbed, for each lineal foot ..... 40.00 
STRUCTURES—connection to existing manhole, catch basin or other structure, for each separate connection ..... 600.00 
STRUCTURES—construction of new manhole, catch basin or other structure, for each separate structure ..... 3,500.00 
TRENCHING in any type of street surface within street right-of-way (including sidewalk area) and in addition to above specified deposits: 
(a)  Where total depth is five (5) feet or less below pavement surface, for each lineal foot of trench ..... 60.00 
(b)  Where total depth is greater than five (5) feet and not more than twenty (20) feet below pavement surface, for each lineal foot of trench ..... 150.00 
(c)  Where depth is greater than twenty (20) feet below pavement surface, for each lineal foot of trench ..... 200.00 
TEST BORINGS on any public street or other public area, for each boring hole ..... 150.00 
CONNECTION of sewer service line or drainage service to cast iron pipe sanitary sewer or stormwater drain, for each separate connection ..... 350.00 
CONNECTION of sewer service line or drainage service line to other type of sanitary sewer or stormwater drain, for each separate connection ..... 275.00 
INSTALLATION OF UNDERGROUND VAULTS in sidewalk areas, for each square foot of overall horizontal surface disturbed ..... 350.00 
and not less than minimum of ..... 4,000.00 
EXCAVATION RELATED TO BUILDING CONSTRUCTION for foundation work, shoring, etc. 
(a)  for each front foot when maximum depth of excavation below sidewalk grade is five (5) feet or less—for each foot of depth ..... 20.00 
(b)  for each front foot when maximum depth of excavation below side walk grade is greater than five (5) feet and not more than twenty (20) feet—for each foot of depth feet for each foot of depth ..... 25.00 
(c)  for each front foot when maximum depth of excavation is greater than twenty (20) feet-for each foot of depth ..... 75.00 
INSTALLATION OF TIEBACKS (cable or bar types) under pavements or sidewalks for shoring support purposes for each tieback ..... 3,500.00 
TRAFFIC CONTROL ITEMS—Excavation or any construction activity within public rights-of-way which will disrupt, damage, or interfere with any portion of the following: 
(a)  Pavement markings: 
Straight arrow, each ..... 350.00 
Turn arrow, each ..... 400.00 
Combination arrow, each ..... 600.00 
Stop bar—12 feet minimum, each ..... 350.00 
Crosswalk—12 feet minimum, each ..... 300.00 
Pavement message, each ..... 600.00 
(b)  Electronic traffic detection loops (all sides) approximate size: 
*6 feet × 6 feet ..... 3,000.00 
*6 feet × 20 feet ..... 4,000.00 
*6 feet × 50 feet ..... 5,000.00 
*Repairs to or replacements of electronic vehicular detection systems are to be performed by qualified personnel only, using procedures which are approved by the commissioner of traffic 
DRIVING PIPES under pavements or sidewalks (amount of deposit to be based on area which would have been disturbed if work had been performed by open-cut trenching method) 
MINIMUM AMOUNT OF DEPOSIT for each street opening in the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 districts ..... 500.00 
MINIMUM AMOUNT OF DEPOSIT for each street opening in all other districts ..... 1,250.00 
PLATING between the dates December 1 and March 31 and for each traffic lane affected the daily fee shall be ..... 50.00 
there shall be an additional charge of $10.00 per plate utilized. 
(b)  When excavating machinery or other equipment is to be used on work related to street openings or when such work is to be performed in or contiguous to any district other than the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 districts, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city, the commissioner, in his discretion, may increase the amount of deposit to be required over and above the amounts herein above specified to an amount which in the opinion of the commissioner would be sufficient to reimburse the city for any damage to the street or for any expense incurred by the city in maintaining and protecting traffic in a satisfactory and necessary manner. 
(c)  When the permittee exceeds maximum size of opening or work specified in permit, the permittee shall, when so ordered and before proceeding with the work, pay to the commissioner such additional amounts of deposit as the commissioner may require. Failure on the part of the permittee to comply promptly with said order will be considered sufficient cause for revocation of the permit. 
(d)  The amount of deposit shall be retained by the city for the duration of the period of maintenance. 
Upon the failure or default by the permittee of any of the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on the permittee's part to be done or performed, said deposit may be used by the city for any expense incurred by the city by reason of such failure or default on the part of the permittee. 
Any balance left after the expense of such failure or default, as determined and certified by the commissioner, has been paid and deducted from the amount of the deposit shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(e)  The period of maintenance shall be considered as a period of six (6) months after the date of final completion, as determined by the commissioner, of the work to be done pursuant to the terms of the permit, except however that, in the event that the termination of the said six (6) months' period shall fall within the months of December, January, February, March or April, then and in that event the period of maintenance shall be considered as extending until the first day of May next thereafter. 
(f)  The permittee shall be responsible for the entire work and shall keep every portion of said work in perfect order and repair during the entire period of maintenance and should the said permittee fail to make the needed repairs to the work or to adequately maintain surfaces disturbed by said permittee, the commissioner reserves the right, in said commissioner's discretion and without prior notice to the permittee, to cause such repairs to be made or such surfaces to be maintained by the city's own forces or by contract or otherwise in which case the city shall be reimbursed for any expense incurred thereby in accordance with the provisions of section 7-3-4 of this Code, and the permittee shall have no claim against the city for loss of anticipated profits or for any losses by reason thereof. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 5; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 4; Ord. of 12-5-55, § 1; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 4; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 6; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 4; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 11-14-96, § 3; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 4; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 4; Ord. of 5-30-13, § 2, eff. 7-1-13)  
Sec. 7-3-45. - Same—Bond as deposit for excavations related to building construction for foundation work, shoring, etc. 
(a)  A permittee in lieu of the deposit herein specified for excavations related to building, construction for foundation work, shoring, etc., and if the amount of such deposit is in excess of thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00), may file and keep on file with the commissioner of public works a bond, in the amount equivalent to the required deposit said bond to be approved as to form, amount and sufficiency of surety or other security by the corporation counsel. Such bond shall be retained as security for the faithful performance by the applicant of all the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on the applicant's part to be done and performed. 
(b)  Such bond shall be considered as a deposit and the provisions of section 7-3-44 of this Code shall in regard to the disposition of the deposit apply to such permit in the same manner as specified for other permittees in section 7-3-44 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 5-a; Ord. of 2-18-57, § 1; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 7; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 5; Ord. of 6-25-73, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-46. - Same—Bond as deposit from public service corporation. 
(a)  Unless otherwise agreed upon between a public service corporation and the city, a public service corporation may, in lieu of deposit hereinbefore specified for street opening, file and keep on file with the commissioner of public works a bond in the amount of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), said bond to be approved as to form, amount and sufficiency of surety by the corporation counsel; said bond to be retained as security for the faithful performance by the applicant of all the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on the applicant's part to be done or performed. 
(b)  Such bond shall be considered as a deposit and the provisions of section 7-3-44 of this Code in regard to the disposition of deposits shall apply to a public service corporation in the same manner as specified for other permittees in section 7-3-44 of this Code. 
(c)  The commissioner may, at his discretion, assign a representative to inspect, on behalf of the city, the work to be done under the provisions of any permit granted to a public service corporation, without any fee in addition to the fees provided in section 7-3-43 of this Code, where a bond is filed in lieu of a deposit. 
(d)  A public service corporation may, in lieu of the insurance hereinbefore specified for street opening, file and keep on file with the commissioner of public works an agreement, approved as to form by the corporation counsel to indemnify and save harmless the city from claims, suits, actions, proceedings, losses, injuries, damages and costs of every name and description arising out of or resulting from any act or omission on the part of such public service corporation under any permit granted to it, or from any negligence or fault of such public service corporation, its contractors, agents, servants or employees in connection with sidewalk, curb or driveway work or repairs or street openings or any work related thereto and to also defend on behalf of the city any such suits, actions or proceedings which may be instituted against the city. 
(e)  Such public service corporation shall be billed by the city for any expenses incurred by the city by reason of any failure or default on the part of said corporation, as determined and certified by the commissioner, and any such bill shall be paid within thirty (30) days after same shall have been billed by the city. 
(f)  In case of emergency due to breakage of pipes, etc., street openings may be made by a public service corporation prior to obtaining a permit for street opening, provided however that the public service corporation shall have filed any required bond and evidence of insurance of indemnity agreement, and provided further that the said public service corporation shall make application for the necessary permit not later than twenty-four (24) hours (Saturdays, Sundays and holidays not included) after said opening has been commenced. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 6; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 5; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 6; Ord. of 2-5-73, § 3)  
Sec. 7-3-47. - Protection of existing structures. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the person by whom or for whose benefit any street opening is to be made for any purpose whatsoever in the city to give written notice thereof to any company whose pipes, conduits or other structures are laid in the street in which any work is to be done by the permittee under the provisions of a street opening permit not less than twenty-four (24) hours before commencing such opening or work; and such person, firm or corporation doing such work shall, at its own expense, carefully support, maintain in operation and protect from injury such pipes, conduits or other structures and, in case of injury shall restore same, at its own expense, to as good a condition as they were before the beginning of such opening or work. 
(b)  In case of failure of said person to comply with the provisions of subsection (a), then same may be done by the company to whom the pipes, conduits or other structures belong, and the costs thereof, and all damages sustained by the said company thereby shall be paid by said person to said company, and who may in default thereof, maintain an action against such person. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 7)  
Sec. 7-3-48. - Traffic. 
(a)  The permittee shall erect and maintain suitable barricades and fences around all of his or its work while excavation or other work is in progress and shall arrange his or its work in such a manner as to cause a minimum of inconvenience and delay to vehicular and pedestrian traffic. The commissioner may require that the work be so arranged as to make possible the complete removal of obstructions to traffic on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays and, at the discretion of the commissioner, during periods of unusually heavy traffic volume. In the event that such requirement is not complied with by the permittee, the commissioner may, in the latter's discretion, cause all or part of the work covered by the permit to be backfilled and temporarily resurfaced by the city's own forces or by contract or otherwise, in which case the city shall be reimbursed for any expense incurred thereby in accordance with the provisions of section 7-3-4 of this Code, and the permittee shall have no claim against the city for loss of anticipated profits or for any other losses by reason thereof. 
(b)  Warning flags or signs and suitably lighted flashing lights shall be provided. In addition, a watchman shall be provided, if so ordered by the commissioner, in accordance with the latter's directions. 
(c)  Where the free flow of traffic is interfered with, the permittee shall designate competent persons to direct and expedite traffic by means of lights or flags. 
(d)  Unless otherwise authorized by the commissioner, vehicular traffic shall be maintained at all times during the progress of the work being performed under the permit. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 8; Ord. of 5-21-51, § 2; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 8; Ord. of 6-25-73, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-49. - Poles and wires. 
No person shall erect or cause to be erected any telephone, telegraph or electric light or electric transmission pole or poles, or install any conduits or change the location thereof or string any wires in, over or upon any street, highway or public place without first obtaining a permit therefor from the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 9)  
Sec. 7-3-50. - Commencement and completion of work. 
All work done under this permit issued pursuant to this division shall be commenced and completed within thirty (30) days of its issuance, or as may be determined and specified in writing by the commissioner, with the exception that the replacement of the permanent pavement, the restoration of other surfaces disturbed and any necessary work required in connection with the specified "period of maintenance" shall be done in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. III, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-50, § 1; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 4)  
Sec. 7-3-51. - Use of plates. 
(a)  Plates shall be used for the minimum possible time and only when specifically requested by the applicant at the time of permit issuance, or as directed at any time by the commissioner. At all times plates shall be anchored adequately to assure covering the street opening. Vertical projecting lifting devices shall not be used. The commissioner reserves the right to direct that temporary pavement be utilized, in lieu of plating, in order to reopen a street to the motoring public. 
(b)  Except if another time period is so indicated, during the period from December 1 up to and including March 31 of each year, the following additional requirements exist: 
(1)  A per diem fee shall be charged as provided for in section 7-3-44(a); 
(2)  Highly reflective signs shall be placed as provided below. Signs shall be orange diamonds, two (2) feet on each side, with black letters and border, and shall be mounted so that the lowest point of the sign is seven (7) feet above the curb or ground surface. The signs shall have a three-eighths inch ( 3/8 ?) margin and a five-eighths inch ( 5/8 ?) border. Signs shall have five-inch (5?) tall letters placed so that one word is centered over the other; 
(3)  A sign shall be placed five (5) feet before the plate, facing oncoming traffic, and read RAISE PLOW; 
(4)  A sign shall also be placed two hundred (200) feet before the plate, or at any side street closer than fifty (50) feet, and read "PLATE AHEAD." This sign may be required at any time during the calendar year, or be waived at the discretion of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 11-14-96, § 2)  
Secs. 7-3-52—7-3-56. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MANNER OF EXCAVATION AND BACKFILLING 
 
Sec. 7-3-57. - Scope. 
Except as specifically provided in this division, the provisions of this division shall apply to all excavations or openings under or in any street, sidewalk or other public place.  
Sec. 7-3-58. - Excavated material. 
Excavated material shall be stored in neat piles, so placed as to cause the least interference with the use of the roadway or sidewalks. If so ordered by the commissioner, such excavated material shall be promptly removed from the site of the work. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. IV, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-59. - Sheathing and shoring. 
(a)  Except where the excavation is in rock and unless otherwise authorized by the commissioner as provided hereinunder, tight sheathing at least two (2) inches in thickness, securely fastened in place with whalers and braces throughout the duration of the work, shall be placed in all trenches having a depth in excess of three (3) feet, shall be driven to the same depth as the lowest part of the pipe, conduit or structure proposed to be installed, and shall be carried down in such a manner that the bottom of the sheathing shall at no time be more than one foot above the bottom of the excavation. 
(b)  Whenever conditions make it necessary, the commissioner may require that the sheathing be driven ahead of the excavation as the latter proceeds. 
(c)  Unless otherwise authorized in writing by the commissioner, sheathing and shoring shall be left in place with a cutoff line eighteen (18) inches below ground surface. 
(d)  The commissioner may, in his discretion, authorize that the use of sheathing and shoring be omitted in whole or in part if the horizontal distance from the edge of the proposed excavation to the nearest edge of the pavement, water main or other surface or subsurface structure is not less than the vertical depth of the proposed excavation as measured from the highest point of such pavement, water main or other surface or subsurface structure. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. IV, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-60. - Rock excavations. 
(a)  A permittee who is conducting rock excavations shall observe all municipal ordinances and all state and federal laws relating to the transportation, storage and use of explosives, and shall obtain all necessary permits and/or licenses pertaining thereto. 
(b)  Any rock excavation within five (5) feet of water or gas main, pavement or other surface or subsurface pipe, conduit or structure shall be done with very slight charges of explosive and the utmost care shall be used to avoid disturbing or injuring said structure. 
(c)  The permittee shall use the utmost caution in properly protecting all surface or subsurface structures from the effects of blasting and any damage done to such structures shall be promptly repaired by the permittee, or by such other parties as the commissioner may direct, at the said permittee's own expense. 
(d)  Sufficient warning shall be given to all persons in the vicinity of the work before blasting. The site of the blast shall be covered with heavy timbers, blasting mats or other devices to prevent damage from flying rock fragments. 
(e)  The time of blasting and the manner and size of charges must be satisfactory to the commissioner. The blasting shall be done only by properly licensed individuals. 
(f)  The permittee shall give adequate notice to the city and to the appropriate public service corporations before proceeding with blasting in the vicinity of water mains, sanitary sewers, stormwater drains or other drains or other public utility lines. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. IV, § 3; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 6)  
Sec. 7-3-61. - Backfilling. 
(a)  No backfilling shall be done by the permittee until the work being done under the permit shall have first been inspected, and backfilling authorized, by the commissioner. In case of nonconformity with this requirement, the commissioner shall have the right to require that the work be uncovered by the permittee at the latter's own expense so that proper inspection may be made. 
(b)  The material used to backfill the bottom of the trench up to a level of two (2) feet above the completed pipe or other structure shall be clean earth, sand or rock dust and shall contain no broken rock, stone or frozen earth. 
(c)  Above a level two (2) feet higher than the top of the completed pipe or other structure, the material used for backfill shall be approved material containing no frozen earth and not more than one-third broken rock and no stone or piece thereof shall exceed one-half (½) cubic foot in size. 
(d)  The space between the pipe or other structure and the bottom and sides of the trench shall be packed full by hand and thoroughly tamped as fast as placed and up to the level of the top of the pipe or other structure, which shall then be covered by hand to a level of at least three (3) feet higher than the top thereof, the backfill material being carefully deposited and tamped in layers not more than six (6) inches thick. 
(e)  Such tamping shall be done with a light tamper weighing from six (6) to eight (8) pounds and shall be conducted in such a manner as to secure compacted backfill without in any way injuring or disturbing the completed pipe or structure. At least one man shall be provided for tamping for each man engaged in backfilling. 
(f)  Backfilling above the level of three (3) feet above the top of the pipe or other structure shall be done in successive horizontal layers not exceeding six (6) inches in depth and each layer shall be thoroughly compacted by means of approved pneumatic tamping equipment or by such other means as may be approved by the commissioner. 
(g)  The use of power equipment or other mechanical means for backfilling will not be allowed unless provision has been made for adequate compacting of backfill material and then only with the prior written authorization of the commissioner. 
(h)  Compacting the backfill by means of flooding or puddling with water will not be allowed except with the prior written authorization of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. IV, § 4; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 9)  
Sec. 7-3-62. - Driving small pipes. 
Tunnelling under pavements or sidewalks will not be allowed but small pipes or conduits having a dimension of six (6) inches or less may be driven beneath pavements or sidewalks in such a manner that the surface shall not be disturbed or injured and provided that: 
(a)  The prior written approval of the commissioner is obtained; 
(b)  No excavation in connection therewith shall be closer than one foot to the edge of a sidewalk or eighteen (18) inches to the edge of a pavement; 
(c)  Such pipes or conduits shall be enclosed in sleeves or larger pipes so that required replacements or repairs may be made in the future without disturbance or injury to the pavement or sidewalk; 
(d)  In the event of damage to a pavement, sidewalk, or subsurface pipe or structure caused by driving such pipe or conduit, the permittee shall repair and make good the damage at the permittee's own expense. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. IV, § 5)  
Secs. 7-3-63—7-3-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RESTORATION 
 
Sec. 7-3-71. - Temporary resurfacing. 
(a)  Immediately after backfilling the excavation, the permittee shall place thereon an acceptable temporary resurfacing as provided hereinbelow. Such temporary resurfacing shall be maintained even with the roadway or other surface as directed until permanent restoration of the surface is completed as specified herein and approved by the commissioner.
