(b)  The temporary resurfacing shall consist of not less than two (2) inches of approved premixed bituminous paving material or the commissioner of public works may permit six (6) inches of temporary concrete flush to surface except that, where top soil, seeded areas or sod have been disturbed by the excavation, or by any work related thereto, the permittee shall restore the entire ground area to the same condition as existed before the work began. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 1; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 11; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 10; Ord. of 6-25-73, § 3)  
Sec. 7-3-72. - Permanent restoration. 
Permanent restoration of the surface over a street opening excavation shall not be made until satisfactory settlement of the backfill has taken place as approved by the commissioner. The permanent pavement must be completed no later than the date indicated on the permit. If said permanent pavement has not been completed within eighteen (18) months from the date of issuance of the permit, such permit shall be in default and the commissioner shall have the right to forfeit the deposit therefor to the city, unless written application for an extension is made to, and granted by, the commissioner, for good and sufficient reason other than neglect by the permittee. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 1; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 11)  
Sec. 7-3-73. - Concrete pavements. 
(a)  Before proceeding with pavement resurfacing, the existing concrete pavement shall be neatly cut back a distance of not less than eighteen (18) inches beyond the edges of the excavation, care being taken not to remove any existing steel reinforcement. Such distance shall not be reduced without prior approval of the commissioner and may be increased as provided hereinunder. 
(b)  Where the existing pavement has been undermined by the excavation or by any work connected therewith, or where spalled or scaled surface areas of existing pavement adjoin the area to be resurfaced, the permittee shall remove additional pavement beyond the distance stated herein, as ordered by the commissioner. 
(c)  In the event that any portion of the proposed concrete resurfacing, as finally determined by the commissioner as provided hereinabove, is nearer than four (4) feet from a joint, then such removal shall be extended to said joint. The smallest horizontal dimension of the concrete resurfacing shall be not less than four (4) feet. 
(d)  None of the subgrade so exposed shall be disturbed in any way except when, in the opinion of the commissioner, such subgrade is unstable, in which case the unstable material shall be removed as ordered, and replaced with approved stable material in layers not to exceed four (4) inches, each layer being thoroughly compacted and tamped. 
(e)  The upper edges of the existing concrete pavement shall be uniformly plumbed and tooled for a depth not to exceed one inch, the remaining depth being left with straight but rough edges. 
(f)  Reinforcement, consisting of deformed steel bars, not less than three-eighths of an inch in size, spaced as ordered, shall be placed two (2) inches above the subgrade and shall be adequately tied in with the existing reinforcement, if any. 
(g)  The edges of the existing concrete pavement shall be thoroughly washed, wire brushed, dampened and painted with a 1:1 neat cement coating immediately previous to the placing of the new concrete resurfacing. 
(h)  The concrete shall be proportioned, mixed, placed, finished and cured as ordered. The commissioner may, in the latter's discretion, require the use of an approved high early-strength cement placed under approved methods. The use of admixtures, and work in freezing weather will be allowed only with the commissioner's prior approval and as directed. 
(i)  Approved joints shall be installed where directed. 
(j)  The resurfaced area shall not be opened to traffic until so ordered by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-74. - Bituminous pavements. 
(a)  Prior to the replacement of bituminous pavements, the subgrade shall be properly prepared and a reinforced concrete foundation of required thickness and proportions shall be placed thereon, all in accordance with the requirements for concrete pavements outlined hereinabove. 
(b)  The existing bituminous pavement shall then be neatly cut back a distance of not less than six (6) inches from the edges of the new concrete foundation. The entire foundation so exposed shall be thoroughly cleaned in an acceptable manner and a new bituminous pavement surface of approved type and thickness shall be placed thereon and rolled in an acceptable manner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 3)  
Sec. 7-3-75. - Macadam pavements. 
(a)  In resurfacing existing macadam pavements, the permittee shall cut back the existing pavement a distance of not less than one foot beyond the edges of the excavation. Such distance shall not be reduced without prior approval of the commissioner and may be increased by the commissioner if the existing pavement has been undermined by the excavation or by any work connected therewith. 
(b)  The permittee shall place on the subgrade four (4) inches of approved crushed stone of required size, properly tamped, and two (2) inches of asphaltic concrete, compacted and finished in an acceptable manner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 4; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 12)  
Sec. 7-3-76. - Other surfaces. 
Any surfaces not elsewhere provided for in this division disturbed by reason of the work performed under the permit shall be restored by the permittee as directed by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 5)  
Sec. 7-3-77. - Option of city to do work at permittee's expense. 
The commissioner may, in his discretion, cause any or all of the work contemplated in this division to be done by the city's own forces or by contract or otherwise, in which case the city shall be reimbursed for any expense incurred thereby in accordance with the provisions of section 7-3-4 of this Code, and the permittee shall have no claim against the city for loss of anticipated profits or for any other losses by reason thereof. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VI, § 6)  
Secs. 7-3-78—7-3-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OBSTRUCTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Use of public areas for manufacturing, etc., § 5-1-5 et seq. 
 
Sec. 7-3-86. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall obstruct, encumber or occupy in any manner or for any purposes whatsoever any public street, highway or sidewalk area without first obtaining therefor from the commissioner a written permit for street obstruction. 
(b)  The use and operation of construction machinery or equipment in connection with building operations, when such machinery or equipment obstructs, encumbers or occupies any portion of a public street, highway or sidewalk area, will not be allowed unless a written permit for street obstruction has first been obtained from the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 1; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 6)  
Sec. 7-3-87. - Term and expiration. 
Permits issued pursuant to this article shall be valid for a period not to exceed thirty (30) consecutive calendar days, to be determined and specified therein by the commissioner. Such period may be extended, if so requested in writing by the permittee prior to expiration thereof, for such additional period as the commissioner, at the latter's discretion, may authorize. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 1; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 6)  
Sec. 7-3-88. - Application for permit. 
Any person desiring a permit for street obstruction shall make application therefor to the commissioner upon forms provided for that purpose. Such application shall contain: 
(1)  The names and addresses of the applicant and of the owner of the property in front of which the street obstruction is proposed; 
(2)  The location of such property, the ward, block and lot designation thereof; 
(3)  The extent and nature of the proposed obstruction, and the dates thereof; 
(4)  Such necessary sketches and additional information as may be required by the commissioner; and 
(5)  A signed statement by the applicant that the said applicant agrees to abide by all the conditions of the permit, the provisions of the charter and the ordinances of the city and the applicable rules and regulations of the department of public works. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 2)  
Sec. 7-3-89. - Fees and deposits—Generally. 
(a)  No permit for street obstruction shall be issued by the commissioner until the applicant thereof shall have first paid to the commissioner in cash, or by check payable to the city: 
(1)  A deposit in the amount to be determined as provided herein; and 
(2)  A minimum fee of one hundred-fifty dollars ($150.00) if such obstruction or any part thereof occurs in streets or public rights-of-way within the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5, and R2-4 districts as defined in the zoning ordinance or three hundred dollars ($300.00) if such obstruction occurs elsewhere, or ten (10) per cent of the amount of deposit, whichever is greater. The commissioner in his discretion may issue a temporary short-term permit for street obstruction valid for a period not to exceed three (3) per cent of the amount of the deposit, or thirty dollars ($30.00), whichever is greater, for one (1) day and five (5) per cent of the amount of the deposit or sixty dollars ($60.00), whichever is greater, for two (2) days. 
(b)  No permit for street obstructions shall be extended by the commissioner until the applicant pays to the commissioner in cash or by check payable to the city a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) if such obstruction or any part thereof occurs in streets or rights-of-way located in R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 districts as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city or three hundred dollars ($300.00) if such obstruction occurs elsewhere or ten (10) per cent of the amount of the deposit, whichever is greater of each extension of thirty (30) days or less. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 4; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 5; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 12; Ord. of 11-3-69, § 7; Ord. of 3-15-71, § 1; Ord. of 8-7-72, § 7; Ord. of 6-25-73, § 4; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of > 5-17-16 , § 3) 
Cross reference— Zoning, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-90. - Same—Calculation generally and disposition of deposit. 
(a)  The amount of a deposit for street obstructions shall be computed in accordance with the following unit prices for areas to be obstructed, encumbered or occupied as determined by the commissioner: 
FOR THE STORAGE OF MATERIALS, or any operation in connection with the erection, demolition, repair, alteration or reconstruction of a building, other than the loading, unloading and/or operation of construction equipment or machinery, for each square foot ..... $6.00 
FOR THE LOADING, UNLOADING AND/OR OPERATION OF CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT OR MACHINERY, in connection with the erection, demolition, repair, alteration or reconstruction of a building, for each square foot ..... 7.00 
MINIMUM AMOUNT OF DEPOSIT for each street obstruction ..... 600.00 
(b)  The amount of deposit, and minimum amount thereof, prescribed above, shall be doubled when the obstruction, or any part thereof, occurs in streets located in or contiguous to any district other than the R1-30, R1-20, R1-12.5, R1-7.5, R1-5 and R2-4 districts, as defined in the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  When permittee exceeds maximum authorized obstruction specified in the permit, the permittee shall, when so ordered, pay to the commissioner such additional amounts of deposit as the commissioner may require. Failure on the part of the permittee to comply promptly with said order shall be considered sufficient cause for revocation of the permit. 
(d)  The deposit shall be retained by the city until expiration of the permit, as security for the faithful performance by the applicant of all the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on the applicant's part to be done or performed. 
(e)  Upon the failure or default by the permittee of any of the terms, agreements, covenants and conditions of the permit on its part to be done and performed, said deposit may be used by the city for any expense incurred by the city by reason of such failure or default on the part of the permittee, and without prior notice thereof to the permittee and the said permittee shall have no claim against the city for loss of anticipated profits or for any losses by reason thereof. 
(f)  Any balance left after the expense of such failure or default, as determined and certified by the commissioner, which has been paid and deducted from the amount of the deposit shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 5; Ord. of 5-19-54, § 9; Ord. of 7-8-58, § 6; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 13; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of > 5-17-16 , § 4) 
Cross reference— Zoning, Ch. 9-2.  
Sec. 7-3-91. - Permissible area of obstruction. 
(a)  In the case of a permit issued by the commissioner for a street obstruction related to the erection, demolition, repair, alteration or reconstruction of a building, the permissible area of the street, highway or sidewalk to be obstructed, encumbered or occupied shall be determined and specified by the commissioner. 
(b)  Unless otherwise authorized in writing by the commissioner, the permittee shall conduct his operation under the permit for street obstruction in such a manner that not more than one-third of the total width of a street or highway, pavement or other surface shall be obstructed. 
(c)  The permittee shall keep clear and unobstructed, at all times, and shall in no way interfere with prompt access to, or adequate operation of, all manholes, catch-basins, hydrants, valves or fire alarm boxes that may be situated in or near the area obstructed or occupied in accordance with the permit. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided herein, the permittee shall also keep clear and unobstructed at all times the sidewalk area and gutter in or near the area occupied under the permit and shall remove promptly therefrom any dirt, rubbish, snow or ice. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 6; Ord. of 4-17-67, § 14; Ord. of 10-2-72, § 13)  
Sec. 7-3-92. - Safeguarding pedestrian and other traffic. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, the permittee shall erect and maintain suitable protective barricades and fences around the obstruction or area occupied and shall at all times provide a safe, adequate and unobstructed passageway not less than four (4) feet in clear width for the use of pedestrians. 
(b)  When materials are to be moved over the sidewalk by means of derrick, crane, hoist or chute, the permittee shall provide a safe and adequate sidewalk shed conforming with the requirements of chapter 9-5 of this Code, or when so ordered by the commissioner, shall provide a safe, adequate and unobstructed temporary sidewalk around the obstruction or area occupied. 
(c)  Temporary sidewalks, when so ordered, shall, wherever practicable be built to the same level as the existing sidewalk and in such a manner as not to interfere with the free flow of water in the street or gutter. 
(d)  The permittee shall also make adequate provision for the safe passage of vehicular traffic by day and by night. Where the free flow of traffic is interfered with the permittee shall designate competent persons to direct and expedite traffic by means of lights or flags. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 7)  
Sec. 7-3-93. - Loading and unloading across sidewalk. 
No permit for street obstruction shall be required for the loading or unloading, across a sidewalk area, of goods, wares or merchandise which are in the process of being transferred to or from trucks or other vehicles standing at the curb line provided, however, that such loading or unloading shall be conducted in the most prompt manner possible and shall be subject to such laws and ordinances as may be adopted by the city, and provided further that the commissioner may, at the latter's discretion, require that such loading and unloading shall take place during certain specified hours. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 8)  
Sec. 7-3-94. - Damage resulting from street obstructions. 
Any damage resulting from the obstruction, encumbrance or occupation of a public street, highway or sidewalk area or from the storage of materials or operation of construction equipment or machinery shall be repaired by the permittee to the satisfaction of the commissioner, when so ordered. 
(Ord. of 4-5-48, Art. VII, § 9)  
Secs. 7-3-95—7-3-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CUSTOMER-OWNED OR -LEASED CURRENCY- OR CREDIT-OPERATED TELEPHONES AND PUBLIC TELEPHONES 
 
Sec. 7-3-100. - Intent and purpose. 
The Common Council of the City of White Plains finds and declares that: 
(a)  The uncontrolled placement of customer-owned or -leased currency- or credit-operated telephones ("COCOT") and public telephones in public rights-of-way presents an inconvenience and danger to the safety and welfare of persons using such rights-of-way, including pedestrians, persons entering and leaving vehicles and buildings, and persons performing essential utility, traffic-control and emergency services. 
(b)  Such telephones so located as to cause an inconvenience or danger to persons using public rights-of-way or improperly maintained or illegally operated in violation of the New York State Public Service Law or regulations promulgated by the New York State Public Service Commission located therein, constitute public nuisances. 
(c)  The provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, morals, and general welfare of persons in City of White Plains in their use of public rights of way. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-101. - Definitions. 
(a)  City shall mean The City of White Plains. 
(b)  COCOT shall mean any customer-owned or -leased currency- or credit-operated telephone as regulated by the Public Service Commission pursuant to the New York State Public Service Law and applicable regulations promulgated thereunder and only for the purposes of this article, any public currency or credit operated telephone owned by the local exchange company (presently known as New York Telephone). 
(c)  Licensee shall mean the person responsible for placing and maintaining a COCOT in a public right-of-way. 
(d)  Monthly gross usage shall mean the sum total of all charges paid by or billed to customers for use of a COCOT during a calendar month. 
(e)  Public right-of-way shall mean any areas dedicated to public use for public street purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, parkways, alleys and sidewalks. 
(f)  Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-102. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, place, maintain or operate, on any public street or sidewalk, or in any other public right-of-way, or in any place requiring the user to stand or otherwise occupy any public right-of-way, in The City of White Plains, any COCOT without first having obtained a permit from the city specifying the exact location of such COCOT. One (1) permit may be issued to include any number of COCOTs and shall be signed by the applicant and countersigned by the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-103. - Application for permit. 
Application for such permit shall be made, in writing, to the commissioner of public works upon such form as shall be provided by him, and shall contain the name and address of the applicant and the proposed specific location of the COCOT, and shall be signed by the applicant. A fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus thirty dollars ($30.00) for each COCOT for which a permit is sought shall accompany the application, such fees to cover operation for each calendar year, or part thereof. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-104. - Conditions for permit. 
(a)  As an express condition of the acceptance of such permit, the permittee thereby agrees to indemnify and save harmless the city, its officers, officials, employees and volunteers, against any and all claims, actions, loss, damage, injury, liability, cost and expense arising out of or incidental to the installation, use, or maintenance of a COCOT within the city. 
(b)  The applicant shall file with the application for the permit a certificate of commercial general liability insurance in the amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage with The City of White Plains endorsed as additional insured, such certificate to be approved as to form, correctness and adequacy by the corporation counsel to insure the city against any loss, injury or damage arising out of the granting of the permit or from any negligence or fault of the applicant, his agents, servants or employees, in connection with the COCOT or with any work related thereto. Such insurance must remain in force throughout the effective period of the permit as well as any authorized extensions thereof and shall carry an endorsement to the effect that the insurance company will give at least thirty (30) days' written notice to the city of any modification or cancellation of any such insurance. 
(c)  Such permits shall be valid for one (1) calendar year, or part thereof, and shall be renewable pursuant to the procedure for original applications referred to in section 7-3-103 and upon payment of the referenced fees. 
(d)  Stickers showing the permit number shall be issued with the permit and must be displayed on the COCOT at all times. 
(e)  The licensee shall pay to the city a quarterly commission for the use of the public right-of-way as provided in section 7-3-110. 
(f)  The licensee shall install, operate and maintain its COCOTs in conformance with all applicable requirements of the New York State Public Service Law and all applicable regulations promulgated by the New York State Public Service Commission. 
(g)  No renewal permit may be granted if any required compliance or other reports or financial statements have not been filed with the city or if the payment of any quarterly commissions are overdue or for any COCOT if the New York State Public Service Commission has ordered the discontinuance of service of a licensee's COCOT at that location. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-105. - Standards for maintenance and installation. 
Any COCOT which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public right-of-way or which requires the user to stand or otherwise occupy any public right-of-way, shall comply with the following standards: 
(a)  No COCOT shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than that dealing with the use of the COCOT itself. 
(b)  Each COCOT shall be equipped with a coin-return mechanism to permit a person using the COCOT to secure an immediate refund in the event the call paid for by the user is unable to be completed. The coin-return mechanisms shall be maintained in good working order. 
(c)  Each COCOT shall have affixed to it in a readily visible place so as to be seen by anyone using the COCOT a notice setting forth all the following: 
(1)  The identity and address of the COCOT licensee. 
(2)  A statement that calls can be made at no charge to the 911 emergency number, the operator, and, where applicable, to local directory assistance. 
(3)  Specific dialing and coin deposit/return information, including instructions for accessing a local exchange telephone company operator and directory assistance. 
(4)  The rates charged for local calls, including the initial charge for a local call and the rates charged for additional time periods. 
(5)  The identity of the interexchange company carrying calls from the COCOT, and instructions for obtaining access to the other interexchange companies. 
(6)  Where applicable, a notice that additional charges are imposed by the COCOT licensee for the use of the telephone or telephone equipment for the placing of a call. 
(7)  A toll-free number which the caller can use to obtain information on the rates, surcharges, terms or conditions applicable to calls placed from the COCOT. 
(8)  The toll-free number to call for resolution by the COCOT of a billing or service complaint and the toll-free number of the Public Service Commission to call for assistance in resolving a complaint. 
(d)  Each COCOT shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times. Specifically, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each COCOT shall be serviced and maintained so that: 
(1)  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease. 
(2)  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof. 
(3)  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon. 
(4)  The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration. 
(5)  The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof, if any, are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading. 
(6)  The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshapen. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-106. - Location and placement of COCOTs. 
Any COCOT which rests in whole or in part upon, or on any portion of a public right-of-way or which projects onto, into, or over any part of a public right-of-way or which requires the user to stand in or otherwise occupy any part of a public right-of-way shall be located in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(a)  No COCOT shall be used or maintained which projects onto, into, or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests, wholly or in part upon, along, or over any portion of the roadway of any public street or which requires the user to stand in or otherwise occupy any part of the roadway of any public street. 
(b)  A maximum of four (4) COCOTs may be placed next to each other and only by the same licensee. 
(c)  No COCOT shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
(1)  Within three (3) feet of any marked crosswalk. 
(2)  Within twelve (12) feet of the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk. 
(3)  Within five (5) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box or other emergency facility. 
(4)  Within five (5) feet of any driveway. 
(5)  Within three (3) feet ahead or fifteen (15) feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop. 
(6)  Within three (3) feet of the outer end of any bus bench. 
(7)  At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than six (6) feet. 
(8)  Within three (3) feet of or on any public area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs, trees or other landscaping. 
(9)  Within one hundred fifty (150) feet of any other COCOT (except when two (2) units are installed by the same licensee next to each other). 
(10)  On any handicap access ramp. 
(11)  On the face of any building so that the COCOT intrudes into the public right-of-way unless the COCOT utilizes a support structure as approved by the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-107. - Permits and licenses. 
A COCOT licensee shall obtain, at its own expense, all permits and licenses required by law, rule, regulation, or ordinance, and maintain the same, in full force and effect, for as long as required. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-108. - Construction, fire and safety codes. 
(a)  A COCOT licensee shall construct, operate, maintain, repair, remove, replace, or restore the COCOT in strict compliance with all current technical codes adopted by the city, the state, or the United States. 
(b)  The codes referred to in paragraph (a) above specifically include, but are not limited to, building, construction, fire and safety, and zoning codes. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-109. - Conditions on use of streets and public ways. 
(a)  During any phase of construction, installation, maintenance, and repair of the COCOT, the COCOT licensee shall use materials of good and durable quality; and all such work shall be performed in a safe, thorough, and reliable manner. 
(b)  All wires, conduits, cable (coaxial, fiber, or functional equivalent), and other property and facilities of a COCOT licensee shall be so located, constructed, installed and maintained so as not to endanger or unnecessarily interfere with usual and customary use, traffic and travel upon the streets, rights-of-way, easements, and public ways of the city. 
(c)  In the event a COCOT creates a hazardous or unsafe condition or an unreasonable interference with property, then, at its own expense, such COCOT licensee shall voluntarily, or upon the request of the city, remove that part of the system that creates the hazardous condition from the subject property. 
(d)  A COCOT licensee shall not place equipment where it will interfere with the rights of property owners or with gas, electric or telephone fixtures, or with water hydrants or mains, or with wastewater pump stations, or any other service or facility that benefits the city's or its residents' health, safety, or welfare. 
(e)  A COCOT licensee, at either its own expense or that of a private contractor, shall protect rights-of-way, easements, and support or temporarily disconnect or relocate in the same street or other public way, any property of such COCOT licensee when necessitated by reason of: 
(1)  Traffic conditions; 
(2)  Public safety; 
(3)  A street closing; 
(4)  Street construction or resurfacing; 
(5)  Change or establishment of street grade; 
(6)  Installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, storm drains, pump stations, force mains, power or signal lines; or 
(7)  Any improvement, construction or repair related to the city's or its residents' health, safety or welfare. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of a COCOT licensee (acting alone or in conjunction with another person) to locate and mark or otherwise visibly indicate and alert others to the location of its underground cable (coaxial, fiber or functional equivalent) before employees, agents, or independent contractors of a COCOT licensee install cable in the marked-off area. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-110. - Commissions. 
(a)  A COCOT licensee granted a permit to install or operate a COCOT after the date this article becomes effective [July 6, 1993], shall pay to the city for the continued privilege and use of the streets, rights-of-way, easements, and public ways, and other facilities of the city in the operation of the COCOT, and for supervision thereof by the city during the term of the permit, a quarterly commission based upon the sum of three (3) months' gross usage of the COCOT as follows: 
$150.00 or less—no fee due. 
$150.01 to $300.00—5% of the monthly usage. 
$300.01 to $500.00—7% of the monthly usage. 
Over $500.00—9% of the monthly usage. 
(b)  A COCOT licensee shall file with the commissioner of public works within forty-five (45) days after the expiration of each quarter a detailed financial and revenue statement clearly showing the gross monthly usage of each COCOT during the preceding quarter and certified by a certified public accountant or officer of a COCOT licensee attesting to the accuracy, completeness, and veracity of the usage figures. Such statement shall be in the form and format approved by the Commissioner of Finance of The City of White Plains. 
(c)  Payment of the quarterly commission shall be rendered to the city not later than the first day of March, June, September and December. 
(d)  In the event that payment is not made within thirty (30) days after the date specified in this section, then such COCOT licensee may be declared in violation of this article; and the license granted hereunder may be revoked, terminated, or canceled in the manner prescribed by this article. 
(e)  The right of audit and recomputation of any and all amounts paid as commissions shall always be accorded to the city. 
(f)  No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as a release of, or an accord, or satisfaction of any claim that the city might have for further or additional sums payable under the terms of this article, or for any other performance or obligation of a COCOT licensee. 
(g)  Payments of compensation made by a COCOT licensee to the city, pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall be considered in addition to, and exclusive of, any and all authorized taxes, business license fees, other fees, other levies or assessments presently in effect, or subsequently adopted. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-111. - Furnishing of reports. 
(a)  If at any time, the Federal Communications Commission or New York State Public Service Commission or another federal or state agency requires or requests the submission of reports, data, or other information by a COCOT operator, then such COCOT licensee shall, at the same time, without a separate or specific request, submit those reports, data, or other information to the commissioner of public works. However, unless specifically authorized by the state, a COCOT licensee, shall not be required to submit state or federal tax returns, or any information exempted under federal or state privacy laws. 
(b)  With respect to any enforcement proceedings brought by the New York State Public Service Commission pursuant to its regulations, the licensee shall promptly file with the commissioner of public works any citations issued against the licensee regarding any COCOT located in the city as well as a copy of notification that the citation is being contested and any subsequent determination of the commission. 
(c)  With respect to reports required by this article, it is noted that a COCOT licensee shall timely submit any required report including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  An annual compliance statement in the manner set forth in this article. 
(2)  A periodic gross revenue statement in the manner set forth in this article. 
(3)  Any other reports or information required by any other section of this article, or by the common council, which are necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-112. - Books and records. 
(a)  A COCOT licensee shall keep complete and accurate books of accounts, and records of the business and operations under, and in connection with, its operation in the city. 
(b)  The Commissioner of Finance of The City of White Plains shall have the right to review (either by mail or at the COCOT licensee's local office) all records pertaining to a COCOT licensee's operations, on seven (7) working days' written notice, which records shall include, but not be limited to, the audited annual financial statements and all pertaining footnotes. Such review, unless mutually agreed upon, or judicially ordered, should occur within the COCOT licensee's normal business hours. 
(c)  The commissioner of finance shall have the right to hire, at the city's expense, an independent certified public accountant, or other business or financial expert, to review the books and records of a COCOT licensee. If, after a financial audit, it is determined that the COCOT licensee has underpaid amounts owed by more than two (2) percent, then the city may require the COCOT licensee to reimburse the city for the actual cost of the audit. 
(d)  A false entry into the books and/or records of a COCOT licensee made by a COCOT licensee of a material and substantial fact shall constitute a material violation of this article. 
(e)  A COCOT licensee, at its local office, shall keep complete and accurate books and records of the key aspects of the COCOT licensee's operation for at least the preceding three (3) years in such a manner that all matters pertaining to the city can be easily produced and/or verified at the city's request. Also, the COCOT licensee shall keep, at its local office, any other applicable records and information that may be required by any other federal or state agency having jurisdiction over the COCOT licensee. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-113. - Annual compliance statement required. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of the compliance statement, the commissioner of public works shall review a COCOT licensee's compliance statement in an effort to determine whether the COCOT licensee is complying with the various provisions and/or requirements of this article. The form or content of the compliance statement may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  Prior to December 1 of each calendar year, the commissioner of public works shall furnish to each COCOT licensee a compliance statement form. 
(c)  Prior to December 31 of each calendar year, each COCOT licensee shall file with the commissioner of public works a completed and executed (by the COCOT licensee or an officer thereof) compliance statement. 
(d)  There shall be no charge or fee associated with returning the annual compliance statement. However, if the COCOT licensee supplies incomplete information which requires independent verification by the city or its consultant, then the COCOT licensee may be required to reimburse the city for all costs associated with the independent verification. Moreover, failure to submit a statement by the deadline, or the provision of false information within the statement, may subject an affected COCOT licensee to any and all penalties and fines listed in this article. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-114. - Violations. 
(a)  Upon a determination by the commissioner of public works that COCOT has been installed, used or maintained in violation of this article, an order to correct the offending condition will be issued. Such order may be telephoned to the licensee and shall be mailed to the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested. The order shall specifically describe the offending condition, suggest actions necessary to correct the condition, and inform the COCOT licensee of the right to appeal. Failure to properly correct the offending condition within five (5) days (excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays) after the mailing date of the order or to appeal the order within three (3) days after its receipt shall result in the offending COCOT's being summarily removed and processed as unclaimed property. If the offending COCOT is not properly identified as to owner under provisions of section 7-3-105(c) hereof, it shall be removed immediately and processed as unclaimed property. 
(b)  Upon a determination by the commissioner of public works that a licensee is operating in violation of this article in that a COCOT licensee has failed to file any report required by section 7-3-111 or has failed to pay any commissions recruited by section 7-3-110 or has failed to allow an audit of the licensee's books and records as required by section 7-3-112 or has made a false entry into its books and/or records pursuant to section 7-3-112(d), an order to correct the violation will be issued. Such order may be telephoned to the licensee and shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested. The order shall specifically describe the section of this article violated, suggest actions necessary to correct the violations and inform the COCOT licensee of the right to appeal. Failure to properly correct the violation within five (5) days (excluding Saturday, Sundays, and legal holidays) after the mailing date of the order or to appeal the order within three (3) days after its receipt shall result in the licensee's COCOTs being summarily removed and processed as unclaimed property. If the licensee's COCOT is not properly identified as to owner under the provisions of section 7-3-105(c) hereof, it shall be removed immediately and processed as unclaimed property. 
(c)  An impound fee, which shall be measured by the city's cost and expense of impounding, shall be assessed against each COCOT summarily removed. The commissioner of public works shall cause inspections to be made of corrected conditions ordered under subdivision (a) hereof or of a COCOT reinstalled after removal under this section. The COCOT licensee shall be charged a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee for each COCOT so inspected. This charge shall be in addition to all other fees and charges required under this article. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-115. - Appeals. 
Any person or entity aggrieved by a finding, determination, notice, order or action taken under the provisions of this article may appeal and shall be advised of his right to appeal to the commissioner of public works. An appeal must be perfected within three (3) days after receipt of notice of any protested decision or action by filing with the office of the commissioner of public works a letter of appeal briefly stating therein the basis for such appeal. A hearing shall be held on a date no more than ten (10) days after receipt of the letter of appeal. The appellant shall be given at least five (5) days' notice of the time and place of the hearing. The commissioner of public works shall give the appellant, and any other interested party, a reasonable opportunity to be heard. At the conclusion of the hearing, the commissioner of public works shall make a final and conclusive decision. This decision shall be appealable to a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to article 78 of the CPLR. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-116. - Commissioner of public works designated representative. 
The term "commissioner of public works" as used in this article shall include his/her designated representative. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-117. - Abandonment. 
In the event a COCOT remains inoperable for a period of thirty (30) continuous days or in the event that the New York State Public Service Commission orders the discontinuance of service of any COCOT, the same shall be deemed abandoned, and may be treated in the manner as provided in section 7-3-114 for COCOTs in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-118. - Existing units. 
Any licensee who erected, placed, maintained or operated a COCOT on any public street or sidewalk or in any public right-of-way or in any place requiring the user to stand or otherwise occupy public right-of-way shall obtain a permit under this article from the commissioner of public works within ninety (90) days after the effective date of this article [July 6, 1993]. In the event that any licensee fails to apply for a permit within such time period or a licensee's application for a permit is denied, the COCOT shall be deemed abandoned and may be treated in the manner as provided in section 7-3-114 for COCOTs in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Sec. 7-3-119. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this article is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-6-93, § 1)  
Chapter 7-4 - VAULTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Environmental quality review, Ch. 3-2. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 7-4-1. - Definitions. 
The term "vault", when used in this chapter, shall mean every description of opening below the surface of the street that is covered over, in front of any improved or unimproved property, but shall not be construed as meaning storage tanks for flammable liquids referred to in the city's fire prevention code. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 1) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention code, Ch. 9-6.  
Sec. 7-4-2. - Location restrictions. 
No person shall erect or cause or permit any vault to be made under the pavement of any alley or to within three (3) feet of the face of the curb on any street. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 8)  
Sec. 7-4-3. - Conduit and piping reservations and protection. 
A vault shall not be constructed so as to interfere with any sewer or water pipe, fire hydrant, manhole, gas pipe, tree, lamp post or other public work or improvements nor with any electrical conduit carrying fire alarm or police wires, unless by the written consent of the commissioner of public works especially granted therefor, and no such consent shall be granted until the applicant therefor has paid to the city through the commissioner of public works a sum of money sufficient in the judgment of the commissioner of public works to defray the cost and expense of removing, rebuilding, relaying or replacing such pipes, hydrant, manhole, tree, post, conduit or other public work and making the necessary connection therewith. Every such applicant disturbing any such public work or improvement enumerated above shall, within ten (10) days after so disturbing it, restore the same to such a condition as will meet the approval of the commissioner of public works. When such public work or improvement is so restored by such applicant, the sum so paid to the commissioner of public works shall be refunded by him to such applicant. If the applicant shall fail to restore such public work or improvement within the time prescribed, the commissioner of public works shall cause the work to be done and the cost thereof shall be paid out of the sum deposited by the applicant, and the balance, if any, refunded. The city, in granting a permit for a vault, reserves the right at any time to construct and maintain under, over or through such vault space water or gas pipes, drains, conduits for electric heat or power, sewers or other pipes or underground work needed for the public service that the commissioner of public works may deem necessary to be placed in, below, over or through the space occupied by the vault, without compensation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 9)  
Sec. 7-4-4. - Restrictions on use. 
Boilers or other heating appliances, gasoline, gas or steam engines, pumps and plumbing fixtures, urinals or water closets, gasoline, petroleum or gas storage tanks, flammable or combustible materials or any pipe or fixture generating or emitting gas, steam or offensive odors shall not be located or permitted in any vault. No fans or pipes ejecting vitiated or super-heated air from the adjoining building or exhaust pipe causing disagreeable noise shall be located in or open into a vault. This section shall not be construed as in any wise affecting storage tanks for flammable liquids, permits for the installation of which have been issued and are in force and effect, under the provisions of the city's fire prevention code. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 13)  
Sec. 7-4-5. - Removal of vault covers. 
No person shall remove or insecurely fix or cause, procure, suffer or permit to be removed or insecurely fixed, so that the same can be moved in its bed, any covering or aperture of any vault. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the owner or occupant of the building with which such vault shall be connected from removing the covering for the purpose of using such vault, providing he encloses such opening or aperture and keeps the same enclosed while such covering shall be removed with a strong box or curb at least three (3) feet high, firmly and securely made; and providing he shall not remove such covering until after sunrise of any day and shall replace it before one-half hour after sunset, unless such opening or aperture is at all times when the same is open adequately illuminated. Such vault openings shall be kept closed when not in use. Where a permit has been issued to a public service corporation in front of real property not owned or leased by it, the provisions of this section shall apply only to such public service corporation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 14; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 3)  
Sec. 7-4-6. - Defective vault covers. 
Upon notification from the commissioner of public works the owner or occupant of the abutting property in front of which there is a vault under the sidewalk, the cover whereof is broken or has a slippery surface, shall, within the time specified in such notice, adequately repair said cover or remove the same and substitute another cover, so that the cover over said vault will provide secure footing for pedestrians. Where a permit for a vault has been issued to a public service corporation in front of real property not owned or leased by it, the provisions of this section shall apply only to such public service corporation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 15; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 3)  
Sec. 7-4-7. - Survey before covering vault. 
It shall be the duty of every person for whom a vault may be in process of construction to procure the same to be measured by a competent surveyor and to deliver to the commissioner of public works a certificate of such measurement, signed by the surveyor, before the arching of such vault or cover shall be constructed. The enlargement or increase in size of any such vault shall be construed to be an original, new and independent and separate construction and shall be governed by the provisions of this chapter as in the case of original, new and independent and separate construction thereof. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 18)  
Sec. 7-4-8. - Records and inspection of vaults. 
The commissioner of public works shall keep a complete record of all vaults and from time to time shall make or cause to be made such inspection of all vaults as may be necessary to determine if the provisions of this chapter are being complied with. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 16)  
Sec. 7-4-9. - Power of commissioner of public works to require repairs. 
Whenever any vault is not covered or secured as herein provided or in the opinion of the commissioner of public works is unsafe or inconvenient for public travel, said commissioner of public works may order the same to be placed in a safe condition satisfactory to him; and, if the same shall not be done within ten (10) days after service of a written notice on the owner or person in possession of the abutting premises, the commissioner of public works may make such change and the expense thereof shall be paid by such owner or person in possession of the premises. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 12; Ord. of 6-21-54, § 4)  
Sec. 7-4-10. - Costs of removal by city. 
(a)  In the event the commissioner of public works causes the removal of all machinery, fixtures and structural parts of or in a vault for which a permit has been granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, upon completion of such work the premises in front of which such work shall have been done shall be subject to a charge for the cost thereof, plus ten (10) per cent. During the month of May in each year the commissioner of public works shall make a list of all such charges and file the same in his office, and give public notice of such filing by publication in the official paper, two (2) insertions, that said list has been made and filed and that for ten (10) days from the date of the first publication of said notice said list may be examined by any person interested therein, and that upon a day and hour stated in such notice, and at least ten (10) days after the first publication thereof, he will attend at his office to hear any objections to said list, and pass upon all objections, and, if need be, alter and correct said list. 
(b)  After said hearing and making of the necessary corrections, if any, he shall attach thereto his certificate that such hearing has been had and that said list is now complete, and file the same with the commissioner of finance, whereupon the commissioner of finance shall mail to each owner of real property included in such list whose name and address he is able to ascertain a statement of the amount of charges, composed of said cost plus ten (10) per cent, against his property. Upon the filing of the said list with the commissioner of finance the several sums mentioned in said list shall be deemed to be assessed against the several persons named therein, and the commissioner of finance shall, when extending the next general tax upon the city assessment roll, place unpaid amounts thereon as against the property of the person named in said list, and such amounts shall be collected at the same time, in the same manner and by the same proceedings as other taxes on said roll. 
(c)  The failure to mail any statement or failure of the addressee to receive the same shall not in any manner affect the validity of the assessment or the penalties imposed by law with respect thereto. 
(d)  In the event such work is performed in front of premises for which a permit has been granted to a lessee, the owner of said premises shall be deemed to have consented to such assessment by signing the written consent for the construction of the vault, required under section 7-4-42 of this Code. 
(e)  If the applicant was a public service corporation, the provisions of this section shall apply to such public service corporation and not to the owner or lessee of the abutting property. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 4; Ord. of 6-21-54, § 2; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-11. - Reports by commissioner of building; restriction on issuance of building permits. 
When plans for a building filed with the commissioner of building show that any portion of the space underneath any sidewalk or other public place is intended to be used as a vault, he shall report such fact to the commissioner of public works and notify the owner of the abutting property that a separate vault permit must be obtained from the commissioner of public works. The commissioner of building shall not approve such plans nor issue a permit for the construction or alteration of such building until a copy of the required vault permit issued by the commissioner of public works shall have been filed in the office of the commissioner of building. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 17; Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-12. - Penalties. 
Any person, who himself or itself or by his or its agents or employees shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or any order, rule or regulation made in pursuance thereof, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days or to both such fine and imprisonment, and each day on which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 20; Ord. of 5-3-93) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 7-4-13—7-4-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 7-4-21. - Materials. 
All vaults shall be enclosed with a sufficient concrete, stone or brick wall, or brick arches between iron or steel beams, to retain the roadway of the street, and the side, end or party walls of such building shall extend under the sidewalk of sufficient thickness to sustain such wall or arch. The thickness of such wall shall be determined by the commissioner of building according to the size, shape and depth of the vault but in all cases shall be at least twelve (12) inches thick and of a strength to resist the pressure of the ground with a factor of safety of not less than four (4). 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(1); Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-22. - Cover. 
(a)  All vaults shall be covered with a safe and substantial noncombustible cover, capable of sustaining a distributed load of three hundred (300) pounds to the square foot of its surface, or a concentrated load of five (5) tons at any point and such covering shall be flush and kept flush with the sidewalk. When a vault is covered with glass in iron or concrete frames, such glass lights shall not be more than four (4) inches square each and the top surface of the same shall be rough and surfaced in such a manner as to be entirely safe for pedestrians. Such glass lights shall be kept in good repair at all times. Floor lights when used in sidewalks shall not exceed one-third of the width of the sidewalk perpendicular to the curb. 
(b)  The aperture or opening in the sidewalk over a vault shall be covered with a strong glass or substantial iron or steel plate and frame with a second top surface and rabbeted flush with the sidewalk. The dimensions of the door in any direction shall not exceed the dimensions of the opening by more than six (6) inches. All covers shall be subject to the approval of the commissioner of building, and the commissioner of public works. When any such cover is placed in any sidewalk it shall be placed as near as practicable to the building. There shall not be more than one opening for each twenty-five (25) feet of street frontage of any building and such openings shall not be closer than fifteen (15) feet to each other, except that openings to transformer vaults shall not be closer than five (5) feet, center to center. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(2, 3); Ord. of 4-5-48, § 1; Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-23. - Ventilation, drainage and pavement. 
All vaults shall be thoroughly ventilated, properly drained and paved. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(4)).  
Sec. 7-4-24. - Open gratings and similar openings. 
No open gratings or openings of a similar kind shall be installed in the sidewalk for the purpose of obtaining light or ventilation or for any other purpose. When in the judgment of the commissioner of building and the commissioner of public works sufficient safeguards are provided by proper design they may, by joint approval, permit open gratings or openings of a similar kind to be installed in the sidewalk in the case of transformer installations under such sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(5); Ord. of 3-15-48, § 1; Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-25. - Protection of hydrant bends. 
When a hydrant bend exists in connection with a vault it shall be protected by a wall of such dimensions and materials as the commissioner of public works may require. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(6))  
Sec. 7-4-26. - Barricades, lamps, etc. 
Every owner or lessee of any property served by any vault, other than a vault constructed and maintained under a permit issued to a public service corporation in front of real property not owned or leased by it, and every person making or having charge of any such vault shall, during the whole of such time such vault shall be open or uncovered, cause the same to be guarded and enclosed with a strong box or curb at least three (3) feet high, and in addition thereto shall at night cause a lighted lamp or lantern to be placed and kept thereon, so as to cast a light upon such vault during the whole of every night. The provisions of this section, however, shall apply to a public service corporation where it has received a permit to install a vault in front of real property not owned or leased by such public service corporation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(7); Ord. of 7-1-57, § 2)  
Sec. 7-4-27. - Time limit on work. 
All vaults shall be completed and the ground closed over them within three (3) weeks after their construction has been commenced, unless an extension of time shall be granted by the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(8))  
Sec. 7-4-28. - Sidewalks. 
The sidewalk over a vault shall be laid according to the sidewalk specifications of the city and shall at all times conform with the established grade and be kept in good condition and repair. Whenever the grade is changed the vault must be changed and repaved at the expense of the owner or permittee, as the case may be, of the abutting property, other than a vault constructed and maintained under a permit issued to a public service corporation in front of real property not owned or leased by it. The provisions of this section, however, shall apply to a public service corporation where it has received a permit to install a vault in front of real property not owned or leased by such public service corporation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(9); Ord. of 7-1-57, § 2)  
Sec. 7-4-29. - Notice when relocation of underground construction is necessary. 
Owners or lessees of abutting property shall notify the public utility companies concerned and the commissioner of public works when the removal or relocation of any underground construction is made necessary by the construction of a vault. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 11(10); Ord. of 6-21-54, § 3)  
Secs. 7-4-30—7-4-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 7-4-41. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any space, or cause any excavation to be made, under the surface of any street, alley or other public place for or to cause or require any vault to be constructed or made in any street, alley or other public place in the city without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a permit therefor as herein provided. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 2)  
Sec. 7-4-42. - Application. 
(a)  The owner of the fee of real property in the city or the lessee of such real property holding under a long term lease of ten (10) years or more, desiring to procure a permit for a vault in front of such real property, or a public service corporation, shall make and sign a written application to the commissioner of public works upon forms provided by the city, at least forty-five (45) days before starting the excavation. Such application shall give the name and address of the applicant, the location of the existing or proposed vault, the use made or intended to be made thereof, the nature of all fixtures, machinery and appliances therein or to be placed therein, and such other information as the commissioner of public works may require. If the applicant be the lessee, or a public service corporation, the applicant shall obtain the written consent of the owner of said property for the construction of the vault, which consent shall be attached to and made a part of said application. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by plans showing the location and dimensions of the existing or proposed vault, the number, size and location of all existing or proposed openings therein from the street, the method or proposed method for protecting such openings, the character of the existing or proposed construction and the existing or proposed method of draining the vault. The commissioner of public works shall forthwith upon receipt thereof refer such application and plans to the commissioner of building for his action. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 3; Ord. of 6-21-54, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 1; Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-43. - Agreement to abandon vault space, etc. 
(a)  The application for the permit required by the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a written agreement upon a blank form provided by the city and signed by the owner and lessee, if any, of the abutting property, that: 
(1)  He, his heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns shall: 
a.  Permit the use of such vault as set forth in section 7-4-3 of this Code; 
b.  Hold the city harmless from any claims for damages to himself or the occupants of such property resulting from gas, sewage or water leaking into such excavation; 
c.  Release, relinquish, vacate and remove without cost to the city all machinery, fixtures and structural parts of or in such vault within ten (10) days after having been ordered in writing to do so by the commissioner of public works or after the revocation of the permit notwithstanding payment of rent or fee; 
(2)  In case of failure to comply with the written order of the commissioner of public works within the time specified the commissioner of public works may cause the same to be done and all expenses incurred or damages paid by the city on account thereof shall be paid to the city by the person to whom the permit is granted upon demand; 
(3)  The city may at any time enter upon the premises for inspection and proper maintenance of anything therein; and 
(4)  The permit is granted with the understanding that the occupancy and use of such space underneath the sidewalk or other public place by the applicant, his heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns is merely an accommodation and no right, title or interest of the public is in any way waived or abridged thereby. 
(b)  If the applicant for such permit is a public service corporation the provisions of this section shall apply to such public service corporation and not to the owner or lessee of the abutting property. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 4; Ord. of 6-21-54, § 2; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 1) 
Cross reference— Deposit for installation of underground vaults, § 7-3-44.  
Sec. 7-4-44. - Issuance, form, assignment, revocation and record. 
(a)  Upon the filing of the application, bond and agreement as required by the provisions of this article, and upon the written approval of the application and plans by the commissioner of building, the commissioner of public works may, upon his approval of the application and agreement and the payment to the city of the fee hereinafter required, issue to the applicant a permit for one year. 
(b)  No permit shall be refused except for a specific reason and for the protection of the city's interest or the safety of the public. 
(c)  All permits shall state clearly the location and size of the vault, the dates of issuance and expiration of the permit, the fee paid, and the name and address of the person to whom the permit is issued. Permits shall be consecutively numbered, nontransferable and nonassignable and revokable by the commissioner of public works upon thirty (30) days' notice at any time the commissioner of public works shall deem revocation advisable for the protection of the city's interest or the safety of the public or for a violation of the provisions of this chapter or any order issued pursuant thereto. 
(d)  A copy of each permit so issued shall be kept on file in the office of the commissioner of public works and copies thereof shall be forthwith upon the issuance of each permit filed by the commissioner of public works with the commissioner of building and the commissioner of finance of the city. 
(e)  In case of the denial of any application or the revocation of any permit, the commissioner of public works shall notify the applicant of the denial of such application or revocation of such permit, as the case may be, in writing, giving his reasons for such denial or revocation. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 5; Ord. of 10-21-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-45. - Expiration. 
All permits and renewal permits issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the thirtieth day of September following the issuance of such permits or any renewals thereof. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 5; Ord. of 5-4-54, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-46. - Fees. 
The person making, using or maintaining any structure as described in section 7-4-41 of this Code shall pay the city such privilege for the first year an amount calculated at the rate of four hundred dollars ($400.00) per square foot for each square foot of ground occupied or required for such vault including the walls and footings thereof. The sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) shall be paid for each subsequent annual renewal of the said permit provided the required bond has been renewed or is still in full force and effect. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 6; Ord. of 8-6-90, § 1; Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 4-3-00, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 5; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 5; Ord. of 5-30-19, § 3, eff. 7-1-19 )  
Sec. 7-4-47. - Transfer. 
Any person to whom a permit has been granted pursuant to the provisions of this article, who conveys the abutting property, or assigns the lease thereon, may notify the commissioner of public works, in writing, of such conveyance or assignment of such lease, and furnish the commissioner of public works, in writing, with the name and address of the purchaser or assignee thereof. Upon the giving of such notice, in writing, and furnishing the name and address of such purchaser or assignee, such person may procure from the commissioner of public works a permit to close such vault in a manner similar to the balance of the sidewalk in front of such premises, otherwise, such purchaser or assignee shall pay a transfer fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and sign an agreement as provided herein, whereupon a renewal permit will be issued to such purchaser or assignee covering and applying to the same vault space specified in the original permit, and it shall not be necessary for the person to whom the original permit was issued to close such opening. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 3; Ord. of 6-21-54, § 1; Ord. of 7-1-57, § 1)  
Sec. 7-4-48. - Permits issued under previous orders. 
Whenever any person holding a contract or permit for the construction or maintenance or use of any vault, which shall have been issued or made under the terms of any ordinance or legal order heretofore in force, the conditions of which have been and are now being fully complied with, shall apply for a permit hereunder and shall desire to have the permit or contract heretofore entered into cancelled, the commissioner of public works shall cancel the same as regards any liability thereunder arising after the date of the issuance of the new permit hereunder, but such contract or permit and the bond given therewith shall remain in full force and effect as to all rights and liabilities accruing under the same, including all amounts due the city for fees or compensation under the same, up to the time of such cancellation. The fee for the said cancellation and issuance of the new permit shall be the same as the annual renewal fee and shall extend said permit for one year. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 7)  
Sec. 7-4-49. - Removal of unpermitted structures. 
Any person using space underneath any sidewalk or other public place for a vault or any person constructing or commencing the construction of a vault who fails to procure a permit as herein provided, shall, in addition to the other penalties imposed by this chapter, be required by the commissioner of public works to remove every such structure and restore the ground to its original condition within ten (10) days after the service upon him of a written notice so to do. In default thereof, the commissioner of public works shall perform the work and the costs shall constitute a debt of such owner to the city, the same to be recovered in a civil action. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 10)  
Sec. 7-4-50. - Appeals. 
(a)  In case of a denial by the commissioner of public works of an application for any permit required by this chapter or its revocation by him, the applicant or the licensee may within ten (10) days appeal from the decision of such commissioner of public works to the common council. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be served personally upon the city clerk. At the same time the appellant shall pay to the city through the city clerk one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such appeal shall include a copy of the application for the permit, with its date of filing in the office of the commissioner of public works, and a copy of such permit, in case a permit shall have been issued, and a copy of the reasons relied on by the commissioner of public works as justifying him in denying the application or in revoking such permit, as the case may be. Such service, with the payment of the said sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00), shall act as a stay in preventing the commissioner of public works from filling in and restoring the space occupied by any such vault which shall have been constructed or made pursuant to any such permit or which may have been heretofore constructed or made pursuant to any ordinance heretofore enacted or otherwise in accordance with law, until a decision of the common council of such appeal. 
(b)  The decision of the common council shall be entered on the minutes thereof and a copy thereof, over the signature of the city clerk, mailed to the appellant, the commissioner of public works and the corporation counsel of the city. In case the decision of the common council shall be in favor of the appellant, the said sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) paid by him to the city through the city clerk shall forthwith be returned to him, otherwise said sum shall be retained by the city to cover the cost to the city of such appeal. The decision of the common council shall be final, and, if in favor of the appellant, the commissioner of public works shall forthwith issue the permit or reinstate the permit revoked, as the case may be. 
(Ord. of 10-3-38, § 19; Ord. of 5-3-93)  
Chapter 7-5 - TREES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4. 
Cross reference— Fastening handbills on trees and other public property, § 5-3-2; protection of trees in parks, § 6-2-8; trees removed for construction of driveways, § 7-3-28. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Note— See the editor's note to art. II of this chapter. 
 
Sec. 7-5-1. - Authority of commissioner of public works generally. 
(a)  The commissioner of public works shall have the authority to act on all matters pertaining to the planting, maintenance, protection and control of shade trees planted or growing upon the public highways or public places in the city. 
(b)  Within the provisions of the city charter and this chapter and with the approval of the common council, said commissioner shall make proper and necessary rules with reference to such matters: 
(1)  To regulate the work to be done on trees now standing, such as pruning, trimming, spraying and cavity work; 
(2)  To select proper trees to fill in the openings caused by the removal of dead trees and the prohibition of any damage which may tend either to retard the health or growth of the trees and to select the variety to be planted on any street. 
(c)  The records of the commissioner shall be open at all reasonable times to public inspection. The commissioner shall cause to be fully published such regulations as he may adopt relating to tree culture. 
(d)  All planting of shade trees on the public highways or public places of the city shall be done by the commissioner, the employees of the department of public works or by persons or corporations under the control of and responsible to the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 1)  
Sec. 7-5-2. - Planting generally. 
Except as otherwise provided, no person shall hereafter plant any tree within the limits of any parkway, street or public place in the city. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(a))  
Sec. 7-5-3. - Killing, breaking, trimming, etc.; permit. 
It shall be unlawful, without the written permit of the commissioner of public works, to cut, break or trim any tree, shrub or plant planted or growing in any park or public highway within the city or to remove any device set for the protection of any tree, shrub or plant in any public highway or city park of said city. Any person desiring for any lawful purpose to remove, cut, prune or trim any tree in any park or public highway of the city shall apply to the commissioner of public works and if in the judgment of the commissioner of public works the desired removal, cutting, pruning or trimming shall appear necessary or desirable and the proposed method and workmanship thereof be such as said commissioner of public works approves, the commissioner of public works shall thereupon issue a written permit for such work, to be done under the supervision of and as directed by the commissioner of public works or his representatives. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, §§ 2(b), (c))  
Sec. 7-5-4. - Trees authorized for street plantings. 
(a)  The following trees only may be used for street tree planting: 
American elm 
Crimean linden 
Silver linden 
European linden 
Tulip tree 
Red maple 
Sugar maple 
Pin oak 
Scarlet oak 
White oak 
Sweet gum 
Red oak 
(b)  The commissioner of public works may from time to time add to or reduce the above list. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(d))  
Sec. 7-5-5. - Attaching wires to trees; location of poles or posts. 
No person without a written permit from the commissioner of public works shall: 
(1)  Attach or cause to be attached any electric wire, insulator or any device for the holding of any electric wire to any tree growing or planted in any public highway or any public place in the city; or 
(2)  Cause or authorize or permit a wire or other conductor charged with electricity to come in contact with any tree in any public highway or city park in the city; or 
(3)  Locate, place or maintain any pole or post in such a manner as to interfere with any tree or shrub growing upon any public highway, park or public place in the city; or 
(4)  Cause any wire to be attached to any tree in any manner. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(e))  
Sec. 7-5-6. - Fastening animals. 
No person shall fasten or cause to be fastened or tied a horse or other animal to, or post any bill, card, notice or advertisement of any kind or attach a sign to any tree, bush or shrub in any public highway or public place in the city or allow any horse or other animal owned by him or in his charge to stand so near any such tree, bush or shrub that the same may be gnawed or otherwise injured by such horse or other animal so allowed to stand. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(f))  
Sec. 7-5-7. - Planting specifications. 
Trees shall be planted at least thirty (30) feet apart, except where special permit is obtained from the commissioner of public works. No tree shall be planted measuring less than two (2) inches in diameter of trunk one foot above ground. The trunk of each tree shall be without branches for not less than seven (7) feet, six (6) inches, nor more than nine (9) feet from the ground. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2)  
Sec. 7-5-8. - Placement of stone, cement, etc., around roots; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful except with the written permit of the commissioner of public works to place or maintain upon the ground in any public highway or city park within the city any stone, cement or other material or substance in such manner as may obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of any tree in any such highway or park. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided for in such written permit as above provided for, there must be maintained about the base of the trunk of each shade tree in the public highway and city parks of the city at least six (6) square feet of open ground for a tree of three (3) inches in diameter. 
(c)  No violation under this section shall occur until thirty (30) days after a specific written notice has been served by the commissioner of public works on the owner or offender. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(g))  
Sec. 7-5-9. - Dump harmful substances near trees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, authorize or permit any brine, oil, gas, gasoline, liquid dye or other substance deleterious to tree life, to lie, leak, pour, flow, or drip on or into the soil about the base of a tree in any public highway or city park in the city, or upon a sidewalk, road or pavement therein, at a point whence such substance may in any manner whatsoever injure each tree. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(1))  
Sec. 7-5-10. - Interference with enforcement.
