It shall be unlawful to interfere or cause or authorize any interference with the commissioner of public works or any employee, agent or servant of the department of public works engaged in planting, cultivating, pruning, spraying or removing any tree in any public highway in the city or city park or in the removal of any device attached to such a tree. 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 2(i))  
Sec. 7-5-11. - Penalty. 
Any person who does any act or thing or causes or directs any act or thing to be done in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by a fine of not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. of 12-31-29, § 3; Ord. of 5-3-93) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 7-5-12—7-5-21. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PROTECTION, PRESERVATION AND MAINTENANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Inclusion of the provisions of §§ I—VII of a resolution adopted Nov. 5, 1984, as ch. 7-5, art. II, §§ 7-5-22—7-5-28, was at the discretion of the editor, the resolution being nonamendatory of the Code. The provisions of the existing ch. 7-5, §§ 7-5-1—7-5-11, were designated as art. I, with the word "chapter" changed to "article" where necessary. 
 
Sec. 7-5-22. - Goals and objectives. 
The city's overall goal is to protect and preserve worthwhile healthy trees, and where removal is necessary, to replenish trees for both aesthetic and many environmental benefits. The city's principal objectives are to: 
(a)  Protect and preserve as many trees as possible, particularly specimen trees and/or select or rare species. 
(b)  Begin a program of reforestation and replacement of those trees which must be removed due to disease or development of the site. 
(c)  Ensure an acceptable level of green foliage in intensely developed areas and retain this feature in low-density suburban settings. 
(d)  Ensure that suitable wildlife habitats are maintained and reinforced in all sections of the city. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § I)  
Sec. 7-5-23. - Definitions. 
(a)  Canopy road tree protection zones: All lands within twenty-five (25) feet of the curbline of major streets and expressways as identified on the land use plan map of the city's comprehensive plan. 
(b)  Crown: All portions of a tree excluding the trunk and roots, such as branches, leaves, flowers and other foliage. 
(c)  Disturbances areas: Any area of a site which will be altered from its natural state as a result of development under a permit issued pursuant to an approved building plan, site plan, conservation development or subdivision plan. 
(d)  Environmentally sensitive site or features: A "lot," plot, parcel or portion thereof, or a characteristic or element of or on such land, as described in chapter 3-5 of the Municipal Code and meeting the thresholds set forth at section 3-5 thereof. 
(e)  Pre-construction site development plan: A plan setting forth how the site will be prepared for and impacted by construction and how the trees, tree clusters, environmentally sensitive features and non-disturbance areas will be preserved and protected. 
(f)  Primary tree protection zone: That portion of a lot constituting the front, side and rear yard setbacks, as established by section 5.3 of the Zoning Ordinance; in cases where the special building setbacks appearing on the zoning map are greater, they shall be the controlling dimension. 
(g)  Protected trees: Red and white dogwood; copper beech; black walnut; mulberry; birch. 
(h)  Road right-of-way tree protection zone: 
(1)  Land in which a governmental entity or property owner owns a legal interest in a roadway or has an easement devoted to or required for the use of the land as a road; 
(2)  That land designated as a road right-of-way by records on file in the department of public works. 
(i)  Secondary tree preservation zone: All land not included in the primary tree protection zone except for sidewalks and street rights-of-way. 
(j)  Specimen tree(s): Trees which have a minimum trunk diameter of twelve (12) inches at a point four (4) feet above the natural grade and/or a minimum crown spread of fifteen (15) feet; any other tree or grouping of trees deemed significant by an approving agency. 
(k)  Tree: Any woody plant having at least one (1) well-defined trunk at least four (4) inches in diameter measured at a height of four (4) feet above the natural grade and having a clearly defined crown; 
(l)  Tree preservation committee: The commissioners of planning and public works and the environmental officer. 
(m)  Tree protection, preservation and reforestation plan: A plan identifying and showing the location, type, size and health of trees; stating the ultimate disposition of the trees; showing the type, size and location of any trees to be planted; and setting forth measures to protect trees before, during and after construction. 
(n)  Tree removal: Any act which causes a tree to die within two (2) years after commission of the act, including but not limited to damage inflicted upon the root system or trunk as the result of: 
(1)  The improper use of machinery on the trees; 
(2)  The storage of materials in or around the trees; 
(3)  Soil compaction; 
(4)  Altering the natural grade to expose the roots or to cover the trunk; 
(5)  Permitting the infection or infestation of the tree by pests, fungus or harmful bacteria; 
(6)  Excessive harmful pruning; 
(7)  Paving with concrete, asphalt or other impervious surface within such proximity as to be harmful to the tree; and 
(8)  Application of herbicides or defoliants to any tree without first obtaining a permit. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § II; Res. of 2-5-96, § 1)  
Sec. 7-5-24. - Applicability. 
These guidelines shall be applied to pending and future development proposals on undeveloped land or portions of otherwise developed sites; redevelopment projects on land to be cleared of structures; conservation developments and conventional subdivisions; plans for new one- and two-family homes and any other development proposals as determined by an approving agency. 
Approving agencies shall use these guidelines in the review and approval of applications for building plans, site plans, special permits, variances, conservation developments, conventional subdivisions and subdivisions involving environmentally sensitive sites and features. 
The tree preservation committee shall follow these guidelines in reviewing and making recommendations on applications on referral from the approving agency, and in the review and approval of pre-construction site development plans and on-site implementing procedures pursuant to section 7-5-28 of these guidelines. In general, modifications recommended by the tree preservation committee affecting elements of an approved plan which are under the jurisdiction of the commissioner of public works shall have the prior approval of the commissioner of public works. 
Technical assistance will be available from the conservation board, the department of planning, the department of public works, the environmental officer and other staff as needed. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § III; Res. of 2-5-96, § 2)  
Sec. 7-5-25. - Application requirements. 
An applicant shall provide the approving agency with a tree protection, preservation and reforestation plan containing at least the following information unless deemed not pertinent or necessary by the agency or official approving the plan. 
(a)  An inventory of existing trees, showing type, location, size and condition. The inventory shall include specimen and protected trees, trees or groupings of trees deemed significant, all trees with a minimum trunk diameter of eight (8) inches at a point four (4) feet above the natural grade, and any grouping of twenty (20) or more trees. 
(b)  An integrated site plan showing the trees to be saved and those to be removed, utilities to be installed, grading, the approximate location of all structures, driveways and curb cuts and proposed tree plantings and other landscaping. 
(c)  A detailed plan to protect and preserve trees before, during and for a period of two (2) years after construction. This shall include a written statement setting forth those steps to be taken to protect trees, roots and crowns from damage during site clearance, excavation, grading, installation of utilities, paving and construction. 
The above items may be integrated into the normal application requirements and submittals. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § IV)  
Sec. 7-5-26. - Standards. 
The approving agency shall apply the following standards in reviewing all development applications and shall attach such conditions and safeguards to any applications as are in its opinion deemed necessary. [4] 
(a)  Healthy specimen and protected trees and other trees deemed significant by the approving agency located in the primary tree protection zone, the canopy tree protection zones and in the road right-of-way tree protection zone shall be preserved where feasible. [5] 
(b)  Healthy specimen and protected trees and other trees deemed significant located in the secondary tree protection zone may be required to be preserved at the discretion of the approving agency. 
(c)  Healthy specimen and protected trees and other trees deemed significant by the planning board located in conservation development required perimeter setback shall be preserved where feasible. Additionally, healthy specimen and protected trees, and other significant trees in other sections of the conservation development may be required to be preserved at the discretion of the planning board. 
(d)  To preserve healthy and specimen trees, particularly in the secondary tree preservation zones, and to maintain the site's unique natural character and environmentally sensitive features as shown on the approved plans including any conditions and attachments thereto, trees and environmentally sensitive features shall be preserved, to the maximum extent feasible, in clusters within their natural setting. 
(e)  Prior to the commencement of any development activity on any part of a site, the tree preservation committee shall meet with the developer, his construction manager or the developer's designee to ensure: 
(1)  That those trees, tree clusters, and environmentally sensitive features designated on the approved plans to be preserved are physically identified on the site so as to be easily recognizable as being protected; and 
(2)  That agreed-to measures to protect trees before, during and for a period of two (2) years after construction are implemented. 
(3)  That areas shown on the approved plans as not to be disturbed shall have no equipment, building, soil or other debris or materials stored on them. These areas of preservation may eventually be enhanced by the planting of additional appropriate trees or other types of landscaping. 
(f)  On any site or part thereof where the approving agency has determined that additional measures are necessary to ensure the protection and preservation of trees, tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features during development of the site, particularly sites with environmentally sensitive features, the approving agency may make issuance of permits required for the development under the approved plan subject to approval by the tree preservation committee of a pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementing procedures pursuant to section 7-5-28 of these guidelines. 
(g)  Reforestation plans shall generally conform to the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Shade and/or decorative trees shall be planted at a ratio of at least one (1) tree per twenty-five hundred (2,500) square feet of lot area or major fraction thereof. [6] 
a.  Trees to be planted in one- and two-family residential districts should have a minimum trunk diameter of two and one-half (2½) inches at a point two (2) feet above the finished grade. [7] 
b.  Trees to be planted in all other districts should have a minimum trunk diameter of three and one-half (3½) to four (4) inches at a point two (2) feet above the finished grade. 4 
(2)  In selecting locations to plant trees, priority should be given to that section of the lot within a canopy tree protection zone and the front yard setback. 
(3)  Credit toward the reforestation requirements shall be at a ratio of one (1) preserved healthy specimen or protected tree or other tree deemed significant for one (1) required planting. [8] 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § V; Res. of 2-5-96, §§ 3, 4) 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Healthy trees can only be saved through cooperation between the approving agency and the applicant. However, the burden of identifying and selecting those trees to be protected and preserved as well as new trees to be planted rests with the developer. He must comply with the city's standards. This will require better site planning on his part and more thorough review by approving agencies and officials. 

--- (5) --- 
The approving agency should be flexible in applying standard (a). It should not create a safety hazard or be so absolute as to make a project technically and/or financially impossible or burden an owner with trees that severely limit the use or enjoyment of his property. However, the applicant must consider tree preservation in design and site planning and justify the removal of any trees. 

--- (6) --- 
Plantings shall be nursery stock with a minimum one year guarantee. 

--- (7) --- 
The agency or official approving the reforestation plan may modify the minimum standards to accommodate special types of trees which may not conform to these standards. 

--- (8) --- 
Preservation of trees within the road right-of-way protection zone are not eligible for credit. 
 
Sec. 7-5-27. - Review. 
The approving agency shall refer all tree preservation, protection and reforestation plans to the tree preservation committee for review and report prior to taking action on the application. 
Except for development applications involving sites which are environmentally sensitive or contain environmentally sensitive features, as defined in the Municipal Code at section 3-5-2 and section 3-5-3, for development applications involving smaller projects of less than ten (10) required parking spaces, or less than three (3) required parking spaces in the central parking area, approval of the applications may be conditioned upon submitting a plan subject to approval by the tree preservation committee. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § VI; Res. of 2-5-96, § 5)  
Sec. 7-5-28. - Review and approval of pre-construction site development plans and on-site implementation procedures. 
This section shall apply to development on any site or part thereof under an approved building plan, site plan, conservation development, subdivision plan or other approved plan where the approving agency has made issuance of permits for the development of the site subject to review and approval by the tree preservation committee of a pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementing procedures. 
(a)  For an approved project meeting the above requirement, the developer shall prepare and the tree preservation committee shall review a pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementation procedures for pre-construction phase activities which shall include the following: 
(1)  Pre-construction phase I activities: Activities subject to review in this initial phase include site preparation for rights-of-way, streets, utility easements, and construction equipment and materials storage areas. 
(2)  Pre-construction phase II activities: Activities subject to review in this phase include site preparation for building lots, detention basins, drainage swales and other development activities not included in phase I. 
The basis for preparation of the pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementation procedures, shall be the plan approved by the approving agency including all conditions and attachments thereto. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of any permits for phase I activities, except as may be required to provide limited access to the site for the sole purposes of surveying the site and analyzing trees and site conditions, the following procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  The developer shall prepare a pre-construction site development plan showing boundaries and maximum disturbance areas for the rights-of-way, streets, utility easements and construction equipment and materials storage areas that are proposed to be developed. 
(2)  The maximum disturbance areas for the activities shown on the phase I pre-construction site development plan shall be clearly staked and marked on the site. 
(3)  Any trees, tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features which are required to be preserved according to the approved plan and which are located in or within ten (10) feet of disturbance areas for phase I activities and shown on the pre-construction site development plan, shall be clearly marked, cordoned off and protected in a manner prescribed by the tree preservation committee. 
(4)  After the phase I pre-construction site development plan has been received by the tree preservation committee and all disturbance areas and areas to be protected have been marked and protected on-site according subsections (2) and (3) above, the tree preservation committee shall inspect the site with the developer or his designee and the professional, as required by the approving agency, who developed the pre-construction site development plan, to determine that all trees, tree clusters, and environmentally sensitive features to be preserved according to the approved plan and the proposed pre-construction site development plan have been properly identified and protected on the site. The tree preservation committee may make recommendations to the developer for modifications to the proposed pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementation procedures to better protect trees, tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features. 
(5)  Except as provided in paragraph (b) above, no departments or agencies shall issue any permits for phase I activities until the tree preservation committee has filed a report approving the pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementing procedures with the approving agency and the departments and agencies responsible for issuing said permits. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of any permits for phase II activities, the following procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  The developer shall submit a staged pre-construction development plan for phase II activities for approval by the tree preservation committee. The plan shall designate the clusters of lots to be reviewed in each stage. The plan shall indicate the proposed maximum disturbance area on each lot in each lot cluster and show within the disturbance areas the maximum approved building foot print in a location having the least impact on existing grades, trees, tree clusters, and environmentally sensitive features. Tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features will necessarily cross lot lines and, within the approved lot layout, tree preservation and preservation of environmentally sensitive features shall be achieved irrespective of lot lines. 
(2)  The maximum disturbance areas for the phase II activities and the maximum building footprint as shown on the phase II pre-construction site development plan shall be clearly staked and marked on the site, and the environmentally sensitive features, trees and trees clusters to be preserved shall be properly identified and protected in a manner prescribed by the tree preservation committee. 
(3)  After the phase II pre-construction site development plan has been reviewed by the tree preservation committee and the developer has marked the site and protected trees, the tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features on-site according paragraph (2) above, the tree preservation committee shall inspect the site with the developer and/or his designee and with the professional who developed the pre-construction site development plan, as required by the approving agency, to determine that all trees, tree clusters, and environmentally sensitive features shown to be preserved on the approved plans and the pre-construction site development plan have been properly identified and protected on the site. The tree preservation committee may make recommendations to the developer for modifications to the proposed pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementation procedures to preserve and protect the trees, tree clusters and environmentally sensitive features. 
(4)  No departments or agencies shall issue any permits for phase II activities until the tree preservation committee has filed a report approving the pre-construction site development plan and on-site implementing procedures for the phase II activities with the approving agency and with the departments and agencies responsible for issuing said permits. The tree preservation committee may issue separate approval reports for separate clusters of lots. 
(Res. of 2-5-96, § 5)  
Sec. 7-5-29. - Penalties. 
It is the stated intention of this article to preserve and maintain a sufficient number of trees and a suitable wildlife habitat throughout the city. Therefore, elimination of trees in violation of conditions imposed by the approving agency shall cause the city to seek penalties which lead to the restoration of adequate plantings to meet those goals. 
Upon any violation of the tree preservation, protection and reforestation plan, the commissioner of building shall issue a stop-work order immediately setting forth the grounds for its issuance and may require that remedial actions be taken. In cases where trees are removed or destroyed, or at the discretion of the commissioner of building, the remedial actions shall be agreed to by the approving agency before a stop-work order may be cancelled. 
The approving agency shall apply to a court of competent jurisdiction to obtain whatever penalties are permitted by law. Once legal proceedings are initiated, such proceedings shall not be withdrawn or discontinued unless a reforestation plan has been agreed to by the applicant. 
Removal of healthy specimen and protected trees or other trees deemed significant after the effective date of this article but prior to submitting an application or during the review process shall be considered a violation of this article and all appropriate sanctions may be applied. 
(Res. of 11-5-84, § VII; Res. of 2-5-96, § 5) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Chapter 7-6 - SOLID WASTES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Garbage collection, § 117. 
Cross reference— Rubbish and litter in parks, § 6-2-9; maintenance of dwelling units so as to be free from rubbish and garbage, § 9-8-220.7. 
 
Sec. 7-6-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(a)  Business area: The area of the city devoted to stores, office buildings, commercial enterprises, manufacturing or other similar business and commercial endeavors. This area shall include stores, restaurants and other establishments with high-waste productions. 
(b)  Collection: The physical picking up of garbage, refuse or other materials by municipal forces. 
(c)  Commissioner: The commissioner of public works of the city or his duly authorized representative or agent. 
(d)  Garbage: Nonrecyclable wastes resulting from the distribution, preparation and servicing of foods. Garbage may originate from domestic or commercial units. Garbage does not include processing wastes from the food industry or animal wastes from veterinary hospitals and veterinary doctors. 
(e)  Ordinary refuse: The routine solid wastes produced in residences and commercial establishments, including garbage and rubbish, but excluding designated recyclables. 
(f)  Refuse: The general term used to describe the total nonhazardous solid waste originating in a community and requiring physical removal from the place of origin to a place of ultimate disposal. This term includes garbage, rubbish and trash produced by households, commercial establishments, special community activities, manufacturing plants and institutions. Refuse is divided into two (2) general classifications, ordinary refuse and trash. 
(g)  Rubbish: The general dry material produced routinely and consists of such waste material as nonrecyclable paper, non- recyclable cans, nonrecyclable bottles, other nonrecyclable and nonhazardous containers and ashes. 
(h)  Street: Any public street, highway, road, lane, alley, way, park, parking area, grounds or other public areas. 
(i)  Trash: All other kinds of nonhazardous solid waste material originating in a community. Trash is distinguished from refuse by special or seasonal characteristics which place it outside the ordinary refuse that is produced in the community and collected and disposed of as a regularly scheduled feature of refuse operations. Trash, therefore, shall include all nonhazardous objects requiring special consideration and handling in refuse operations, such as: 
(1)  Leaves, brush, branches, Christmas trees, lawn rakings and similar waste material produced on a seasonable basis and representing intermittent or seasonal collection problems. 
(2)  Bulky objects such as discarded refrigerators or furniture, which are discarded occasionally and which do not fit into regular refuse collection vehicles. 
(3)  Specialized waste material presenting a special handling problem either in collection or disposal. 
(j)  Nonresidence: A building or parcel of land not used primarily as a residential dwelling unit. 
(k)  Recyclables and designated recyclables: Items designated for recycling, to be separated from ordinary refuse and collected for reuse, reduction or remanufacturing. 
(l)  Source separated: The separation of designated recyclables from ordinary refuse at the point of waste generation for separate collection or other disposition. 
(m)  Commingled recyclables: Designated food and liquid/beverage containers, bottles, jars and cans, which have been rinsed of food residue, and mixed together in the same container for recycling collection. 
(n)  Contaminated recyclables: Recyclables not in a condition acceptable for reuse, reduction or remanufacturing. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1, Ord. of 3-6-95)  
Sec. 7-6-2. - Unlawful deposits. 
No person shall throw, cast or lay, or direct, suffer or permit any servant, agent or employee to throw, cast or lay any ashes, offal, vegetables, garbage, dross, cinders, shells, straw, shaving, paper, dirt, swill, brine, filth, broken glassware, crockery, bottles, or any offensive animal matter, or any bad smelling or noxious liquid or refuse of any kind whatsoever in any street of the city, either upon the roadway or sidewalk thereof or in any public place. All loose material shall be put in proper containers or receptacles as provided by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1) 
Charter reference— Police power of city, § 4.  
Sec. 7-6-3. - Containers. 
(a)  Owners or occupants of private houses, apartment houses, business or commercial buildings, or lots, desiring to have ashes, garbage, paper, boxes, light refuse or rubbish removed by the city, shall place such material in metal or substantial plastic containers equipped with adequate handles for lifting and suitable lids or covers for keeping the contents protected from vermin and animals and from scattering by wind. The city will not be responsible for damage to any containers, covers or private property necessary for access to refuse collections sites. 
(b)  Each manually unloaded container shall have a capacity not exceeding thirty (30) gallons or three (3) bushels, shall be filled to a level no higher than four (4) inches below the top and shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds total weight, including contents. 
(c)  Such containers shall be placed on the premises at a location readily accessible, at ground level, outside of any building or other enclosure. Material from buried or recessed cans in the ground will not be collected unless such cans have been cleared of ice and snow and made accessible. Any damage to any buried or recessed appliance or can will not be the responsibility of the city. 
(d)  Automated loading containers must be compatible with the city's refuse collection vehicles, and shall contain suitable cover(s) and shall be constructed of reinforced heavy gauge steel or molded polyolefin cross-linked plastic. These containers must meet all applicable U.S. Federal Safety Standards and C.P.S.E. (U.S. Consumer Product Safety Standards). Additionally, "Tipping Resistance Specification ANSI Z.275.3" shall be exceeded. All such containers must be located on a reinforced concrete pad with suitable collection vehicle access and screening, according to city specifications. They shall be filled to a level no higher than four (4) inches below the top. 
(e)  Rear-loading type containers shall be equipped with a minimum of four (4) heavy-duty wheel assemblies two (2) fixed and two (2) caster type having a minimum tire diameter of six (6) inches. These containers are to be equipped with side handles/hooks, and a center hook, to be compatible with the city's winch unloading mechanism. No container shall have a manufacturer's rated capacity of more than three (3) cubic yards, nor a total gross weight, including contents, of more than three thousand (3,000) pounds. 
(f)  Front-loading type containers shall be equipped with side receptacles capable of accepting the "Flipper Arms" of the city's refuse vehicles. The containers must be reinforced with ribbing to maintain rigidity and shape during rugged loading and unloading operations, and any access doors shall be self-closing during dumping. No container shall have a manufacturer's rated capacity of more than eight (8) cubic yards, nor a total gross weight, including contents, of more than six thousand (6,000) pounds. 
(g)  Side-loading type containers will not be permitted. 
(h)  The municipal collection of recyclables shall be in containers prescribed by the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 3(a)—(c); Ord. of 12-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-4. - Rubbish not placed in containers; unbundled refuse; corrugated cardboard. 
(a)  Rubbish of such nature and size that it cannot be placed in metal containers shall be compactly bundled, covered and securely tied. Rugs and carpeting shall be tightly rolled and tied with rope or twine. Such rolls shall not exceed six (6) feet in length. Corrugated cardboard cartons and boxes shall be broken and tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long, eighteen (18) inches wide and eighteen (18) inches high. All other material shall be properly secured to prevent scattering thereof by animals or wind. Refuse not properly bundled or tied up will not be picked up by the city. 
(b)  If the average quantity of standard sized cardboard boxes placed for collection at each nonresidence exceeds twenty-five (25) per week, then such nonresidence is required to privately recycle such corrugated cardboard. 
(c)  Loose-piled leaves will be picked up at curbside only during the period from October 1 through December 10. Leaves are not to be stored in or along the gutter of the pavement or within ten (10) feet of catch basins. At all other times, they must be placed in sealed, biodegradable bags at the curb. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 3(d); Ord. of 12-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 9-9-92, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-5. - Transportation of garbage or refuse originating outside city. 
No person shall transport into the city any garbage or refuse which originated outside of the city without the permission of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 3(e); Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-6. - Placement of materials in public trash receptacles. 
No person shall place in a public trash receptacle maintained by the city in any public place, including but not limited to sidewalks, streets, public parking areas, parking garages and public buildings, any garbage or refuse, that originates from a house, place of business or elsewhere. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 3(f); Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-7. - Disposal of dead animals. 
Dead animals shall be disposed of as directed by the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-8. - Removal of litter receptacles. 
No person shall remove a public litter receptacle maintained by the city on a pubic sidewalk or at a publicly-owned place or city-owned building from the position established by the commissioner to another position without the express permission of the commissioner. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 3(g); Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-9. - Placement for collection; removal of containers after collection. 
(a)  In the business area, all ashes, garbage, light refuse recyclables or rubbish shall be placed at the curb except Saturday, Sunday and holidays. No refuse or recyclables shall be placed on the curb or on the sidewalk or in the doorway of a store prior to 6:00 a.m.. In all other areas, any refuse, rubbish, bulk trash, or recyclable materials positioned at the curb shall be so placed only on a designated collection day between 6:00 a.m. and the time of collection. 
(b)  Empty metal containers shall be removed by the owner, tenant or occupant within one-half hour after the collection by municipal forces. 
(c)  Doors shall be removed from the hinges of all ice boxes, refrigerators, freezers, gas or electric stoves, or other major metal appliances with doors affixed, prior to being placed on the curb for collection. 
(d)  In the event of ice or a snowfall of more than three (3) inches in depth, a suitable pathway from the curb to the refuse container shall be provided; and said path shall be strewn with sand, de-icer pellets or some other approved abrasive material as necessary. Failure to comply with this requirement for residential as well as commercial properties may result in temporary suspension of refuse collection, until container access is improved. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 4(a), (b); Ord. of 12-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 10-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-10. - Placement of newspapers and commingled recyclables. 
(a)  The owners, lessees or occupants of single- and multi-family dwellings and nonresidences are responsible to separate recyclables from municipally collected ordinary refuse and shall separately place newspapers and commingled recyclables for collection and recycling by the department of public works or its duly authorized agent. 
(b)  No person shall place recyclables in a receptacle designated for ordinary refuse pickup, but rather, such recyclables shall be source separated and these packages shall be placed within the vicinity of the curb, edge of pavement, or in other authorized location, for collection on days specified by the commissioner. 
(c)  When recyclables are placed within the vicinity of the curb or edge of pavement for pickup collection and recycling, they shall become the property of the department of public works and it shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person, firm or corporation other than the owner, lessee or occupant of the residential dwelling or a duly authorized agent of the department of public works, to disturb or pick up such packages or bags of newspapers and/or recyclables for his own use. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 4(d); Ord. of 9-3-74, § 1; Ord. of 2-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 9-9-92, § 2; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-11. - Items city will not collect. 
(a)  The following materials will not be picked up by municipal forces: corrugated cardboard in excess of twenty-five (25) standard size boxes per week from any location or establishment, designated recyclable office paper, wood over three (3) inches in diameter or over four (4) feet long, including tree stumps, tree trunks, branches and other wood; railroad ties, telephone poles, discarded automobiles and trucks, house renovation discards, construction debris such as lumber, concrete, plaster, dirt, rock, brick, black-top or large wooden crates or boxes, stones or quantities of sod, flammable or highly combustible matter such as cleaning establishment wastes or other industrial and household hazardous wastes found to contain varnish, paint, thinner or other dangerous materials, sawdust, explosives, ammunition, oil drums either full or empty, cans or barrels containing combustible liquids, rubber tires, rubber wastes, batterycases, tar paper roofing, tar cans or any large metal products or abandoned machinery and television tubes. 
(b)  The city will not pick up burned out or used television, X-ray, fluorescent, neon or cathode tubes, unless such tubes have been broken to release the vacuum present inside. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 5; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-12. - Authority of commissioner to regulate city's collection. 
(a)  The commissioner shall have the authority to regulate the amount of material to be removed and the method of removal by the city, in accordance with the city's ability to effect such removal. 
(b)  Up to six (6) metal or plastic containers, each having a maximum capacity of thirty (30) gallons, shall be collected at each general location or establishment. As an alternative, up to three (3) automated type, rear-loading containers may be used in lieu of the smaller thirty-gallon manual loading containers. 
(c)  Effective July 1, 1987, the city will provide the additional alternative of collection of a maximum of two (2) automated type, front-loading containers. 
(d)  All containers at a particular location or establishment must be of the same configuration. For example, automated, front-loading and smaller manual loading containers cannot be presented at the same stop. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 6; Ord. of 12-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-13. - Covering vehicles. 
All refuse transported on a city street in trucks or other vehicles shall be covered with suitable covers to prevent scattering or dropping on said street. 
(Ord. of 2-3-69, § 7)  
Sec. 7-6-14. - Sale of scrap metal, etc., found in refuse collections. 
The commissioner of public works is hereby authorized, from time to time, to sell on the open market or at private sale, scrap metal and other waste materials of any kind found or contained in the refuse collection of the city at the best price obtainable or at a price which will be for the best interests of the city, or to make contracts for periods not exceeding one year, for such sale of such scrap metal and other waste materials. 
(Ord. of 4-1-57, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-95)  
Sec. 7-6-15. - Landscape gardener permits for dumping of compostable material. 
(a)  Compostable material consisting solely of leaves, or lawn rakings produced on a seasonal basis, shall be accepted, at the city's Gedney Way Recycling Yard from landscape gardeners having a valid permit issued by the commissioner. Such permit shall be issued to landscape gardeners who have been retained on behalf of city residents for the purpose of yard care of their respective property within the city limits. A permit shall consist of a coupon book, containing twenty (20) perforated coupons, which shall be issued to a landscape gardener after payment of a one thousand and five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) dumping fee and submission of a completed application form listing the city resident's name and address, and bearing the signature of said resident. Only one (1) coupon book will be issued per resident at any given time. Upon utilization of all coupons in a book, or the expiration of the book (which shall expire two (2) years from the issuance date), said permit shall be invalidated and another must be obtained to continue the landscape gardener's dumping privileges for that particular resident. 
(b)  Compostable material which has absolutely no grass or lawn rakings in it shall be accepted by using a special "No Grass" coupon book, which shall be issued after a payment of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and submission of a completed application form. All other standard coupon book rules and requirements shall apply to this book. 
(c)  Each truckload of up to four (4) cubic yards of acceptable material shall require the landscape gardener to present the coupon book to the Gedney Yard gatekeeper, who shall remove one (1) coupon and return the book. Trucks with more than four (4) cubic yards of material shall result in multiple removal of coupons for every successive four (4) cubic yards of material, or portion thereof. 
(d)  The commissioner shall have the authority to revoke the Gedney Yard permit from any landscape gardener at any time, based upon the city's ability to accept material at the Gedney Yard. In this event, the city shall refund any remaining fee on a pro rata basis according to the number of coupons left in the coupon book. Further, the commissioner shall have the authority to immediately revoke a landscape gardener permit, without reimbursement, or ban subsequent issuance of permits to the subject landscape gardener, or any combination thereof when abuse of said permit has occurred, i.e. attempts to dump material which is not attributable to the property location listed on permits, or nonacceptable material such as hazardous waste, garbage, rubbish, or any materials listed in section 7-6-11. 
(Ord. of 5-7-90, § 2; Ord. of 5-3-93; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-07, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 6; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 6; Ord. of 5-21-12, § 1)  
Sec. 7-6-16. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, except for section 7-6-10, shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine which shall not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) in amount, nor exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in amount and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in amount, nor exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in amount, or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(b)  Refuse receptacles which contain recyclables mixed with other refuse may not be collected or serviced until such recyclables have been removed therefrom. Any person violating any of the provisions of section 7-6-10 shall in the first instance be warned and shall, in the case of any subsequent violation, either be solely responsible for the separation of recyclables from the offending refuse containing recyclables or upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine which shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) in amount, or both such separation of refuse and fine for each such violation. 
(Ord. of 4-5-76, § 1; Ord. of 12-1-86, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-88, § 1; Ord. of 5-7-90, § 1; Ord. of 9-9-92, § 3; Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1; Ord. of 10-4-10, § 10) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 7-6-17. - Compliance to Westchester County Source Separation Law. 
Pursuant to Chapter 825 of the Laws of Westchester County, the "Westchester County Source Separation Law," the city designates the commissioner of public works as the local enforcement official for said county law. 
(Ord. of 3-6-95, § 1)  
Chapter 7-7 - PROHIBITION OF ILLICIT DISCHARGES, ACTIVITIES AND 
[1]
Footnotes: 
 
Sec. 7-7-1. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this amendment to the Municipal Code is to provide for the health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the City of White Plains through the regulation of connections to the city's municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) and the regulation of nonstorm water discharges to the MS4 to the maximum extent practicable as required by federal and state law. This chapter establishes methods for controlling the introduction of pollutants into the MS4 in order to comply with requirements of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation's (NYSDEC) SPDES General Permit (GP-02-02) for municipal separate storm sewer systems. The objectives of this chapter are: 
(a)  To meet the requirements of the SPDES General Permit for Storm Water Discharges from MS4s, Permit No. GP-02-02 or as amended or revised; 
(b)  To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the MS4 since such systems are not designed to accept, process or discharge nonstorm water wastes; 
(c)  To prohibit unauthorized and illicit connections, activities and discharges to the MS4; 
(d)  To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter; and 
(e)  To promote public awareness of the hazards involved in the improper discharge of trash, yard waste, lawn chemicals, pet waste, wastewater, grease, oil, petroleum products, cleaning products, paint products, hazardous waste, sediment and other pollutants into the MS4. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Approving agency shall mean the City of White Plains governing body, board or officer charged by the Zoning Ordinance of the City of White Plains with the authority to approve a land use application, such as a special permit, site plan, subdivision, conservation development, area variance, or use variance. 
(2)  Best management practices (BMPs) shall mean schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to storm water, receiving waters, or storm water conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
(3)  City shall mean the City of White Plains, New York. 
(4)  City engineer shall mean the Commissioner of Public Works of the City of White Plains. 
(5)  Clean Water Act shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
(6)  Code shall mean the Municipal Code of the City of White Plains. 
(7)  Commissioner shall mean the Commissioner of Public Works of the City of White Plains, or his duly authorized representative. 
(8)  Connection permit shall mean an authorization for connection as well as a discharge permitted under section 7-7-14 of this chapter, as well as a discharge permitted under a SPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the NYSDEC. This permit is subject to special terms and conditions by the city engineer. The permit will expire on or before the expiration of the NYSDEC SPDES permit, waiver or order or upon change of ownership or use of the property. 
(9)  Construction activity shall mean activities requiring authorization under a NYSDEC SPDES permit for storm water discharges from construction activity, GP-02-01, as amended or revised, or activities covered by erosion and sediment control or pollution prevention plan laws, ordinances or regulations of the city. These activities include construction projects resulting in land disturbance equal to or greater than the area stipulated in statutes or regulations of the state, county or the city, whichever is most restrictive. Such activities include, but are not limited to, clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
(10)  County shall mean the County of Westchester. 
(11)  Design professional shall mean New York State licensed professional engineer or licensed architect. 
(12)  The words "directed," required," "permitted," "ordered," "designated," "selected," "prescribed," "determined," "certified," "specified," "or words of like import used in this chapter shall mean, respectively, the direction, requirement, permission, order, designation, selection, prescription, determination, certification or specification of the commissioner of public works. 
(13)  Drainage service line shall refer to the pipe or conduit laid between his connection point on a storm water drain and a building or property for the purpose of conducting waste other than domestic sewage and other than injurious water liquids from the said building or property into the said storm water drain. 
(14)  General permit shall mean an authorization for the connection as well as the discharge of storm water or authorized nonstorm water (per section 7-7-4(d)(1) of this chapter), from properties occupied by private dwellings. 
(15)  Hazardous materials shall mean any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
(16)  Illicit activity shall mean any action or condition, active or passive, that results in nonstorm water entering the city's MS4. 
(17)  Illicit connection shall mean any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illegal discharge to enter the MS4 including, but not limited to: 
(a) Any conveyances which allow any nonstorm water discharge including treated or untreated sewage, process wastewater and wash water to enter the MS4, and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted or approved by an authorized enforcement agency; or 
(b) Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the MS4 which has not been documented in plans, maps or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency; 
(c) Any building or structure floor drain or trench drain; and 
(d) Any unauthorized connection as defined elsewhere in this section. 
(18)  Illicit discharge shall mean any discharge through an unauthorized connection, and any direct or indirect nonstorm water discharge to the MS4, except as exempted in section 7-7-4 of this chapter. 
(19)  Individual sewage treatment system shall mean a facility serving one or more parcels of land or residential households, or a private, commercial or institutional facility that treats sewage or other liquid wastes for discharge into the ground waters of New York State, except where a permit for such a facility is required under the applicable provisions of Article 17 of the Environmental Conservation Law. 
(20)  Industrial activity shall mean activities requiring the SPDES permit for discharges from industrial activities except construction, GP-98-03, as amended or revised. 
(21)  Invert shall mean the lowest point in the internal cross section of a sanitary sewer, storm water drain, house sewer or drain. 
(22)  MS4 shall mean municipal separate storm sewer system owned by the city or another municipal entity. 
(23)  Municipal separate storm sewer system shall mean a conveyance or system of conveyances and retention and infiltration facilities; (including roads with drainage systems, curbs and gutters on municipal streets, manholes, catch basins, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains, storm water basins, drainage reserve areas, drywells or any other component of a storm water system) that is: 
(a) Owned or operated by the city or another municipal entity; 
(b) Designed or used for collecting or conveying or storing or infiltrating or managing storm water; 
(c) Which is not a combined sewer; and 
(d) Which is not part of a publicly owned treatment works (POTW) as defined at 40 CFR 122.2. 
(24)  Municipality shall mean a county, town, city, village or other unit of government. 
(25)  Nonstorm water discharge shall mean any discharge to the MS4 that is not composed entirely of storm water. 
(26)  NYSDEC shall mean the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. 
(27)  Office of the city engineer shall mean the Office of the City Engineer of the City of White Plains or office of the commissioner of public works. 
(28)  Person shall mean any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
(29)  Pollutant shall mean anything, which causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to, dredged spoil, filter backwash, solid waste, incinerator residue, treated or untreated sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, hazardous materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand and industrial, municipal, agricultural waste and ballast discharged into water; which may cause or might reasonably be expected to cause pollution of the waters of the state in contravention of the standards. Also, paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; hazardous or nonhazardous liquid and solid wastes, yard wastes including branches, grass clippings and leaves; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects and accumulations so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; and discharges of soaps, detergents, or floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; sewage, fecal coliforms and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building, structure or site improvements; cement, gravel, sand, silt, mud, other soils, and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
(30)  Premises shall mean any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
(31)  Sanitary sewer shall refer to the lateral or street sewer or manhole built thereon in public street, highway, sidewalk area, easement or other public area and under the control of the city. 
(32)  Sewer service line shall mean the pipe or conduit laid between its connection point on a sanitary sewer and a building for the purpose of conducting domestic sewage and on-injurious water liquids from the said building into the said sanitary sewer. 
(33)  Sidewalk drain and curb drain shall refer to the pipe or other conduit laid under or across the sidewalk area between the curb or curb line and the property line for the purpose of conducting roof and surface water from buildings and ground into the gutter. 
(34)  Special conditions shall mean: 
(a) Discharge compliance with water quality standards. The condition that applies where the city's MS4 has been notified that the discharge of storm water authorized under the city's MS4 SPDES permit may have caused or has the reasonable potential to cause or contribute to the violation of an applicable water quality standard. Under this condition the MS4 must take all necessary actions to ensure future discharges do not cause or contribute to a violation of water quality standards. 
(b) 303(d) listed waters. The condition in an MS4 SPDES permit that applies where the MS4 discharges to a NYSDEC 303(d) listed water. Under this condition the MS4's storm water management program must ensure no increase of the listed pollutant of concern to the 303(d) listed water. 
(c) Total maximum daily load (TMDL) strategy. The condition in an MS4 SPDES permit where a TMDL including requirements for control of storm water discharges has been approved by EPA for a water body or watershed into which the MS4 discharges. If the discharge from the MS4 did not meet the TMDL storm water allocations prior to September 10, 2003, the MS4 was required to modify its storm water management program to ensure that reduction of the pollutant of concern specified in the TMDL is achieved. 
(d) The condition in an MS4 permit that applies if a TMDL is approved in the future by EPA for any water body or watershed into which an MS4 discharges. Under this condition, the city must review the applicable TMDL to see if it includes requirements for control of storm water discharges. If the city's MS4 is not meeting the TMDL storm water allocations, the city must, within six (6) months of the TMDLs approval, modify its storm water management program to ensure that reduction of the pollutant of concern specified in the TMDL is achieved. 
(35)  Special permit shall mean an authorization for the connection as well as the discharge of storm water or authorized nonstorm water (per section 7-7-4(d)(1) of this chapter), from all properties occupied by other than private dwellings. 
(36)  State shall mean the State of New York. 
(37)  State pollutant discharge elimination system (SPDES) storm water discharge permit shall mean a permit issued by the NYSDEC that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the state. 
(38)  Storm water shall mean rainwater, surface runoff, subsurface drainage and snowmelt. 
(39)  Storm water drain shall refer to the lateral or main storm water drain in public street, highway, sidewalk area, easement or other public area, and under the control of the city. 
(40)  Storm water management officer (SMO) shall mean the Commissioner of Public Works of the City of White Plains (or the person serving in the capacity of the city engineer) or his/her authorized deputies, agents or representatives, including employees of other city departments, as appropriate. The SMO is to enforce this code, review storm water pollution prevention plans, cause the forwarding of the plans to the applicable approving agency and inspect storm water management practices. 
(41)  303(d) list shall mean a list of all surface waters in the state for which beneficial uses of the water (drinking, recreation, aquatic habitat, and industrial use) are impaired by pollutants, prepared periodically by the NYSDEC as required by Section 303(d) of the Clean Water Act. 303(d) listed waters are estuaries, lakes and streams that fall short of state surface water quality standards and are not expected to improve within the next two (2) years. 
(42)  TMDL shall mean Total Maximum Daily Load. 
(43)  Total maximum daily load shall mean the maximum amount of a pollutant allowed to be released into a water body so as not to impair uses of the water, allocated among the sources of that pollutant. 
(44)  Unauthorized connection shall mean a permanent or temporary unapproved direct or indirect conveyance to the city's MS4. Any connection, pipe, hose, or other conveyance that is not documented on plans, maps, or equivalent records signed by the city engineer or that is not approved by a permit issued by the city engineer, is considered unauthorized regardless of whether the discharge is otherwise allowed by this chapter. 
(45)  Uncontaminated shall mean "free of pollutants" (see definition of "pollutant"). 
(46)  Wastewater shall mean water that is not storm water is contaminated with pollutants and is or will be discarded. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-3(a). - Applicability. 
This chapter shall apply to discharged connections to the city's MS4. This includes activities that result in discharge, seepage or deposition into the city's MS4, and all water entering the MS4 generated on any developed and undeveloped lands unless explicitly exempted by an authorized enforcement agency and allowed by a discharge or connection permit or other document approved by the city engineer. This chapter shall also apply to discharges and connections entering another MS4 that is tributary to the city's MS4. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-3b. - Responsibility for administration. 
The commissioner of public works, as the storm water management officer (SMO) for the city, or duly authorized deputies, agents or representatives, including employees of other city departments, as appropriate, shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-3c. - Severability. 
The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable. If any provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this chapter or the application thereof to any person, establishment, or circumstances shall be held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions or application of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-4. - Restriction as to type or amount of discharge. 
(a)  No domestic sewage, industrial wastes or injurious waste substance shall be discharged into a storm water drain, watercourse or body of water through any connection thereto. 
(b)  No industrial wastes or any injurious waste substances shall be discharged into a sanitary sewer unless the method and degree of treatment, prior to discharge, have been approved by the Commissioner of Health of the County of Westchester, the Commissioner of Public Works of the County of Westchester and the Commissioner of Public Safety of the County of Westchester, and unless such method and degree of treatment continues at all times to meet with such approval. 
(c)  Subject to the prior approval of the city's commissioner of public works, waste lines from a swimming pool shall be connected into a sanitary sewer and discharge of waste water from a swimming pool into the sanitary sewer shall be restricted to the period between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. The size of the discharge line at the point of connection shall not, in general, exceed four (4) inches, and may be further reduced by the city's commissioner of public works at his or her discretion. 
(d)  Prohibition of illegal discharges. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the city's MS4 any materials other than storm water except as provided in subsection 7-7-4(d)(1). The commencement, conduct or continuance of any illicit (illegal) discharge to the MS4 is prohibited except as described as follows: 
(1)  The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this Code, unless they are subsequently determined to be substantial contributors of pollutants: water line flushing or other potable water sources, uncontaminated landscape irrigation or lawn watering, existing diverted stream flows, rising ground water, uncontaminated ground water infiltration to storm drains, uncontaminated pumped ground water, foundation or footing drains, uncontaminated crawl space or basement sump pump discharges, air conditioning condensate, uncontaminated irrigation water, springs, water from individual residential car washing, natural riparian habitat or wetland flows, dechlorinated swimming pool discharges, residential street wash water, water from fire fighting activities, and any other water source not containing pollutants. Such exempt discharges shall be made in accordance with an appropriate plan for reducing pollutants. 
(2)  Discharges approved in writing by the city engineer to protect life or property from imminent harm or damage, provided that such approval shall not be construed to constitute compliance with other applicable laws, codes and requirements, and further provided that such discharges may be permitted for a specified time period and under such conditions as the city engineer may deem appropriate to protect such life and property while reasonably maintaining the purpose and intent of this Code. 
(3)  Dye testing in compliance with applicable state and local laws or codes is an allowable discharge, but requires a verbal notification to the city engineer prior to the time of the test. 
(4)  The prohibition shall not apply to any discharge permitted under a SPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the NYSDEC, provided that the discharger is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and other applicable laws, codes and regulations, and provided that written approval has been granted for any discharge to the MS4 by the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-5. - Service lines, taps, etc., generally. 
(a)  The installation and repair of sewer or drainage service lines within the limits of any public street, highway or easement or other public property, and the connections of such lines to the sanitary sewers or storm water drains of the city shall be done in accordance with the provision of the rules and regulations of the city's department of public works and shall also conform to such specifications as may be promulgated by the commissioner. The tapping of water mains and the installation and repair of water service lines, in addition to such herein above rules, regulations and specifications, shall also conform with the rules and regulations for the water bureau of the department of public works. 
(b)  A sewer service line between its connection point at the sanitary sewer and a point at least two (2) feet back of existing curb or established or proposed curb line, shall be of heavy cast iron pipe with lead joints or such other approved types of joints as may be allowed by the Department of Building of the City of White Plains and shall be laid by a licensed plumber. 
(c)  A drainage service line, between its connection point at the storm water drain and a point at least two (2) feet back of existing curb or established or proposed curb line, shall be of heavy cast iron pipe or other material as approved by the commissioner. 
(d)  Such service lines shall be laid on a straight alignment and uniform gradient of not less than one-fourth (¼) of an inch per foot unless otherwise specifically authorized by the commissioner, and having all changes in direction made with approved fittings. 
(e)  Connections to the city's MS4 without a permit are prohibited. 
(1)  Any connection to the city's MS4 is considered to be an unauthorized connection unless it has been approved by a permit issued by the city engineer or documented on a plan, or map that has been approved by the city engineer. This constraint applies to all connections, permanent or temporary, regardless of whether the discharge is otherwise permitted by this chapter. 
(2)  The construction, use, maintenance or continued existence of unauthorized connections to the city's MS4 is prohibited. 
(3)  This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was permissible under law, code or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of connection. 
(4)  A person is considered to be in violation of this Code if the person connects a line conveying sewage or other pollutants to the city's MS4, or allows such a connection to continue. 
(5)  The connection of interior floor drains and trench drains at the entrances to buildings or other structures is prohibited. 
(f)  Remedy unauthorized connections. Where the city engineer has identified an unauthorized connection as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter, the city engineer may require that a proper permit be obtained or that the connection be removed at the property owner's expense. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 1)  
Sec. 7-7-5.1. - Owner's maintenance responsibility. 
The property owner shall, at his own expense, keep in good order, repair and shall maintain in a proper operating condition, all sanitary sewer and storm water drain service lines and associated appurtenances serving his property from and including the point of connection at the public municipal sanitary sewer or storm water drain to the building or structure serviced. 
The commissioner of public works may direct the owner to repair or replace any or all portions of said service lines to prevent leaks or to eliminate illegal or improper connections. All repairs to sanitary sewer and/or storm water drain service lines shall be done in an approved manner by a plumber licensed in the city in accordance with the applicable requirements of the department of public works and the department of building. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-6. - Connection specifications. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, connections to sanitary sewers and storm water drains shall be made by means of forty-five (45) degree or ninety (90) degree M-D cut-in connections of approved size, as manufactured by Joseph G. Pollard Co., Inc., or approved equal. 
(b)  The use of an existing Y-branch, or other existing fitting, for the purpose of connecting a service line thereto, shall be allowed only when such branch or fitting is already available and in place as part of sanitary sewer or storm water drain, is in satisfactory condition and at an acceptable location, and is of adequate size to receive said service line. 
(c)  A manhole shall be built over a sanitary sewer or storm water drain at the point of connection, whenever the proposed service line to be connected is five (5) inches or greater and the sanitary sewer or storm water drain is eight (8) inches or less, or when the proposed service line is greater than six (6) inches and the sanitary sewer or storm water drain is ten (10) inches or more, unless otherwise specifically authorized. The above sizes refer to the internal diameter of the pipes or conduits. 
(d)  M-D cut-in connections and other approved types of connections shall be installed in such a manner that the invert of said connection shall be higher than the invert of sanitary sewer or storm water drain by an amount not less than one-half (½) the vertical diameter of said sanitary sewer or not less than three-fourths (¾) the vertical diameter of said storm water drain unless otherwise authorized by the commissioner of public works. 
(e)  Connections to an existing cast iron pipe sanitary sewer or storm water drain shall be made by burning an opening in said pipe in an approved manner or by such other means as may be authorized by the commissioner of public works. 
(f)  When a connection is made into an existing manhole or when a manhole is required to be built at the point of connection, as specified herein above, the invert of the service line at the point of connection shall be higher than the invert of the sanitary sewer or storm water drain by an amount not less than the vertical diameter of said sanitary sewer or storm water drain, unless otherwise authorized by the commissioner of public works. 
(g)  When the difference in invert elevation in the manhole at the point of connection exceeds three (3) feet, a drop connection shall be installed in said manhole. 
(h)  Adequate provision shall be made so that the discharge from a service line within a manhole shall be conducted smoothly into, and in the direction of flow of, the main channel of the sanitary sewer or storm water drain by means of a built-up channel or by extending said service line partly into the manhole as may be necessary and in such manner as may be approved by the commissioner of public works. 
(i)  Construction of new manholes, drop connections and any other necessary structures and connections to existing structures, shall conform with such specifications as may be promulgated by the commissioner. In general, the current standard specifications and construction details of the department of public works shall be followed, subject to the prior approval of the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-7. - Building drainage. 
(a)  Roof and other drainage from properties on which buildings are hereinafter constructed shall be discharged through drainage service lines directly into a storm water drain through an approved connection thereto when such a storm water drain is available and unless such connection, in the opinion of the commission, is deemed impracticable. 
(b)  Discharge of such drainage through sidewalk or curb drains and discharge or roof or other drainage from any privately owned buildings or properties into a catch basin will not be allowed, except with the prior approval of the commissioner and provided that the owner of said property has filed with the commissioner a signed statement by said owner that the city is to be saved harmless from any loss, injury or damage arising out of the approval of the commissioner of public works of the discharge of drainage into a catch basin or through sidewalk or curb drains. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-7A - Manner of discharge of unpolluted water. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, including sump pumps, to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet or as approved by the commissioner. Exceptions to this requirements are any discharges for which the discharger must apply for a SPDES permit and those discharges subject to direct state and federal regulation. 
(Ord of 3-7-16 , § 1)  
Sec. 7-7-8. - Sidewalk and curb drains. 
(a)  Unless otherwise authorized in writing by the commissioner of public works, drainage outlets laid under or across the sidewalk area between the property line and the curb line, and discharging into the gutter or into a catch basin or curb inlet, shall be of approved cast iron or steel construction. 
(b)  When holes are cut through curbs, for the purpose of providing drainage outlets, care shall be taken not to damage curb and any damage or injury to said curb shall be repaired by the permittee at the latter's own expense and to the satisfaction of the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-9. - Prohibition against failing individual sewage treatment systems. 
No persons shall operate a failing individual sewage treatment system in areas tributary to the city's MS4. A failing individual sewage treatment system is one which has one or more of the following conditions: 
(a)  The backup of sewage into a structure. 
(b)  Discharges of treated or untreated sewage onto the ground surface. 
(c)  A connection or connections to a separate storm water sewer system. 
(d)  Liquid level in the septic tank above the outlet invert. 
(e)  Structural failure of any components of the individual sewage treatment system that could lead to any of the other failure conditions as noted in this section. 
(f)  Contamination of off-site groundwater. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-10. - Prohibition against activities contaminating storm water or maintaining or using an unauthorized connection to the city's MS4. 
(a)  Activities that are subject to the requirements of this section are those types of activities that: 
(1)  Cause or contribute to a violation of the city's MS4 SPDES permit. 
(2)  Cause or contribute to the city being subject to the special conditions as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter. 
(3)  Cause or contribute to the city's MS4 receiving pollutants as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter. 
(4)  Cause or contribute to the city's MS4 receiving discharges from an undocumented or unauthorized connection (whether permanent or temporary). 
(b)  Such activities include failing individual sewage treatment systems as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter, improper management of pet waste or any other activity that causes or contributes to violations of the city's MS4 SPDES permit authorization. 
(c)  Upon notification to a person that same is engaged in activities that cause or contribute to violations of the city's MS4 SPDES permit authorization or causes or contributes to pollutants being discharged to the city's MS4, that person shall take all reasonable actions to correct such activities such that same no longer causes or contributes to violations of the city's MS4 SPDES permit authorization, or causes or contributes to pollutants to be discharged or deposited into the city's MS4. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-11. - Requirement to prevent, control and reduce storm water pollutants by the use of best management practices. 
(a)  Best management practices. Where the city engineer has identified illicit discharges as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter or activities contaminating storm water as defined in section 7-7-4 of this chapter, the city engineer may require implementation of best management practices (BMPs) to control those illicit discharges and activities. 
(1)  The owner or operator of a commercial or industrial establishment shall provide, at its own expense, reasonable protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials, pollutants or other wastes into the MS4 through the use of structural and non-structural BMPs. 
(2)  Any person responsible for a property or premise, which is, or may be, the source of an illicit discharge as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter or an activity contaminating storm water as defined in section 7-7-9 of this chapter, may be required to implement, at said person's expense, additional structural and non-structural BMPs to reduce or eliminate the source of pollutant(s) to the MS4. 
(3)  Compliance with all terms and conditions of a valid SPDES permit authorizing the discharge of storm water associated with industrial activity, to the extent practicable, shall be deemed in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Individual sewage treatment systems. Response to special conditions requiring no increase of pollutants or requiring a reduction of pollutants: 
Where individual sewage treatment systems are contributing to the city's MS4 being subject to the special conditions as defined in section 7-7-2 of this chapter, the owner or operator of such individual sewage treatment systems shall be required to: 
(1)  Maintain and operate individual sewage treatment systems as follows: 
a.  Inspect the septic tank annually to determine scum and sludge accumulation. Septic tanks must be pumped out whenever the bottom of the scum layer is within three (3) inches of the bottom of the outlet baffle or sanitary tee or the top of the sludge is within ten (10) inches of the bottom of the outlet baffle or sanitary tee. 
b.  Avoid the use of septic tank additives. 
c.  Avoid the disposal of excessive quantities of detergents, kitchen wastes, laundry wastes and household chemicals; and 
d.  Avoid the disposal of cigarette butts, disposable diapers, sanitary napkins, trash and other such items. 
(5)  Repair or replace individual sewage treatment systems as follows: 
a.  In accordance with 10 NYCRR Appendix 75A to the maximum extent practicable. 
b.  A design professional licensed to practice in New York State shall prepare design plans for any type of absorption field that involves: 
1.  Relocating or extending an absorption area to a location not previously approved for such. 
2.  Installation of a new subsurface treatment system at the same location. 
3.  Use of alternate system or innovative system design or technology. 
c.  A written certificate of compliance shall be submitted by the design professional to the city at the completion of construction of the repair or replacement system. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-12. - Suspension of access to MS4.
