(a)  The city engineer may, without prior notice, suspend MS4 discharge access to a person when such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge, which presents or may present imminent and substantial danger to the environment, to the health or welfare of persons, or to the MS4. The city engineer shall notify the person of such suspension within a reasonable time thereafter in writing of the reasons for the suspension. If the violator fails to comply with a suspension order issued in an emergency, the city engineer may take such steps as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the MS4 or to minimize danger to persons. 
(b)  Suspension due to the detection of illicit discharge or unauthorized connection. Any person discharging to the city's MS4 in violation of this chapter may have their MS4 access terminated if such termination would abate or reduce an illicit discharge or result in the remedy of an unauthorized connection. The city engineer or his or her duly authorized representative will notify a violator in writing of the proposed termination of its MS4 access and the reasons therefore. The violator may petition the city engineer for a reconsideration and hearing. Access may be granted by the city engineer if he/she finds that the illicit discharge has ceased and the discharger has taken steps to prevent its recurrence, or that the discharger has obtained proper permission for the connection. Access may be denied if the city engineer determines in writing that the illicit discharge has not ceased or is likely to recur or the unauthorized connection has not been remedied. A person commits an offense if the person reinstates MS4 access to premises terminated pursuant to this section, without the prior approval of the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-13. - Industrial or construction activity discharges. 
Any person subject to an industrial or construction activity SPDES storm water discharge permit shall comply with all provisions of such permit. Proof of compliance with said permit may be required in a form acceptable to the city engineer prior to the allowing of discharges to the MS4. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-14. - Connection permits. 
(a)  General. Any discharge or connection to the city's MS4 requires a permit issued by the Commissioner of Public Works. Applications for permits shall be made on forms provided by the department of public works. Permit applications shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, analyses, calculations or other information considered pertinent by the city engineer. The city considers any discharge to its MS4 as a last resort to solve flooding problems. Before approving any direct connection, the city will require that Applicants use on-site best management practices to handle storm water and other authorized non-storm water discharges to the maximum extent practicable. The department of public works will assess the adequacy of the applicant's on-site storm water disposal management practices. 
(b)  Permit types: 
(1)  General permit. An authorization for the connection as well as the discharge of storm water or authorized non-storm water (per section 7-7-4(d)(1) of this chapter), from properties occupied by private dwellings. 
(2)  Discharge permit . An authorization for connection as well as discharge authorized under section 7-7-14 of this chapter, as well as for a discharge permitted under a SPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the NYSDEC. This permit is subject to special terms and conditions by the city engineer. The permit will expire on or before the expiration of the NYSDEC SPDES permit, waiver or order or upon change of ownership or use of the property. 
(3)  Special permit . An authorization for the connection as well as any discharge of storm water or authorized non-storm water (per section 7-7-4(d)(1) of this chapter), from all properties occupied by other than private dwellings. 
(c)  Permit fees. The following fee schedule: 
(1)  General permit: Application and filing fee: ..... $250.00 
Inspection fee: ..... 350.00 
(2)  Section 7-7-2(d)(4) permit: Application and filing fee: ..... 2,000.00 
Inspection fee: ..... 3,000.00 
(3)  Special permit: Application and filing fee: ..... 1,750.00* 
Inspection fee: ..... 2,250.00* 
*At no time shall the total cost of a Special Permit Application fee and Inspection Fee exceed 50% of the cost of the storm water construction costs. The cost of construction will be determined by the Commissioner of Public Works after reviewing information submitted by the permitee. All determinations by the Commissioner will be final. 
In the case where any of the aforementioned permits shall be under review for a third time or more, the city may require the applicant to pay reasonable costs at prevailing rates for review of such permits. 
(d)  Inspection. Any physical connections to the city's MS4 shall be subject to the approval and inspection by the city. The applicant must notify the department of public works at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to commencing work and at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to final restoration. 
(e)  Indemnification. The property owner shall indemnify and save the city harmless from any loss, damage or expense, including reasonable attorneys fees and costs, claims or suits arising out of and in connection with the installation and connection to the city's MS4. In addition, the city makes no guarantee that its MS4 will not become surcharged or otherwise overburdened and that water from the MS4 will not back-up through the connection onto the owner's property. By making a connection, the applicant/owner assumes all of the risk and liability that may arise from it. 
(f)  Permit transfers. General permits may be transferred with the sale of a residential property, provided the use does not change. The new property owner shall comply with the terms and conditions of the transferred permit. Special permits are not transferable without approval of the commissioner of public works. 
(g)  Work within city roads. Any connection made within or involving work within a city road will also comply and be subject to any and all applicable codes and regulations pertaining to permits for work on and within city streets and roads. A permit under this chapter does not relieve the applicant from the permits under the foregoing codes and regulations. 
(h)  Other permits required. A connection permit issued pursuant to this Code does not relieve the applicant from any and all other permits, permissions, or compliance with rules and regulations that may be required by federal, state, county, town, city government agencies or other public or private parties. This permit does not supersede any of the above. 
(i)  Permit rules and regulations. The commissioner of public works may promulgate rules and regulations for the permitting process within the constraints of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2; Ord. of 6-1-09, § 2; Ord. of 5-24-10, § 7; Ord. of 5-26-11, § 7; Ord. of 5-30-13, § 3, eff. 7-1-13; Ord. of 8-5-19, § 1 )  
Sec. 7-7-15. - Access and monitoring of discharges. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to all facilities that the city engineer must inspect to enforce any provision of this chapter, or whenever the authorized enforcement agency has cause to believe that there exists, or potentially exists, in or upon any premises any condition that constitutes a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  Access to facilities. 
(1)  The SMO shall be permitted to enter and inspect facilities public and private subject to regulation under this Code as often as may be necessary to determine compliance with this Code. If a discharger has security measures in force that require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, the discharger shall make the necessary arrangements to allow access to the SMO. 
(2)  Facility operators shall allow the SMO ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, examination and copying of records as may be required to implement this chapter. 
(3)  The city shall have the right to set up on any facility subject to this chapter such devices as are necessary in the opinion of the city engineer to conduct monitoring and/or sampling of the facility's storm water discharge. 
(4)  The city engineer has the right to require the facilities subject to this chapter to install monitoring equipment as is reasonably necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the discharger at its own expense. All devices used to measure storm water flow and quality shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy. 
(5)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the city access to a facility subject to this chapter are a violation of this chapter. A person who is the operator of a facility subject to this chapter commits an offense if the person denies the city reasonable access to the facility for the purpose of conducting any activity authorized or required by this chapter. 
(6)  If the SMO has been refused access to any part of the premises from which storm water is discharged, and he/she is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this chapter, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program designed to verify compliance with this chapter or any order issued hereunder, then the SMO may seek issuance of a search warrant from any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-16. - Notification of spills. 
Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any person responsible for a facility or operation, or responsible for emergency response for a facility or operation has information of any known or suspected release of materials which are resulting or may result in illegal discharges or pollutants discharging into the MS4, said person shall take all necessary steps to ensure the discovery, containment, and clean up of such release. 
In the event of such a release of hazardous materials said person shall immediately notify emergency response agencies of the occurrence via emergency dispatch services. In the event of a release of nonhazardous materials, said person shall notify the city engineer in person or by telephone or facsimile no later than the next business day. Notifications in person or by telephone shall be confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed to the city engineer within three (3) business days of the telephone notice. If the discharge of prohibited materials emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an on-site written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three (3) years. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-17. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of violation: When the city engineer finds that a person has violated a prohibition or failed to meet a requirement of this chapter or a permit issued pursuant to this chapter, he/she may order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible person. Such notice may require without limitation any or all of the actions listed below: 
(1)  The elimination of illicit or unauthorized connections or discharges; 
(2)  That violating discharges, practices, operations, activities, or connections shall cease and desist; 
(3)  The abatement or remediation of storm water pollution or contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property; 
(4)  The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting; 
(5)  Payment of a fine; and 
(6)  The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs. If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is required, the notice shall set forth a deadline within which such remediation or restoration must be completed. Said notice shall further advise that, should the violator fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline, the work will be done by a designated governmental agency or a contractor and the expense thereof shall be charged to the violator. 
(b)  Penalties. In addition to or as an alternative to any penalty provided herein or by law, any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a violation punishable by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for a period not to exceed two (2) months, or both for conviction of a first offense; for conviction of a second offense both of which were committed within a period of five (5) years, punishable by a fine not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or imprisonment for a period not to exceed two (2) months, or both; and upon conviction for a third or subsequent offense all of which were committed within a period of five (5) years, punishable by a fine not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) nor more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or imprisonment for a period not to exceed two (2) months, or both. However, for the purposes of conferring jurisdiction upon courts and judicial officers generally, violations of this chapter shall be deemed misdemeanors and for such purpose only all provisions of law relating to misdemeanors shall apply to such violations. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate additional violation. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-18. - Appeal of notice of violation. 
Any person receiving a notice of violation may appeal within fifteen (15) calendar days of its issuance. The city engineer shall hear the appeal within thirty (30) days after the filing of the appeal, and within five (5) days of making his/her decision, issue a decision by certified mail to the discharger. The city engineer may conduct the hearing and take evidence or may designate in writing a hearing officer to do so. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-19. - Corrective measures after appeal. 
(a)  If the violation has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth in the notice of violation, or, in the event of an appeal, within five (5) business days of the decision of the city engineer, then the city engineer shall request the owner's permission for access to the subject private property to take any and all measures reasonably necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. 
(b)  If refused access to the subject private property, the city engineer may seek a warrant in a court of competent jurisdiction to be authorized to enter upon the property to determine whether a violation has occurred. Upon determination that a violation has occurred, the city engineer may seek a court order to take any and all measures reasonably necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. The cost of implementing and maintaining such measures shall be the sole responsibility of the discharger. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-20. - Injunctive relief. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter. If a person has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this chapter, the city engineer may petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the person from activities which would create further violations or compelling the person to perform abatement or remediation of the violation. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-21. - Alternative remedies. 
(a)  Where a person has violated a provision of this Code, same may be eligible for alternative remedies in lieu of a civil penalty, upon recommendation of the corporation counsel and concurrence of the city engineer, where: 
(1)  The violation was unintentional. 
(2)  The violator has no history of previous violations of this chapter. 
(3)  Environmental damage was minimal. 
(4)  Violator acted quickly to remedy violation. 
(5)  Violator cooperated in investigation and resolution. 
(b)  Alternative remedies may consist of, but are not limited to, one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Attendance at compliance workshops. 
(2)  Storm drain stenciling or storm drain marking. 
(3)  River, stream or creek cleanup activities; and 
(4)  Such other and further remedial actions which reasonably will promote environmental awareness and best management practices. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-22. - Violations deemed a public nuisance. 
In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is a threat to public health, safety, and welfare, and is declared and deemed a nuisance, and may be summarily abated or restored at the violator's expense, and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin, or otherwise compel the cessation of such nuisance may be taken. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-23. - Remedies not exclusive. 
The remedies listed in this chapter and any regulations promulgated thereto, are not exclusive of any other remedies available under any applicable federal, state or local law and it is within the discretion of the authorized enforcement agency to seek cumulative remedies. 
(Ord. of 12-20-07, § 2)  
Sec. 7-7-24. - Stop work orders. 
(a)  The city may issue a stop work order for violations of this chapter. Persons receiving a stop work order shall be required to halt all land development or redevelopment activities, except those activities that address the violations leading to the stop work order. The stop work order shall be in effect until the city confirms that the land development or redevelopment activity is in compliance and the violation has been satisfactorily addressed. Failure to address a stop work order in a timely manner may result in civil, criminal, or monetary penalties in accordance with the enforcement measures authorized in this chapter. 
(b)  Any work done without a required permit shall be subject to a five hundred dollar ($500.00) additional fee in addition to all applicable permit fees. 
(Ord. of 5-30-13, § 4, eff. 7-1-13)  
Chapter 7-8 - WATER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Water generally, § 182 et seq.; damaging water system, § 194; connecting supply pipes, § 196; water rates and charges, § 197. 
Cross reference— Enclosure of notices of newspaper pickup and glass salvaging in water and tax bill, § 2-1-6; contamination of watershed, § 3-1-1; restriction on activities in wetlands, § 3-5-3; prohibition of illicit discharges, activities and connections to the City of White Plains' municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) Ch. 7-7. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 7-8-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in this section: 
(a)  City shall mean the City of White Plains, New York. 
(b)  Commissioner shall mean the commissioner of public works of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
(c)  Rules and regulations shall refer to the herein contained rules and regulations approved and ratified by the common council, including any further rules and regulations or amendments that may be approved and ratified by the common council. 
(d)  Bureau of water shall mean the bureau of water of the department of public works of the city and the employees thereof. 
(e)  Water main shall mean the water pipe laid in a street, right-of-way, easement or other public ground and forming part of the water distribution system of the city. 
(f)  Fire main shall refer to the piping laid from a water main, including the connection to the main, for the purpose of conveying water for fire use from the city's water distribution system to fire hydrants not located on city property. 
(g)  Domestic service line shall refer to the piping laid from a water main other than a fire main or fire service line, including the connection to the main for the purpose of conveying water from the city's water distribution system into a building or property, to and including the official water meter, and shall include the gate valve with gate box, or corporation stop and curb stop with curb box. 
(h)  Fire service line shall refer to the piping laid from a water main or fire main, including the connection to the water main or fire main for the purpose of conveying water for fire protection from the water main or fire main into a building, and shall include the gate valve with gate box. 
(i)  House piping shall refer to all plumbing, including pipe, fixtures and other devices on the house side of the official water meter of the domestic service line. 
(j)  Official water meter shall mean a meter designated by the commissioner as being the water meter used to register the water consumption and shall include the remote register attached thereto complete with wiring and seals. 
(k)  Cross connection shall mean a physical connection through which a supply of potable water could be contaminated or polluted, or a connection between a supervised potable water supply and an unsupervised supply of unknown potability. 
(l)  Interconnection shall mean a physical connection between two (2) or more supervised water supply systems. 
(m)  Acceptable backflow prevention device shall mean an acceptable air gap, reduced pressure zone device or double check valve assembly as used to contain potential contamination within a facility. These devices shall meet the following criteria and shall be on the latest approved list of the New York State Department of Health as being acceptable for containment control in New York State. 
(1)  Air gap separation: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device and the flood level rim of the receptacle. The differential distance shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe. In no case shall the air gap be less than one (1) inch. 
(2)  Reduced pressure zone device (RPZ): A minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves, together with an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the two (2) check valves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks shall be less than the upstream (supply) pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the checks at less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. 
(3)  Double check valve assembly (DCV): Two (2) single independently acting check valves, including tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable test cocks for testing the water tightness of each check valve. 
(n)  Degree of hazard shall mean the classification of a facility as hazardous, aesthetically objectionable or nonhazardous in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Hazardous facility: A facility in which substances may be present which if introduced into the city's water supply system would or may endanger or have an adverse effect on the health of other water consumers. The city's water supply system shall be protected from potential contamination from the facility by means of an acceptable air gap or a reduced pressure zone device. 
(2)  Aesthetically objectionable facility: A facility in which substances are present, which if introduced into the city's water supply system could be a nuisance to other water consumers, but would not adversely affect human health. The city's water supply system shall be protected from potential contamination from the facility by means of an acceptable air gap, reduced pressure zone device or double check valve assembly. 
(3)  Nonhazardous facility: A facility which does not necessarily require the installation of an acceptable air gap, reduced pressure zone device or double check valve assembly but will require the installation of other types of devices to prevent backflow such as dual check backflow preventers to be used in conjunction with internal plumbing control. 
(o)  Containment shall mean cross-connection control which isolates the consumer's entire facility from the city's water supply system so as to provide the protection necessary to prevent contamination of the city's water supply system in the event of backflow from the consumer's facility. 
(p)  Contamination shall mean the presence in water of a substance that tends to degrade its quality. 
(q)  Plumbing control is prevention and elimination of cross connections within the consumer's water system by enforcement of building and plumbing codes. 
(r)  City's water supply system or city's water distribution system shall mean the water system of the city, including the source, treatment works, pumping stations, transmission mains, distribution system and storage facilities serving the public. 
(s)  Supplementary water supply shall mean any water source or system, other than the water supply of the city, that is available within the water consumer's facility. 
(t)  Outside consumer shall be a consumer who utilizes water supplied by the city to an improvement outside the city limits. 
(u)  Licensed plumber shall mean a plumber licensed by the city. 
(v)  Certified backflow prevention device tester shall mean a person who is certified by the New York State Department of Health as a backflow prevention device tester. 
(w)  Basic schedule shall mean the water rate schedule that applies to all per capita users and those non-per capita users who consume less than two hundred fifty thousand (250,000) cubic feet (cf) of water in any six-month period of the previous two six-month periods. 
(x)  Excess non-per capita schedule shall mean the water rate scheduled that applies to all non-per capita users with water consumption in excess of one hundred twenty thousand (120,000) cubic feet (cf) of water in any quarter of the previous four quarters. The commissioner of public works shall have the final authority to determine users in this class. 
(y)  Reserved. 
(z)  Meter transmission unit (MTU) shall mean the battery powered meter reading radio transmitter wired to a water meter used to record hourly, interval water usage data. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.01; Regs. of 4-27-81; Regs. of 7-3-85; Ord. of 4-7-04, § 1; Ord. of 12-6-10, § 1; Ord. of 12-5-11, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-16 , § 1)  
Sec. 7-8-2. - Applications for taps, service, etc. 
(a)  All applications for tapping and making connection to the water mains, fire mains or other water pipes of the city shall be made at the office of the commissioner by the property owner who shall sign the tap book and pay in advance the specified charges for such tap connection. 
(b)  The owner's duly authorized agent may sign the tap book in lieu of the owner provided the owner's written delegation of authority to said agent for such purpose has first been filed with the commissioner. 
(c)  The signature of the owner, or his duly authorized agent, to the tap book shall be evidence: 
(1)  That the owner subscribes to these rules and regulations; 
(2)  That the said owner will abide thereby; 
(3)  That the owner also agrees to abide by any rules and regulations that may hereafter be established by the commissioner; and 
(4)  That the owner further agrees that he will be responsible for any failure on the part of all or any of his tenants to abide by these or future water rules and regulations. 
(d)  Applications for installation of refrigeration and/or air conditioning equipment requiring the use of water from the municipal water supply must be made at the office of the commissioner of building, in conformance with section 7-8-35 of this Code. 
(e)  Prior to starting any work within a street, right-of-way, easement or any other public ground, the owner or his duly authorized agent shall be required to obtain and pay for all necessary permits as specified in chapter 7-3 of this Code. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.02)  
Sec. 7-8-3. - Reserved.  
Sec. 7-8-4. - Fire hydrants and valves. 
No person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity other than the commissioner or those acting with the written permission, or under the direction of the commissioner, or authorized employees of the bureau of water, or authorized members of the fire department performing their official duties, shall open or close, obstruct or interfere with any hydrant, gate valve, or curb stop connected to the water distribution system of the city. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.034)  
Sec. 7-8-5. - Cross-connections. 
No person owning or occupying premises that is receiving water service from the city's water distribution system shall make, or allow to be made, any connection, either of a direct or of an indirect nature between his piping system and a water supply from any other source, or install, or allow to be installed, any fixture or appliance of waste or soil pipe from which water may flow, be siphoned or to be pumped into the city's water distribution system. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.033)  
Sec. 7-8-6. - City's control of tap's mains, etc.; liability of city for shutting off water. 
(a)  The commissioner reserves to himself full control of all taps, mains, valves, valve boxes, meters and other fixtures and the commissioner also reserves to himself the right to take charge of, and fully control, valves, and service lines whenever, in the opinion of the commissioner, a violation of these rules and regulations is believed to have occurred. 
(b)  The city will not be liable for any damage which may result to any person or property from shutting off the water supply for any purpose whatsoever, even in cases where no notice has been given by the city, and no deduction will be allowed from the water bill in consequence of such shutting off or such damage. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.04)  
Sec. 7-8-7. - Notice of excavations. 
(a)  The excavator shall notify the bureau of water at least forty-eight (48) hours in advance of his intent to perform any excavations. The bureau of water will locate the existing water main and/or service lines in the vicinity of the proposed excavation. Any information provided by the city as to the size, type, location and depth is to be considered as only approximate, and the city shall not be held responsible for any information that may not be accurate or correct. After the city has completed their location work, the excavator should verify the location of the existing water main or service lines by hand dug test holes. 
(b)  The excavator shall use extreme caution when excavating with heavy equipment and only hand excavation will be permitted when excavating within eighteen (18) inches of a water main or service line. If an excavator damages a water main or service line he shall, at his own expense, have the water main or service line replaced or repaired, whichever may be directed by the commissioner. Water main repairs shall be done only by the bureau of water; service line repairs and/or replacement shall be done only by a licensed plumber. Unless otherwise permitted by the commissioner, damaged galvanized iron service lines must be replaced in accordance with the requirements specified in sections 7-8-51 through 7-8-75 of this Code. The cost of shutting down and restoring water service by the bureau of water shall be borne by the excavator whenever the shutdown is a result of damage caused by the excavator. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.05)  
Sec. 7-8-8. - City's right to shut off or restrict use of water. 
(a)  At any time the commissioner is of the opinion that there is an actual shortage of water or insufficiency of water pressure, or that such shortage or pressure is anticipated, the commissioner shall have the right to prohibit or restrict the use of water, or to curtail the supply of water to a property owner or consumer, or in the case of emergency to shut off the water supply in any water main, fire main or service line without notice. 
(b)  In the event that any of these rules or regulations are violated by a property owner, tenant, contractor, or other consumer, the commissioner shall have the right, at the said commissioner's option and upon twenty-four (24) hours' notice to the property owner to shut off the supply of water to the property where such violation has occurred, and the water shall not be turned on again until such violation has been corrected and this chapter has been complied with. 
(c)  The city shall not be held liable for failure or inability to supply water to any property owner or consumer on account of unforeseen circumstances beyond the city's control, catastrophes or "Acts of God," nor for any damages which may be caused to persons or property as a result of the shutting off of the water supply from any water main, fire main or service line for any purpose whatsoever, and no deduction will be made from water bills at any time in consequence thereof. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.031; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-8.1. - Prevention of watershed contamination. 
(a)  No person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall enter upon the area known as the White Plains Watershed, shown on the Tax Assessment Map of the city as Ward 5, Block 66, Lot 9, without express written permission of the commissioner. Orchard Street, Old Road to Kensico, Reservoir Road, Hall Avenue and Nethermont Avenue, being public streets, are not affected hereby. Lawful existing easements and rights-of-way are not affected hereby. 
(b)  No person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall discharge or drain into, throw, cast, deposit or lay, or direct, suffer or permit any servant, agent, or employee to discharge or drain into, cast, deposit or lay any substances or materials of any kind whatsoever upon the said White Plains Watershed without the express written permission of the commissioner. 
(c)  Section 7-8-10 of this article notwithstanding, the violation of this provision shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable on conviction for a first offense by a fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding six (6) months, or both, and for a second or subsequent offense by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding one (1) year, or both. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.032; Regs. of 7-3-86)  
Sec. 7-8-9. - Liability of city for water discoloration or improper pressure. 
The city shall not be liable to the owner or his tenants for any inconvenience or damage resulting from water discoloration or low or excessive pressure. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 6.01(b))  
Sec. 7-8-10. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, doing or permitting to be done or causing to be done, any act or thing contrary to the provisions of these rules and regulations, upon conviction thereof, shall be guilty of a violation and subject to a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or both fine and imprisonment, and on any subsequent conviction thereof shall be guilty of a violation and subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or both fine and imprisonment for each such violation. Every violation of any provision of these rules and regulations shall be a separate and distinct offense; and, in case of continuing violation, every day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 1.06; Regs. of 7-3-86) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Sec. 7-8-11. - Amendments. 
The commissioner reserves the right to make such changes in the water rules and regulations as he may from time to time deem desirable. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 6.01(a)) 
Charter reference— Power of commission to promulgate rules and regulations governing the use of water, § 197.  
Sec. 7-8-12. - Conflicting ordinances, rules or regulations. 
All ordinances, or rules or regulations, or any part thereof, inconsistent herewith, are hereby repealed and rescinded. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 6.02)  
Sec. 7-8-13. - Validity. 
If any section, article, paragraph, subdivision, clause, phrase or provision of these rules and regulations shall be adjudged invalid, or held unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of these rules and regulations as a whole or any part or provision thereof other than the part finally determined to be invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 6.03)  
Sec. 7-8-14. - Effective date. 
These rules and regulations shall take effect March 20, 1979. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 6.04)  
Secs. 7-8-15—7-8-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER USAGE REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 7-8-27. - Generally. 
Unless otherwise specifically authorized by the commissioner in writing as provided hereinunder, no person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, shall use, cause to be used, or permit to be used, any water of the city unless such water shall first pass through an official water meter and the amount of such water shall be properly measured and recorded. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.01)  
Sec. 7-8-28. - Water for construction purposes. 
(a)  Persons desiring use of water for construction purposes shall make all necessary arrangements with the property owner. Application for a service line shall be made by the property owner or his duly authorized agent as prescribed in sections 7-8-51 through 7-8-75 of this Code. 
(b)  In general, all water used for construction shall be metered, unless prior written permission of the commissioner is obtained as described herein. The commissioner may authorize the use of water for construction purposes without metering when deemed advisable by the commissioner and when suitable arrangements, satisfactory to the commissioner, have been made for payment for said water. In general, payment for unmetered water will be made at a daily flat rate, as determined by the commissioner. 
(c)  All service lines which are to be used to supply water for construction purposes shall be protected from backflow of water from the premises into the city's water supply system by means of an approved backflow prevention device. 
(d)  Deposits and fees as determined by the commissioner shall be paid in advance for the meter and backflow prevention device used during construction as outlined in section 7-8-121. The deposits shall be refunded upon return of the meter and backflow prevention device less the cost of repairs, if any. If the meter and/or backflow prevention device is not returned, the full deposit for the item or items not returned shall be forfeited. 
(e)  After the meter has been set and sealed by the city, it shall not be removed or relocated, except by authorized water bureau personnel. 
(f)  The owner and the contractor must arrange between themselves as to the method of payment, and the owner will be held responsible for payment for any water used during construction and also for ensuring that the user of the water abides by the herewith rules and regulations. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.02; Regs. of 7-3-86)  
Sec. 7-8-29. - Use of fire hydrant or fire service lines. 
No person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall be permitted to take water from a fire hydrant or fire service line for any purpose whatsoever other than fire protection without first having obtained a written permit from the commissioner, in accordance with the procedure specified in section 7-8-104 of this Code. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.03; Regs. of 7-3-86)  
Sec. 7-8-30. - Discontinuance or resumption of water service. 
(a)  Water service lines shall not be turned on or off by any person except authorized employees of the bureau of water or those acting with the written permission or under the direction of the commissioner. The request of a tenant for the discontinuance or resumption of the use of water shall not be recognized or acted upon by the commissioner except on the written authorization of the property owner. 
(b)  A property owner desiring to temporarily discontinue the use of water for an extended period of time shall give forty-eight (48) hours prior written notice thereof to the commissioner. The bureau of water shall then shut off the service line at the curb stop or gate valve, read the official water meter and render a bill for water consumed. A property owner desiring to resume the use of water shall give written notice thereof to the commissioner in order to have the water turned on. 
(c)  The property owner desiring to permanently discontinue the use of water shall give forty-eight (48) hours prior written notice to the commissioner and secure all necessary permits. The bureau of water shall temporarily shut off the service line at the curb stop or gate valve, read and remove all city-owned meters and render a bill for water consumed. Upon notification by the commissioner that a temporary shut-off has been made, the permittee shall perform the necessary excavation for a permanent discontinuance at the main. The bureau of water shall disconnect the service at the main and the permittee shall backfill and restore all disturbed surfaces at his own expense. 
(d)  A property owner desiring to temporarily shut off the water to make repairs or replacement shall notify the bureau of water forty-eight (48) hours in advance (except in emergencies), and the service line shall be shut off by the bureau of water at the curb stop or gate valve and the official water meter read. The owner or his duly authorized agent shall obtain all permits required, to effect the necessary repairs or replacements in accordance with these rules and regulations. 
(e)  In the event of a leak on a service line, city forces may excavate to control and/or disconnect the service line if necessary. Upon notification by the commissioner that an emergency shut-off has been made, the owner or his duly authorized agent shall obtain all required permits and do all work to effect the necessary repairs or replacements, including backfilling and restoring all disturbed surfaces at his own expense. 
(f)  If, in the opinion of the commissioner, a service line has been abandoned, he may order the property owner to excavate to have the service permanently discontinued in accordance with these rules and regulations. In such case the commissioner shall send notice by certified mail to the owner as shown on the current tax assessment roll of the city affording the owner ten (10) days opportunity to show cause why the service should not be permanently disconnected. The owner shall be afforded a hearing on the facts and if the line in question is determined to be abandoned by the commissioner, he may order the property owner to do the work necessary for a permanent discontinuance. If after thirty (30) days such work is not performed by the owner, the commissioner may have the work performed by contract or by city employees and charge same to owner as water service in the manner provided by sections 7-8-31 and 7-8-32 of this Code as a miscellaneous charge. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.04)  
Sec. 7-8-31. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  All water rates and charges shall be determined by the commissioner with the approval of the common council. 
(b)  Water rates to be paid by property owners or other consumers shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(c)  Availability/demand charges based on the size of the domestic service connection at the main shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(d)  Fire service lines and fire mains, when unmetered, shall be subject to an annual stand-by charge as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(e)  Charges for maintaining hydrants used for fire protection on private property within easements shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(f)  All charges are a lien on the property and the property owner shall in all cases be held liable for all charges. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.06; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-32. - Billings generally. 
(a)  In general an account is established for each official metered domestic service line. However, where there is more than one (1) official metered domestic service line serving a building or structure, the meter readings will be combined and billed as one (1) account. 
(b)  Water bills shall be due and payable at the office of the commissioner of finance at the end of each billing period, as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(c)  For premises receiving water service through an official water meter, where a reading of said meter serving the premises is not available for a billing period, an estimated bill based on available information, may be rendered, charged and collected, as for water actually consumed, subject to adjustment when a reading becomes available. In the event that a reading is unavailable for two (2) successive billing periods, the commissioner shall then serve a notice to the owner of record, by certified mail, that water service to the premises may be discontinued ten (10) days after mailing of the notice unless the official water meter is made available for reading by the bureau of water within said ten-day period. Thereafter, the commissioner may discontinue the service if the official water meter is not made available during the stated period. Once discontinued, the water service will not be resumed until the meter is read, and accrued water charges paid in full. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.05; Regs. of 7-3-85; Ord. of 5-25-05, § 1) 
Cross reference— Notice of newspaper pickup and glass salvaging to be placed in water bill, § 2-1-6.  
Sec. 7-8-33. - Special meter readings and billings. 
A property owner or his duly authorized agent may request a special reading and water statement to be made and rendered at a time other than the normal reading schedule. Said request must be made to the bureau of water at least forty-eight (48) hours in advance. A service charge as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code shall be added to the water charges for the property affected in the same manner as provided by these rules and regulations and the law for the collection of water consumed. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.07)  
Sec. 7-8-34. - Special provisions for service outside city. 
(a)  The commissioner, with the approval of the Common Council of the City of White Plains, may enter into contracts for the sale of water to individuals, firms, partnerships, corporations, or municipalities outside the limits of the City of White Plains. Such contracts shall provide that the water sold shall be metered at the city line through a meter approved by the commissioner. Said meter shall be provided and maintained by the individual, firm, partnership, corporation or municipality purchasing said water provided, however, that all such contracts which, by their terms exceed a period of one year, shall contain a provision that the same may be terminated by the city, at its option, upon one year's notice of its intention to do so. 
(b)  All outside consumers shall be required to comply with all of these rules and regulations. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.08)  
Sec. 7-8-35. - Water for refrigeration and air conditioning. 
(a)  No refrigeration and/or air conditioning equipment requiring the use of water shall be installed on any premise supplied from the municipal system until a permit authorizing such installation has been issued to the installer by the commissioner of building. 
(b)  All installations of any individual or collective system of refrigeration and/or air conditioning equipment of over six (6) tons shall be equipped with a water conserving device such as economizer, evaporative condenser, water cooling tower or similar apparatus, which device shall not consume for makeup purposes, in excess of five (5) per cent of the consumption that would normally be used without such device. 
(c)  All installations of refrigeration and/or air conditioning equipment under six (6) tons shall be provided with an automatic water supply regulating device so as to limit the flow of water in relation to the condenser temperature reduction requirements of the apparatus. In no case shall the equipment use in excess of two (2) gallons per minute per ton capacity. 
(d)  All water conserving or regulating devices shall be subject to the approval of the Building Department of the City of White Plains. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 2.09)  
Secs. 7-8-36—7-8-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SERVICE LINE AND FIRE MAIN REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 7-8-51. - Generally. 
(a)  Prior to the installation of service lines and/or fire mains, the property owner shall make the necessary application to the commissioner. Upon approval of the application, the property owner shall pay all required charges, fees, deposits and obtain the necessary street opening and other required permits. 
(b)  Tapping and making connections to the water mains or fire mains, shall in all cases be done by authorized employees of the bureau of water, and shall not be done by any other persons, unless acting with the written permission or direction of the commissioner. 
(c)  Unless otherwise directed, no new service line shall be made available for the use of water until all inactive service lines have been shut off and permanently disconnected in accordance with section 7-8-30 of this Code. 
(d)  Unless otherwise directed, no new service line shall be made available for the use of water until the new line has been tested and disinfected in accordance with chapter 9-7 of this Code (the plumbing code) and as approved by the commissioner. The property owner shall pay the charges as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.01)  
Sec. 7-8-52. - Installation. 
(a)  In general, and unless otherwise specified, new service lines and replacement of existing service lines shall be a minimum of one inch in diameter. Service lines up to and including two (2) inches in diameter shall be of copper tubing (type K) with flared joints and service lines greater than two (2) inches in diameter shall be of cast iron or ductile iron cement lined pipe. All materials and methods of installation shall conform to the latest requirements as specified in the "Standard Construction Specifications" and "Standard Construction Details" of the city. 
(b)  The property owner shall do all work necessary for the installation of the service line and/or fire main, including but not limited to excavation, shoring, backfilling, dewatering, rodding, concrete thrust blocks and surface restoration in a manner satisfactory to the commissioner except for tapping and making connections to the water main and furnishing and laying service lines as may be provided for and specified in section 7-8-53 of this Code. 
(c)  In general the trenches excavated for service lines and/or fire mains shall be straight and perpendicular to the water main, opposite the owner's property and to a sufficient depth so that said service lines and/or fire mains can be laid with not less than four and one-half (4½) feet of cover and not more than six and one-half (6½) feet of cover below the existing or future street surface as established by the commissioner, whichever is lowest. If the main is in an unusual location or because of solid rock, the commissioner may grant permission to lay the line in another generally accepted manner. If the conditions are such that the service line and/or fire main will have less than four and one-half (4½) feet cover, it shall be insulated with an approved protective covering. 
(d)  No tap shall be made by the bureau of water until the depth of the trench and dimensions of excavation are such as will allow adequate room for tapping the main and for laying the service line and/or fire main as shown in section 7-8-124 of this Code, and/or as may be determined and required by the commissioner. The permittee shall notify the commissioner not less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, that the trench is ready for the tap and installation of the service line and/or fire main. 
(e)  Not more than one (1) building shall be connected to any one (1) tap and service line. The commissioner may, however, at his option, grant permission to connect with accessory buildings on the same building lot. 
(f)  There shall be no alterations made in the service line and/or fire main or appurtenances, and no additional appurtenances shall be installed on the street or inlet side of the official water meter unless approved in writing by the commissioner. 
(g)  Domestic service lines in all cases shall be separate from fire service lines and fire mains. Unless otherwise approved by the commissioner, fire service lines and fire mains shall not be less than four (4) inches in diameter. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.02; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-53. - Tap fees and pipe charges. 
(a)  All charges for tapping and making connections with the water mains of the city and furnishing and laying service lines, shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(b)  The charge for taps three-fourths inch to two (2) inch inclusive in diameter shall include the cost of tapping the water main, furnishing and installing a corporation stop, furnishing and laying a copper service line equal to the size of the tap, from the water main to a point approximately two (2) feet beyond the curb line or edge of pavement, furnishing and installing a curb stop and furnishing a curb box. The curb box shall be installed at the property owner's expense in accordance with these rules and regulations and the directions of the commissioner. Where necessary, a meter shall be furnished by the city and shall be the official water meter for that tap. If more than one meter is desired by the property owner, such additional meters shall be furnished and installed at the owner's expense on the house or outlet side of the official water meter. 
(c)  The charge for taps greater than two (2) inches in diameter shall cover the cost of tapping the water main, installing a tap sleeve and gate valve and furnishing a gate box. The gate box shall be installed at the property owner's expense in accordance with these rules and regulations and the directions of the commissioner. When requested by the owner, the city may furnish and install cast iron or ductile iron pipe from the water main in a public street to a point approximately two (2) feet beyond the curb line or edge of pavement or from a water main or fire main located in a city easement to the edge of the easement. The charge for furnishing and laying the pipe shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. Where necessary, the owner shall furnish and install the official water meter at his own expense and in accordance with these rules and regulations and the directions of the commissioner. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.03; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-54. - Special taps and valves. 
(a)  Where the property owner requests a tap on a water main which is of a material other than cast iron or ductile iron, special equipment and materials may be required. The city shall not be held liable for any delay in obtaining special equipment and materials needed to complete the work. The tap fee shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(b)  Where isolation and/or insertion valves are to be installed on a water main or fire main, the property owner shall request such work in writing. The charges for the installation shall be as specified in section 7-8-121 of this Code. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.04; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-55. - Repair, maintenance, etc., of lines. 
(a)  The property owner shall, at his expense, maintain and keep in good order, repair and proper operating condition all service lines serving his property. The commissioner may direct the owner to replace and/or repair as directed, any and all parts of the service lines or house piping serving said property, which in his opinion may be necessary to prevent leakage and/or waste of water or damage to property. When directed by the commissioner, a leaky or damaged service line shall be replaced and/or repaired in accordance with the requirements specified under section 7-8-52 of this Code. All repairs to water service lines shall be made in an approved manner by a licensed plumber. 
(b)  The property owner shall at his own expense, keep service line boxes readily accessible to the bureau of water for the purpose of turning water off or on. He shall also maintain the boxes level with the surface of the adjoining ground, pavement, walk or driveway, for the safety of pedestrians or other traffic. In the event that the commissioner shall deem it necessary to raise or lower the service line water box so as to make the top of the said box level with the surface of the adjoining ground, pavement, walk or driveway for the safety of pedestrians or other traffic, all such work including the removal and replacement of portions of the adjoining ground, pavements, sidewalks or driveways, as necessary, shall be done by the property owner upon written order of the commissioner and at the said property owner's expense. Upon failure of the property owner to conform with such written order within the time specified, the commissioner may proceed with any such work as may be required to assure the safety of pedestrians and other traffic, at the property owner's expense, in accordance with the appropriate provisions of the charter and ordinances of the city. 
(c)  The city shall not be responsible for their inability to turn water off or on in the event that the water service valve is inaccessible or inoperable, nor shall they be held liable on account of injury to persons, or damage to property, by reason of the fact that the gate box or gate valve, curb box or curb stop, or any part of the service line was not properly maintained in accordance with these rules and regulations. 
(d)  The city shall not be liable in any way for injury to persons or damage to property, by reasons of breaks, obstructions, leaks in service lines and house piping or any part thereof, as the result of frost or necessary maintenance operations of the bureau of water or any other cause. 
(e)  Any service line, house piping, or any part thereof which may become frozen shall be thawed, repaired or replaced by the property owner at his own expense, as directed by the commissioner. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.05)  
Sec. 7-8-56. - Easements and agreements. 
(a)  The property owner shall grant and provide easements of a width not less than six (6) feet on each side of water mains, fire mains and hydrants and the city will undertake to maintain and repair same when and as long as the commissioner may deem it necessary. The adequacy and form of the easement grant, easement map and written agreement shall be subject to the approval of the commissioner and the corporation counsel of the city. The owner shall agree that said easement area is to be kept free and clear of buildings, structures or other encumbrances in order to avoid interference with the proper maintenance and operation of said water main, fire main or hydrant by the city. 
(b)  The easement map shall be prepared by a land surveyor licensed in the State of New York, and shall indicate all as-built information, including but not limited to accurate location of gate valves, hydrants, water meter vaults and angle points along the line of pipe. In general the scale of the easement map shall not exceed fifty (50) feet to one inch. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 3.06)  
Secs. 7-8-57—7-8-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WATER METERS 
 
Sec. 7-8-76. - Generally. 
(a)  All water meters shall be of a type approved by the commissioner and unless otherwise specified shall be in accordance with section 7-8-78 of this Code. 
(b)  The city shall furnish the official water meter for each tap up to and including two (2) inches in diameter. This meter shall remain the property of the city and shall be installed and protected by the property owner at his own expense. Normal wear and tear maintenance on this official water meter shall be provided by the city. All other maintenance shall be provided at the property owner's expense. 
(c)  Where taps are greater than two (2) inches in diameter, the official water meter shall be furnished, installed, protected and maintained by the property owner at his own expense. 
(d)  In the case of all taps, of any size whatsoever, only one official water meter shall be used to record water consumption for each tap. The official water meter shall be the only one read by the bureau of water. Any and all additional meters desired by the property owner shall be installed on the house, or outlet, side of the official water meter and all such additional meters shall be furnished, installed and maintained by the property owner at his own expense. 
(e)  Gate valves, check valves and approved backflow prevention devices shall be installed at the official water meter in accordance with the "Detail of Meter and Backflow Prevention Device Installation" as shown in section 7-8-122 of this Code and as required by the plumbing code of the city. Only those devices and appurtenances as shown herein in section 7-8-122 and as required by the plumbing code shall be installed on the street or inlet side of the official water meter. No other devices or appurtenances shall be installed on the street or inlet side of the official water meter unless approved in writing by the commissioner. 
(f)  When a backflow prevention device is to be installed on the outlet or house side of the official water meter, no connections, taps, fixtures, devices or other appurtenances shall be allowed between the backflow prevention device and the official water meter. 
(g)  All valves, check valves, backflow preventors and other fixtures must be of a type approved by the commissioner. 
(h)  Whenever heating or other water using systems are supplied with water from the city mains, a suitable valve or other suitable device must be installed so as to prevent damage from collapse or explosion in case it is necessary to shut off the supply of water from the city mains. 
(i)  No person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall interfere, tamper with or remove the official water meter after it has been inspected, approved and sealed by the bureau of water, by order and under the authority of the commissioner. 
(j)  Notwithstanding the provisions of 7-8-76(d), the Commissioner may authorize the installation of two water meters from a single tap for a single building for which a vertical subdivision map has been filed with the Westchester County Clerk's Office, and approved by the City of White Plains Planning Board prior to January 1, 2017, which have a primarily commercial subdivided unit and a primarily residential subdivided unit, each unit having a separate owner and having at least 100,000 square feet of rentable floor area, provided the Commissioner finds that the plumbing on each unit's side of the tap services only the separate commercial and residential subdivided units of the building. The meter size, manufacturer and model type shall be approved by the Commissioner of Public Works prior to installation. 
Applicants shall prepare and submit to the City, acceptable to the Commissioner and the Corporation Counsel, an agreement between the two owners stating who is responsible for the service line up to each respective meter which must include a hold harmless clause from each owner to hold the City harmless for loss of service from the joint service line because of a shutdown due to a problem with either one of the unit service lines in the building. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.01; Regs. of 4-19-82; Regs. of 7-3-85; Ord. of 6-5-17, § 1 )  
Sec. 7-8-77. - Installation. 
(a)  The official water meter shall be set in a horizontal position as close as practical to the point where the water service line enters the building or meter vault as shown in section 7-8-122 of this Code. 
(b)  In general, the official water meter shall not be located in excess of fifty (50) feet from the property line. The commissioner may require the owner to install the meter in a vault which shall be located within the owner's property at the property line as directed. The vault shall be constructed in accordance with the detail as shown in section 7-8-123 of this Code. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain a dry vault and where necessary dewater and protect the official water meter as directed. 
(c)  Unless otherwise directed by the commissioner, the rated size of the official water meter shall be equal to or less than the diameter of the domestic service line. A minimum of a three (3) inch meter will be required for domestic service lines four (4) inches in diameter or larger. 
(d)  In the case of domestic service lines greater than two (2) inches in diameter a valved by-pass shall be installed to facilitate testing and meter repair. The valve on the "by-pass" shall be an approved lockable type valve, which shall be sealed by the bureau of water. 
(e)  After installation, the official water meter shall be tested in place in accordance with section 7-8-125 of this Code, by an acceptable meter testing company in the presence of the commissioner's authorized representative. A certificate of accuracy shall be furnished to the commissioner before the line will be put into service. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary contained in this section herein, the commissioner reserves the right to modify the requirements set forth in sections 7-8-122, 7-8-123 and 7-8-124 so as to protect the integrity of the public water supply and minimize disruption of service to existing water consumers. This authority shall include, but not be limited to, the requirements for a dry or wet connection and the need for insertion valves and/or line stops at the sole expense of the applicant requesting the connection(s). 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.02; Regs. of 7-3-85; Ord. of 12-2-13, § 1)  
Sec. 7-8-78. - Specifications. 
(a)  All official water meters furnished by the city shall be magnetically driven nutating disc type straight reading in cubic feet and shall comply with the latest A.W.W.A. Standard C-700 entitled "Cold Water Meter Displacement Type," and shall be equipped with an electrically operated remote register, which shall be direct reading in cubic feet and connected by a two-wire connection to the generator. The generator shall be self-powered (by the energy of the water passing through the meter), waterproof, and equipped with an indoor totalizer and test circle, and shall meet the latest A.W.W.A. Standard C-706. 
(b)  Unless otherwise directed by the commissioner, all official water meters furnished by the property owner shall be new magnetic drive cold water meters, compound type, straight reading in cubic feet equipped with separate strainer and tapped boss for testing and shall meet the latest A.W.W.A. Standard C-702 entitled "Cold Water Meters—Compound Type," and shall be equipped with electrically operated remote register, which shall be direct reading in cubic feet and connected by a two-wire connection to the generator. The generator shall be self-powered (by the energy of the water passing through the meter), waterproof, and equipped with an indoor totalizer and test circle, and shall meet the latest A.W.W.A. Standard C-706. An affidavit of compliance that the meter and remote register complies with all applicable requirements of these standards shall be furnished to the commissioner for his approval prior to the meter installation. 
(c)  The location of all remote registers shall be approved by the commissioner prior to installation. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.06; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-79. - Accessibility. 
(a)  The property owner shall keep the official water meter, backflow prevention devices and other fixtures readily accessible and unobstructed for inspection, testing and repair. Where meters, backflow prevention devices and/or other required devices and fixtures are in locations which are inaccessible or unsafe due to water or other obstructions, as determined by the commissioner, the property owner shall be responsible for the removal of water or obstructions at his own expense. 
(b)  The commissioner and/or any authorized employee of the bureau of water shall have the right to enter the premises or property of any property owner, tenant or other consumer where city water is being supplied, at any time between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. for the purpose of installing, inspecting, reading, removing, testing or repairing the official water meter or for inspecting the backflow prevention devices and house piping. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.04; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-80. - Accuracy and testing. 
(a)  An official water meter which ceases to register shall be repaired or replaced as directed by the commissioner within thirty (30) days upon written notification. In the case of taps two (2) inches or less in diameter, repair or replacement of the official water meter will be made by the bureau of water. In the case of taps larger than two (2) inches in diameter, such repair or replacement shall be made by the owner at the owner's expense. In general a meter which cannot be repaired to function properly for twelve (12) consecutive months and has been in service over ten (10) years shall be replaced in accordance with these Rules and Regulations. 
(b)  The property owner's account for water consumed during the period when the meter ceased to register shall be calculated by taking either the average amount of water consumed, as recorded by the new meter, or the average amount of water consumed during a previous similar period, at the option of the commissioner. 
(c)  In the event the property owner questions the accuracy of the official water meter owned by the city (two (2) inches or less in size), the bureau of water shall, upon written request, test the meter in the presence of the owner or his authorized representative. If the meter tested is found to be registering less than one hundred three (103) percent of the amount of water actually passing through the various test flows, the property owner shall pay a testing charge as outlined in section 7-8-121 of this Code. If the meter tested is found to register in excess of the allowable one hundred three (103) percent, then the owner will not be required to pay the testing charge and an adjustment may be made to the consumption shown on the latest bill rendered for the difference between the allowable one hundred three (103) percent and the actual registration found, as determined by the commissioner. 
(d)  All official water meters shall be tested in accordance with section 7-8-125 of this Code. The test interval shall be as indicated in the following table: 
Size of Meter 
(inches) 	Test Interval 
(years) 
 ¾ and less 	15 
1 	10 
1½ and 2 	 6 
3 	 4 
4 	 3 
6 and larger 	 2 
 
The commissioner reserves the right, however, to require a meter test at any time, if, in his opinion, it appears the official meter has been tampered with, the seal broken or removed, or when there is a significant change in recorded consumption. 
Where the official water meter is furnished by the city, the water meter shall be tested for accuracy by the bureau of water, and if necessary, the meter shall be recalibrated or replaced at the commissioner's option. 
Where the official water meter is furnished by the property owner, the meter shall be field tested for accuracy at the owner's expense, by a meter testing company acceptable to the commissioner and in the presence of the commissioner's authorized representative. In the event the meter does not register within the accuracy limits specified for said meter in the aforementioned section 7-8-125, it shall be repaired and then retested to determine if it registers within the accuracy limits. The results of all meter tests shall be furnished to the commissioner in writing on the forms provided within ten (10) days after the tests. If the meter cannot be repaired to the required degree of accuracy, it shall be replaced at the owner's expense in accordance with these rules and regulations. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.05; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-81. - Responsibility for damage. 
(a)  An official water meter damaged by frost or damaged through negligence or misuse by the property owner or any other person shall be replaced or repaired at the property owner's expense. For taps up to and including two (2) inches, meter repairs shall be made by the city in accordance with the charges as outlined in section 7-8-121 of this Code. For taps greater than two (2) inches, the owner shall retain the services of an approved meter repair company. 
(b)  The city will not be held responsible in any way for damage to service lines, meters, house piping, valves, or any other fixtures as a result of frost or for any other reasons, nor shall the city be responsible in any way for damage to property from the above causes or from leakage of water from any part of the service lines or house piping. 
(c)  In the event that it becomes necessary for the city to remove or replace the official water meter, and the commissioner is of the opinion that such removal or replacement cannot be effected or is inadvisable until repairs have been made by the property owner to the service line or house piping, the commissioner may, at his option, order such repairs to be made by the property owner or he may discontinue and turn off the supply of water to said property until such repairs have been satisfactorily made. 
(d)  In any event the city shall not be liable for any damage to service lines, house piping or property caused by removal, replacement or testing of the official water meter, or for any cause whatsoever. 
(Regs. of 3-5-79, § 4.03; Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-82. - Penalties. 
Any person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, doing or permitting to be done or causing to be done, any act or thing contrary to the provisions of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) in amount, nor exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars in amount, nor exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) in amount, or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. of 4-7-04, § 1)  
Secs. 7-8-83—7-8-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BACKFLOW PREVENTION REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 7-8-91. - General. 
(a)  All service lines from the city's water supply system shall be protected from backflow of water by means of an approved backflow prevention device to prevent contamination from the premises into the city's water supply system. 
(b)  Each service line to a facility shall be protected in a manner commensurate with the degree of hazard of the facility. The degree of hazard and type of backflow prevention device to be used to achieve containment shall be based on use of the facility and availability of contaminants. 
(c)  The tabulation in section 7-8-126 shows the degree of hazard for various facilities and the required type of backflow prevention device. For those types of facilities not shown on the tabulation in section 7-8-126, the commissioner shall determine the type of backflow prevention device to be installed based upon his determination of the degree of actual or potential hazard. 
(d)  All reduced pressure zone devices (RPZ) and double check valve assemblies (DCV) must be on the current listing of acceptable devices issued by New York State Department of Health. The design of all backflow prevention device installations shall be approved by the New York State Department of Health or Westchester County Department of Health. 
(e)  All backflow prevention devices shall be acceptable to the commissioner of public works. 
(f)  No cross connections are permitted between a supplementary water supply and the city's water supply. 
(Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-92. - Installation. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specified, backflow prevention device(s) shall be installed at the official water meter in accordance with section 7-8-122 and as required by the plumbing code of the city. 
(b)  No RPZ or DCV backflow prevention device shall be placed in service until such time as a completed works approval has been issued by the New York State Department of Health or the Westchester County Department of Health. 
(c)  All backflow prevention devices shall be furnished, installed, tested, protected and maintained by the property owner at his own expense. 
(Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-93. - Testing. 
(a)  After installation, all backflow prevention devices shall be tested in place, by a certified backflow prevention device tester in the presence of the commissioner's authorized representative. The tester's written certification shall be furnished to the commissioner within ten (10) days after the test has been performed. A new service line will not be put into service before certification is received and approved by the commissioner of public works. 
(b)  Yearly tests shall be performed on each RPZ and DCV backflow prevention device by a certified backflow prevention device tester to ensure continued reliability. The tester's written report shall be forwarded to the commissioner within ten (10) days after the test has been performed. 
(c)  Any backflow prevention device which fails to function properly shall be repaired or replaced within thirty (30) days, or as directed by the commissioner, and tested after the repair or replacement by a certified backflow prevention device tester. The tester's written report shall be forwarded to the commissioner within ten (10) days after the test has been performed. 
(d)  The results of all tests, as specified herein under this section, shall also be forwarded to the Westchester County Department of Health by the tester within ten (10) days after the test has been performed. 
(Regs. of 7-3-85)  
Sec. 7-8-94. - Penalties. 
Any person, persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, doing or permitting to be done or causing to be done, any act or thing contrary to the provisions of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) in amount, nor exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in amount, nor exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) in amount, or imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. of 4-7-04, § 2)  
Secs. 7-8-95—7-8-100. - Reserved.
