Chapter 8-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 8-1-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Jan. 3, 1995, § 1, repealed § 8-1-1, highway safety committee, derived from an ordinance adopted Aug. 5, 1968, §§ 1—3.  
Sec. 8-1-2. - Traffic violations bureau. 
(a)  The city court of the City of White Plains is hereby authorized to establish a traffic violations bureau to assist the court in the disposition of offenses in relation to traffic violations. 
(b)  The bureau is hereby authorized to dispose of violations of traffic laws, ordinances, rules and regulations when such offenses shall not constitute the traffic infraction known as speeding or a misdemeanor or felony, by permitting a person charged with an offense within the limitations stated in section 371 of the General Municipal Law to answer within ten (10) days at the traffic violations bureau either in person or by written power of attorney in substantially the form prescribed in this section by paying a prescribed fine and in writing waiving a hearing in court, pleading guilty to the charge and authorizing the person in charge of the bureau to make such a plea and pay such a fine in court. 
(c)  Such power of attorney shall be in substantially the following form: 
"I, the undersigned, hereby waive a hearing in the city court of The City of White Plains, New York and plead guilty to the charge specified in the annexed summons. I authorize the person in charge of the traffic violations bureau of said court to make such a plea and pay the prescribed fine in court. 
Dated the _____ day of ________, 19___. 
_______" 
(Ord. of 9-4-52, §§ 1—3) 
State Law reference— Power of council to authorize traffic violations bureau, General Municipal Law, § 370.  
Chapter 8-2 - TRAFFIC ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF WHITE PLAINS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— With the permission of the city, the editor has used the compiled traffic ordinance (Ord. of 9-3-46, as amended) prepared by the city as the basis for this chapter. 
Cross reference— Residential zone commercial vehicle parking restrictions, Ch. 4-12. 
State Law reference— Regulation of traffic by cities and villages, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1640 et seq. 
 
Sec. 8-2-1. - Saved from repeal. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect the validity of the Traffic Ordinance of the City of White Plains, being an ordinance adopted on September 3, 1946, as amended, and such ordinance is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect as if set out at length in this Code.  
Chapter 8-3 - BICYCLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Bicycles in parks, § 6-2-7; bicycles, Ch. 8-3. 
State Law reference— State regulation of bicycles, Vehicle and Traffic Law, §§ 1230—1236; local regulation of bicycles, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1641. 
 
Sec. 8-3-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
(1)  Bicycle: Every two (2) or three (3) wheeled device upon which a person or persons may ride, propelled by human power through a belt, a chain or gears, with such wheels in a tandem or tricycle, except that it shall not include such a device having solid tires and intended for use only on a sidewalk by preteenage children. 
(2)  Commissioner: The commissioner of public safety. 
(3)  Person: Persons residing in or having a place of business in, the city. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 102.  
Sec. 8-3-2. - Obedience to traffic control devices. 
Any person operating a bicycle shall obey all official traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(a))  
Sec. 8-3-3. - Application of rules of the road. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon a public highway shall be granted all of the rights, and shall be subject to all of the duties, applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles, or by chapter 8-2 of this Code, applicable to the driver of a vehicle. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(b)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1231.  
Sec. 8-3-4. - Operation on sidewalk. 
No person shall ride a bicycle upon any public sidewalk within the city. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(i))  
Sec. 8-3-5. - Operation on right side of roadway; bicycle paths. 
(a)  Establishment of bike routes. As an aid in the guidance of bicyclists, the city has established bike routes throughout the city in accordance with the "City of White Plains Bike Routes" map dated April 1, 2002, as maintained by the city department of traffic and the city clerk. 
(b)  Every person operating a bicycle upon the roadway of a public highway shall ride as near to the right-hand side of such roadway as practicable and shall not ride two (2) abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(e); Ord. of 5-6-02, § 1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1234(a).  
Sec. 8-3-6. - Speed. 
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(f))  
Sec. 8-3-7. - Clinging to vehicles. 
No person riding upon a bicycle shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(g)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1233.  
Sec. 8-3-8. - Maximum number of persons allowed on bicycles. 
No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(d)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1232.  
Sec. 8-3-9. - Carrying packages. 
No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handle bars. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(h)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1235.  
Sec. 8-3-10. - Seats. 
A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride and seated upon a permanent seat attached thereto. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(c)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1232.  
Sec. 8-3-11. - Parking. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a public street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(j))  
Sec. 8-3-12. - Equipment and maintenance. 
Every bicycle on a public highway shall be equipped and maintained in compliance with Section 1236 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 9(k))  
Sec. 8-3-13. - Penalty. 
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter may be punished by a fine of up to one hundred ($100.00) dollars or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days or by any combination thereof. 
(Ord. of 3-22-54, § 10; Ord. of 11-5-18, § 1 ) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Chapter 8-4 - PARADES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Parades generally, General City Law,, § 5; regulation of parades, Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1640(a)(12). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8-4-1. - Exemption. 
This chapter shall not apply to the movements of the armed forces of the United States, to the New York Guard, to the police and fire departments of the city and to funeral processions. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 2)  
Sec. 8-4-2. - Violations. 
Every person participating in any procession or parade for which a permit has not been issued as required by this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or by imprisonment for not to exceed ten (10) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 111-4-43, § 3) 
Charter reference— Penalties for violations of ordinances, § 37.  
Secs. 8-4-3—8-4-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 8-4-16. - Required. 
(a)  No procession or parade shall be permitted on any street or any public place in the city without permit being first obtained from the commissioner of public safety. 
(b)  Special permits for occasions of extraordinary public interest may be granted by the commissioner of public safety for any day or hour with the written approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-17. - Application. 
An application for a parade or procession permit shall be made in writing upon a suitable form prescribed and furnished by the commissioner of public safety not less than thirty-six (36) hours prior to the forming or marching of the parade or procession. If a special permit is applied for, the application may be made at any time prior to the forming or marching of the procession or parade. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-18. - General conditions for issuance. 
(a)  The commissioner of public safety shall not grant the permit required by this article when he has good reason to believe that the proposed procession or parade will be disorderly in character or tend to disturb the public peace. 
(b)  The commissioner shall not grant such a permit for the use of any street or any public place or material portion thereof which is ordinarily subject to great congestion of traffic, except on holidays or on weekdays. 
(c)  No such permit shall be granted if the procession or parade is not to be completed prior to sundown. 
(d)  A permit shall be granted only after due investigation by the commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1(a), (b), (g); Ord. of 12-16-54, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 8-4-19. - Designation of route and other rules and regulations. 
Each parade or procession permit shall designate specifically the route through which the procession or parade shall move and it may also specify the width of the roadway to be used and may further include such rules and regulations as the commissioner of public safety may deem necessary. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1(c))  
Sec. 8-4-20. - Insurance ad prerequisite. 
Except where a special permit is granted as provided in this article, before any parade or procession permit shall be granted there shall be furnished the city, without cost to the city, a public liability and property damage policy insuring the city against any loss or damage arising out of the granting of the permit, which said policy must meet with the approval of the corporation counsel of the city as to form and correctness and of the commissioner of public safety as to sufficiency. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1(d))  
Sec. 8-4-21. - Sunday parades. 
Permits may be granted by the commissioner for the conduct of, the witnessing of and the participation or engagement in processions or parades and the playing of music in any such procession or parade on Sunday after 2:00 p.m. for patriotic, fraternal, veteran, military and religious organizations. 
(Ord. of 12-16-54, § 2(h)) 
State Law reference— Power of city to allow parades on Sunday, General Business Law, § 14.  
Sec. 8-4-22. - Compliance. 
The chief officer of any procession or parade for which a permit has been granted by the commissioner of public safety shall be responsible for the strict observance of all rules and regulations included in the permit. 
(Ord. of 11-4-43, § 1(f))  
ARTICLE III. - PARADE VENDORS AND PERMITS 
 
Sec. 8-4-23. - Application. 
This article shall apply only to parades and events of extraordinary public interest as determined by the mayor and under permit granted by the commissioner of public safety under section 8-4-16. This article does not apply to the traditional annual parades or events as may be conducted on Memorial Day or Columbus Day. 
(Ord. of 6-17-91, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-24. - Parade vendor. 
A parade vendor is a hawker, peddler or solicitor, as defined in chapter 4-9 of the White Plains Municipal Code, entitled, "hawkers, peddlers and solicitors," who is engaged in selling souvenirs or such other items as may be related to the special event or parade. 
(Ord. of 6-17-91, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-25. - Permit required. 
All persons desiring to be parade vendors shall obtain a permit from the city clerk. Application shall be made to the city clerk at least one (1) week in advance of said parade or special event. A fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in cash or certified check shall accompany said application. However, persons already licensed under chapter 4-9 of the White Plains Municipal Code and persons exempt under any other federal, state, or county statute are not required to obtain such permit. 
(Ord. of 6-17-91, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-26. - Display of identification. 
All persons issued a parade vendor's permit shall also be issued a button identifying them as parade vendors. Said button shall be worn on the apparel of the parade vendor during such parade or special event. Said permit must be shown upon request to any police officer of the city. 
(Ord. of 6-17-91, § 1)  
Sec. 8-4-27. - Penalty. 
Any person acting as a hawker, peddler or solicitor during the parade or special event without having obtained a permit shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. of 6-17-91, § 1)  
Chapter 8-5 - VISUAL OBSTRUCTIONS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 8-5-1—8-5-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 8-5-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commissioner of building shall mean the commissioner of building of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
Commissioner of public works shall mean the commissioner of public works or his duly authorized representative. 
Department of parking shall mean the department of parking of the city. 
Parking commissioner shall mean the commissioner of parking of the city. 
Residence districts shall mean all the districts classified as residence in the zoning ordinance of the city. 
Street lines shall mean curb line or edge of street pavement lines. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 1; Ord. of 12-3-12, § 2)  
Sec. 8-5-22. - Prohibited. 
No fence, wall, hedge or planting shall be erected, placed, or maintained on any corner lot in a residence district more than thirty (30) inches in height within the triangular area formed by the intersecting street lines and a straight line joining said street lines at points which are forty-five (45) feet distance from the point of intersection measured along said street lines as shown on Appendix A attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived and made a part hereof. The height of thirty (30) inches shall be measured from the top of the curb or in the absence of a curb, the top edge of the pavement. This article shall not apply to utility poles, buildings and structures placed pursuant to a permit issued by the city. This article shall not apply to isolated or ungrouped trees, shrubs, or plants, or fences of open design provided that they are not a visual obstruction which would create a traffic hazard. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 2)  
Sec. 8-5-23. - Duty of owner, lessee or occupant. 
It shall be the duty of any owner, lessee or occupant of any corner lot in a residence district of the city to cut or remove all such obstructions as often as may be necessary to comply at all times with the provisions of section 8-5-22 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 3)  
Sec. 8-5-24. - Notice of removal; removal. 
The department of parking shall refer any obstruction to vision which has not been brought into conformity with the sight line requirements of this article and which the department determines to be a traffic safety hazard, along with its recommendation for appropriate action, to the traffic commission. After consideration of all the facts, the parking commissioner shall, if it agrees with said recommendation, refer the matter to the commissioner of building or commissioner of public works who shall serve written notice upon the owner, lessee, occupant, or any person having the the care or control of any such lot requiring him to remove the obstruction within ten (10) calendar days thereafter. Any existing condition, which is prohibited by section 8-5-22 of this Code, may be permitted to remain after a review of the conditions by the transportation commission with the understanding that its continued presence does not convey any permanent license, easement or other vested rights to the property owner, but rather is a revocable temporary license which may be revoked at any time without cause upon written notice to the property owner by the commissioner of building or the commissioner of public works and furthermore that the city does not accept any liability for damage to such objects or conditions from any activity of the city or any third party. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 4; Ord. of 12-3-12, § 3; Ord. of 9-2-14, § 1)  
Sec. 8-5-25. - Failure to remove; removal by city; lien for cost. 
If the property owner shall fail to remove the obstruction within the designated time as required in this article, the city may perform such removal using city forces or a contractor employed for that purpose and shall charge the cost of such removal and restoration to the owner of the property. Such charges shall become a lien upon the property until paid. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 5)  
Sec. 8-5-26. - Administrative liability. 
No officer, agent or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any omission or act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 7)  
Sec. 8-5-27. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article, or who shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided, or who shall resist or obstruct the commissioner of public works, or his employees or any employee of the city in carrying into effect the provisions of any notice served hereunder, shall be guilty of a violation and on the first conviction thereof, be subject to a fine which shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in amount, and on any subsequent conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine which shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) in amount, or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 8-4-80, § 6; Ord. of 5-3-93)  
Chapter 8-6 - WRECKERS AND TOWING OF VEHICLES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8-6-1. - Wrecker rotation list. 
(a)  The commissioner of public safety or his or her deputy is hereby granted the authority to draft and employ a rotating list of towing companies or towing services. No person, corporation, or entity shall engage in rotational towing without having first obtained a medallion for such towing issued pursuant to section 8-6-3 of this article. Such medallion shall be referred to as a license to engage in public safety/parking department related towing. No person shall engage in said towing without having obtained a medallion plate issued pursuant to section 8-6-3 of this article for each tow truck and flat bed tow truck. The commissioner shall have discretion to include on said list any towing company or service subject to the provisions of subsection (b). 
(b)  To be eligible for inclusion on the rotating list, any towing services or towing company must: 
(1)  Demonstrate to the satisfaction of the commissioner or his or her deputy that the service or company has equipment which is sufficient to perform the required tasks including one (1) two truck and one (1) flatbed tow truck which shall meet the standards set by the department of public safety as well as those standards and/or rules or regulations promulgated by the federal or state departments of transportation, as those standards, rules or regulations may be amended from time to time; 
(2)  Agree to hold harmless and indemnify the city, and its employees, officers and agents from all claims, suits, actions, damages, and costs which may result from the towing of any vehicle under this section; 
(3)  Procure any and all insurance required by the department of law of the city. 
(c)  Any towing company or towing service included on said rotation list providing services to the city shall be considered an independent contractor with the city. The towing service or towing company shall not in any way be considered an agent or employee of the commissioner of public safety, the department of public safety, the city or the department of parking. 
(Ord. of 8-3-81, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 1; Ord of 7-9-07, § 1; Ord. of 5-28-09, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-2. - Removal from the list. 
After due notice and opportunity to be heard, the commissioner of public safety or his or her deputy may remove a tow company from the rotation list for a period of time designated by the commissioner or his or her deputy, if such owner and/or operator is found to have violated any of the following: 
(a)  Any provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to this chapter; 
(b)  Was found to have operated a tow truck in a negligent manner or in a manner showing reckless disregard for life or property. For purposes of this subsection, a finding that any such operator violated section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law in the course of operating a tow truck shall be deemed negligence; 
(c)  Repeatedly refuses tow calls, or fails to respond in a reasonable time for no legitimate reason; 
(d)  Refuses without justifiable grounds to render towing services upon request of the department of public safety, or the department of parking; 
(e)  Repeated complaints of substandard service, overcharging or improper care of vehicle towed resulting in damage to the vehicle; 
(f)  Habitual violator of the regulations of the department of parking. 
(Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 2; Ord of 7-9-07, § 2)  
Sec. 8-6-3. - Medallion fees. 
The fees to obtain a medallion pursuant to this chapter shall be: 
(a)  The annual fee for a medallion to engage in towing as part of the wrecker rotation list shall be five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each tow truck. 
(b)  A minimum of two (2) medallions shall be issued per company one (1) for a tow truck and one (1) for a flatbed tow truck. 
(c)  In the event of the loss, mutilation, destruction or transfer of any medallion issued hereunder, the licensee may file such statement and proof of facts as the commissioner shall require, with a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per medallion, at the department of public safety, and the department of public safety shall issue a duplicate or substitute medallion. 
(Ord. of 5-28-09, § 1)  
Secs. 8-6-4—8-6-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TOWING OF VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 8-6-21. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall be defined as is indicated below: 
Abandoned vehicle shall mean an abandoned vehicle as defined in Vehicle and Traffic Law section 1224(1). 
Booting shall mean the clamping, affixing or locking of a booting device onto the wheel of a motor vehicle to prevent the wheel from rotating, thereby immobilizing the vehicle. 
Booting device shall mean any device that is clamped, affixed or locked onto the wheel of a motor vehicle to prevent the wheel from rotating, thereby immobilizing the vehicle. 
Commissioner shall mean the commissioner of public safety of the city or his or her designee unless as otherwise specified herein. 
Disabled vehicle shall mean any vehicle for which towing is necessary because of a vehicular accident or for which towing is necessary because of the vehicle's inability to proceed under its own motor power due to reasons other than a vehicular accident. 
Evidence vehicle shall mean any vehicle which is suspected of having been used as a means of committing a crime or employed in aid or furtherance of a crime or held, used or sold in violation of law or which may be required to be held or produced as evidence in a criminal investigation or proceeding. 
Flatbed tow truck shall mean any tow truck where the entire back of the truck is fitted with a bed that can be hydraulically inclined and moved to ground level, allowing the customer's vehicle to be placed on it under its own power or pulled by a winch. 
Habitual violator shall mean any person who has five (5) or more unpaid summonses and/or parking violations against him or her or any vehicle owned by him or her. 
Medallion shall mean a plate issued by the commissioner of public safety as the physical evidence of a tow truck operation license, and is affixed to the outside of such authorized tow truck. 
Parking violations are deemed outstanding when said violations and/or unpaid parking summonses have not been answered by the required appearance date. 
Rotational towing shall mean the operation of a tow tuck, or the offering to transport a vehicle by means of a tow truck as part of an independent contractor agreement with the City of White Plains. 
Storage area shall mean an area or region designated by the commissioner or commissioner of parking owned or under the control of the tow company and/or city to hold vehicles towed under this article until disposed of under the provisions of this chapter. 
Towing shall mean the moving for hire of a vehicle subject to towing, as herein defined. 
Tow truck shall mean a vehicle that is equipped with a crane, winch, tow bar, push plate, or other device designed to pull or push a vehicle or to raise a vehicle to raise or the front or rear end thereof. 
Vehicle shall mean a motor vehicle as defined in section one hundred twenty-five of the vehicle and traffic law, a tractor as defined in section one hundred fifty-one of such law or a trailer as defined in section one hundred and fifty-six of such law. 
Vehicle subject to towing shall mean any vehicle which: 
(1)  Cannot safely be removed as a result of an accident or some mechanical failure, or 
(2)  Is owned or operated by a habitual violator and is stopped or parked in violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law or the Traffic Ordinance of the city or vehicles which have five (5) or more outstanding and unpaid parking violations issued against them, and which, after mailing to the registered owner a final notice, at the address provided by the department of motor vehicles records, are found operated or parked on any public street, public highway, roadway, any portion of the entire width between the boundary lines of any publicly maintained or any property owned by, or in the possession and control of the City of White Plains, or 
(3)  Is found unattended where it constitutes an obstruction to traffic, or 
(4)  Is unattended and is stopped or parked in an area designated by the commissioner to be an unsafe road condition, or 
(5)  Is unattended and is stopped or parked in a place where stopping or standing is prohibited by the Vehicle and Traffic Law or the Traffic Ordinance of the city, or 
(6)  Is abandoned, as herein defined. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 1; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 6-3-02, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 3; Ord of 7-9-07, § 3; Ord. of 5-28-09, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-22. - Towing generally. 
Subject to any regulations promulgated hereunder by the commissioner: 
(a)  Any operator may, upon the request of any person listed below, tow or cause to be towed any vehicle subject to towing under this article; 
(b)  The following persons may request that a vehicle subject to towing be towed: 
(1)  The owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  Any other person authorized to have possession; 
(3)  Any police office of the City of White Plains; 
(4)  Any authorized parking enforcement officer of the department of parking. 
(c)  Unless requested to do otherwise, such vehicle shall be towed to the storage area provided by the tow company which storage area shall be approved by the commissioner or his or her designee or the city storage area as designated by the commissioner of parking or his or her designee. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 2; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 4; Ord of 7-9-07, § 4)  
Sec. 8-6-23. - Fees. 
Subject to regulations promulgated by the commissioner: 
(a)  The maximum charge for towing a vehicle shall be: 
(1)  In case of vehicles which do not exceed four (4) tons gross weight, one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) per tow; 
(2)  An additional charge not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is authorized for services requiring a flatbed tow truck; 
(3)  In the case of vehicles which exceed four (4) tons of gross weight, ten dollars ($10.00) per additional ton gross weight. 
(b)  The storage charge shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for all or any part of a day. Such charge shall commence at the time the vehicle enters the storage area; 
(c)  In the event that the owner or person authorized to have possession of the vehicle subject to towing arrives at the scene after a tow truck has been called but before the vehicle has been hooked up to the tow truck: 
(1)  The charge imposed by paragraph (a)(1) shall be twelve dollars ($12.00); 
(2)  The charge imposed by paragraph (a)(3) shall be five dollars ($5.00) per ton gross weight. 
(d)  An additional charge not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) is authorized for services necessarily rendered by the tow truck operator to prepare a disabled motor vehicle for towing in instances such as, but not limited to, overturned vehicle, a vehicle in a ditch or embankment, or where the use of a flatbed truck is necessary to transport a vehicle. 
(e)  The fee to be paid to remove a booting device, affixed pursuant to section 8-6-29 of this article, shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). There shall also be a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) for all or any part of a day that a booted vehicle remains in a public location. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 3; Ord. of 5-16-83, § 1; Ord. of 12-5-94; Ord. of 6-3-02, § 2; Ord. of 6-2-03, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 5; Ord of 7-9-07, § 5; Ord. of 5-22-08, § 1; Ord. of 5-28-09, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-24. - Notice and disposal of vehicles, other than abandoned vehicles. 
If a vehicle other than an abandoned vehicle remains unclaimed for ten (10) days after being towed, the commissioner or the commissioner of parking, as the case may be, shall mail a notice of removal to the last registered owner or lienholder, if such can be ascertained with reasonable diligence. Such notice shall state: 
(a)  The date of towing and the place of storage. 
(b)  That if the vehicle is not claimed within ten (10) days, it will be sold at a public auction within forty (40) days from the date of the notice or otherwise placed in use by the police department as the commissioner may direct. 
Notice of the auction shall be published in the official newspaper of the city once, at least five (5) days prior to the auction. If the commissioner determines that a vehicle may be suitably used for police purposes, he may direct that, in lieu of the auction, the vehicle be kept and used by the police department, except any vehicle which was towed and stored as a scofflaw vehicle, in which case, the commissioner of parking may determine that a vehicle may be utilized for parking enforcement and/or parking department purposes. 
(c)  Fees collected pursuant to this section shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 4; Ord. of 5-2-88, § 1; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 6; Ord of 7-9-07, § 6)  
Sec. 8-6-25. - Disposal of abandoned vehicles. 
Abandoned vehicles, as herein defined, shall be disposed of in accordance with section 1224 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 5; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-26. - Proceeds from sale of towed vehicles. 
The proceeds from the sale of any vehicle sold as provided in sections 8-6-24 and 8-6-25 of this Code shall be applied first to the cost of sale; second, against any towing charges; third, against any storage charges; fourth, against any municipal administrative charges; fifth, to any and all unpaid outstanding summonses against the vehicle and the registered owner thereof. In the event that the sale proceeds exceed the above costs and charges, the excess shall be held by the commissioner of finance for the benefit of the owner for a period not to exceed five (5) years. If the proceeds remain unclaimed after the five-year period, the proceeds shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 6; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-27. - Reimbursement of tow truck operator. 
Upon the presentation of proof of towing, the operator will be reimbursed for the charges imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 7; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1)  
Sec. 8-6-28. - Rules, regulations, etc. 
The commissioner is hereby authorized to: 
(a)  Promulgate regulations with respect to towing rates, storage charges, and the method for reimbursing operators and; 
(b)  Employ operators as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-21-81, § 8; Ord. of 12-5-94, § 1; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 7; Ord of 7-9-07, § 7)  
Sec. 8-6-29. - Booting. 
(a)  Booting. The commissioner and/or the commissioner of parking may, in lieu of towing a vehicle owned or operated by a habitual violator, or vehicles which have five (5) or more outstanding and unpaid parking violations issued against them, and which, after mailing to the registered owner a final notice, at the address provided by the department of motor vehicles records, are found operated or parked on any public street, public highway, roadway, any portion of the entire width between the boundary lines of any publicly maintained or any property owned by, or in the possession and control of the City of White Plains, order that the operator of the towing and/or booting service or such similarly related state of the art service immobilize the vehicle by affixing a booting device. 
(b)  Notice. 
(1)  When an immobilization device is used, the department of public safety, department of parking, or the operator shall attach or cause to be attached to the vehicle, in a conspicuous manner, in such form as directed by the commissioner, in consultation with the commissioner of parking, a notice containing the following information: 
a.  The location and identifying characteristics of the vehicle. 
b.  The date and time of placement of the device and the signature of the installer. 
c.  Notice that any such person tampering with, defacing, removing or destroying the device or vehicle will be subject to prosecution and liability for any loss to the city due to such attempt. 
d.  A warning that any attempt to move such vehicle might result in damage to such vehicle. 
e.  The steps which the owner must take to obtain release of the vehicle. 
f.  Such other information, statements, notices and warnings as the commissioner of parking shall from time to time determine. 
(2)  The commissioner in consultation with the commissioner of parking shall also provide for such notice to the last registered owner or lien holder of the booted vehicle as provided for in section 8-6-24, if such vehicle remains unclaimed. 
(c)  Tampering with immobilized vehicles. 
(1)  Any attempt by any person to tamper with, deface, remove or destroy an immobilization device or to move by any means a vehicle towed or secured as herein provided is a violation of this ordinance punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by incarceration for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, or both. 
(2)  Any person tampering with, removing, defacing or destroying an immobilization device shall be liable to the city for any loss due to such attempt. 
(Ord. of 6-3-02, § 3; Ord. of 3-5-07, § 8; Ord of 7-9-07, § 8)

Chapter 9-3 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 9-3-1. - Official map or plan. 
The map or plan of the city entitled, "Official Map or Plan of the City of White Plains, Westchester County, New York," signed by Eugene Halpin, Jr., Commissioner of Public Works of said city, dated the fourth day of April, 1927 and filed with the Common Council of said city on the fourth day of April, 1927 be, and the same hereby is adopted and established as the official map or plan of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-2-27, § 1) 
State Law reference— Official map, General City Law, § 26.  
Sec. 9-3-2. - Comprehensive plan management group and committee. 
(a)  There is hereby established the comprehensive plan management group as follows: 
(1)  The management group shall consist of not more than eighteen (18) members who shall be residents of the city and shall be appointed by, and serve at the pleasure of, the mayor. 
(2)  The chairman of the management group shall be appointed by the mayor from among its members. 
(3)  The function of the management group shall be to develop, organize, and manage the citizen participation process for updating the 1977 comprehensive plan. 
(4)  The management group shall adopt rules and procedures to establish a responsible and flexible comprehensive planning process. 
(5)  The management group shall foster discussion, analysis, and review of all relevant matters encompassed in General City Law § 28-a(5)(a)—(o), which statute will take effect on July 1, 1994. 
(6)  The chairman shall appoint the chairmen of all task forces who shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(b)  There is hereby established the comprehensive plan committee ("CPC") as follows: 
(1)  The CPC shall consist of the chairmen of each of the task forces established by the management group and such other individuals as may, from time to time, be appointed by the chairman of the management group. 
(2)  The chairman of the CPC shall be appointed by the mayor, and shall be a member of the management group. 
(3)  The CPC and the task forces shall assure effective communication of information, data, proposals, and recommendations to civic and business groups, neighborhood associations, and the general public. 
(4)  The CPC and the task forces shall prepare general statements of goals and objectives upon which proposals for the immediate and long-range enhancement, growth, and development of the city can be based, and proposed measures and programs to implement said goals and objectives. 
(c)  The commissioner and members of the department of planning shall serve as staff to the management group, comprehensive plan committee and all committees and task forces. All other city departments, as directed through their respective department heads, shall cooperate and assist the management group, the COC, and all committees and task forces. 
(d)  Participation in the COC and all committees and task forces shall be open to all residents of the City of White Plains who may participate as individuals or representatives of neighborhood associations or other civic or business groups. 
(e)  The common council encourages all social and economic groups to participate. 
(f)  It is the goal of the common council to receive a final draft of a proposed update of the 1977 comprehensive plan within the next two (2) years. 
(Res. of 4-4-94; Res. of 6-5-95) 
Editor's note— Inclusion of the provisions of a resolution adopted Apr. 4, 1994, as § 9-3-2 was at the discretion of the editor, the resolution being nonamendatory of the Code.  
Sec. 9-3-3. - Comprehensive plan, acceptance. 
The common council accepts and recognizes with appropriate recognition of public comments, the Comprehensive Plan of the City of White Plains as the basic policy framework for actions relating to land use, community facilities and public improvements. Plan implementation shall be achieved by decisions which involve zoning, urban renewal, subdivision regulation, the official map, land acquisition, capital and operating budgets, environmental protections, design regulations, and historic preservation. 
The accepted comprehensive plan and any amendments thereto shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and a copy thereof shall be filed with the White Plains Planning Board and the Westchester County Planning Board. 
(Res. of 9-8-97) 
Editor's note— The resolution adopted Sept. 8, 1997, which pertained to acceptance of the comprehensive plan, did not specify manner of codification; hence inclusion as § 9-3-3 has been at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 9-3-4—9-3-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING BOARD 
 
Sec. 9-3-16. - Created; composition. 
(a)  A planning board is hereby created pursuant to the General City Law, to consist of seven (7) members. Pursuant to section 27(16) of the General City Law, three (3) alternate planning board member positions are hereby established for purposes of substituting for a member in the event such member is unable to participate because of a conflict of interest. Alternate members of the planning board shall be appointed by the mayor for a term of seven (7) years. 
(b)  The chairperson of the planning board may designate an alternate member to substitute for a member when such member is unable to participate because of a conflict of interest on an application or matter before the board. When so designated, the alternate member shall possess all the powers and responsibilities of such member of the board. Such designation shall be entered into the minutes of the initial planning board meeting at which the substitution is made. 
(c)  All provisions of section 27 of the General City Law relating to planning board member training and continuing education, attendance, conflict of interest, compensation, eligibility, vacancy in office, removal, compatibility of office and service on other boards, shall also apply to alternate members. 
(Ord. of 5-2-27, § 3; Ord. of 4-15-46, § 1; Ord. of 1-4-99, § 1) 
State Law reference— Planning board authorized, General City Law, § 27, General Municipal Law, § 234.  
Sec. 9-3-17. - Approval of plats. 
The planning board is hereby authorized and empowered to approve plats showing lots, blocks or sites with, or without, streets or highways and to approve the development of plats entirely or partially undeveloped and which have been filed in the office of the county clerk, division of land records, prior to the creation and appointment of such planning board. The chairman of the planning board shall issue in behalf of the city, the certificate of failure to take action in plats referred to in the General City Law. 
(Ord. of 5-2-27, § 4; Ord. of 8-3-64, § 1) 
State Law reference— Approval of plats by planning board, General City Law, §§ 31, 32.  
Sec. 9-3-18. - Submission of changes in zoning ordinance. 
There shall be referred to said planning board for consideration and report to the common council proposed changes in the city's zoning ordinance, which the common council has before it for action. 
(Ord. of 5-2-27, § 5; Ord. of 3-18-46, § 2)  
Sec. 9-3-19. - Other functions. 
In addition to its other powers and duties, the planning board shall: 
(a)  Recommend to the common council amendments, extensions, additions and other changes in and to the city's official plan as seem desirable to the board. 
(b)  Recommend to the common council changes in the city's zoning ordinance which the board deems advisable. 
(c)  Consider plans for public housing and the replanning, rehabilitation, improvement and redevelopment of neighborhoods. 
(Ord. of 5-2-27, § 6; Ord. of 3-18-46, § 2; Ord. of 9-20-54, § 1)  
Secs. 9-3-20—9-3-30. - Reserved.
